HEADLINE: A VOLATILE MARKET;
Tokyo Closes Higher, But Traders Still Wary

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Taking their cue from Monday's advance in New York, stock prices here moved up strongly today, recovering much of their losses from the previous session.
But trading remained extremely thin and nervous, as the unusual volatility of the past week left many institutions shaken.
The Nikkei average of 225 stocks closed at 34,996.08, for a gain of 527.39 points, or 1.53 percent, erasing much of Monday's decline of 647.33 points, or 1.8 percent.
The Nikkei picked up much of its gain shortly after the market opened, gaining 435.11 points in the first hour of trading. 
Still, market analysts said the big institutions remained on the sidelines, as the sharp swings here of the past week left many investors shellshocked and unwilling to commit themselves. Reflecting this, trading volume was declining throughout the morning, traders said.
 
Relief and Anxiety
The general attitude in Tokyo was one of relief that the New York stock market had recovered, but anxiety over the fact that the exchange in Tokyo had been so roiled by external events.
''Generally, the economic conditions and the fundamentals are good, and over time they will prevail,'' said Masahiro Dozen, deputy president of the Daiwa Securities Company, Japan's second largest brokerage house. ''But what is happening in New York and in the foreign exchange market is dominating the thinking at the moment.''
Toyoharu Tsutsui, head of equities at CS First Boston (Japan), said that in some ways the declines and the nervousness here were worse than was suggested by the Nikkei average, which concentrates on blue-chip shares. He pointed out that the so-called second section of smaller and often more speculative shares had fallen much further on Monday and rebounded more wildly today.
''The volatility has upset many investors,'' he said. ''I still don't think the institutions have gotten active.''
 
Strong Recoveries Elsewhere
Other Pacific Rim markets also showed strong recoveries today.
The Hong Kong stock market, which has been buffeted in recent months both by political developments in China as well as Wall Street's gyrations, rebounded smartly. The Hang Seng Index was up 92.74 points, or 3.6 percent, to 2,710.84 by midday.
''All in all, everyone is simply relieved,'' said Jim Loh, head of stock sales and trading in Hong Kong for CS First Boston (Hong Kong) Ltd. ''Things have stabilized after a lot of activity early in the morning.''
Like analysts elsewhere in the region, he lamented the fact that New York was really calling the tune in Hong Kong. ''If you want to know the real influence, you look at the U.S. of A.,'' he said. ''That will dictate what is happening in the short-term.''
In New Zealand, the first market to open, the Barclays stock index gained 117.70 points, or 5.7 percent, to end the day at 2,176.42 in active trading. In Australia, the All Ordinaries index, which had tumbled 141 points on Monday, was up 70.4 points, or 4.4 percent, to 1,671.3 by midday. In Taiwan, the market index gained 410.32 points, or 4.2 percent, to close at 10,100.52. And the Singapore Straits Times Index opened up 2.1 percent, or 27 points, at 1,312.04.
 
Stocks Fall in Europe
LONDON, Oct. 16 (Special to The New York Times) - Europe's stock exchanges were battered today as individual investors and small institutions sold heavily, ignoring the pleas of their governments to remain calm in the wake of Friday's market decline in New York.
But the declines - ranging from 3.2 percent in London to 6.9 percent in Paris and 12.8 percent in Frankfurt -would undoubtedly have been much worse had the American markets not rallied this morning, giving European investors heart and causing stocks on many markets to recoup some of their losses.
In London and other European markets, investment houses said most big institutional investors stayed on the sidelines for much of the day, and entered the market in significant numbers - as buyers -only in the afternoon.
 
Sharp Markdowns Made
With rumors flying around all morning that the Dow Jones industrial average might open 200 to 300 points below its close on Friday, market makers in many exchanges decided to play it safe and marked down stock prices sharply at the opening of trading, and buyers seemed absent much of the day.
In London, The Financial Times index of 100 leading stocks opened down 157.1 points, or 7 percent.
Prices were marked down so much in Paris, Milan and Amsterdam that the permitted limits on the stocks were exceeded from the start, and many stocks did not trade, either for a portion of the day or all day.
Perhaps the hardest hit today was the Frankfurt exchange. It was swamped by panic selling by small investors, which caused the Deutsche Aktien index of 30 leading stocks to fall by 203.56 points, or 12.8 percent, its largest one-day drop since World War II.
The Financial Times index, which plunged 250 points in the 1987 crash, today closed down by 70.5 points, or 3.2 percent, at 2,163.4.
The drop was still large - especially since the London market had already fallen 7.9 percent since Sept. 5, when it hit a post-crash peak of 2,426.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE VOLATILE MARKETS
 
The stock market overcame a shaky opening and roared back on heavy volume to regain about half its losses of Friday. Prices were buoyed both by corporations buying their own shares and by institutions buying shares they considered cheap. [Page A1.] Stock prices in Tokyo climbed today, recovering much of their loss of Monday. [D9.] Prices rose in the ''junk bond'' market. [D17.] 
 
Crushing volume in the first hours of trading on the nation's financial exchanges gave the new computer systems their first test in live trading. And industry officials said the systems held up, with only minor problems. [D1.]
 
Arbitrage firms might have lost as much as $100 million just on the stock of AMR and UAL. [D10.]
 
The much-feared crush of redemptions did not materialize in the mutual funds industry. [D1.]
 
Brokerages and money management firms did their best to reassure their clients. [D7.] Politicians, economists and business executives are reappraising the economy. [D7.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply, as dealers unloaded issues when the stock market began to recover. [D17.]
 
The dollar finished moderately lower against most major foreign currencies. [D22.] Copper futures fell sharply. [D22.]
 
COMPANIES
 
Donald J. Trump withdrew his $120-a-share offer for AMR, but some people suggested he would come back with a lower offer, given the sharp drop in AMR stock. [D1.] A bill to forestall airline acquisitions moved ahead on Capitol Hill, over the objections of the Bush Administration. [D8.]
 
Domestic and international banks have told Citibank that they are willing to lend more than enough money to finance a $6.75 billion leveraged buyout of UAL, a top Citibank official said. [D1.]
 
I.B.M.'s profits fell 29.7 percent in the third quarter, at the low end of the range of what the company had anticipated. [D1.]
 
Merrill Lynch's profits fell 37.5 percent in the quarter. Paine Webber's net income declined 20 percent; Charles Schwab's earnings rose 70 percent, and Bear Stearns was up 8 percent. [D6.]
 
J. P. Morgan reported a loss of $1.82 billion for the third quarter. NCNB's profit more than doubled; Security Pacific was up 10 percent, and First City Bancorporation rose 22 percent. [D5.]
 
G.M. has notified workers that it will shut several plants in North America in the next few years. [D19.]
 
Farley agreed to sell Cluett, Peabody to a French group for $600 million. [D4.]
 
K Mart agreed to acquire Pace Membership Warehouse for $23 a share in cash, or $322 million. [D4.]
 
British Aerospace is considering a merger of its missile division with France's Thomson-CSF. [D4.]
 
ECONOMY

 
The Supreme Court agreed to resolve a major dispute in Federal antitrust law: whether a state or a private party can sue to undo a merger on the ground that the newly combined company poses a threat to competition. [D13.]
 
Business sales far outpaced inventory accumulation in August, the Government said in a report. [D2.]
 
Spending cuts of $16.1 billion will be made under an order signed by President Bush. [A20.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS

 
The widespread deterioration of roads, bridges and airports is a severe drag on business and industry, says Frank T. Callahan of Greiner Engineering. Talking Business. [D2.]
 
Widely different indications of value were offered Friday by the stock market and the stock-index futures market. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D10.]
 
Magazines for customers of beauty parlors are being planned by two publishers. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [D25.]

HEADLINE: Congressman Enters Connecticut Primary

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 16

 BODY:
United States Representative John G. Rowland entered the race for the 1990 Republican gubernatorial nomination today, attacking Gov. William A. O'Neill for the state's constantly changing budget picture and trying to clear up questions about his stance on abortion.
Unlike others who weigh the success of a fund-raising committee before making a formal announcement, Mr. Rowland, 32 years old, said that there was nothing to explore, that he was convinced people are ready for the first Republican governor in two decades. 
He said he was entering the race with ''no caveats, no hedging, no testing the waters.''
The three-term Congressman from Waterbury said that the 9-year-old O'Neill administration had been marked by economic chaos - a theme that another O'Neill challenger, United States Representative Bruce A. Morrison, a Democrat, has sounded.
''One political party has controlled this state far too long,'' Mr. Rowland said during his announcement in the Legislative Office Building, a block from the Capitol, where he served two terms as a state representative.
He said that he had the strongest record of budget reform and restraint among Connecticut's Congressional delegation.

HEADLINE: Rebels Reject Salvador Government Offer at Talks

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 16

 BODY:
The Salvadoran Government opened critical talks here today with guerrilla representatives by proposing an end to all hostilities in two days and the demobilization of the rebels in three months.
The proposal was immediately dismissed by the guerrillas, who said it was tantamount to a demand that they surrender.
Oscar Alfredo Santamaria, the Minister of Justice, declined to discuss details of the five-page peace plan, which had been expected. He said, ''We hope the proposal will be evaluated with the same seriousness in which it was made.'' 
But representatives of the guerrillas said the plan paved the road to the liquidation of their army.
''We maintain that it's a proposal for unconditional surrender,'' said Joaquin Villalobos, a senior rebel commander.
 
The Guerrillas' Conditions
The guerrillas, who have made several conciliatory proposal in recent months, insist on judicial and economic changes before they end the war, which so far has claimed 70,000 lives.
The Government plan seemed to open the door to negotiations on reductions in the size of the 57,000-man army, a rebel demand. The Government also offered to guarantee the safety of members of the rebel organization, the Faribundo Marti National Liberation Front, and offered undefined measures to help the rebels establish a political party.
The new Government offer was the highlight of five hours of talks in the community house of a convent on the outskirts of San Jose. They are the first substantive negotiations since the outbreak of the civil war a decade ago.
The Government proposal followed a recent offer by the rebels to lay down their arms and join the political process in exchange for sweeping political changes and deep cuts in the armed forces, which have long ruled the country in a coalition with the oligarchy.
 
Both Sides Under Pressure
The quick rejection of the Government offer is a setback for the negotiations but is unlikely to prove fatal to the developing peace process, which has gained some momentum in recent weeks.
The meeting is considered a key test of the two sides' sincerity in seeking a negotiated solution to the war, because it includes the first substantive discusions. Previous talks, which had taken place intermittently, were largely limited to procedural questions and quickly collapsed.
Both the Government of President Alfredo Cristiani and the rebels say they expect the negotiations will take months to complete and have promised not to withdraw unilaterally. Both sides are under intense domestic and international pressure to negotiate and have begun competing politically for the mantle of peacemaker.
 
55 Arrested in Washington
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) - The police arrested 55 protesters today after they blocked the entrance to a House office building, disrupted a House session and demonstrated at two Congressional offices to protest United States military aid to El Salvador.
About 200 demonstrators rallied outside the Capitol, then marched to the Rayburn House Office Building, where 44 of them were arrested as they blocked an entrance.
One protester got a bloody nose, a police spokesman said.
Two other groups of demonstrators disrupted the offices of Senator Christopher Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, and Representative Stephen Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn. Four protesters were arrested in each office, the spokesman said. Neither lawmaker was present.

HEADLINE: Taxes Short Of Forecast, Regan Says

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Revenues from New York State's major taxes were more than $200 million below projections for the first six months of the fiscal year, according to a report issued today. The report renewed debate over whether the state can afford a scheduled $400 million tax cut next year.
The most serious shortfalls were in business and real-estate taxes, which together accounted for almost two-thirds of the shortfall. Business-tax revenues for the first six months of the fiscal year, from April through September, fell more than 6 percent below the same period last year, noted the report, prepared by Comptroller Edward V. Regan. 
Budget Director Dall W. Forsythe said it was too early to say whether the state would be forced to take major steps to head off a deficit in the current $47 billion budget. He noted that because tax revenues fluctuated every year, it was not prudent to use midyear figures to predict where the revenues would wind up at the end of the fiscal year.
 
'Bad News in the Northeast Economy'
He said however that the numbers in the Comptroller's report mirrored ''bad news in the Northeast economy generally and bad news in the New York City economy, in particular.'' Another disturbing factor, Mr. Forsythe said, was a weak real-estate market downstate, which has led to sharp reductions in the capital-gains taxes paid on the sale of houses.
The spending so far, $15.4 billion, is in line with projections, as is the $7.75 billion from personal income taxes.
The problems indicated by the revenue data were nowhere near as severe as a year ago, when officials projected that overestimates of tax revenue had left the state facing a potential deficit of almost $2 billion, which was largely reduced through a combination of spending cuts and borrowing from reserve funds.
Moreover, the figures seemed to show that those fiscal problems might not be as daunting as those in New York City, where officials recently reported that business taxes were down 17 percent and that some real-estate taxes were down 25 percent compared with the same period last year.
Mr. Cuomo's spokesman, Gary Fryer, said the revenue figures bolstered Mr. Cuomo's case that there were ''formidable challenges ahead'' in developing next year's budget. The state is planning the third phase of a cut in the personal income tax, a move that could save taxpayers $400 million next year, although the Governor has suggested that a wise course might be to ''put it off'' and use the money to address the budget problems.
Still, leaders of the Republican-controlled State Senate have repeatedly said that the fiscal problems are manageable and that the tax cut is a promise that should be kept.
A spokesman for the Senate Finance Committee, Gerald McLaughlin, said that the Comptroller's report was being reviewed and that leading Senators would look at a more detailed report expected this month from the Budget Office. So far, he said, ''there's been no deviation from the plan'' for the tax cut.

HEADLINE: Cornel Wilde, 74, a Performer and Film Producer

BYLINE: By PETER B. FLINT

 BODY:
Cornel Wilde, an athletic actor who was expert in fencing and horsemanship but who won stardom with his portrayal of the tubercular composer Frederic Chopin in the 1945 film ''A Song to Remember'' died of leukemia yesterday in Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, three days after his 74th birthday.
The tall (6 foot 1 inch), muscular and dashing actor was often cast in routine swashbucklers and action melodramas. He was able to stretch his talent, however, in such roles as a paroled convict in ''Road House'' (1948), an embattled parole officer in ''Shockproof'' (1949), a dedicated policeman in ''The Big Combo'' (1955), a daring aerialist in ''The Greatest Show on Earth'' (1952), an ambitious executive in ''Woman's World'' (1954) and a heroic emperor in ''Constantine and the Cross'' (1961).
In 1955, Mr. Wilde formed his own company, Theodora Productions, and began directing, producing and starring in modest-budget movies shot overseas. These included ''The Naked Prey'' (1966), in which he was relentlessly hunted through a jungle, and ''Beach Red'' (1967), a passionately pacifist work. Reviewing the latter film, Howard Thompson of The New York Times credited Mr. Wilde with having ''nimbly piloted . . . a graphic, unflinching and honest drama of men in combat'' with ''simple, unrestrained and stinging honesty, semidocumentary vigor'' and ''crisp economy.'' 
Other Wilde productions included ''Storm Fear,'' ''The Devil's Hairpin,'' ''Maracaibo,'' ''Sword of Lancelot,'' ''No Blade of Grass'' and ''Shark's Treasure.'' The films met with mixed success and were praised by reviewers for having bold aspirations; but some reviewers said several of them were naive, simplistic and brutal.
 
Traveled Widely in Europe
The actor and film maker was named Cornelius Louis Wilde at his birth on Oct. 13, 1915, in Manhattan. He spent much of his youth accompanying his father on business trips to Europe and became fluent in several languages. In New York he studied at Townsend Harris High School and City College while working as a Macy's toy salesman and commercial artist.
Mr. Wilde won a scholarship to the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University and was a leading member of the 1936 American Olympic fencing team, but he abandoned his ambitions to be a surgeon and a champion fencer to pursue an acting career. He gained his first major notice as Tybalt in the Laurence Olivier-Vivian Leigh production of ''Romeo and Juliet'' on Broadway in 1940.
That performance won him a Hollywood contract and the role of Chopin in ''A Song to Remember.'' The public flocked to buy recordings of works by the composer and to see the handsome actor who, in one vivid scene, coughed blood on the piano keys. The film also provided Merle Oberon (playing George Sand) with the celebrated advice to Chopin to ''discontinue that so-called Polonaise jumble you've been playing for days.''
The baroque script was criticized by most reviewers and prompted the critic James Agee to denounce the movie as ''infuriating and as funny a misrepresentation of an artist's life and work as I have ever seen.'' Criticism notwithstanding, Mr. Wilde was nominated for an Academy Award.
 
Played D'Artagnan in 1979
Mr. Wilde's other films included ''A Thousand and One Nights'' (as Aladdin, in 1945), ''Leave Her to Heaven'' (1945), ''The Bandit of Sherwood Forest'' (as Robin Hood's son, in 1946), ''Centennial Summer'' (1946), ''Forever Amber'' (1947), ''Omar Khayyam'' (in the title role, in 1957) and ''The Fifth Musketeer'' (as D'Artagnan, in 1979).
Reviewing his deepest preoccupations in 1986, Mr. Wilde remarked: ''I am very concerned about the environment and psychological health of this beautiful planet. Throughout my work is the idea, over and over, that we must all learn to respect one another.''
The leading actress in many of Mr. Wilde's independent productions was Jean Wallace, whom he married in 1951. They divorced in 1981. They had a son, Cornel Wallace Wilde, of Beverly Hills, Calif. The film maker also had a daughter, Wendy, of Berkeley, Calif., by his first wife, the actress Patricia Knight, whom he married in 1937 and was divorced from in 1951. He is also survived by two stepsons, Pascal Franchot Tone of Hamilton, Mass., and Thomas Jefferson Tone of Ottawa, and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: A VOLATILE MARKET;
Fresh Look Is Taken at the State of the Economy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
The decline in the stock market Friday, the rebound today and the nervousness about what it all might mean led politicians, economists and business executives today to reappraise the state of the American economy and the Government's economic policies.
President Bush was asked about Friday's market drop at a picture-taking session this morning at the White House. ''I'm not worried,'' he responded. He went on to say that Administration officials were ''monitoring the situation'' closely. 
The White House press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said today that Mr. Bush believed that ''the economy remains strong'' and that ''the economic outlook continues to look good.''
 
Spending Cuts Put Into Effect
But Mr. Bush had no choice except to sign an order putting across-the-board spending cuts into effect at midnight, since his Administration and Congress failed to to meet a deadline for adopting a deficit reduction plan.
Among economists, the prevailing view is that neither the budget deadlock nor any other specific development in Washington precipitated the market break last Friday or the rebound today.
''People in Washington flatter themselves to think anybody on Wall Street gives a damn about what they do,'' said John H. Makin, director of fiscal policy studies at the American Enterprise Institute.
But many economists do say that the inability of the politicians to come to grips with the deficit and the apparent disagreement between the Treasury and the Federal Reserve over interest rates caused a general unease among investors.
For weeks now, the Fed and the Treasury have been at odds over interest rates. The Fed has kept them high to ward off inflation, while Administration people in the Treasury and elsewhere have urged lower rates to drive down the dollar.
 
'Underlying Fragility'
Robert H. Chandross, chief economist in the New York office of Lloyds Bank, said that the ''underlying fragility of the system'' was caused at least in part by high interest rates and that ''progress to reduce the deficit would take pressure off interest rates and improve the strength of the financial system.''
President Bush's spending-cut order was automatic under the budget law, but many Democrats in Congress blamed the President for failing to exert more leadership on the economy in general and the budget deficit in particular.
''The President seems unwilling to make the hard choices, or the easy ones for that matter, preferring to be carried along by the current of events,'' said Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas.
Richard G. Darman, the budget director, turned that criticism around. At a news conference, he maintained that the budget impasse was caused by Congressional Democrats who insist on attaching ''objectionable material'' like expansion of child-care benefits to the budget legislation.
The chief executives of the nation's largest companies, who met over the weekend in Hot Springs, Va., are mostly Republicans and have favorable feelings about Mr. Bush. But while they criticized Congress in interviews, they expressed disappointment with what they saw as the President's lack of forcefulness on the economy.
''On initiative, I'd give him a 'C,' '' said Howard P. Allen, chairman of the Southern California Edison Company. ''I don't think he has taken the initiative. He has not attacked the problem.''
Richard Rahn, chief economist at the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, attributed Friday's drop in the market directly to the Senate's decision to postpone a vote on cutting the capital gains tax. The statement was seen even by Mr. Rahn's friends as a political observation rather than economic analysis.
Except for the Federal Reserve, however, the Government has little power to affect the stock market day to day. ''Making soothing noises is about all they can do,'' said Charles L. Schultze, an economist at the Brookings Institution, who was chief of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Carter Administration.
 
Fed Takes Action
As for the Fed, it pumped $2 billion into the banking system today by buying Treasury securities from banks. That increased the amount of money banks had available to make loans to brokers and securities dealers and presumably increased investor confidence.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, gave a scheduled speech on bank capital requirements to the American Bankers Association this morning just as the stock market was opening. He referred to the market only briefly at the outset.
 
'Watching Developments'
''We at the Federal Reserve are watching developments in financial markets rather closely,'' he said, adding that he was in close contact with Government regulators and central banks overseas. It would be extraordinary if he were not.
Some economists maintained that the decline in the stock market Friday could have the paradoxical effect of leading to an improvement in the economy, if it encouraged the Fed to lower interest rates.
''That would be a stimulus,'' Mr. Chandross said.
One of the rates most closely controlled by the Fed, the Federal funds rate, which is what banks charge each other for overnight loans, fell slightly today, to 8.96 percent, from 8.93 percent Friday.

HEADLINE: A VOLATILE MARKET;
Airline Takeover Bill Clears a House Panel

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
A bill to forestall airline acquisitions moved ahead on Capitol Hill today, over the objections of the Bush Administration.
In objecting to the measure, the Administration in effect delivered a rebuff to Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner, who had testified that the legislation would make his department's reviews of airline takeovers more effective.
The Administration's objections were voiced in a letter from Deputy Transportation Secretary Elaine L. Chao, sent while Mr. Skinner was out of town. 
 
Department's Authority
''The Department of Transportation currently has sufficient statutory authority to act where an acquisition raises questions about an air carrier's fitness,'' she said in a letter to James, L. Oberstar, a Minnesota Democrat who is chairman of the aviation subcommittee of the House Public Works and Transportation Committee.
She added: ''The Administration is reviewing the current merger and acquisition activity in the airline industry. In light of the significance of this issue, and the analysis under way within the Administration, we therefore object to proceeding with the House bill.''
The measure was approved today by the subcommittee, and the full panel will take it up later this week.
Last week, they said, John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and top economic policy officials told Mr. Skinner that the Administration would oppose the proposed legislation.
 
Safety and Financial Concerns
The bill would require the Transportation Department to review any transaction in which an investor acquired more than 15 percent of an airline. The purchase could be blocked if the department determined that it would undermine safety, jeopardized the financial health of the airline or would lead to the sale of assets by the new management.
Under current law, the department can review the fitness of new owners to operate an airline but not before they take control.
Inspired by a wave of airline takeovers, the bill and a companion measure in the Senate, which has cleared the Commerce Committee, have picked up support in recent weeks, gaining endorsements from ranking members of both parties on committees with jurisdiction over the airlines.
 
Trump's Objections
Another objection to the proposed legislation came today from Donald J. Trump, the investor who recently bought the Eastern Airlines' shuttle and who today withdrew the bid for American Airlines that he made earlier this month.
In a letter to the legislators, Mr. Trump said: ''The attempts by AMR to have legislation rushed through the Congress cannot be in the interests of anyone but AMR executives. I believe that the perception that legislation in this area may be hastily approved contributed to the collapse of the UAL transaction and the resulting disruption in the financial markets experienced this past Friday.''
While the legislation, in its current draft, would apply to any takeover of an airline with annual revenues above $750 million, some of its clauses are written in ways that would especially complicate Mr. Trump's bid for AMR, which has lobbied for the measure.
Several committee members bitterly denounced Mr. Trump, rejecting his contention that their work might have contributed to the market collapse last week.

HEADLINE: U.S. OFFERS TO AID GORBACHEV'S PLAN TO REVAMP SYSTEM

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said last night that the United States was prepared to provide Moscow with advice and technical assistance to help it restructure the Soviet economy and society.
It was the Bush Administration's most open endorsement of the economic changes brought about by the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and it seemed to represent a new approach by an Administration that has been criticized for being too tepid in its response to Mr. Gorbachev.
Speaking before a nonpartisan foreign-policy association in Manhattan, Mr. Baker repeatedly emphasized that the Bush Administration recognized the ''historic opportunity'' now at hand to make a ''lasting improvement'' in Soviet-American relations. [Excerpts from the speech, page A14.] A New Enthusiasm Although Mr. Baker's speech lacked new initiatives beyond an offer to send American economic experts to Moscow, its tone and substance reflected an element of enthusiasm for joining with the Soviet Union in reshaping East-West relations. It stood in marked contrast to statements by other Administration officials, who seemed in recent months to express more fear than excitement for the extraordinary changes in the Eastern bloc. 
Only a month ago, in a widely quoted speech, Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger said that helping Mr. Gorbachev's reforms ''is not the task of American foreign policy, nor should it be that of our Western partners.'' He added, ''Our task, however, is to devise policies which will serve our interests whether Mr. Gorbachev succeeds or fails.''
 
Promise of Perestroika
Administration officials were clearly hoping that the Baker speech would help silence critics in the Democratic Party who have said that the Bush team does not recognize the opportunities at hand. In the speech, Mr. Baker's most comprehensive talks on East-West relations since taking office, the Secretary declared that Mr. Gorbachev's success in restructuring the Soviet Union was itself a fundamental American interest.
''We want perestroika to succeed,'' Mr. Baker told the Foreign Policy Association, a nonpartisan organization that examines foreign affairs, during the speech at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.
''We have reached this conclusion not because it is our business to reform Soviet society or to keep a particular Soviet leader in power - we can really do neither - but because perestroika promises Soviet actions more advantageous to our interests,'' he said.
''Our task is to search creatively for those points of mutual U.S.-Soviet advantage that may be possible. And many more may be possible because of perestroika.''
State Department officials made no effort to hide that the speech was intended to communicate how far Mr. Baker's views toward Moscow had evolved in the last nine months, and in particular since the end of the summer.
In that time, Poland's first non-Communist postwar Government took office, Hungary's Communist Party dissolved itself and recast itself as a socialist party, East Germany began to feel similar winds of change, and Mr. Baker himself engaged in an extensive round of talks with his Soviet counterpart, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, in Wyoming.
A sign of how far the Administration is now ready to go in engaging Mr. Gorbachev was Mr. Baker's declaration that ''we are prepared to provide technical assistance in certain areas of Soviet economic reform.''
''The Soviets are entering uncharted waters, experimenting with markets, competitive enterprises and realistic pricing, all of which we take for granted,'' he said. ''The Soviet leadership is clearly interested in our ideas about their economic reforms, and we will continue our discussion on these issues.''
 
'Intellectual Help'
Administration officials said Mr. Baker's reference to technical assistance meant the type of ''intellectual help'' provided last week by the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, who spent the week in Moscow meeting with top economic advisers and discussing the role of a central bank and a commercial banking system.
Another idea, said an Administration official, would be for the United States to provide a team of experts to help the Soviets develop a statistical base for their economy - anything from a consumer-price index to real production and consumption indexes - which are now lacking in the Soviet Union, making economic reform much more difficult to plan and chart.
There was virtually no emphasis in the Baker speech on the dangers of Mr. Gorbachev's loosening hold on Eastern Europe but rather a constant focus on the possibilities that have resulted from Mr. Gorbachev's program of perestroika, or political and economic restructuring.
There was also an indication that the Administration now thinks Mr. Gorbachev is sincere in his desire to engage in Western-style reforms and is not trying to win a ''breathing space'' so that the Soviet Union can do battle with capitalism down the road.
 
Call for Economic Reform
Mr. Baker said: ''Perestroika is a Soviet response to a rapidly changing world in which they see themselves increasingly hard-pressed to compete economically, technologically, politically and militarily. The very logic of perestroika requires that the Soviets solve their own problems in a comprehensive, organic way.
''Not only must the economic system be reformed but the political and legal systems, too. Perestroika is, therefore, different than earlier, failed attempts at reforming the state Lenin founded and Stalin built.''
Mr. Baker took note of what Administration officials say is a widening awareness, at least at the State Department, that Mr. Gorbachev is engaging in reforms so far-reaching that they will make many of his initiatives more difficult to reverse, no matter who might succeed him. Mr. Baker said ''the self-reliant and radical nature of domestic perestroika has become even more crucial as the reforms have encountered increasing difficulties.''
Mr. Baker said that in defense policy and arms control, and in certain regional conflicts like Afghanistan and Central America, the Soviets have not gone far enough to show the kind of new thinking that they have at home.
The transformation of ''tanks into tractors'' that Mr. Gorbachev spoke of has yet to materialize, he said. Nevertheless, Mr. Baker said: ''By acting realistically to engage Moscow in the search for mutual interests, we can seize the opportunities inherent in Gorbachev's revolution. By standing pat, we would gain nothing and lose this chance to revolutionize East-West relations.''
 
Future of Germany
In a brief section on East Germany, Mr. Baker appeared to indicate that while the United States continued to support a united Germany in theory, it would not tolerate neutrality for such a Germany.
''Normalization must occur on the basis of Western values and with the end result being a people integrated into the community of democratic European nations.''
At the same time, Mr. Baker cautioned Eastern Europeans and residents of the Soviet Baltic republics who are striving for greater freedom to recognize that this will have to be a gradual process, and to understand that neither they nor Mr. Gorbachev nor the United States will benefit from changes that could bring a crackdown from Moscow.
''We favor a process that gives these countries their right to self-determination and freedom,'' said Mr. Baker. ''No one - I repeat, no one - will benefit if the entire trend toward beneficial economic and political change is engulfed in violence. But all will benefit if the reforms succeed in Eastern Europe.''

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
Morgan Posts a Loss; Other Banks Record Gains

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

 BODY:
As expected, J. P. Morgan & Company announced yesterday that it had reported a loss of $1.82 billion for the third quarter. Meanwhile, the Security Pacific Corporation yesterday reported a 10 percent increase in third-quarter profits; the NCNB Corporation's profits more than doubled, with half its profits coming from its Texas operations, and the First City Bancorporation of Texas reported a 22 percent increase in profits.
 
J.P. Morgan
J. P. Morgan said last month that it would report the third-quarter loss since it had added $2 billion to its reserve against third world loans. Increases in a bank's reserves for losses on its loans are subtracted from its earnings. The move brought Morgan's total reserves to $3 billion, which equals 100 percent of its portfolio of medium- and long-term debt to lesser developed countries and 68 percent of its total lending to third world countries. A year earlier, the reserves equaled 23 percent of total third world lending. 
In another sign that Morgan was trying to free its capital from loans tied to developing countries, the bank holding company also said that by the end of the quarter, it had sold $500 million of its loans, reducing its total exposure to $4 billion.
The loss for the quarter compares with a profit of $233.6 million, or $1.25 a share, for the 1988 period.
''It was a weak quarter,'' said Chris Kotowski, a bank analyst for Oppenheimer & Company. ''Morgan's strategy may ultimately prove to be right. But over the near term, earnings are weak and the stock is vulnerable to be clipped a couple of points.''
Expenses in the quarter increased by $67 million, to $496 million, Mr. Kotowski said. ''That kind of increase coming in the face of weaker revenues is a bad combination,'' he said. The company attributed the increase to increased employee benefits and costs associated with its move to a new office in downtown Manhattan.
Other big banks, including Chase Manhattan, Manufacturers Hanover, and Chemical, have said their third-quarter results would be poor after moves to shore up their loss reserves from problems with third world debt.
Morgan's interest income for the quarter was $254 million, down from $347 million in the 1988 quarter.
It also said non-interest income had risen by $45 million, to $414 million. for the corresponding period last year. The increase reflected increased corporate finance fees and gains from the sale of investment securities.
Morgan's stock rose $1.50 to close at $44.125 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
NCNB
The NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., said earnings in the quarter more than doubled, to $143.6 million, or $1.45 a share, compared with $58.9 million, or 69 cents a share, in the corresponding period last year.
The banking company's NCNB Texas unit contributed more than half of the net income, or $76.1 million. Overall profit within the Texas operation was $123.1 million, including $63.1 million in gains from sales of investment securities.
NCNB acquired the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's 51 percent stake in NCNB Texas in July, a year after the F.D.I.C. picked NCNB to manage and subsequently to buy the largest bank franchise in Texas, formerly held by the First Republicbank Corporation.
All the operations in Texas have been consolidated as part of NCNB's total financial results since it bought the F.D.I.C.'s stake last July. In a statement, NCNB's total assets increased to $60.8 billion in the third quarter, from $28.8 billion in the corresponding period last year.
In the quarter, nonperforming assets rose to $474.1 million, or 1.43 percent of total loans and leases. Most of the nonperforming assets, or $348.3 million, were in the company's Southeast banking unit, which operates principally in Florida. That figure for the Southeast unit rose by 51 percent, from $230.8 million, in the period a year earlier.
 
Security Pacific
Security Pacific said its third-quarter net income had increased 10.2 percent, to $185.1 million, or $1.55 a share, from $167.9 million, or $1.47 a share, in the comparable period last year.
Richard J. Flamson 3d, the chairman and chief executive of Security Pacific, attributed the increase to strong growth in the California consumer and residential real estate markets, continued strength in the bank company's Pacific Northwest operations and a strong showing in its financial services affiliates.
For the quarter, interest income increased 8 percent, to $727.9 million, and non-interest income declined 6 percent, to $457.1 million.
Security Pacific's stock fell 37.5 cents yesterday, to $44.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
First City
First City Bancorporation of Texas said its profits rose 22 percent in the third quarter, largely reflecting new loan business.
The Houston-based bank group said it had earned $28.8 million, or $1.19 a share, up from the $23.6 million, or 97 cents a share, for the comparable period a year earlier.
First City's asset base at Sept. 30 totaled $13.6 billion, up from $12.9 billion June 30 and $11.6 billion Sept. 6, 1988. Loans grew to $7.8 billion at the end of the quarter, an increase of 4 percent from the previous quarter and 15 percent from the corresponding period one year ago.
In the third quarter, First City acquired the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's interest in the bank, allowing it to operate with more freedom and to extend its franchise with more flexiblity, the bank's chairman, A. Robert Abboud, said. After First City was shored up with Federal assistance of $970 million, Mr. Abboud's group bought the institution for $500 million raised privately in April 1988.
During the last year, the book value of First City's shares has increased 25 percent, to $28.55 from $22.89, the company said. For the year ended Sept. 30, the company's stock price has risen 50 percent, and closed at $36.50, off $1.50. in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: LEADER FALLS BACK IN BRAZILIAN RACE

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 16

 BODY:
One month before Brazilians vote for a new President, the race looks increasingly like a tossup.
As the Nov. 15 voting date approaches, a center-right front-runner is dropping steadily in the polls while a trade unionist with Marxist ties appears poised to move into second place.
The top two vote winners among the 22 candidates will confront each other in a runoff election on Dec. 17.
The rapidly changing political picture is taking place against a deteriorating economic backdrop. Brazil has suspended payments on its foreign debt, the largest in the developing world, and last month consumer prices rose 36 percent. 
A sudden surge in food prices last year contributed to the unexpected victory of a Marxist candidate for Mayor of Sao Paulo, Brazil's largest city.
 
Jitters in the Market
In the presidential campaign, Brazil's first direct vote for President in 29 years, the fall of the right and the rise of the left have caused market jitters.
''Gold has taken off, the dollar has taken off - only Collor can give confidence to the market,'' said Helio Costa, a member of the Chamber of Deputies who is an adviser to Fernando Collor de Mello, the center-right candidate.
In the last five weeks, Mr. Collor, a 40-year-old Governor, has seen his lead drop from 45 percent voter support to about 30 percent in Brazil's Gallup polls.
Mr. Collor's decline has benefited a rightist challenger, Guilherme Afif Domingos, and the trade unionist, Luis Inacio da Silva of the Marxist-influenced Workers' Party.
The prospect of a victory by the Sao Paulo leftist, commonly known as Lula, drew an unusually sharp attack this month from Mario Amato, president of the Sao Paulo State Federation of Industries, Brazil's most powerful business organization.
If Lula wins, ''everyone who can transfer his capital will flee,'' he warned. Although the leftist enjoys only a 12 percent approval rating in the polls, Mr. Amato predicted that his victory would prompt 800,000 business people to leave Brazil.
 
Capital Flight Grows
Because of general uncertainty over Brazil's political future, capital flight is believed to be running at twice last year's rate.
But one month before Brazilians are to vote, it is unclear who the top two candidates will be. Brazil's electorate of 82 million, the largest in the Western Hemisphere after the United States, is notoriously fickle.
''In Brazil, the electorate fluctuates enormously,'' said Fernando Henrique Cardoso, a Senator with the Brazilian Social Democracy Party. ''There is very little party allegiance. I think it will be decided between Nov. 1 and 15.''
Since early September, all candidates have had a chance to broadcast their views on a nightly program of 70 minutes of free political advertising. But according to the polls, 43 percent of voters are undecided and 65 percent have no party preference.
On paper, Brazil's most powerful party is the Brazilian Democratic Movement, which controls 22 of 23 state governorships. But in the polls the party's candidate, Ulysses Guimaraes, a 73-year-old member of the Chamber of Deputies, consistently receives only 4 percent of voter support.
 
Hobbled by Alliance
In a race where no candidate wants to be associated with the Government's record of 1,198 percent inflation in the last 12 months, Mr. Guimaraes is hobbled by his party's governing alliance with Brazil's President, Jose Sarney, as well as by his age.
Among today's top contenders, two other candidates, Paulo Salim Maluf, a former Governor of Sao Paulo state, and Leonel Brizola, a former Governor of Rio de Janeiro state, seem unable to break out of their regional strongholds.
Campaign positions are sharpening over an issue that concerns the United States - Brazil's $120 billion foreign debt. American banks are Brazil's largest creditors.
The fact that Brazil quietly suspended servicing the debt last month has done little to soften growing public intransigency about repaying foreign banks.
Mr. Collor, long a moderate on the debt issue, asserted at a news conference this month that ''the negotiation of Brazil's foreign debt has been conducted with the payment of bribes and has been shot through with illegalities and favors.'' Mr. Collor said that if elected he would cut Brazil's annual debt service and profit remittance payments to $7 billion, about half this year's level.
Mr. Collor advocated a two-prong strategy: withdrawing federal guarantees that the debt will be paid and forcing Brazilian businesses and states to individually renegotiate their debts with foreign bankers.
Virtually all other major candidates advocate suspending payments until the debts are renegotiated.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Out, Out, Brief Hope

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
The Arab states have stamped out a faint, brief hope that they might take one small step toward real peace in the Middle East.
For a while, some Israelis and Westerners cherished the thought that maybe this year the Arabs would be wise enough and want peace enough to drop their annual ritual of trying to throw Israel out of the United Nations General Assembly.
It would cost the Arab states almost nothing and win considerable political profit.
At a time of negotiations about Israeli-Palestinian talks, it would get them an admiring press around the world. It would signal that they might at least be giving a little thought to solving the one basic problem lying behind the Israeli-Palestinian dispute, which prevents peace in the Middle East and keeps the possibility of another war ever present. 
That problem is the refusal of every Arab state except Egypt to make peace with Israel. With arrogance and contempt, they demand that Israel turn over territory and weaken its security while surrounded by nations that consider themselves at war with Israel.
Anyway, that brief hope is dead. Sometime today, the Libyan delegate is scheduled to march to the rostrum and in the name of the Arab states demand again that Israel be kicked out as an outlaw country unfit to sit in the community of nations. Libya!
The move will fail. But the Arabs are not looking for a voting victory. Their objective is to continue the relentless effort to obliterate Israel as a nation worthy of respect in the world - part of a continuous and sophisticated campaign of psychological warfare.
The campaign is worth considering not only for what it tells us about the intentions of the Arab states but our own double standards.
Think: How many news stories have you read or heard on TV during the current session of the General Assembly about this annual ugliness and about the Arab decision to continue it for the seventh straight year?
A number of American columnists and editorial writers and members of Congress are demanding that Israel at once accept Egyptian or American or Palestinian suggestions about Israel's own election proposals. How many also have written to remind Arabs that peace efforts between Israelis and Palestinians are hardly helped by a simultaneous Arab campaign to drive Israel out of the United Nations?
Like most Americans and Israelis I hope some way can be found to put Israel's plan into operation. But I think that with their very existence involved, the Israelis have the duty to use all the political mine-detectors they own.
It is strangely unfeeling for Americans to scream for the United States Government to harass, threaten and blackmail Israelis into acquiescence while remaining silent about the continuing Arab rejection of Israel.
But the sorrow is that the double standard about Israel and the Arabs is so ingrained now we hardly notice it anymore. The world reacts in anger about the killing of Palestinians on the West Bank - except when the Palestinians are being killed by Palestinian terrorists.
Hard conditions in an Israeli camp for Palestinian prisoners get continuing attention - correctly. But two years ago, when the Iraqis dropped poison gas on the Kurds, fellow Muslims and inhabitants of Iraq, the world hardly noticed. Thousands were killed, according to Kurdish leaders, and hundreds of thousands fled into exile. When the atrocity surfaced, the story lasted a day or two. Then most diplomats and journalists yawned and turned away.
Every deliberately obscure word Yasir Arafat mumbles about accepting Israel's existence is praised. But when he travels around the world inspiring the economic boycott of Israel, nobody pays much attention.
The double standard is not the fault of Israel's enemies. They do not hide the depth of their enmity against Israel. Four decades after Israel's creation, European publishers have to print special maps in school textbooks if they want to sell them in most Arab states. The maps obliterate the very name of Israel.
The fault lies in the rest of the world, particularly the West, where the truth can be known and said. But it is not, year after year it is not said.
Peace will come in the Middle East when the Arab states are ready to make peace, not before. To pretend otherwise is a sardonic joke.
It is not absolutely necessary to have a sense of humor to follow what is going on in the Middle East. But it does help, particularly if it is a taste for sick comedy.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Copper Prices Fall Sharply; Grains and Soybeans Rally

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Copper futures fell sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York, while precious metals gained and grains and soybeans rallied, and energy futures sagged.
Copper futures slumped to two-week lows, partly on stock market jitters and partly on a report that a settlement of the 14-week-old strike at Canada's Highland Valley copper mine was imminent. Officials of the mine, in British Columbia, announced a breakthrough in contract negotiations last week.
The copper market, particularly vulnerable to industrial demand, opened sharply lower on stock market jitters, then recovered along with stocks only to retreat in afternoon trading amid speculation about the Canadian strike situation.
On the bullish side, the London Metal Exchange said in a weekly report that stocks of copper registered for delivery against its futures contracts tumbled by 13,575 tons, to 89,300 last week.
Copper futures settled 1.5 cents to 3.5 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in December at $1.2745 a pound.
Precious-metals futures rallied on the Comex, partly reflecting investor nervousness about the stock market.
Precious metals are often perceived as a safe haven during times of economic uncertainty.
Gold and silver made intraday highs before the stock market opened but they remained firm, despite stocks' recovery, on lingering doubts about the stock market, said Bette Raptopoulos, a metals analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York.
Gold settled $3.90 to $4.10 higher, with October at $367.30 an ounce; silver was 1.5 cents to 2.5 cents higher, with December at $5.163 an ounce.
Grain and soybean futures prices rallied on the Chicago Board of Trade as traders, relieved by the stock market's recovery, reacted to news that China was bidding for 400,000 metric tons of American wheat and had purchased 150,000 metric tons of corn.

LENGTH: 1171 words

HEADLINE: This Year, Series 'Travel Day' Means An Easy Hop for Everyone Concerned

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16

 BODY:
In less time than it takes most people to travel from home to the airport, the commissioner of baseball changed headquarters today on World Series travel day.
''It's a beautiful day,'' Fay Vincent said upon arriving at the Westin St. Francis Hotel on Powell Street in San Francisco after a 25-minute ride from the Hyatt Regency Hotel on Broadway in Oakland. ''There was no traffic on the bridge. Everyone tells me how lucky I am not to have to go from west to east. I consider it Irish good fortune.'' 
World Series travel day. It happens twice during baseball's championship gathering if the Series goes beyond five games. ''Travel day,'' though, often is a euphemism. The off days, while providing time for travel of great distance, insure that if the Series reaches the sixth and seventh games, television will have a second weekend of telecasts.
Unlike most years, the only traveling done by either of the teams today was by the Oakland Athletics, who took a 22-mile, 30-minute bus trip from the Oakland Coliseum to Candlestick Park for a late-afternoon workout.
Actually, most of the players exercised the option given them by Manager Tony La Russa and drove to Candlestick directly from their homes. Jose Canseco was not one of them.
 
'I Don't Want to Be Arrested'
The Athletics' slugger, as notorious for his driving exploits as he is known for his home-run achievements, drove to the Coliseum and tried to get one of his teammates to accompany him in his car to Candlestick.
''I don't want to be arrested,'' Dave Henderson said, playfully rejecting Canseco's offer.
A minute later, Walt Weiss walked into the clubhouse and Canseco said, ''Walt, do you want to drive up there?''
''To the Stick?'' the shortstop replied, then thought about it for a second and headed for the bus. Minutes later, resigned to driving alone or riding the bus, Canseco boarded the bus and it departed.
The Airporter bus, with Don Donaldson at the wheel, departed without fanfare and proceeded along Interstate 880 north to 980 east to 580 west to 80 west and finally onto the approach to the Bay Bridge. Fluttering in the wind from light poles on the left side of the approach were green and gold (Athletics) pennants; black and orange (Giants) pennants adorned the light poles on the right side.
As the bus crossed the bridge, Alcatraz Island was off to the right with the Golden Gate Bridge farther in the distance. The hills of San Francisco loomed at the other end. Reaching the end of the span, the bus headed for Route 101 south.
Ten minutes later, the bus reached Candlestick. A lone 6-year-old boy stood outside the parking lot and waved to the players.
Other players had already arrived, driving from home as if they were regular people driving to regular jobs.
Taking note of the simplicity of it all in this year's neighborhood World Series, Hank Greenwald, one of the Giants' television and radio announcers, had said the evening before at Oakland Coliseum: ''It's a strange feeling in a sense. You feel if you're in a World Series, you should get on a plane and go somewhere and stay in a hotel.''
Visitors, like the commissioner, are staying in hotels, although some are remaining in a hotel on one side of the Bay or the other. As baseball's top official and a diplomat, Vincent switched sites this morning.
 
A Geography Lesson
Accompanied by a friend from Washington, Vincent Burke, and a security aide, Phil Knecht, the commissioner made the short trip in a white Chevrolet Caprice. (''They're a sponsor of baseball,'' he explained.) ''My wife and Mrs. Burke rode in another car,'' Vincent related, sitting in the St. Francis lobby, casually dressed in brown sports jacket, tan slacks and open-collared white shirt. ''Our driver, a San Francisco detective who does security work for us here, gave us a local geography lesson on the way.''
When they reached the tollbooth -one has to pay to get into San Francisco; leaving is free - Knecht gave the driver, Ron Kramer, a dollar bill for the toll. ''Phil got a receipt,'' Vincent said, smiling.
Vincent's journey was made in a far less conspicuous manner than the Giants' trip to Oakland for the first two games. The players' buses received a police escort, with motorcycle and squad car lights flashing and sirens blaring when necessary. Members of the San Francisco police force and the California Highway Patrol provided the escort and were joined by Oakland police motorcycles halfway across the bridge.
 
'Cops Gave Them Away'
''Actually, if it wasn't for us, no one would have noticed anything,'' Ray Shine of the San Francisco police, one of the escorts, said after the Sunday trip. ''It was definitely the cops that gave them away. But even then I was waiting to see how many people were giving thumbs up or thumbs down and there weren't many.''
Dirk Smith, the Giants' travel director, said the players on the bus enjoyed the escort. ''They got a kick out of them pulling cars over so we could get through but people thinking they were getting tickets,'' he recalled.
Much is different about this World Series, including the vastly reduced expenses the teams have incurred.
The teams' expenses aren't quite as low as they were when the Yankees played the Giants (New York) or the Dodgers (Brooklyn) in the 1940's and 1950's. ''It was only a 15-cent ride on the subway from Brooklyn to Yankee Stadium,'' said Roger Craig, the Giants' manager, who pitched for the Dodgers in the 1955 and 1956 Series.
But saving more than $100,000 on a chartered airplane alone underscores the economic advantage this year. Smith said the Giants' charter to Chicago for the National League Championship Series cost $130,000 round trip, and he estimated that a round-trip charter to Toronto would have cost the club at least $160,000.
 
Saving on Hotel Costs
The other major savings is on hotels. Smith said that the Giants would have needed approximately 75 rooms at their Toronto hotel, at a cost of $99 Canadian a room. Translated into United States currency, a room would have cost about $76, for a total of $5,700 a day. If the Series had gone the full seven games, the Giants would have needed their rooms for six nights at a total of $34,000.
They are not saving that entire amount, though. Both the Giants and the Athletics offered players the opportunity to stay in hotels. The teams explained that in some cases the players' leases had run out. Smith said that 15 Giants were staying at hotels, and Morabito said six or seven Oakland players had accepted the team's offer.
Despite the convenience and the overall financial savings inherent in this World Series, an official of one of the teams made a surprising admission before the Series began.
''I'd rather be on the road,'' said the official, who didn't want to be identified even by his affiliation because he feared the other team might use his comment as psychological fodder. ''Everybody wants tickets for both parks. They couldn't do that if we were playing somewhere else.''

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Baker's Remarks on Soviet Union

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from an address by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, delivered tonight before the Foreign Policy Association in New York, as provided by the Federal News Service:
We are in a time of rising promise. Relations with the Soviet Union have improved considerably since 1985, when Mikhail Gorbachev launched what he called perestroika, a total restructuring of Soviet society, including Soviet foreign and defense policy. And this administration has been building on what was achieved during the Reagan years so that improved American-Soviet relations will last.
We now have a historic opportunity with the Soviet Union. We have the chance to leave behind the postwar period with the ups and downs of the cold war. We can move beyond containment to make the change toward better superpower relations more secure and less reversible. Our task is to find enduring points of mutual advantage that serve the interests of the United States and the Soviet Union. 
 
Promise for the Future
As a consequence of the failure of their system, the Soviets, led by Mikhail Gorbachev, have begun the process of reform and rebuilding called perestroika. And it is this process, combined with our own achievements, that offers promise for the future. The President has said and I have said that we want perestroika, including the restructuring of Soviet-American relations, to succeed.
We have reached this conclusion not because it is our business to reform Soviet society or to keep a particular Soviet leader in power -we can really do neither - but because perestroika promises Soviet actions more advantageous to our interests. Our task is to search creatively for those points of mutual U.S.-Soviet advantage that may be possible, and many more may be possible because of perestroika. . . .
 
Regional Conflicts
President Gorbachev has repeatedly pointed to the links between domestic reform and the new thinking in foreign policy, saying just a few months ago that there exists an indissoluble link between the new foreign policy and perestroika in the country.
And that is where we come in. Fascinating as change in the Soviet Union may be, we are mainly affected by the way the Soviet Union approaches the rest of the world. Here, too, perestroika promises a radical reform. . . . Regional conflicts are likely to be more difficult to contain, more likely to engulf more countries, and more susceptible to escalation.
Neither the United States nor a Soviet Union in the midst of perestroika has an interest in being drawn into such conflicts. . . . This is an area where the Soviets can help themselves. And we have made it clear that we are ready and willing partners, partners who recognize that settling and defusing regional tensions can diminish the dangers we face. . . .
 
The Success of Glasnost
While our primary focus is on those points of mutual advantage that we can find in these three areas - Europe, regional conflicts, and arms control - we are also seeking a fourth area: the strengthening of glasnost and democratization.
Through our exchanges, we are actively encouraging the growth of pluralistic institutions and practices in the Soviet Union. We believe the emphasis on the rule of law in the writings of the reformers is a positive step. We are encouraging the Soviets to make permanent in their legal code and practice the protection of individual rights to which they subscribed in the Helsinki Accord. . . .
Finally, we have begun to explore a fifth area of potential mutual advantage. This last area relates to perestroika's internal aspects.
We are prepared to provide technical assistance in certain areas of Soviet economic reform. The Soviets are entering uncharted waters, experimenting with markets, competitive enterprises, and realistic pricing, all of which we take for granted.
In Wyoming, Minister Shevardnadze and I had extensive discussions on the kinds of steps that would facilitate price reform, a necessary step toward ruble convertibility. The Soviet leadership is clearly interested in our ideas about their economic reforms, and we will continue our discussions on these issues. . . .
We do neither of us any good if we relax our own standards in the name of helping reform. That's why we've told the Soviets to codify the changes we're seeing in their emigration practice so that we can waive Jackson-Vanik as we've promised.
That's why today we see discussions about Soviet membership in GATT or the other international financial institutions as premature.
That's also why our approach to trade, based on previous experience both with the U.S.S.R. and other countries, must be on a commercial basis. Mutually beneficial, non-strategic commercial exchanges are the best way to expand Soviet participation in the international economy. . . .
We want perestroika to succeed at home and abroad because we believe that it will bring about a less aggressive Soviet Union, restrained in the use of force and less hostile to democracy. A perestroika that resulted simply in a more efficient and more capable Soviet state would indeed be a more formidable and dangerous competitor. But I do not believe that perestroika can succeed without increasing measures of free markets, free speech and institutions more accountable to the people. . . .
That means a more democratic society, more respectful of human rights and legal norms which could provide a lasting foundation for more constructive, less dangerous Soviet behavior abroad; a society that produces not su?jects who are to be acted upon but citizens who participate in policy; and a society where citizens have a say in what their government does at home and abroad. . . .

HEADLINE: Sales Far Outpace Rise Of 0.3% in Inventories

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Business sales far outpaced inventory accumulation in August, the Commerce Department said today in a report that suggested unsold goods were not piling up and the economy was in fairly strong shape.
The department said inventories edged up by three-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $789.9 billion, while sales advanced a steep 3.1 percent, to $526.8 billion. The pace in inventories was down from a nine-tenths rise in July; sales rose from a nine-tenths decline. 
The combination of sales advancing far faster than the accumulation of goods on shelves and backlots is good news for the economy. If inventories were to pile up excessively, it could mean cutbacks in production and a loss of jobs.
 
No Vulnerability Seen
''Basically, the inventories do not appear to show any signs of vulnerability,'' said Robert G. Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Company of Chicago. ''I've been impressed by how managements have been keeping inventories from getting seriously out of hand.''
The Commerce Department's report showed a decrease in the ratio of inventories to sales to 1.50 in August, from 1.54 in July. That means it would take one and a half months to exhaust inventories at the August pace.
Manufacturers' inventories, which represent about 45 percent of the total, were up by only three-tenths of 1 percent, while wholesalers' backlogs actually dropped by one-tenth.
 
Automobile Rise a Factor
Retailers' inventories, however, rose by seven-tenths of 1 percent, which Michael P. Niemira, an economist at the Mitsubishi Bank in New York attributed in large part to a 1.6 percent automobile rise. He described the slowing pace of inventory growth as a ''mini-inventory correction'' that began last year in manufacturing and has been working its way through the other sectors.
Manufacturers' sales, on the other hand, rose 5.6 percent, followed by wholesalers' sales, up 1.5 percent. Retailers' sales increased by seven-tenths of 1 percent.
Over all, both inventories and sales were 7.1 percent above those of August 1988.

HEADLINE: Qaddafi and Mubarak Seek to Heal Rift

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Oct. 16

 BODY:
Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi drove across 120 miles of desert from Libya to meet President Hosni Mubarak today on his first visit to Egypt in 16 years. He sought to end a longstanding feud with Cairo that ranks among the longest in the Arab world.
The two leaders met in the Egyptian Mediterranean resort of Matruh, 300 miles northwest of Cairo, pursuing a rapprochement that started at an Arab summit conference in Morocco in May after years of open hostility that led to a brief war between them in 1977.
After almost three hours of talks, however, there was no immediate announcement that the two men, divided by Egypt's 1979 peace with Israel, had agreed a restoration of formal diplomatic ties. President Mubarak said, ''I did not open this issue today.'' 
He said he would travel to the Libyan town of Tobruk on Tuesday to continue discussions with Colonel Qaddafi, who flew back to Libya tonight in an Egyptian presidential jet.
 
Bases for Cooperation
''There are many fields and bases for cooperation between Egypt and Libya, especially in economic and trade matters,'' Mr. Mubarak told Egyptian reporters. ''There was a rift between us and Libya for a long time. But I believe there is mutual agreement and water is returning to its stream,'' the Egyptian leader said, using an Arab proverb signifying normalization.
Despite Egypt's re-entry into the public conclaves of Arab politics at the Morocco summit meeting after a decade of ostracism caused by the peace with Israel, Libya and Syria have remained the last two Arab countries without embassies in Cairo.
Colonel Qaddafi told Egyptian reporters he felt he was ''among my family and my brothers'' and, after his earlier efforts to pursue a merger between Egypt and Libya, seemed finally to acknowledge that the two were distinct entities.
Western diplomats said the site of the talks enabled Colonel Qaddafi to avoid visiting the only Arab capital to act as host for an Israeli embassy. And, by keeping the talks out of Cairo, President Mubarak avoided further affront to Washington, his principal diplomatic and economic supporter, which virulently opposes the Libyan leader as a sponsor of international terrorism.
Colonel Qaddafi last set foot on Egyptian soil shortly after the 1973 Middle East war. But his relationship with President Mubarak's predecessor, Anwar el-Sadat, soured over issues including Egypt's resistance to a merger with Libya, Colonel Qaddafi's criticism of the way Egypt fought the 1973 war and President Sadat's growing warmth toward the United States.
 
Border War in 1977
Relations worsened as President Sadat labeled Colonel Qaddafi a madman, and hostile propaganda poured from the two capitals, leading to a five-day border war in July 1977. Egypt had earlier accused Libya of being responsible for several bomb attacks in Cairo and elsewhere in 1975 and 1976.
The Camp David accords of 1978 and the peace treaty with Israel in 1979 prompted Libya to take a leading position in the ensuing Arab boycott of Egypt. In more recent years, however, the climate has shifted. Starting in November 1987, Arab countries have gradually restored ties with Egypt, Libya's populous neighbor. And Colonel Qaddafi, unnerved by an American bombing raid on his capital in 1986 and sensing ever-deeper isolation, has sought to project more conciliatory policies.
Western diplomats said Colonel Qaddafi and President Mubarak had some converging interests. The Libyan leader seeks warmer ties with Egypt as a way of gaining respectability both in the Arab world and the West. Egypt, for its part, sees a closer relationship with Colonel Qaddafi as a form of restraint and as a possible source of badly needed income from Egyptians returning to Libya to work.
After their meeting in Morocco in May, the two leaders reopened their border, closed after the 1977 war, and permitted the resumption of regular flights.

HEADLINE: ON HORSE RACING;
Making The Best Of Winter

BYLINE: By Steven Crist

 BODY:
What little humor surrounded closing day at Belmont Park yesterday was of the sort heard among men on their way to the gallows. It won't be so bad, the horseplayers wryly told one another: after just 29 weeks at Aqueduct, a mere 1,566 races, Belmont will be running again.
The opening of Aqueduct each fall is no more avoidable than the first freezing rain of winter, or paying your taxes, and just about as popular. The track that opens tomorrow is the one New Yorkers love to hate, but if they want to play horses here for more than 23 weeks a year, they have to make the best of it. 
Actually, Aqueduct is not half as bad as most horseplayers make it out to be, and it is getting better by the year. Its continuing transformation into the permanent home of New York winter racing has meant the installation of more creature comforts every season: more work stations where bettors can spread out their Racing Forms and set up shop for the day, more big-screen televisions for watching the races.
Aqueduct, where the dominant color scheme is an icy electric blue, increasingly seems like the nation's biggest off-track betting parlor, even though the races are being held right outside the insulated doors. From December through March, many patrons never catch a glimpse of horseflesh in the flesh all day long.
In a less imperfect world, none of this would be necessary. Racing in New York would shut down around Dec. 1, the horses would go to Florida, and New Yorkers would bet on world-class racing from Gulfstream and Hialeah at OTB parlors and mini-theaters at the track. Everyone would get a rest, a change of pace and scene, and the return of racing to New York in the spring would be enlivened by anticipation and a sense of season.
Don't bet on it. New York's politicians will never surrender the revenue they extract from 52 weeks a year of live racing. Also, the increasing number of cheap horses and statebreds that populate the New York stables would be unable to earn their keep without the New York winter's high-purse, low-quality version of the sport. The Phipps and Mellon horses pay their way by winning the toney races of summer, but most outfits make their nut in the colder seasons.
Racing at Aqueduct is better than no racing at all, but it also is not what it was just a few years ago. The Breeders' Cup has diminished the importance of major fall races almost everywhere, and nowhere more so than at Aqueduct.
The N.Y.R.A. Mile on Saturday might yield a starter or two for the Breeders' Cup Sprint, but no other race in New York for the rest of this year will attract a horse who is in contention for a divisional title.
Aqueduct's biggest fall races have been stripped of their importance. The Vosburgh has of necessity been moved to Belmont and turned into a prep for the Breeders' Cup. The Remsen and the Demoiselle, which once offered a last chance for a juvenile's championship bid, now are Grade II races that attract the late-bloomers who passed the Breeders' Cup. The Ladies' Handicap, the year's last Grade I race, might once have crowned a champion filly, but now draws only those who skip the Breeders' Cup Distaff.
As for the 42-day Belmont fall meeting that ended yesterday, business dipped, as many horses disappointed as delivered, and some new names topped the jockey and trainer standings.
Daily average attendance slipped 5 percent to 10,938, and the daily average on-track betting handle fell by 7 percent to $2,573,158. Track officials blamed a downturn in the local economy and the continuing erosion of live business by offtrack and intertrack betting.
Three horses lit up the races. Easy Goer's victories in the Woodward and the Jockey Club Gold Cup made him look more and more like the horse of the decade. Bayakoa's front-running Ruffian Handicap victory over the best field of fillies assembled in years proved her the sport's reigning queen. And Yankee Affair, a 7-year-old Pennsylvania gelding, stirred memories of John Henry with his Man o' War and Turf Classic triumphs.
On the downside, the two best 3-year-old fillies of the last two seasons, Open Mind and Winning Colors, both suffered dispiriting losses. No older handicap males made an impression, and the 2-year-old racing faded badly after a promising start, as Summer Suqall and Red Ransom were forced to the sidelines with injuries.
The daily racing fare picked up a bit toward the end of the stands, as higher purses began drawing runners from the Meadowlands. No trainer did better at shipping in from there than Robert Klesaris, who won his first Belmont training title by sending out 14 winners. Among the jockeys, the veteran Jerry Bailey took his first New York title by winning 32 races.
So it's off to Aqueduct, where the game will go on, and on. Not to worry: just 204 days until the first daily-double of 1990 at Belmont.
