HEADLINE: Talking Business with Callahan of Greiner Engineering;
Proposals to Fix Public Works

BYLINE: By Phillip H. Wiggins

 BODY:
A recent spate of water-main breaks in New York City has provided another sign of the widespread deterioration of the nation's infrastructure, including roads, bridges and airports. Postponing maintenance of the country's public works has produced problems that some experts believe could cost $3.3 trillion to solve. Frank T. Callahan is president and chief executive of Greiner Engineering Inc., an 81-year-old design services company in Irving, Tex., that specializes in transportation and other public works projects. He insists that infrastructure improvements are an investment in the economy and that they should be a priority of government and business.
 
Q. Isn't this a public policy issue for the Government to resolve? Why involve business? 
 
A. Clearly, responsibility for building and maintaining the nation's public works systems rests with the Government. However, the decaying condition of this infrastructure can acutely affect economic growth and development. Studies have demonstrated that a significant correlation exists between infrastructure investment and the health of the general economy. In Los Angeles, in 1988, costs of traffic congestion for both business and commuter travelers exceeded $500 million. And by 2005, traffic delays alone will cost the nation an estimated $50 billion a year in lost wages and wasted gasoline.
 
Q. Just how pervasive is this problem?
 
A. In a word, America's infrastructure is crumbling. Of the 2.1 million miles of paved roads, more than 60 percent require some degree of renovation and more than 40 percent of the bridges are structurally deficient or functionally obsolete. At the same time, the current number of highways, bridges and airports is inadequate to cope with the demand. As a result, traffic congestion regularly occurs on 70 percent of urban highways, and airport gridlock has reached epidemic proportions.
 
Q. Why were public works projects postponed to the point of creating this crisis?
 
A. Last year, a Congressionally mandated special commission, the National Council on Public Works Improvement, issued a report that succinctly answers that question: ''Of all public services, infrastructure may be the easiest to take for granted. When it functions best, it is noticed least.'' In fact, that is what happened. In seeking ways to trim expenditures from the budget, the Government reduced the annual increase in infrastructure spending from 4.5 percent in the 1961 to 1970 period to about eight-tenths of a percent between 1981 and 1987.
 
Q. Since fiscal retrenchment remains in force, where will the money come from?
 
A. Not only have budgetary constraints reduced funds available for public works projects, but the effort to shrink the deficit has prompted the Federal Government to withhold about $29 billion in user-paid revenues that are supposed to be reinvested in infrastructure projects like highway redevelopment. Releasing these revenues would be a good first step. However, the only conceivable way to really rebuild America's infrastructure is through a concerted program from all levels of government.
 
Q. What would such a multilevel government commitment involve?
 
A. There are any number of specific ideas being proposed and several bills are currently being debated in Congress. One recommendation calls for the creation of a Federal infrastructure bank to better manage the use of public works funds. Another proposal would make state and local governments responsible for the design and construction of all projects and limit the Federal role to co-financing the projects with the states and localities.
 
Q. Relieving urban traffic congestion would seem to require additional infrastructure building, not just repairing what exists. How can this be accomplished, given urban land-use restrictions and space limitations?
 
A. Our design engineering studies indicate many bottlenecks at interchanges between interstates and secondary traffic arteries. One promising solution is the ''urban interchange,'' a design configuration built within an existing right-of-way to improve traffic flow. In the case of airports, part of the solution requires improved air-traffic control, gate-capacity expansions and landing systems.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
After 'Eleni,' Life of a Woman's Children in America

BYLINE: By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:

A Place for Us
By Nicholas Gage
419 pages. Houghton Mifflin Company.
$19.95.
In his critically acclaimed book ''Eleni'' (1983), Nicholas Gage gave us a chilling account of his mother's arrest, torture and execution by Communist guerrillas in the Greek civil war in 1948. Eleni Gatzoyiannis's brave defiance of the guerrillas - who were rounding up young people to send them to re-education camps in Eastern Europe - led to her own death, but she succeeded in winning her children the chance to begin a new life abroad. Mr. Gage, then 9 years old, and three of his sisters were sent to America the next year to live with their father, who had emigrated there many years earlier. It is their story that Mr. Gage now proposes to tell in ''A Place for Us.'' 
Whereas ''Eleni'' reverberated with the heightened drama of a Greek tragedy - the book concluded with Mr. Gage in the role of Orestes, tracking down his mother's murderers, in a quest for justice and revenge - ''A Place for Us'' tells a gentler if no less moving story. It is the familiar story of a young boy's coming of age, his passage through the assorted rites of childhood and adolescence, his discovery of sex, romance and vocation. At the same time, it is the story of an immigrant family struggling to reconcile the traditions of the Old World with the freedoms of the new, the ghosts of the past with the possibilities of the future.
When Mr. Gage and his sisters arrive at their father's home in Worcester, Mass., they experience a severe case of culture shock. After the impoverished conditions of their isolated village, after the deprivations of a refugee camp, the prospect of living in a house - a real house with linoleum floors, an indoor bathroom and a kitchen full of technological marvels - seems like an impossible dream. It's like living in a palace, ''good enough for a king.''
Yet at the same time, the young Mr. Gage realizes that he has profoundly ambivalent feelings toward the father he has just met. He reasons that his mother might still be alive if his father had not procrastinated about bringing them all to the States instead of continuing to live as a bachelor who mailed his paychecks home. If his father had really loved them, they might still be a unified family.
Added to these feelings of anger and resentment is the disappointment Mr. Gage and his sisters experience on learning that their father is not the successful businessman they imagined but an unemployed short-order cook with quickly mounting debts. After accompanying his father on a fruitless round of job interviews, Nick wonders how he will ever manage to support the family, how they will ever manage to survive in this expensive and confusing new country.
There are further difficulties ahead: because they do not speak English, Nick and his sister Fontini are placed in a class for retarded children; they are subjected to the usual playground taunts suffered by newcomers and outsiders; another sister, Olga, undergoes a disfiguring operation for a goiter. Yet gradually, the family's luck begins to change. Mr. Gage's father gets a job as a cook at a classy restaurant; the family learns that Glykeria - a fourth sister, who had been spirited away by the Communist guerrillas - has managed to escape; and Nick, who has become an ardent movie buff, discovers that his imitations of Bogart, Brando and Cagney have won him new popularity at school.
A brief flirtation with delinquency ends when he exchanges Cagney and Rocky Marciano as role models for Paul Muni. He begins to do well at school, determines to go on to college and settles on journalism as a career - a career that will eventually take him back to Athens as a bureau chief for The New York Times, a career that will give him the tools to investigate his mother's murder.
Given the strict customs governing the behavior of women in Greece, Mr. Gage's sisters have a considerably more difficult time adapting to life in America. Having been raised in a world of arranged marriages, a world in which girls are virtually enjoined from speaking to boys, they are perplexed, even dismayed, by a country in which teen-agers casually dance with each other and make out in cars. In due course, however, each one finds a husband and starts a family of her own.
Olga, strict and tradition-minded, marries a man her father has found for her in Greece: she accepts the choice as a fait accompli, and falls in love with him on sight. The strong-willed Kanta, who has become a modern career woman, returns to Greece to look for a mate, meets the nephew of a cousin's husband, and after warning him about the hardships of earning a living in America, pledges to marry him upon his arrival in the States. Glykeria falls in love with a poor young immigrant and decides -against her father's advice - to wait for him to earn enough money to support her. And the shy, melancholy Fontini marries a man from Philadelphia and moves there, where she is free ''at last of the stultifying atmosphere of Worcester and the overbearing presence of her siblings.''
Actually, life in the Gatzoyianni home rarely seems stultifying; rather it is portrayed as tumultuous, intense, passionate, ''like life in the Greek village, where extended families live next to each other: a mixture of grandparents and babies, newlyweds, aunts and uncles.''
Because the early family scenes in ''A Place for Us'' are so vividly written, some of the later portions of the book, dealing with the author's adventures in college and graduate school, feel pallid in comparison. Indeed it is Mr. Gage's affectionate but unsentimental portraits of his family (from his tyrannical and fiercely parsimonious grandfather to his spirited, bickering sisters) combined with his careful delineation of the spiritual geometry connecting one generation to the next that lend this volume the real-life power of a memoir, the emotional density of a novel.

HEADLINE: Review/Television;
'Some Girls' and Teen-Age Pregnancy

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
''Intercom,'' the soberly inclined PBS series, introduces us tonight to a few of the adolescents who give West Virginia one of the nation's highest rates of unplanned teen-age pregnancy. ''Some Girls,'' at 11:30 P.M. on Channel 13, treats its five subjects as individuals rather than as data, helping us to understand why they are likely to have babies before they have husbands.
Attention is focused on the Youth Health Service in Elkins, a town in the north-central part of the state, with its high unemployment and cultural remoteness. The agency tries to prevent teen-age pregnancies, but failing that, concentrates on making sure that the babies are born healthy and that their parents know how to care for them. 
We first meet 14-year-old Shannon, whose broken home and truancy make her a candidate for early pregnancy. Sympathetic counseling helps her to improve her grades and her feelings about herself (''Last year,'' she says, ''I thought I was the ugliest person in the whole school'') and to give her the confidence to say no to an importuning boyfriend.
''Low self-esteem,'' in the counselors' favored phrase, is common among adolescents who find they can become popular and even enjoy something resembling love if they are willing to say yes to sex. A 15-year-old named Michelle says, ''It was like, everybody's doing it, and I thought I've got to have sex or I'm going to be the oddball.'' Coming from a family of alcoholics, Michelle had her own bouts with alcohol and drugs. One drug she did not try was a birth control pill. When her boyfriend learned she was pregnant, he said so long, a not uncommon reaction. At Youth Health Services, she found help in getting off drugs and alcohol and in having her baby, but when we leave her, she is pregnant again.
Most teen-age mothers, we are told, have a second child before they are 20. So it is with Carla, a school dropout who cannot find a job. Asked, with no hint of pressure, whether she would consider an abortion, she says, ''That's murder.'' Carla's counselor reports that she is turning out to be a good mother: ''If nothing else, she has done this thing very well.''
For all their problems, the girls profiled here are a hopeful group; they have sought help and seem to be getting it from counselors who talk to them frankly about their predicaments without making them feel like felons. In a switch from most documentaries on such subjects, all the clients here are white and several of the counselors are black. The implicit and important message is that teen-age pregnancy has less to do with race than with the conditions of life.
The true subject of ''Some Girls,'' produced by Mark Samels, is Youth Health Services. We come to appreciate the compassionate yet straightforward approach of the counselors and their efforts to give these young women, with their troubled pasts and troubling futures, a feeling that they are not alone and that even if they cannot manage to avoid getting pregnant, they can, with a little help, still be good mothers.

HEADLINE: Governors Ignored Poverty's Role in Education

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I would give the education summit organized in Charlottesville, Va., by our political leadership (news story, Sept. 29) A for its achievements in schooling. But I'd give it a C or maybe a D- for its contribution to education.
Like the school reform movement in the United States, the President and governors operate on the assumptions that children and youth get their education in schools, and that fixing schools will fix young people. Nothing could be further from reality. The most significant educational institution in the lives of all of us, particularly in our early years, is the family. Without families that work well, kids show up in schools lacking the capacity to learn. Restructuring and otherwise adjusting schools to serve children who are delivered for repairs from neighborhoods and homes that have failed them is useful, but not sufficient. 
Poor parents love their kids as much as rich parents, maybe more because they experience deprivation early and long. But a family in poverty has a very hard time delivering a child to school with the same prospects as children from middle-class families, and Head Start is not an infallible safety net. More than any other source, poverty limits the lives of our young.
You go partway to recognizing this issue in ''Little Kids'' (editorial, Sept. 30) when you back Gov. Bill Clinton's call for ''a comprehensive development policy for children under 5.'' But both you and the Governor should think of more direct attacks on poverty among families with children.
Poverty gnaws at the capacity of families to be families. The high correlation of poverty with behavior we deplore among the young (drugs, dropping out, delinquency, irresponsible sex) is no coincidence.
We are busy designing programs to deal with each of these behaviors, but we are much less busy finding ways to address poverty. We treat the symptoms and ignore the disease -mainly because of the expense of dealing with it. It is interesting that most countries the United States competes with economically do more than we to provide decent lives for their poor.
Head Start and health and nutrition programs are valuable but insufficient. Poverty among our children is growing: one out of seven were poor in 1969, one out of five today, one out of four predicted for the year 2000.
The bipartisan report of Representative George Miller's Select Committee on Children, Youth and Families issued Oct. 2 underlines these issues, which the Children's Defense Fund has highlighted for years.
In the 1930's, our country responded to inhuman conditions among our older citizens with the Social Security Act, which moved toward decent lives for the aging. We now need equally generous thinking about decent lives for the young. New strategies are required for both preschoolers and teen-agers.
The Family Support Act, now coming into operation, offers hope on that front. Its success will depend on matching funds from states for linking welfare and educational endeavors, as well as on adequate Federal support. The least the governors could do is to call for the funds to make this new legislation work by creating an alliance between educators and human service providers, thus linking welfare and schooling to attack poverty.
 
HAROLD HOWE 2D
Cambridge, Mass., Oct. 2, 1989
 The writer, senior lecturer in the Harvard Graduate School of Education, was Commissioner of Education in the Johnson Administration.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

HEADLINE: U.S. Economists Are Ready to Advise the Soviets

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
American officials said today that they were prepared to advise the Soviet Union on how to revive its stagnant economy by decontrolling prices, cutting Government subsidies, encouraging private enterprise and permitting the exchange of rubles for gold and foreign currencies.
Following up on an offer by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, the officials said they were also encouraging private American economists to provide advice.
Mr. Baker said it was not appropriate for United States officials to ''offer detailed prescriptions to the Soviets.'' But an aide to Mr. Baker said Soviet leaders ''keep pressing'' for American advice on such questions as how to write a bankruptcy law, how to shut down unprofitable enterprises, how to set up a stock exchange, how to protect property rights, how to encourage private farming, how to reward employees for superior work and whether to tolerate more unemployment. 
The Soviets are receiving so much American advice that they could be confused by conflicting recommendations. ''Have you ever met two economists agreeing with each other?'' asked Valery P. Sorokin, the economic counselor at the Soviet Embassy here.
 
'Beware of Visiting Americans'
On a recent visit to Moscow, Marshall I. Goldman, a professor of economics at Wellesley College, warned the Soviets, ''Beware of visiting Americans giving you advice,'' because ''every American economist rides his own hobbyhorse.''
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, was in Moscow last week, lecturing on the role of banks in a market economy, and Wayne D. Angell, another member of the board, visited the Soviet Union last month.
Martin S. Feldstein, a chairman of President Reagan's Council of Economic Advisers, was there in August. Georgy S. Markosov, a political counselor at the Soviet Embassy, said he spoke often to ''my very good friend'' Jude Wanniski, an apostle of supply-side economics who fortified President Ronald Reagan's commitment to that philosophy.
Increasingly, Western economists say the Soviets cannot muddle through with a gradual approach but must rapidly and abruptly make many changes. ''A cold-turkey strategy is the best approach,'' said Ed A. Hewett, an economist at the Brookings Institution who visited Moscow earlier this month.
American economists agree that the Soviet Union needs to give a bigger role to private enterprise and encourage the profit motive, but they disagree on the radical steps needed to move from a centralized socialist command economy toward a market economy. Most believe that the necessary steps will unleash fierce inflationary pressures once prices are decontrolled and government subsidies curtailed.
 
Making Currency Convertible
Mr. Wanniski and Mr. Angell contend that the Soviets should, as a first step, define the value of the ruble in terms of gold, so rubles could be freely bought and sold in exchange for gold or foreign currency. The ruble, they said, would then have a predictable value throughout the Soviet Union and in other countries. Soviet authorities have discussed making the ruble fully convertible for decades but have never taken practical steps toward that end.
At present, Mr. Wanniski said, ''the ruble has a different meaning on every street corner in the Soviet Union,'' and its value varies when people are buying food, shelter and other items because the Kremlin dictates prices with little regard for supply and demand.
Mr. Baker spoke favorably of a gold-convertible ruble when he testified before the Senate Finance Committee two weeks ago. ''The sizable Soviet gold stocks might be used to back the value of the ruble or Government bonds,'' he said. ''Since the Soviets are major gold producers, they could use future gold production to regulate the money supply.''
However, the new Soviet Finance Minister, Valentin S. Pavlov, said there were big risks in going immediately to a convertible ruble. ''This is a spectacular proposal,'' he said in an interview with a Soviet magazine. ''It is more suitable for teaching a novice how to swim: Push him out of a boat at a deep spot, and if he does not drown he will swim. In these cases I prefer to measure the depth and height of a jump and to prepare life-saving devices.''
Prof. Wassily Leontief of New York University, who won the Nobel Prize for economics in 1973, said that ''it's not very practical'' to make rubles convertible into gold. ''The number of rubles stashed away under mattresses is huge,'' he said. ''If you start to sell gold for rubles, everybody will want it. You won't have enough gold.'' Reliable Statistics Needed Officials at the Commerce Department and the Labor Department said they had begun discussions with Soviet officials about how to collect data and produce reliable statistics on gross national product, retail sales and consumer prices.
Janet L. Norwood, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics; Robert P. Parker, associate director of the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis, and Barbara Boyle Torrey, chief of the Census Bureau's Center for International Research, all said they had had recent discussions with Soviet officials.
Mrs. Norwood said it would be difficult to create a consumer price index for the Soviet Union because many consumer goods were in short supply. Mr. Parker said Soviet estimates of gross national product were deficient by Western standards because they counted the value of goods but not of services.
Several American officials said Soviet statistics were biased because managers of Soviet enterprises reported production as conforming to Government targets even when it fell short. In addition, they said, Soviet statistics on imports, exports and foreign debt were flawed by uncertainty about the value of the ruble.
Soviet officials say they would permit some businesses to go bankrupt, but Mr. Hewett said, ''Until you change the Soviet price system, it is hard to know which enterprises should go bankrupt.'' An inefficient factory might look profitable because it is obtaining oil at artificially low prices, he said, and an efficient coal mine might look unprofitable if coal prices are kept low by Government decree.
The Soviet economy is plagued with shortages of consumer goods like soap, sugar, shoes and gasoline. Prof. Nikolai P. Shmelev, a Soviet economist, told American officials last month that Moscow must alleviate those shortages before it could carry out any American recommendations. ''Before you can have price reform, you have to figure out a way to increase the supply of consumer goods in the market,'' he said.
American officials say a rational system of prices would achieve that goal. If prices were set by the market rather than by Kremlin decrees, Mr. Baker said, they would ''signal the scarcity of goods and create incentives for production.''

LENGTH: 561 words

HEADLINE: Help Who?

 BODY:
We are prepared to provide technical assistance in certain areas of Soviet economic reform. . . . We want perestroika to succeed. . . . Such words would have been unutterable in official Washington even a few months ago. Such thoughts would have been unimaginable just a few years ago. To Ronald Reagan, the Soviet Union was the evil empire. To Americans generally, the U.S.S.R. remained the implacable enemy. 
That Secretary of State James Baker can now say these words, out of American self-interest, signals a welcome, monumental moment in the history of the cold war and of the Bush Administration.
Probably not since World War II, when U.S. cargo ships carried lend-lease aid to Murmansk and Stalin was still old ''Uncle Joe,'' have American officials spoken so openly in support of a Soviet leader. And at no time since taking office has this Administration so clearly acknowledged the significance of Mikhail Gorbachev's efforts to transform his economy and society.
In marked contrast to the dangers perceived by others in the Administration, Mr. Baker looks upon perestroika as a ''historic opportunity.'' He offers few specifics but his tone is reassuringly right.
The Administration's hesitancy till now has inspired puzzlement, even alarm. The White House seemed unable to comprehend the vast transformation in the Soviet Union, even conveying the impression that it wanted Mr. Gorbachev to fail. First the Administration spokesmen said Mr. Gorbachev wasn't serious; then that he wouldn't last; finally that his reforms posed risks to the U.S.
President Bush set the earlier tone in four speeches this spring. Instead of welcoming the changes in Moscow and reciprocating, he adopted a ''show-me'' stance. Saying it was time to move ''beyond containment'' to ''integration of the Soviet Union into the community of nations,'' Mr. Bush insisted the new relationship had to be ''earned.''
The deputy national security adviser, Robert Gates, wondered whether the Soviet changes were fundamental and irreversible. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney predicted Mr. Gorbachev would fall. Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger warned of ''the danger that change in the East will prove too destabilizing to be sustained'' and disparaged calls for ''measures to insure the success of Gorbachev's reforms.''
Now, in one strong speech, Mr. Baker has moved to reassure the Soviets that the Administration recognizes its own interest in their reforms and to enlist Americans to act on that recognition.
Mr. Baker's offer of technical assistance is modest, yet to be spelled out. Even so, there's nothing presumptuous about this help. The U.S. may not have an answer to the Communists' problem, how to move from a command economy to a demand economy. But it can share its abundant experience with markets.
Soviet and U.S. economists already exchange ideas, as the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, did in Moscow last week. Economics departments and business schools are welcoming Soviet students and managers. Perhaps Washington can help with a new version of Fulbright (why not call them Kennan?) grants. The Jackson-Vanik amendment awaits repeal, to open trade.
But before the Administration finally starts doing the right thing, it's worth applauding Mr. Baker's willingness, finally, to say the right thing:
We want perestroika to succeed.

LENGTH: 459 words

HEADLINE: Unnecessary, or Worse, for Airlines

 BODY:
Should the public worry about attempted airline takeovers, like Donald Trump's aborted bid for American Airlines? Such takeovers inevitably saddle new management with huge debt. That, in turn, raises fears that the company will go bankrupt or else skimp on safety.
Congress seems to think the fears are justified. A Senate committee bill would empower the Secretary of Transportation to block airline takeovers for reasons of safety. A House bill scheduled for committee vote today would also enable the secretary to block takeovers that sap an airline's competitive strength. Neither measure is necessary. The Senate bill might help calm fears about safety. But the House bill gives the secretary powers best left to the market. 
The gigantic debt involved in the attempted takeovers raises two concerns. First, airlines might reduce maintenance. But airline safety is tightly regulated by the Federal Aviation Administration, which sets standards so high that minor reductions in maintenance do not threaten public safety.
Second, debt burdens could leave airlines vulnerable to economic recession. Unable to pay its creditors, an airline might declare bankruptcy or be forced to sell off some assets. But bankruptcy or asset sales do not make the planes, gates or air routes disappear. Another airline will fill in, causing only temporary disruption. Nor is new regulation needed. Deregulation has worked. Careful studies by Steven Morrison and Clifford Winston at the Brookings Institution show that deregulation has brought the public lower fares, increased safety, greater convenience - and even more competition. Only eight carriers dominate the industry nationwide. But on individual routes - where it matters - the average number of effective competitors has increased since 1978.
In the last two years, some gains have been lost. Competition has fallen; fares have risen. But the trend is too new to be worrisome.
Both bills would make a useful administrative change. The Transportation Secretary may now protect the public from an unfit carrier by revoking its certificate - but only after a takeover is complete. That's a Draconian process. The Senate and House bills require approval before an airline reorganizes. The constructive result would be negotiation instead of protracted battle.
The public wouldn't suffer from the Senate bill. The House bill, however, requires the secretary to determine whether a restructured airline would be competitive. This requirement substitutes administrative fiat for market discipline. The White House correctly opposes the bill, against the wishes of its Transportation Secretary. Such control invites abuse and a return to the regulatory stranglehold of yesteryear. AMRd(American Airlines)

HEADLINE: Capital Gains Cut Would Further Roil Markets;
I.R.A., but Different

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Much ado is expressed over the cost of the proposed reinstatement of the tax deduction for Individual Retirement Accounts. I suggest that the I.R.A. will not cost the Treasury a cent if a little creative thought is applied.
The first premise of my proposal is that, although tax revenues will decrease in the year of the I.R.A. contribution, those taxes materialize in the year of the I.R.A. withdrawal. Actually, taxes probably will be higher because the appreciation on the investment will also be taxable. Also, cynicism causes me to believe that tax rates will again creep up, as they always have, yielding even higher Treasury revenues. 
What I propose is that the Treasury not wait 20 years to ''book'' its tax revenues on I.R.A. contributions and withdrawals. Rather, funds should be transferred to the Treasury from Federal borrowings equal to the taxes that would have been paid. The source of the borrowed funds is simple: new I.R.A.'s will have to be invested in securities similar to Series E bonds.
Rather than losing these funds into the economy for 20 years, the Treasury will receive these funds now. If $100 billion were invested in I.R.A.'s, assuming a 28 percent tax rate, $28 billion would be ''booked'' as tax revenues. The Treasury's borrowing from foreign investors would decline by $100 billion because the I.R.A.'s have been invested in Treasury securities. The large I.R.A. inflow will finance the deficit to a greater extent from American sources than from the Japanese.
One problem relating to the old I.R.A. deduction was that it allowed liberal investment choices. Brokerage houses promoted real estate, equipment leasing, and oil and gas investments as safe places for I.R.A. dollars. Under my proposal, these funds will go to the safest haven for retirement moneys, investment in the United States Government.
The administrative cost of the I.R.A. program will also decline. Bonds would be purchased at commercial banks in the same manner as Series E bonds and would be registered in the investor's name. The I.R.A. bonds could not be traded on the securities markets; they could be redeemed only at a commercial bank. The bank would simply issue a Form 1040 at the time of redemption in case of early withdrawal. When an investor retires, the bonds could be exchanged for taxable annuities or cashed in and taxes paid in the year of redemption.
This idea seems so simple it risks the chance of getting discarded. Yet it accomplishes many positive goals: increased savings, increased funds available to the Treasury, reinstatement of a tax break to the lower income taxpayer and less dependency on foreign funds to finance our economy. And if Congress can be creative and allow the Treasury to ''book'' these tax revenues when invested in an I.R.A., tax revenues won't decrease as the Office of Management and Budget claims: arguments that tax brackets at retirement are lower can be dispelled by having a minimum tax on the withdrawal at retirement.
Individual Retirement Accounts are a good thing for the economy and especially for Americans in lower income brackets struggling to save for retirement. Congress should reinstate the I.R.A. and, if my proposal is emplaced, will reap greater benefits than now perceived.
 
GERARD A. HERLIHY
 New York, Sept. 27, 1989
The writer is managing director of an investment banking group.

HEADLINE: Face It, the Dollar Coin Seems Doomed

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I disagree with your editorial ''Right Change for Small Change'' (Sept. 24). Abolish the penny, no; reduce production, yes. Since 1981 an average of one billion pennies have been minted monthly. At the end of last March just over 100 billion pennies were minted in 99 months. There is no need for this. The sensible solution is to cut back production by a third or to 1970 levels. 
Discontinue the half dollar? Why not? It hardly circulates except at gambling casinos. Most vending machines are not made to accept more than quarters, despite inflation. For more than a decade, less than 100 million half dollars have been minted yearly. None were struck in 1987. Half dollars belong with $2 bills.
If the Treasury and Congress took a history lesson on United States coinage, they would learn why minting a dollar coin is senseless. Since 1804 the silver dollar has never really circulated. Between 1840 and 1873 there was minimal production and acceptance. When the Bland-Allison Act was enacted in 1878 (followed by the Sherman Silver Purchase Act in 1890), production skyrocketed only to see circulation almost nonexistent. Silver purchased under these two laws dried up in 1904 and production ceased until 1921. Then coinage resumed only to see history repeat itself. The last silver dollars were minted in 1935.
When the Eisenhower dollar began in 1971, hopes were that a dollar coin would revive itself. It was a lost cause. In 1973 the Federal Reserve faced the same situation it had with the half dollar. Except for the bicentennial coinage in 1976, production was minimal and the coin was a forgotten item. Hope that a smaller coin would succeed was behind the introduction of the Susan B. Anthony dollar, and everyone knows the rest of that story. In the last few years the mint has offered to sell Anthony dollars by the bag to reduce stockpiles.
It is true a coin will last longer than a piece of paper currency. But public acceptance cannot be ignored. In short, reduce penny production, abolish the half dollar and forget minting a dollar coin altogether.
 
CARL VOGT
 Florham Park, N.J., Sept. 25, 1989
The writer is a numismatist.

GRAPHIC: drawing

HEADLINE: A Prosperity Agenda for the 90's

SERIES: TOMORROW'S NEW YORK: THE NEXT MAYOR - AN OCCASIONAL SERIES

BYLINE: By Roger C. Altman; Roger C. Altman is chairman of the Public Development Corporation of New York, a city agency.

 BODY:
The mayoral candidates make a lot of noise about fighting drugs and crime, but they have yet to tell us how to pay for it. With New York's economy deteriorating, we need a mayor who understands the connection between economic growth and social priorities.
New York needs a new strategy for economic development. Some of the key 1980's approaches are no longer effective. The central business district of Manhattan already is stretching city services - especially transportation, health and law enforcement - to the limit. It cannot continue as the main engine of growth. Nor can the financial services industries, whose boom is over. 
New York should revise its development agenda in three ways.
First, it should intensify its efforts outside Manhattan, where prospects are better now than at any time in the last 20 years. The securities processing, apparel and financial printing industries have taken a renewed interest in downtown Brooklyn, and this can be accelerated. The Long Island City-Hunters Point area is moving up fast, as is the Teleport-Charleston area of Staten Island.
City Hall should pick out five or six of these emerging commercial zones for further emphasis, marketing them aggressively to industry, nationally and internationally. Through tax, financing and energy incentives, the city should insure that operating costs in these zones are brought low enough to be competitive with the surrounding metropolitan region.
Second, to promote tourism, we need to rebuild the dilapidated waterfront. We have a coastline that is twice as large as that of Boston, Toronto, Philadelphia and Oakland combined. It is baffling that these cities successfully developed plans for their waterfronts while we failed. Look no further than the South Street Seaport to see the opportunity.
The next mayor must find common ground between developers and environmentalists. For instance, there is a role for commercial and residential development on Manhattan's West Side waterfront, but only to help pay for a three- or four-mile esplanade.
Third, further development of central Manhattan should proceed only with great care. Beyond the proposed 42d Street renewal, there are few Manhattan mega-projects that will improve the economy in the long run.
Central Manhattan's density is now becoming a deterrent to business. Thickening it could boomerang and drive out more jobs than new projects would generate. For example, if Donald Trump should fulfill his promise to erect the world's tallest building, or if the huge East River Landing project actually rose beside the South Street Seaport, New York could be a big loser.
So far, the candidates have mostly avoided these issues. Perhaps they can - but the city can't.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: OP-ED; Series

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (97%);

HEADLINE: Rise in Babies Hurt by Drugs Is Predicted

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

 BODY:
If current drug abuse patterns continue, 5 percent of all newborn babies in New York City could require admission to intensive-care wards by 1995, state health officials say.
The figure for nonwhite babies could approach 10 percent in that time.
The projections, based on neonatal intensive-care admissions data from 1983 to 1987, cover only those children admitted to neonatal wards. The total number of children born to drug-abusing mothers, officials said, is undoubtedly much higher in New York City. 
For the rest of the state, the New York State Department of Health projected that in 1995 fewer than 0.5 percent of an estimated total of 145,000 live births would be admitted to intensive-care units because of drug abuse. Officials said they did not know of any other states or cities that had made such projections.
 
Costly Care Provided
Neonatal intensive-care wards provide among the most costly, labor-intensive and advanced types of medical care. They are designed for the sickest newborns: those with extremely low birth weights or, as with many children of drug abusers, those who suffer seizures, severe respiratory problems, congenital infections and withdrawal symptoms.
''This is very much the tip of the iceberg,'' said Dr. Linda A. Randolph, director of the State Office of Public Health, referring to babies admitted to intensive-care wards. Because of drug abuse, particularly crack, she said, ''we are seeing dramatic increases in infant mortality, in congenital syphilis and in the number of AIDS-infected women who are giving birth.''
New York City Health Department officials recently estimated, based on interviews with mothers, that births to drug-abusing mothers had increased by about 3,000 percent in the last 10 years.
''Things might flatten out, but it hardly pays to argue about whether or not the projections are accurate,'' Dr. Stephen C. Joseph, the New York City Health Commissioner, said of the state study. ''We are already in a crisis in terms of our ability to provide neonatal intensive care.
''Society needs to deal with teen-age pregnancy, the crack epidemic, poverty and social justice. The implications are clear, but whether we are willing to attack this in a practical way is in question, and there are not a lot of hopeful signs.''
Robert D. Gumbs, executive director of the Health Systems Agency, a public planning group, said: ''In terms of occupancy rates, neonatal intensive-care wards in 1988 and 1989 throughout the city are running at approximately 108 percent. That is the highest occupancy rate of any area of the hospital industry, and the major reasons are substance abuse and AIDS.''
 
Rose by 20 Percent
In 1987, Mr. Gumbs said, ''we spent $300 million on approximately 15,000 discharges from neonatal intensive-care units citywide, and I know that rose by at least 20 percent last year.''
At many hospitals, neonatal intensive-care occupancy rates have soared well beyond manageable levels.
''Our nursery is chronically at 200 percent occupancy,'' said Dr. Sterling Williams, director of obstetrics at the Harlem Hospital Center. ''We have to resort to diversionary measures. If you're trying to man 17 patients with only one nurse, quality assurance become rather problematic.''
Between 1983 and 1987, according to the state report, there was a 37 percent average annual increase in drug-related admissions to neonatal intensive-care units in New York City. For whites, the average annual increase stood at 31 percent. For non-whites, admissions increased at a 39 percent annual rate on average.
 
'A Lifelong Handicap'
Beyond the extremely high cost of providing intensive care to newborns, public health experts said the rising numbers of drug-damaged children carried weighty consequences for other public services.
''If there is one phenomenon that sort of encapsulates all of the socio-economic and health-related problems we are having, it is the baby born to a substance-abusing - paticularly a crack-abusing - mother,'' said Bruce C. Vladeck, president of the United Hospital Fund, a New York City-based health-care research group and philanthropy.
''These kids become your border babies, and that is why the foster system is collapsing,'' Mr. Vladeck added. ''Even after they are out of the neonatal unit, they are likely to be heavy consumers of resources because of physical and developmental impairments, and these kids are going to be a problem for themselves and society for 40 or 50 years. This is going to be a lifelong handicap and potential cost in a great number of ways.''
Asked what could be done to address the crisis, Mr. Vladeck said: ''In terms of capacity versus the size of the problem, we are starting off way behind. We are beginning finally, however glacially, to move toward substantial expansion of drug treatment, but there absolutely has to be an emphasis on reproductive-age women.''
 
Women 'Hard to Reach'
Asked if the state and city were doing enough to face the crisis, Dr. Randolph, the state's director of public health, said: ''We are trying to increase the utilization of services on the part of the drug-addicted mother in areas like prenatal care. We know that many of these women have had late, or no, prenatal care.''
Many drug-abusing pregnant women, she added, are ''very hard to reach and are leery of coming into contact with the human services, probably out of fear of the potential for incarceration or taking chldren away from them.''
In response to complaints of a lack of programs aimed at drug abusers, Dr. Randolph allowed, ''We still do not have enough drug-treatment programs available, never mind for pregnant women.''
''We need more appropriate space -more neonatal intensive-care beds,'' said Dr. Joseph, the Health Commissioner. ''And as we get deeper into the cocaine epidemic, it will probably turn out that these kids need more intensive longer-term care than we thought. We don't have havens for mothers and babies to get well, so that means pressures will continue to grow.''

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Cavazos Presses Parental Choice in Public Schools

BYLINE: By LEE A. DANIELS

 BODY:
Secretary of Education Lauro F. Cavazos came to a highly praised, innovative school district in East Harlem this week to press the Bush Administration's view that giving parents more say in choosing public schools would be a major step toward improving education.
But some of the remarks he heard from parents and local school officials Monday night and yesterday suggested that carrying out such plans, called ''parental choice'' or ''school choice,'' might be more complicated and run into more criticism than the Bush Administration thinks, particularly in poor urban neighborhoods.
For one thing, parental choice might demand more money from local, state and Federal governments than some advocates have acknowledged. Those who favor school choice, however, say it is a low-cost way to raise educational levels. 
 
One Parent Praises Results
''We've proved District 4 works,'' said Robert DeLeon, a parent whose two daughters attend one of the schools in the predominantly Hispanic neighborhood in upper Manhattan.
But Mr. DeLeon, speaking before an overflow audience Monday night in the auditorium of Intermediate School 117, asserted that the community's schools had improved ''most often not because of government support, but in spite of it.''
His statements, similar to those of several other speakers, drew heavy applause.
The speakers said that despite improvements in local schools and the plaudits they have won, they still were not getting enough money from either the Department of Education or the New York City Board of Education.
A school board spokesman said the board had supported and continued to support the district, which includes a total of 52 different kinds of schools in 20 school buildings.
Some advocates of parental choice who are closely involved with the East Harlem schools, however, said the neighborhood had largely been given the money available under Federal and local financing formulas.
 
Struggling to Save Jobs
On Monday night, several parents referred to the Education Department's rejection of the district's application for a $1.4 million Federal grant to support schools with specialized curriculums, called magnet schools. The local district board said it is now struggling to save 30 teaching and staff positions.
''The irony is that we're celebrating choice at a time when we're in a crisis in this district,'' said Ray Rivera, who has two children in the district's schools. ''Instead of increased support, we're getting less support.''
Mr. Cavazos, in remarks at the end of the session, said ''the funding issue will continue to be a major, major discussion.''
Mr. Cavazos has called parental choice the ''cornerstone'' of the Bush Adminstration's educational policy, and President Bush has called choice ''the single most promising idea'' in education today.
School choice supporters say that if parents could more freely choose schools for their children, the competition would compel schools to improve and drive bad schools ''out of business.''
 
Open Enrollment in Some States
Minnesota, Arkansas, Iowa and Nebraska already have in place statewide ''open enrollment'' plans giving parents wide discretion in choosing schools. Scores of cities around the country have for years offered magnet and alternative schools that extend options beyond neighborhood schools.
Mr. Cavazos, noting that more than 600,000 students drop out of public schools each year, said Monday night that the nation ''must find ways to address its education deficit.''
He said that the department's regional meetings on school choice rightfully began in East Harlem because it ''is one of the finest examples of how choice can improve the quality of education.''
In the early 1970's the district of 15,000 pupils ranked last in reading and mathematics scores among the city's 32 school districts.
Since then under a program that emphasizes parental involvement, a wide choice of curriculums geared to special academic situations, and staff innovation, the district's performance has risen to 16th place.
Despite their criticisms about a lack of money, the East Harlem parents and school officials unanimously praised parental choice as a way to improve schools.
 
Opposition in New Jersey
In contrast to the praise of parental choice in East Harlem, several parents with children in the Newark, N.J., schools voiced concern that the Administration's support of parental choice could hurt continued financing of programs for poor children.
Some lawmakers and educators have also questioned the Bush Administration's support for choice.
Representative Augustus Hawkins, a California Democrat who is chairman of the House Committee on Education and Labor, said last month that he was concerned that the five regional meetings ''may be offering only one point of view on educational choice.''
Several education groups have also voiced concern about the Administration's advocacy of parental choice.
Critics have said that such a program may produce sharply negative results in some school districts, like increasing racial and economic segregation in schools.
That criticism prompted department officials to say that advocates of other school reform strategies are welcome at the meetings.
 
'Encouraged' by Comments
Ted Sanders, Under Secretary of Education, said yesterday that Federal officials were ''encouraged'' by the comments they had heard.
''We want debate among those who believe in choice and those who are skeptical of it,'' he said in a break between workshops. ''We're not looking for a single definition of choice. East Harlem is proof that there's strength in having a variety of approaches.''
Intermediate School 117, which was once a school of 2,000 students, now has different academies of about 200 students on each of its four floors. All have a basic academic course of study, but offer enhanced programs in different areas.
Mr. Cavazos's two-day visit to the school was the first of five regional meetings on parental choice planned by the administration. The other scheduled meetings are in Minneapolis-St. Paul on Oct. 23-24; Charlotte, N.C., Nov. 13-14; Denver, Nov. 16-17, and Richmond, Calif., Nov. 28-29.

GRAPHIC: Photo of Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos, left, during his visit Monday night to Intermediate School 117. Among the members of the audience who questioned him was Anna Taliaferro, above; other parents waited in line to speak. (NYT/Bill Swersey)

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
2-Year College Viewed As Vital to Life in City

BYLINE: By LEE A. DANIELS

 BODY:
Urban community colleges have the potential to improve the quality of life substantially in cities and spread equality of opportunity among their residents, but they need more government money and greater coordination of effort, a new report says.
The report, by the nation's leading association of community colleges, asserts that amid the pressing social and economic problems of many inner -city neighborhoods, these two-year institutions have become ''the best hope for a generation of Americans that has virtually no other opportunity for education, training, and in some cases, economic and social survival.''
The study, ''Who Cares About the Inner City: The Community College Response to Urban America,'' maintains that improving those opportunities is crucial. It urges the Federal Government to consider creating a ''National Urban Extension Act'' to provide job-training and academic preparation for high school students. 
Dale Parnell, president of the American Association of Community and Junior Colleges, which produced the document, said that an urban extension act would encourage greater cooperation between city governments and community colleges.
 
A National Focus
Officials from the Federal Departments of Housing and Urban Development and Education said that while it was too early for the Bush Administration to commit itself to such a measure they do want to increase Federal support to the colleges.
''Who Cares About the Inner City,'' released Friday at a Washington news conference, is the latest example of an increasing national focus on the role of community colleges.
K. Patricia Cross, a professor of education at the University of California at Berkeley and an expert on community colleges, said these institutions have gotten ''short shrift from the general public in terms of both their achievements and their needs.''
That has particularly hurt urban community colleges, said Ronald Temple, chairman of the committee that produced the report.
Copies may be obtained by writing to the American Association of Community and Junior Colleges, Suite 410, One Dupont Circle, Washington, D.C. 20036-1176.
 
Not Winning the Battle
The document listed numerous programs that community colleges in the Bronx, Los Angeles and Miami have begun in response to community needs. But Dr. Temple said, ''We don't think we're winning the battle at all.''
Dr. Temple, president of Wayne County Community College, in Detroit, said urban colleges needed more resources to meet more costs than suburban and rural community colleges. He said these included the need to provide various kinds of financial aid, counseling, and tutorial services to students and the need to spend more money on security for the campus.
Roscoe C. Brown Jr., a committee member, said the committee has yet to complete its proposal for a new cooperative education act. But, he said, committee members envision it as the focus of a broad initiative attacking the urban crisis and drawing money from Federal departments like Education, Agriculture, Labor and Health and Human Services.
 
Why Visibility Is Rising
The nation's 1,211 community, technical and junior colleges enroll more than 5 million of the nation's 12.6 million college students. And, according to the community and junior college association, another 5 million adults annually take noncredit courses.
Recently, Dr. Cross and other education experts, brought together by the Institute for Research on Higher Education at the University of Pennsylvania, cited that figure as a major reason that community colleges are gaining more visibility.
Another reason is that most black and Hispanic college students attend community colleges. That has caused great concern among educators at both two-year and four-year colleges, since relatively few community college students go on to four-year institutions.
 
Charges Made in Book
One issue surrounding community colis whether community they have neglected their academic offerings in favor of vocational and technical courses.
That charge is made in a recent book (''The Diverted Dream: Community Colleges and the Promise of Educational Opportunity in America, 1900-1985'', Oxford University Press, 1989) by Jerome Karabel and Steven Brint, sociologists at the University of California at Berkeley and at Yale University, respectively.
''We're trying to get the doors opened and have the community colleges' situation examined in ways it hasn't been before,'' Mr. Parnell said.
But despite the problems and uncertainties, Robert Zemsky, the institute's director and a professor of education at Penn, said community colleges were not undergoing a crisis. He said he sees this as a time of innovation and opportunity.

SECTION: Section C; Page 15, Column 1; Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 1790 words

HEADLINE: A $27 Million Loan by Sotheby's Helped Alan Bond to Buy 'Irises'

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
When Vincent van Gogh's ''Irises'' was sold at auction for $53.9 million in 1987 at Sotheby's in New York, it became the world's most expensive painting. Now, nearly two years later and on the eve of a new auction season, ''Irises'' has become the center of a controversy over how works of art are promoted and sold in today's marketplace.
A major element of concern is a recent confirmation by Sotheby's that it lent the buyer of the painting, the Australian financier Alan Bond, about half of the purchase price - approximately $27 million. Sotheby's also stirred disquiet when it said it was still in control of ''Irises'' and was storing the painting in an undisclosed place until Mr. Bond finishes repaying the remainder of the purchase price.
When the magnitude of the loan was disclosed earlier this month by Michael Cross, the managing director of Dallhold Investment Ltd., a privately held company owned by Mr. Bond in Perth, Australia, some art dealers and other art specialists were highly critical. They questioned the size of the loan, its timing and the fact that the painting is not directly in the hands of its purchaser but in a secret place under Sotheby's control. 
 
An Artificial Bench Mark
What troubles critics of the transaction is that the extraordinary price paid for ''Irises,'' less than one month after the Wall Street crash on Oct. 19, 1987, fueled an atmosphere of euphoria in the art market. The price became the bench mark most often cited as proof that art was a commodity that had weathered the economic crisis.
''Every painting sold since then has been measured against it,'' said Alan E. Salz, the director of fine arts at the New York gallery of Didier Aaron, a Paris dealer. ''Maybe that wasn't a real price.''
David Tunick, a New York art dealer, agreed. ''Now there is this suspicion that it was a manipulated sale,'' he said. ''At a time when the art market has become so monetized, when people have begun to think of art as a legitimate form of investment, to see that all thrown into a specious gray area - I don't like it.''
''It's exactly like buying on margin,'' Richard L. Feigen, a New York art dealer, said. ''The problem is, there are regulations in the securities market that are not in the art market. By extending credit you are further inflating prices, which are rapidly getting out of control.''
 
'It Is the Ethic of Our Time'
But other dealers said they were not surprised when they learned ''Irises'' was sold with the kind of financing most often used in buying buildings or corporations.
''I'm not shocked,'' said Eugene V. Thaw, a New York dealer and former president of the Art Dealers Association of America. ''It is not a conservative thing to do to lend money on art. It is the ethic of our time that is encouraging living out on the edge of credit.''
Jeffrey Deitch, a New York art dealer who formerly was a vice president of Citibank in its Art Advisory Service, said, referring to Mr. Bond, ''A man of that worth can support a loan of that size.''
Mr. Deitch said financing art purchases is not new. ''At Citibank for nine years I saw many cases where people used leverage to buy works of art.''
David Bathurst, a London dealer who is the former head of Christie's, defended Sotheby's financing, saying the practice is hardly new. In a letter published on Oct. 9 in London in The Evening Standard, he wrote: ''Critics of auction house loans say they are a way of artificially pumping up prices. This is no more true than saying building societies pump up house prices when they grant mortgages.''
 
Traditional Financing Aids
Although art dealers traditionally have extended credit to clients, allowing buyers to pay for their purchases over weeks, months and, less frequently, a year or more, most do not charge interest, though they may give a discount for paying cash.
Mr. Bond's communications, brewing and real-estate empire has suffered financial setbacks recently, but Sotheby's says he has made all his payments on time. Mitchell Zuckerman, the president of Sotheby's Financial Services Inc., a subsidiary of Sotheby's Holdings, the parent company of the auction house, said the unpaid balance is now ''significantly less than half of the purchase price.''
Diana D. Brooks, the president of Sotheby's Inc., the North American subsidiary of Sotheby's Holdings, denied an assertion made in the British press that Sotheby's had plans to foreclose on the van Gogh and was trying to sell it anew.
Mr. Cross, in a telephone interview from London, said: ''Mr. Bond has met all the payments due and will continue to do so. He is not in default.'' Mr. Cross said the amount still to be paid was between 10 percent and 25 percent of the purchase price. This amounts to about $13.5 million at most.
If that is the case - Sotheby's has not confirmed the figure - Mr. Bond's loan could be greatly reduced or repaid when another work he owns, Manet's ''Walk,'' is auctioned at Sotheby's on Nov. 15. ''If it sells, he will use the proceeds to reduce or completely repay the debt,'' Mr. Cross said.
 
Estimates for the Manet
Sotheby's presale estimate on the Manet from 1880 is between $10 million and $14 million - well above the $3.96 million Mr. Bond paid for it in 1983 at Christie's New York at a sale of paintings owned by the financier Paul Mellon.
Mrs. Brooks, who is a former banker at Citibank, negotiated the loan on ''Irises.'' Neither she nor Mr. Cross would disclose the interest charged on the loan to Mr. Bond. Mrs. Brooks said Sotheby's aims at 3 percentage points above the prime rate, but will sometimes charge lower or higher rates.
Mrs. Brooks and Mr. Cross disagreed on who initiated the financing talks. Mr. Cross, who went to work for Mr. Bond in May 1988, said he understood Sotheby's had suggested it. Mrs. Brooks said Mr. Bond's agent went to Sotheby's in New York two or three days before the sale ''to discuss the availability of credit terms.''
The first negotiations were conducted by Mr. Bond's representative, Neville Keating, a London dealer, who declined comment on these talks. Mrs. Brooks said he went to Sotheby's and met with David J. Nash, head of fine art sales, and asked what financing would be available.
 
Doing Business by Fax
Mr. Bond's agents handled all the presale discussions and signed an agreement in which, Mrs. Brooks said, Sotheby's stated the maximum amount it would finance. Mrs. Brooks said her first contact with Mr. Bond about the loan was a fax he sent several days after the sale, confirming the terms he had accepted. Two or three weeks after the sale, Mrs. Brooks flew to London and negotiated the actual loan. ''We reached agreement in principle,'' she said. The loan was signed later, on Dec. 7, 1987.
Mrs. Brooks said the seller of ''Irises,'' John Whitney Payson, had agreed to allow Sotheby's to offer financing under the condition that ''Sotheby's was willing to take the credit risk on whoever was involved.'' Mr. Payson was to be paid in full over six months, whether the buyer paid or not. All payments were made on time, Mr. Payson said: half was paid in December 1987 and the rest by May 1988.
Last December, Mr. Zuckerman said, after the loan was renegotiated for another year, Mr. Bond finally took possession of ''Irises.'' Then, three days before Christmas, he called a press conference in his penthouse office in Perth where the painting hung, to announce he was the mystery buyer.
The yearlong delay, Mr. Cross said, was because Mr. Bond's new office was under construction until then. ''Now it's a fortress on the top of the building,'' he said.
''Irises'' remained in Mr. Bond's office from last December through June, when it traveled to museums in five Australian cities. In mid-September, Sotheby's placed the painting in storage.
 
Differences Over Access
''We have unlimited access to it,'' Mr. Cross said. ''But we cannot move it without Sotheby's consent.'' He cited security problems at Mr. Bond's office as the reason why the painting was put into storage.
''Unlimited goes too far,'' Mr. Zuckerman said. ''They have the right to inspect the painting. If they wanted to change the location of the painting our consent would be required.''
Financing of art purchases, a phenomenon of the 1980's, is not done by major banks.
''We lend against art that collectors already own,'' said Kevin V. Buchanan, a Citibank vice president in its Art Advisory Sevice. ''If they have already bought an artwork, we will give a loan on it as collateral. But we will not give a 'mortgage' on artworks that they wish to buy.'' Chase Manhattan makes similar loans.
Christie's, the London-based auction house and Sotheby's major rival, says it does not make loans to buyers, but assists clients who wish to seek financing elsewhere. In addition, the availability of financing arranged through a seller is announced for the first time in a Christie's catalogue for the Nov. 7 sale of contemporary art from the Robert B. Mayer collection.
 
Extended Terms at Christie's
Christopher Burge, the president of Christie's in the United States, said the largest Christie's sale on which there was extended terms was Monet's ''Seashore at Trouville,'' which was auctioned a year ago in New York for $10.78 million. In that sale the consignor agreed to delayed payment of ''less than 90 days,'' Mr. Burge said.
Christopher M. Davidge, the managing director of Christie's International, said Christie's viewed its role as an agent, not as a banker. ''Some time ago we suggested to the Office of Fair Trading in London and the Department of Consumer Affairs in New York that they should look into this matter of financing,'' he said. ''Neither seemed very interested and we were somewhat surprised.''
''We have reviewed the selling of 'Irises' to Mr. Bond by Sotheby's and find no violations of the auction house rules and regulations,'' said Gary Walker, the public affairs director of the Consumer Affairs Department.
Mrs. Brooks said she has arranged financing for clients since shortly after she joined Sotheby's in 1979. In 1988, Sotheby's broadened its financing of art purchases in a formal program, operated by Sotheby's Financial Services.
Mrs. Brooks said that one other potential bidder on ''Irises'' asked in advance of the sale for financing. ''But he never got into the bidding,'' she said.
Asked whether Sotheby's has attempted to sell ''Irises'' since Mr. Bond bought it, Mrs. Brooks said: ''We have been approached by dealers, lawyers, bankers and others asking if 'Irises' is for sale. Technically it is not for sale. If they are interested in making an offer, we tell them we will put them in touch with Mr. Bond's representatives.''

TICKER: BID (NYSE) (92%); 

INDUSTRY: NAICS454390 OTHER DIRECT SELLING ESTABLISHMENTS (92%); SIC5963 DIRECT SELLING ESTABLISHMENTS (92%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%); AUSTRALIA (88%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (92%); WESTERN AUSTRALIA, AUSTRALIA (57%); 

CITY: PERTH, AUSTRALIA (79%);

HEADLINE: UAL's Share Price Drops $24.875, to $198

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Stock in the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, fell another $24.875 yesterday, to $198, as speculators and option traders sold their shares, uncertainty continued about the financing for a buyout of the airline and the machinists' union renewed its efforts to block such a deal.
An avalanche of 2.82 million shares of UAL stock, 13 percent of the total outstanding, changed hands as some professional takeover speculators sold shares frantically to cut their losses and repay debts while other arbitragers bought heavily in hopes that the nation's second-largest carrier may yet be sold. UAL was the fourth-most-active issue on the New York Stock Exchange.
UAL stock had closed last Thursday at $285.25, and the many arbitragers who together hold nearly a third of UAL's 21.6 million outstanding shares have watched the value of their stakes drop by about $500 million in three trading days. 
Marvin Davis, the wealthy California investor, last night withdrew his $300-a-share offer for UAL. He said, however, that he was still interested in acquiring the company.
Citibank officially confirmed yesterday that it had received enough expressions of interest from other banks to finance a proposed buyout of the airline by its pilots and management together with British Airways.
But terms of the proposed financing were not disclosed, and it was not certain whether the package would be acceptable either to UAL's board or to the parties trying to buy UAL.
The buyout group, organized as the Airline Acquisition Corporation, announced on Friday that its inability to attract financing was preventing it from completing its $300-a-share bid, worth a total of $6.75 billion. The announcement was widely viewed as the cause of a 190-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average on Friday.
The master executive council of the United pilots' union was scheduled to begin a regularly scheduled quarterly meeting at 5 P.M. yesterday, said a union official who asked not to be identified. The meeting's agenda called for the union's financial advisers to begin the meeting with a presentation on the proposed takeover, he said.
 
No Formal Agreement
Although Japanese news agencies have been predicting a $250-a-share cash bid, the pilots have not even discussed whether that is a reasonable price, nor has any formal agreement been reached, the union official said.
American bank officials said Citibank had not been promoting the deal widely in this country and voiced skepticism that the money could be raised quickly. Citibank's reported moves to increase the fees and interest rates on the lending have not addressed the questions of whether UAL has enough assets to insure continued debt payments during an economic downturn, one top United States banker said.
But news agencies in Japan have reported growing optimism that large Japanese banks may participate in the lending.
Traders said the stock fell yesterday partly because investors were worried that the machinists' renewed opposition to a buyout of their employer might make the bid's financing more difficult to obtain.
The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers yesterday called on the UAL board to resign and asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to investigate a takeover bid by United's pilots and management, together with British Airways P.L.C.
The union sent a letter to the S.E.C., requesting an investigation of whether the buyout group had been in contact with Mr. Davis, who started the current battle for control of United with a bid on Aug. 7. The machinists' group sent a letter to Stephen M. Wolf, the chairman and chief executive of UAL, demanding his resignation and those of the other directors on the ground that the company's leadership had ''betrayed the trust and confidence'' of United employees.
Mr. Davis, UAL and the S.E.C. declined to comment on the machinists' letter. Mr. Wolf issued a statement in which he refered to the machinist group's call for resignations as ''divisive and uncalled for.''
Mr. Wolf said work continued ''toward a revised proposal for majority employee ownership.''
John F. Peterpaul, the general vice president of the machinists' association who signed both letters, said the union was suspicious of how the proposed buyout by the Airline Acquisition Corporation was put together. ''We see something here that we don't like the looks of, and we're asking Government agencies to investigate,'' he said in an interview.
In addition, a person close to the machinists said the union would send a letter later this week to the Internal Revenue Service requesting another investigation. The letter will criticize the Airline Acquisition Corporation's plan for employees to hold only common stock while British Airways would hold preferred stock, a claim on company assets that would take precedence over common stock in any bankruptcy, the person said.
Mr. Peterpaul declined to comment on the union's plans.
But a partner of a major New York law firm with extensive experience in corporate takeovers said that not one of the union's actions was likely to carry much legal weight, although they may scare some bankers.

HEADLINE: Dow Ends With Drop Of 18.65

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
After a turbulent morning that saw share prices briefly plunge, the stock market closed yesterday with moderate losses.
Early in the day, trading was halted in shares of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, which is the stock that touched off the market's 190-point tumble on Friday. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 30 points, then gained it all back in a 20-minute period shortly after 11 A.M. At its low, the market was down more than 60 points.
Share prices were lower all day, reflecting in part a disappointing report on the United States trade balance. That also sent bond prices down and interest rates up, further depressing stock traders. 
 
Declines Outpace Advances
The Dow ended the day down 18.65 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 2,638.73. Declines on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advances by about 3 to 2, with 931 issues down in price and 658 higher.
On Friday, the Dow plunged by 190.58 points, reviving memories of the 1987 crash, which took place two years ago tomorrow. But the market rose by 88.12 points on Monday.
''For the time being, I think we've seen the worst,'' said Peter G. Grennan, head of stock index futures trading at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.
Volume on the Big Board came to 224.1 million shares, a figure higher than normal but down sharply from the 416.3 million shares traded on Monday. That turnover was the largest since the week of the 1987 crash.
 
Prices Higher in Tokyo
Share price movements in the United States have rippled through the world this week, with markets in Asia and Europe falling on Monday, in response to the heavy American selling late Friday, and rising yesterday following the United States gains on Monday. In late morning trading today in Tokyo, share prices rose despite yesterday's decline in the United States. An hour before the close of morning trading, the Nikkei average of 225 stocks was up 118.14 points, to 35,114.22.
As the New York Stock Exchange prepared to begin trading yesterday, John J. Phelan Jr., its chairman, said in an interview that the expectation from reports on orders coming into the system was that the opening would be ''basically flat.'' But the trade figure, released an hour before the market opened, provoked more selling than had been expected. The report said the trade deficit in August was $10.8 billion as imports rose to a record $41.2 billion and exports slipped. The deficit was greater than expected and the highest since December.
The relatively moderate decline at the final bell in many ways belied the frenetic morning activity. The early mood of the market was fragile with the Dow off 30 points at one moment, off 60 the next, and then down only 30 again.
UAL plunged 24 7/8, to 198, amid speculation that Japanese banks might be unwilling to help finance the proposed management-pilot buyout of UAL despite a plan by Citicorp, the lead banker, to sweeten the terms being offered to the banks. The temporary trading halt in UAL was caused by an imbalance of sell orders, evidently brought on by margin calls - which require shareowners who bought stock with borrowed money to come up with more cash or sell their shares - and by rumors that some speculators who owned the stock were being forced to liquidate their positions. UAL has fallen 81 3/4 points, or 29 percent, over the last two days.
 
Smaller Companies Down
While shares in large companies have gyrated this week, stocks of smaller companies have moved down consistently. The American Stock Exchange's market value index dropped 1.25, to 375.16, for its fifth consecutive decline. In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index slipped by 1.05, to 459.93.
There was general relief on Monday when the Dow rallied after Friday's steep drop following the announcement of problems in financing the proposed UAL buyout at $300 a share, and much of that enthusiasm survived yesterday's decline.
Mr. Grennan, of Shearson Lehman, said that while a certain amount of nervousness and apprehension existed among investors, especially small ones, there also was confidence that the Federal Reserve would step in and prevent an extremely serious disruption in the market. On Saturday, a top official of the Fed said that the nation's central bank would meet any sudden demands for money that might result from the market's steep drop the day before.
 
Rally Predicted
A money manager, James Kalil Sr., president of Compu-Val Investments Inc. of Wilmington, Del., said he thought a rally would come soon.
''The latest sharp and short stock market declines appear to be replacing the traditional, prolonged bear market,'' he added. ''I'm optimistic that when this latest series of dramatic sharp downward swings ends, they will be followed by a sustained rise which will ultimately challange previous highs.''
But some analysts thought that the relief was not completely justified. ''There are too many Pollyannas around,'' said Harry Laubscher, an analyst at Tucker, Anthony & R. L. Day. ''There should be more pessimism.''
The Dow Jones transportation average plunged 49.96 points, or 3.8 percent, to 1,254.27, with the decline in UAL accounting for almost three-quarters of the fall.
 
Airline Problems Cited
William M. Lefevre, investment strategist at Advest Inc., said that some of the market's problems were tied to traders being forced to raise cash to cover losses from UAL and AMR, the parent of American Airlines, which also fell after Donald J. Trump withdrew a takeover offer. Yesterday, AMR dropped another 3 1/4 points, to 73 1/4, after sliding 22 1/8 points on Monday.
''The tendency is to sell better-quality stocks and keep the lesser-quality issues,'' he said. ''It's apparent that the bulk of the problem we are experiencing now continues to come from speculation in a few large airline companies.'' He added that ''after you've had a whack like Friday and then a recovery, the market usually tries to test its previous low.''
Broader indexes than the Dow also retreated widely, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index down 1.69 points, to 341.16, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index 0.87 point lower at 188.89.
Procter & Gamble climbed 3 3/8, to 127. Analysts said they expected the company to show strong results in its first fiscal quarter in the range of $2.71 to $2.79 a share, up from $2.36 a share a year earlier.
Among other major stocks, I.B.M. dropped 3/4, to 102 1/4; A.T.&T. slipped 3/4, to 42 1/4; Bristol-Myers was off 1/2, to 51 3/8; General Electric was unchanged at 56 1/2, and Upjohn rose 1 1/2, to 39.
Chase Manhattan fell 1/8, to 40, after trading as low as 39 1/2. Late Monday, the bank announced that a new issue of 14 million shares was being priced at 40 1/8.
