HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Widened by Import Surge

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit grew sharply in August, to $10.8 billion, as imports surged to a record and exports showed a small decline, the Commerce Department reported today.
This was the biggest deficit since December, and considerably higher than analysts had expected. But for various reasons it was not clear how serious a deterioration in trade the figures represented or what they said about the state of the economy.
Private economists tended to avoid expressions of alarm and generally accepted the view of Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, a leading Administration voice on trade. 
''While the trade deficit number for August was disappointing after two very good months,'' he said in a written statement, ''we believe that monthly data are subject to wide fluctuations and must be used cautiously.'' He added that the deficit was still about 7 percent lower this year than for the first eight months of 1988 despite a slowing in export growth.
The report sent the dollar down initially and appeared to contribute to a drop in stock prices. But the dollar rebounded as traders began to focus on the stock market. And there, after early declines seesawing between 30 and 60 points, the Dow Jones industrial average revived to end with an 18.65-point drop.
Various economists studying the latest trade data, which are published with a greater lag than most other indicators, cited reasons for their relative equanimity despite a $2.6 billion one-month jump in the deficit.
''People shouldn't be overly alarmed,'' said Frank McCormick, a senior economist at the Bank of America who prefers looking at the figures over a somewhat longer period. He pointed out that the deficit for the latest three months now averaged $9 billion, which was under the $9.3 billion average for the March-May period and the $9.7 billion for December through February.
At the Philadelphia-based CoreStates Financial Corporation, Ben K. Han, an economist, said his first reaction was to assume that the dollar's 1989 strength was beginning to take its toll - causing imports to climb and further dampening exports - but he added on reflection that there was little in the data to demonstrate this.
Instead, Mr. Han said, he found himself wondering about the adequacy of the Commerce Department's seasonal adjustment process because this was the third straight very large August rise. He also noted that swings in trade with Britain and Canada by themselves accounted for half the total deficit rise. In that light, he added, the result ''doesn't look like that bad a number.''
 
Upward Revision for July
Without adjusting for seasonal variation, the August deficit climbed by $844 million, or about 8 percent. With the adjustment, the increase was about 31 percent even after an upward revision in the July deficit, to $8.2 billion, from the $7.6 billion initially reported.
Economists did, however, agree that the report provided further evidence that the export surge that helped drive the industrial sector for two years had probably ended. The August level was actually slightly lower than the level of exports in April. ''The export boom is over,'' said Kevin Logan, chief economist in New York for the Swiss Bank Corporation.
Reflecting the continued weakness in the economy's manufacturing sector, the Federal Reserve reported today that industrial production slipped by one-tenth of 1 percent in September, the first drop in six months, and the operating rate of factories, mines and utilities also fell, by two-tenths of a percentage point, to 83.6 percent.
Mr. Logan and others also took little comfort in the fact that much of the import rise was in capital goods, items used to make other goods and that thereby expand the nation's own long-term productive capacity. Many of these capital imports, Mr. Logan said, were electronics and other goods used in the service sector of the economy. The broader question than whether the imports represent investment or consumption, he added, should be ''why doesn't the United States produce its own capital goods?''
 
Imports Soar by 6.4 Percent
Today's report showed that imports soared by 6.4 percent, to a new high of $41.18 billion, as exports edged down by two-tenths of 1 percent, to $30.41 billion.
Capital goods imports rose by $1.3 billion, vehicles and parts increased by $600 million and foods and beverages were up by $200 million. Among exports, the biggest changes were a $500 million decline in industrial supplies and materials, a $300 million drop in capital goods and $400 million increases for vehicles and parts and the category of ''other'' merchandise.
The nation's deficit with Japan was practically unchanged in August, at $3.98 billion, despite a 2.4 percent decline in imports of Japanese cars. However, the deficit widened significantly with all four of the newly industrialized areas of the Far East -Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore - with the aggregate deficit at $2.71 billion, up 23 percent from July's $2.20 billion.
The deficit with Western Europe eased by $133 million, but this included a huge, unexplained deterioration in the trade account with Britain - to a $100 million deficit from a July surplus of $579 million.
 
Deficit With Canada Jumps
The deficit with Canada, the biggest American trading partner, soared to $1.16 billion from $471 million, partly reflecting the resumption in August of automobile production in both countries, analysts suggested.
Imported oil cost the United States the same $4.3 billion that it spent in July, as a 17-million-barrel rise in consumption was offset by a 98-cent decline in the average price, the Commerce Department also reported.
Exports of manufactured goods climbed by $600 million, to $22.6 billion, in August while imports of manufactured goods rose $1.5 billion, to $32.8 billion.
On a three-month seasonally adjusted moving average, the August deficit reading was $9.01 billion, up from $8.78 billion in July and the highest level since May's $9.28 billion.

HEADLINE: Dow's Next Step? Up or Down;
Forecasts as High as 3,100

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
With a single question hanging on the lips of every investor - What now? - the inevitable parade of analysts and economists rushing forth with answers has begun.
For those with a rosier outlook, three days of hectic, up-and-down trading have not altered their basic conviction: that the market will keep climbing.
Many of their arguments are rooted in the belief that interest rates are falling in the long run. Lower rates traditionally chase some investors out of fixed-income securities and into stocks. 
Lower rates also help the stock market by making it easier for companies to borrow money. The more their ''cost of capital'' drops, the more able they are to undertake investments that raise corporate profits.
 
Short-Term Doubts
The bulls, many of whom work for Wall Street's best-known brokerage houses, acknowledge that their forecasts will probably not be borne out in the short term, and they look beyond Friday's upheaval, and even beyond the disappointing earnings that many prestigious companies like I.B.M. reported for the third quarter.
''People are borrowing less,'' said Charles I. Clough Jr. chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch. The total level of domestic debt, including households, corporations and government, he said, is running at about $9.7 trillion, 8 percent higher than last year, but a far cry from the 14 to 16 percent growth rates of the mid-1980's.
''We're sort of unwinding the great postwar credit boom,'' he said. ''The U.S. now has the lowest rates of growth of both money and credit in the last 20 years. The U.S. is moving from a borrowing and spending economy into a savings economy, and that's why interest rates are dropping.''
The flurry of disappointing profits is partly symptomatic of that shift, he said, and is one reason why Merrill is advising its customers to be half invested in long-term bonds and half in stocks. ''There are large chunks of this economy that have been built up to service this consumer spending boom, and as it unwinds many sectors will see earnings weakness,'' he said. ''But the long-term backdrop here is quite positive.''
Low interest rates also convince Elaine Garzarelli, the director of sector analysis for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., that the Dow could end up between 2,850 and 3,100 within six months to a year - 8 to 18 percent above yesterday's close. And she thinks it highly unlikely that the Dow will fall below 2,350, given the current levels of corporate dividends and earnings.
 
Seeing a Buying Opportunity
Her index of 13 key indicators, which was negative before the 1987 crash and turned positive in February 1988, now suggests that the market is flirting with historic lows, and thus presents a buying opportunity.
After the 1987 crash had shaken investor confidence, the market bottomed out on Dec. 4, 1987, at a price that implied that investors were virtually assured of getting at least 4.1 percent of their capital back in annual dividends. When the dividend yield gets that rich, investors typically scoop up stocks.
For the market to have a similarly attractive yield given current dividend levels, it would need to fall only about 10 percent, to 2,350, before investors would rush in.
''If we did go down another 10 percent, it would be so rock-bottom cheap, it'd be as cheap as the bottom after the crash,'' Mr. Garzarelli said.
 
Recession Argument Dismissed
One of the bears' best arguments, that a sweeping recession is imminent, does not concern her.
Even if there is a recession next year and it depresses earnings, she does not see the market going below 2,350.
''I'm trying to make the case you really don't have much downside from here,'' she said.
Martin T. Sosnoff, chairman of Atalanta/Sosnoff Capital, which manages about $2 billion in institutional money, does not share the bears' jitters either.
''The bears' case is that the economy picks up steam in the next three to six months, the Federal Reserve panics and interest rates go up into double digits,'' he said. ''We create a recession with huge credit losses in the banking system and stocks sell at a low valuation of earnings. Foreigners don't come into our market, and takeovers don't come back because banks are loaded up with high-risk paper.''
 
Expectation of a 3,000 Dow
Personally, he thinks the Dow could reach 3,000 by the end of 1990, so long as interest rates remain under 8 percent, and corporate earnings over all hold up at their current levels.
Robert S. Salomon Jr., director of equity research at Salomon Brothers Inc., which thinks the market will rise at least 15 percent over the next six to nine months, argued that the dip in reported profits was being misunderstood.
''Corporate profits for the things that you can buy and sell in the public marketplace are rising,'' he said. The Government's aggregate statistics, he contends, are distorted by the avalanche of insolvent savings and loans and by leveraged buyouts that convert profitable companies into unprofitable ones largely for tax purposes.
 
A Slightly Less Bullish View
Only slightly less bullish than the others, Monte Gordon, the director of research for the Dreyfus Corporation, which manages $48 billion in assets, thinks fundamentals are strong enough for the Dow to end 1989 somewhere between 2,500 and 2,900.
''The U.S. economy is resilient and the recession will be shallow and short-lived,'' he said.
He takes the flurry of bad earnings surprises as further evidence that United States companies are taking long-term steps to improve their competitiveness.
''I.B.M. is having problems, no question, but it's also looking to reduce its staff by another 1,000 people, and General Motors is looking to close plants,'' he said. ''So I think the U.S. companies are still working to make themselves more competitive and efficient.''

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Morning Line On the Next Nobel

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
TRYGVE who? It is a safe bet that most economists under age 50 barely recognized the name of the latest winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, announced last week in Sweden. Trygve Haavelmo's critical contributions to the infant discipline of econometrics in the 1940's are now ancient history.
But economists are a gossipy, competitive lot. And it is an even safer bet that this year's unanticipated trip down memory lane will not inhibit speculation on who will win next year's prize - or more interesting, who deserves to win it. Here is the morning line, unscientifically culled from a dozen phone chats with economists who, sensibly, prefer to remain nameless. 
The handful of older economists whom everyone accepts as Nobel-class - Robert Samuelson, Milton Friedman, Kenneth Arrow, James Tobin, Robert Solow - already have their prizes. But among the generation still in its productive prime, a few others are almost guaranteed a moment in the Stockholm sun.
First on most lists is Gary Becker, the great intellectual empire builder from the University of Chicago, who dared use economics to explain everything from decisions to have children, to discriminate by race and even to break the law.
Another in this category is Robert Lucas (also from Chicago), who has led the effort to rescue classical macroeconomics from the debacle of the 1930's Depression. Yet another is Joseph Stiglitz, the versatile theorist from Stanford. He has ripped gaping wounds in the soft underbelly of economics, the presumption that free markets are more efficient than the alternatives.
Since prizes may only be awarded to the living, it would be understandable if the Royal Swedish Academy gave priority to grayer eminences. Three stand out:
* Ronald Coase, an 80-year-old emeritus professor at Chicago, is remembered for one idea. But what an idea: The ''Coase Theorem'' subtly but profoundly changed the way economists view property rights, and in the process spawned a whole school of conservative jurisprudence that is rocking the foundations of the common law.
* Richard Musgrave, an 80-year-old emeritus at Harvard, is often dismissed as the man who wrote a good textbook in the 1950's covering the economics of taxation. Those with historical perspective remember that Mr. Musgrave invented much of what went into the book - and most public finance textbooks since.
* Edmond Malinvaud, the fine French theorist, is not quite old enough (67) or (in the eyes of some) sufficiently original to rate inclusion as an eminence grise. But he wrote a widely admired textbook in econometrics. And he is the most distinguished European economist who has yet to win a Nobel - a significant fact to the notoriously Eurocentric Nobel committee.
David Romer, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, has been informally polling economists for the last seven years on who is most likely to win the prize. Mr. Malinvaud, along with Mr. Becker, is consistently at the top of the list.
A third group consists of the safe choices, prolific economists at the top of their specialties. A non-exhaustive - repeat non-exhaustive - list would include Jagdish Bhagwati (Columbia), Peter Diamond (Massachusetts Institute of Technology), Martin Feldstein (Harvard), Robert Hall (Hoover Institution), Dale Jorgensen (Harvard), Edwin Phelps (Columbia).
However it is the dark horse category that is the most fun, the economists who have done something special but whose awards would be sure to arouse controversy.
A short list might include Albert Hirschman at Princeton's School of Advanced Studies, who has ventured deep into sociology, anthropology and philosophy to explain economic phenomena; Robert Fogel at the University of Chicago, who takes no prisoners in his war on the conventional wisdoms of economic history; Mancur Olson, the Maryland economist who used new ''public choice'' models of group behavior to explain why mature industrial economies lose their productive edge; Robert Mundell at Columbia, who turned traditional macroeconomic theory on its head to accommodate the realities of wide-open trade and capital movement; Martin Weitzman at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, whose brilliant blend of classical and Marxist economics offers a way to eliminate chronic unemployment in market economies without generating inflation.
Have a better idea who will win? Perhaps you could make a little money on it. David Romer's straw poll is actually a pool. If a long shot like Trygve Haavalmo were to win next year, a strategically place dollar bet might return 40 or 50.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Control Data's New Computer

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17

 BODY:
The Control Data Corporation today announced a new high-end mainframe computer, the Cyber 2000, which it said had twice the power of its current top model, the Cyber 990.
The Minneapolis-based company also introduced a new disk system for its entire Cyber mainframe line and said it had a joint development agreement with MIPS Computer Systems Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif. 
Control Data calls the Cyber 2000 a ''supermainframe'' because it has characteristics of both a supercomputer and a mainframe. The new machine is air-cooled and has the fastest processors in the mainframe class, Control said.
In the agreement with MIPS, the two companies will work together to develop a new computer based on RISC, or reduced instruction set computing, which speeds computing by limiting the tasks the processor must perform. A manufacturer of microprocessors and computers, MIPS has emerged as the leading contender to Sun Microsystems Inc. and its Sparc chip as the new standard for RISC-based computers.
Control Data's stock slipped 12.5 cents a share today, to $18, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

HEADLINE: Eastern Air Is Rebuilding At Fast Pace

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Top executives of Eastern Airlines said yesterday that because a substantial number of striking workers were returning, they expected the airline to emerge from bankruptcy by early next year at 85 to 90 percent of its former size.
Eastern had previously said it expected to become a smaller airline, perhaps 65 percent of its former size.
At a news briefing yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, Frank A. Lorenzo, chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, which owns Eastern, and Phil J. Bakes, president of Eastern, said the airline's reorganization was proceeding more quickly than they had anticipated. 
Mr. Bakes conceded that many risks were associated with the rebuilding, that Eastern was still hurt by heavy losses and that the expense of reorganizing under the bankruptcy code was offsetting some improvements in revenue in recent months.
The carrier is struggling to get its unsecured creditors to agree to support its plan for reorganization. Both executives said they planned to file a revised plan soon in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan.
Eastern needs the approval of its creditors and of the court to emerge from bankruptcy.
E. A. Orr, a spokesman for the pilots' union at Eastern, responded that much of the rebuilding had been done at low fares and that historically airlines that used low fares to rebuild had fared poorly.
''Unless the operational figures can be combined with a successful financial operation, then the reorganization is still in great jeopardy,'' he said. 2,500 Pilots Seen on Strike Mr. Orr estimated that about 2,500 of Eastern's pilots remained on strike, while about 20 percent had either crossed picket lines or shown a willingness to go back to work.
In April, a month after the airline filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, its management projected that it would emerge at about two-thirds of its former size. The airline was struck by the machinists' union on March 4, and the pilots' and flight attendants' unions have been honoring the picket lines.
Mr. Bakes said at the news briefing that the return of striking workers had ''allowed us to solidify the rebuilding plan somewhat quicker.''
 
Unsecured Creditors Meet
Members of the unsecured creditors' committee met yesterday and were poring over a report by their financial adviser, Goldman, Sachs & Company, on Eastern's attempts to rebuild.
Mr. Bakes said that although he had not seen the report, he understood that Goldman had pointed out the many risks involved in attempting to rebuild in an industry that he called ''a risky business'' to begin with.
Several analysts who attended the briefing said they were impressed with the pace and success of the rebuilding effort.
''They're reorganizing much faster than expected,'' said Kevin Murphy, airline analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company. ''The question is, are they going to make money with it?''
He said that although the carrier had been able to get its operating costs down, it was still faced with heavy interest costs on its huge debt and was vulnerable if a recession made it more difficult to charge fares high enough to make money.
 
Eastern's Cash Position
Raymond E. Neidl, analyst for Dillon, Read & Company, said that he agreed with Mr. Bakes and Mr. Lorenzo that the carrier could begin to make money by next year, but that its cash position was still thin for a carrier its size.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Executive Search Finds A New Chief for Zemex

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
The Zemex Corporation, a producer of industrial minerals, metal powders and tin, said yesterday that Gerard E. Wood had been named its new president and chief executive.
Mr. Wood, 51, succeeds Harry A. Durney, who is retiring at age 65 and will become a consultant to Zemex and remain a director. Mr. Durney has led Zemex, once known as the Pacific Tin Consolidated Company, since 1976. 
Zemex, based in New York, has its roots in the Yukon gold rush in Canada earlier in the century. The company was founded 70 years ago as the Yukon Gold Company and owned by Guggenheim family interests. The company is still connected with the Guggenheims; its chairman, Peter Lawson-Johnston, is the grandson of Solomon R. Guggenheim and head of the foundation, which operates the Guggenheim Museum in Manhattan.
But the company's majority owner today is Denison Mines Ltd., Toronto, which owns a 50.1 percent stake. Zemex produces clay, sand and feldspar for industrial uses, along with high purity silica sands used in semiconductor applications.
Mr. Wood, who was found through an executive search, had been president and chief executive of Steep Rock Resources Inc., a Canadian mining concern, since 1985. Of Zemex, he said, ''I intend to make it more profitable and expand it in the future.''
A graduate of Leeds University in England, Mr. Wood was a mining engineer for the Iron Ore Company of Canada, the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company and the Cerro Metal Products Company before becoming an investment analyst in Toronto with the firm of H.M. Chisholm. After five years there, he became senior mineral economist for the Government of Canada before joining Steep Rock.
He and his wife, Jacqueline, who have moved to New York, have three daughters.

HEADLINE: Graphs of Industrial Production from April '88-Sept. '89 (source: Federal Reserve Board) (NYT); total output as a percentage of capacity from April '88-Sept. '89 (source: Federal Reserve Board) (NYT);
Industrial Output Shows First Drop in Six Months

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Industrial production slipped by one-tenth of 1 percent in September, the first drop in six months, the Federal Reserve said today in a report that reflected continued weakness in the economy's manufacturing sector.
But Michael Evans of Evans Economics Inc., a Washington forecasting firm, said that ''while the economy is not strong, there's no sign of a downturn.''
The Fed said last month's decline in output was the first since a drop of two-tenths of 1 percent last February. It followed a revised rise of three-tenths in August and an unchanged rate in July. 83.6 Percent Operating Rate In another report, the Fed said the operating rate of the nation's factories, mines and utilities also fell in September, by two-tenths of a percentage point, to 83.6 percent. This also reflected the decline in the production rate. 
Indications of the slip in industrial production were contained in a Labor Department report earlier this month that said manufacturers reported a September loss of 103,000 jobs, including 33,000 at auto plants. It was the biggest drop since November 1982, at the end of the last recession.
''The most significant declines occurred in the output of trucks, basic metals and construction supplies,'' the Fed said today. ''The decline in truck production more than offset a sharp rise in auto assemblies.''
The manufacturing sector has been among the hardest hit by the Fed's tight-money policies as the central bank tries to contain inflation by slowing the economy without tipping it into a recession.
 
Easing of Credit Urged
William K. MacReynolds, forecasting director for the United States Chamber of Commerce, called on the Fed to ease further its grip on credit. ''Falling industrial production in September was accompanied by indications that business investment stopped growing,'' he said. ''With inflation coming down, it is incumbent on the Fed to reduce interest rates to encourage investment.''
Regarding the report on the industrial operating rate, analysts generally consider a rate of 85 percent or above an indication of inflationary pressures because the closer American industry gets to full operating capacity, the greater difficulty it has producing enough to meet demand, leading to shortages and price increases.
Industrial production at manufacturing plants making both durable and nondurable goods fell by two-tenths of 1 percent in September after a three-tenths rise the month before.
''The decrease in manufacturing output mainly reflected widespread weakness in durables,'' which fell by five-tenths of 1 percent, the Fed said. Production of nondurable goods edged up by one-tenth.
 
Oil and Mining Output Up
Output at mines and oil wells increased by nine-tenths of 1 percent, while production at utilities rose by 1.2 percent.
The Fed said its industrial production index in September stood at 142.3 percent of its 1977 base, down from 142.4 percent in August.
In its factory use report, the Fed said the operating rate at manufacturing plants fell from 84.1 percent in August to 83.7 percent in September. It peaked at 84.7 percent in January. The rate at factories producing durable goods - big-ticket items expected to last more than three years - fell by six-tenths of a percentage point, to 82.1 percent. The rate at factories producting nondurable goods fell by two-tenths, to 86 percent.

HEADLINE: South Korea Offers Plans To Ease U.S. Trade Surplus

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17

 BODY:
President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea told President Bush today that his nation would take significant steps to curb its trade surplus with the United States by the mid-1990's.
The measures would provide the United States with access to South Korean markets equivalent to that it receives from other leading industrial countries.
The pledge, which entails cutting tariffs in half and sharply reducing nontariff barriers - like the requirement that importers to South Korea have Government licenses - was made at a White House meeting of the two leaders. 
American officials, while welcoming steps South Korea has taken to increase American imports, are looking for speedier progress in the future.
 
More Study Required
The officials said the pledge -which would open markets in South Korea to a degree equivalent to that of the nations of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a Paris-based club of industrial countries - requires more study before any comment could be made. ''We just noted it,'' a State Department official said.
Differences over timing of the new access were highlighted in remarks the two leaders made as they adjourned for lunch, according to Richard Solomon, the Assistant Secretary of State for Asia and Pacific Affairs, who briefed reporters later.
''President Roh said that if an apple is picked before it is ripe, it is tough and sour. But if you wait, it is nice and sweet,'' Mr. Solomon said.
''President Bush,'' Mr. Solomon added, ''noted that you don't want the ripening to take so long that you're too old to enjoy the fruit.''
 
Many Protectionist Barriers
As a newly industrializing country, South Korea has retained a large number of trade barriers to protect its infant industries and large farm population from import competition.
President Roh, a former four-star general who came to power after elections in 1987, is under strong domestic political pressure not to yield too much too quickly to the United States.
For example, farmers have demonstrated against American efforts to sell more beef to South Korea; snakes have been freed in Seoul theaters that show American movies, and the residence in Seoul of the American Ambassador, Donald P. Gregg, was broken into last Friday by South Korean students who said they opposed American trade pressure.
Ravaged by war three decades ago, South Korea has not only prospered economically since then, but grown into the seventh-largest trading partner of the United States.
 
Substantial Results
Responses to market-opening pressures by the United States have already yielded substantial results in terms of reducing the American trade deficit with South Korea. Having topped $10 billion a year in the mid-1980's, the trade deficit with South Korea has fallen 35 percent so far this year and for the full year is projected by South Korean officials at around $5 billion.
In a report on trade results for August, the United States Commerce Department said today that the deficit with all four of the newly industrialized countries of the Far East -Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore - was $2.71 billion for the month, up 23 percent from July's $2.20 billion.

HEADLINE: MCI Profit Jumps 58.7%; GTE's Net Also Rises

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The MCI Communications Corporation and the GTE Corporation reported sharply higher third-quarter earnings yesterday. Another telephone company, the Southwestern Bell Corporation, said its profits had fallen, mainly because of one-time factors.
MCI, the second-largest provider of long-distance services, after the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said its third-quarter earnings were $165 million, up 58.7 percent from $104 million. Revenues were $1.67 billion, up 23 percent from $1.36 billion for the comparable quarter last year. Earnings per share rose to 62 cents, from 38 cents. 
The company said it was the seventh consecutive quarter in which it set records for operating revenue, earnings and earnings per share.
Despite the sharp increase in earnings, MCI stock fell $2.625 a share yesterday, to $42.375, apparently because its profits merely met analysts' expectations. In previous quarters, MCI has exceeded projections.
The company said its residential business grew faster than service to businesses during the quarter, largely because of its new Prime Time calling plan and expansion of operator and pay phone services.
MCI, based in Washington, also said it had won several large contracts in the period, including service for Congress and Montgomery Ward & Company.
''It was a good quarter,'' said Edward M. Greenberg of Morgan Stanley. ''It wasn't a blow-them-away quarter.'' MCI's stock had been trading very strongly last week, he said.
''They were at expectations, as opposed to ahead of expectations, which they have historically been,'' said Jack B. Grubman of Paine Webber Inc. He added, ''I wouldn't exactly call 60 percent earnings growth shabby, but revenue and earnings growth is slowing as they become a bigger company.''
''To some degree, we're splitting hairs,'' Mr. Grubman said. ''They had a 60 percent gain in earnings and good business momentum. They're going to have very good double-digit growth over the next several years, in terms of revenues and earnings.''
 
GTE
GTE, based in Stamford, Conn., reported third-quarter net income of $367.6 million, up 17.6 percent from $312.7 million. Sales rose to $4.35 billion, from $4 billion, an increase of 8.8 percent. Per-share earnings were $1.06, up from 91 cents.
The company attributed the increase in revenues to telephone operations, including an increase in long-distance calls, which originate and terminate in local-exchange networks that it owns. The company said the number of access lines in service was up 5 percent from a year earlier.
Analysts said a corporate revamping earlier this year had resulted in higher productivity.
Mr. Grubman of Paine Webber called GTE's quarterly results ''pretty awesome.'' He also noted that the company had nearly doubled the number of cellular phone subscribers, boding well for future revenues.
 
Southwestern Bell
Southwestern Bell said third-quarter earnings were down 8.7 percent, to $295.3 million, from $323.3 million in the third quarter of last year. Revenues also declined slightly, to $2.21 billion, from $2.23 billion.
Earnings per share were 98 cents, down 9.3 percent from $1.08 a year earlier.
The company, based in St. Louis, said the decline was expected. Southwestern Bell had received a tax refund last year, inflating its earnings then. This year, among other factors, it shifted production of several Yellow Pages directories from the third quarter to the fourth.
Income for the first nine months was $795.6 million, up 5.4 percent from the comparable period of 1988, the company said, and revenues were $6.4 billion, up 2.2 percent. ''The outlook for the rest of the year remains positive,'' Zane E. Barnes, chairman and chief executive, said in a statement.
The company said the economy in its service region - Arkansas, Kansas, Missouri, Oklahoma and Texas - was strongly improving, with 308,000 telephone lines added in the current year, compared with 22,000 in all of 1987.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mixed in U.S. After Declining in Europe

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar recovered from an early loss yesterday and finished mixed in United States trading after falling against most major currencies in trading in Europe following the news of a bigger-than-expected United States trade deficit.
Gold prices edged higher in New York after a mixed showing overseas. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold of $366.40 an ounce, up 60 cents from Monday's late bid. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery rose 10 cents an ounce, to $367.40. 
The dollar dropped early in the day on news that the United States trade deficit widened in August to $10.8 billion when many traders were expecting a deficit of about $9.5 billion.
 
Effect of Rising Deficit
A rising deficit suggests the dollar is too expensive, making American goods less competitive in foreign markets and making foreign goods cheaper in the United States.
But Graham Broyd, vice president in the foreign exchange department at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, said the dollar bounced back fairly quickly as traders focused for another day on price movements in the United States stock market.
The dollar fell as the Dow Jones industrial average dipped about 60 points early in the day, but then the currency recovered to finish above the closing levels reached earlier in Europe as the Dow retraced lost ground. The Dow finished with a loss of almost 19 points.
One reason for the interaction between the two markets is that the Federal Reserve may encourage lower interest rates if the stock market were to come anywhere near Friday's 190.58-point decline in the Dow. Falling interest rates would make the dollar less attractive to foreign investors.
 
Dollar Up in Tokyo
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 142.25 Japanese yen, from 140.75 yen at Monday's close. Later in London, it edged up further to 142.35 yen. In New York, the dollar rose to 142.70 yen, from 141.80 yen on Monday.
The dollar weakened against the British pound. In London, the British pound rose to $1.5835, from $1.5820 late Monday. Later in New York, the pound edged up to $1.57575, from $1.5750 late Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Monday, included: 1.8672 West German marks, down from 1.8680; 1.6365 Swiss francs, up from 1.6340; 6.3475 French francs, down from 6.3480; 1,400.375 Italian lire, up from 1,374.50, and 1.17555 Canadian dollars, down from 1,17675.
Silver for current delivery slipped 0.2 cent, to $5.102 a troy ounce, on New York's Comex. In London, silver rose to a late bid of $5.12, from $5.11 late Monday.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Notes and Bonds Drop

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped in moderately active trading yesterday, as dealers ignored a bigger-than-expected increase in the nation's trade deficit and focused instead on movements in stock prices and the dollar.
The dollar's resilience in the face of the $10.77 billion trade deficit for August helped to limit price declines of short-term Treasury note issues. So too did a slightly weaker stock market, which fell by 18.65 points, to 2,638.73.
At the same time, however, the offering of $4 billion worth of securities by the Tennessee Valley Authority, which included $2 billion of 30-year bonds, had an adverse effect on longer-term Treasury notes and bonds, sectors that recorded the largest price declines yesterday. 
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 101 3/32, down 17/ 32, to yield 8.02 percent.
Among secondary Treasury note issues, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 29/32 in late trading, down 1/4 of a point, to yield 8.01 percent. And the 8 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 29/32, down 1/32, to yield 7.86 percent.
 
Bill Rates Spurt
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose sharply yesterday, even though the overnight Federal funds rate, an important barometer for short-term rates, remained soft.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.50 percent, up 15 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by 11 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.51 percent. And one-year bill rates were offered late in the day at 7.35 percent, up 2 basis points.
The Fed funds rate, which analysts suspect may have been pushed lower by the Fed on Monday, traded in a narrow range of 8 11/16 percent to 8 5/8 percent yesterday. Money market economists are fairly sure that the Fed has pushed the closely watched funds rate down to a range of 8 7/8 percent to 8 5/8 percent, and perhaps as low as 8 1/2 percent.
The next resting place for the funds rate depends largely on what happens in the stock market this week, analysts said. In addition, yesterday's merchandise trade numbers, which showed little growth in exports and a big rise in imports, could also buttress arguments among Fed governors that the 8 1/2 percent rate is justified.
 
Cut in Prime Expected
''The economy is very fragile,'' said Sung Won Sohn, a senior vice president and chief economist at the Norwest Corporation in Minneapolis. ''And the bad trade number may force Mr. Greenspan to look at interest rates again.''
''I think Fed funds will settle in the 8.5 percent range in the next week or so,'' he said. ''And as soon as the banking community has confirmed that the Fed has moved the funds rate to that level, the prime lending rate will be cut by half a point, to 10 percent.''
Demand for the T.V.A. securities priced yesterday was so strong that the size of the offering was increased by $1 billion, including a $500 million rise in 30-year bonds.
Another test of the market's appetite for highly regarded long-term paper will begin today, as the Resolution Funding Corporation, the Government entity established to finance the bailout of the nation's savings and loan industry, is expected to announce details of an auction of securities.
Officials of the corporation said last week that the auction, which will take place next week, will consist of $4 billion to $6 billion of securities with maturities of more than 20 years.
 
First Sale to Public
The auction will be the first sale to the public of the corporation's securities. Last summer Congress authorized total borrowing of $50 billion to pay for the savings and loan cleanup. The first $20 billion was borrowed by the Treasury Department in the third quarter.
The corporation is expected to continue its auctions on a quarterly basis until its remaining $30 billion in authority is exhausted.
Aside from the overall size of the offering, speculation about the announcement has centered on whether a 40-year bond would be included in the auction.
Following today's announcement, the corporation's issues will trade on a when-issued basis just like Treasury issues. Dealers said the securities are likely to trade at a premium of 15 to 20 basis points over comparable Treasury coupons.
Elsewhere, continued volatility in the stock market and the market for Treasury securities caused trading in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds to slow markedly yesterday.
Dealers said that prices of most issues fell by 1/8 of a point to 1/4 of a point.
''With the markets getting whipsawed, a lot of accounts are a little nervous,'' a corporate bond trader said.
Trading was equally sluggish in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds. Market participants said prices of most issues fell by 1/4 of a point to 3/8 of a point.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
$4 Billion T.V.A. Offering Meets With Strong Demand

 BODY:
In its first public offering since 1974, the Tennessee Valley Authority priced a $4 billion offering of notes and bonds yesterday through an underwriting syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation.
Demand for the securities was so strong that the size of the offering was increased by $1 billion.
The offering is part of an overall plan to refinance $6.7 billion worth of outstanding issues borrowed at higher interest rates from the Federal Financing Bank, an arm of the Treasury Department, earlier in this decade. 
The T.V.A., which used to offer its securities to the public on a regular basis, has borrowed exclusively from the Federal Financing Bank since 1974. A refusal by the Financing Bank to refinance the high-cost debt pursuaded the T.V.A. to tap the public market.
''It's not every day you save your company $75 million a year in interest payments,'' William F. Malec, T.V.A.'s chief financial officer, said in a telephone interview from Knoxville, Tenn., where the agency is based. ''We are pleased as punch.'' The offering consisted of $1 billion worth of 5-year notes, $1 billion of 10-year notes and $2 billion of 30-year bonds that are noncallable for five years.
The 8.25 percent five-year notes were priced at $99.672, to yield 8.33 percent, which is 43 basis points, or hundredths of a point, over the prevailing yield on 8 1/4 percent 5-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The 8 3/8 percent 10-year notes were priced at $99.672, to yield 8.33 percent, or 43 basis points over the prevailing yield on the 8 percent 10-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
And the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds were priced at $96.808, to yield 9.06 percent, 1.05 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's bellwether 8 1/8 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing.
Underwriters at First Boston said that as of late yesterday the 5-year and 10-year securities were completely sold out, and that only ''tag ends'' of the 30-year bonds remained unspoken for.
The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: Study Finds High Turnover in Child Care Workers

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
People who care for children in day care centers are leaving their jobs in growing numbers and the turnover is hurting the children's development, according to a study released yesterday.
The study, by the Child Care Employee Project, found that turnover at child care centers had nearly tripled in the last decade -from 15 percent a year in 1977 to 41 percent in 1988. In the same period, the number of centers reporting no turnover fell from 40 percent to 7 percent.
''What the study says is that staff are the key to good child care, and we're having a hard time keeping good child care staff because the pay is just too low,'' said Marcy Whitebook, executive director of the Child Care Employee Project, a nonprofit group based in Oakland, Calif. The project's goal is to improve salaries and training of day care teachers and aides and to raise state and Federal child care standards. 
The study was based on classroom observation and testing at 227 child care centers in the Atlanta, Boston, Detroit, Phoenix and Seattle metropolitan areas. The centers served more than 16,000 families and had more than 3,000 employees.
 
Lag Is Linked to Turnover
The study found that the persistent turnover had measurably hurt the children at the centers.
''Children attending lower-quality centers with more teacher turnover were less competent in language and social development,'' Ms. Whitebook said. ''We always thought that high turnover would have bad effects, but this is the first time we've actually been able to show that link.''
Specifically, the study found that children at centers with a high turnover of staff members were less engaged in social activities with their peers and scored worse on vocabulary tests than children at centers with a lower turnover.
Besides Ms. Whitebook, the principal investigators in the study were Carolee Howes, associate professor of education at the University of California at Los Angeles, and Deborah Phillips, assistant professor of psychology at the University of Virginia.
 
Pay Factor in Turnover
According to the study, released at a news conference in Washington, turnover is directly related to pay and working conditions. Center teachers earning $4 an hour or less left their jobs at twice the rate of those who earned more than $6 an hour.
''There's all this talk now about how important the early years are and how important education is,'' Ms Whitebook said, ''but as a society we are going to have to put our money where our mouth is. We have to value child care teachers more, and there is some movement in that direction in a few states and in some of the child care legislation that is before Congress.''
The House approved a $22.7 billion child care package early this month, and lawmakers are working out differences between the House version and one passed earlier this year by the Senate. The legislation could give states Federal money that could be used to raise salaries of day care employees.
The pay for child care teachers in the study was highest at nonprofit centers that were not church-sponsored and had an average hourly wage of $6.40. It was lowest at profit-making day care chains, where the average hourly wage was $4.10. Annual turnover at nonprofit centers was 30 percent, as against 74 percent at the chains. #27% Drop in Earnings Despite gains in overall formal education and experience, child care teachers were paid even less last year than in 1977, the study said. The teachers' earnings, adjusted to allow for inflation, have fallen by 27 percent since 1977. Assistants' earnings have fallen by 20 percent.
The average hourly wage for child care teachers in 1988 was $5.35, providing an annual income of $9,363. The Federal poverty threshold for a family of three, the average family size in the sample, was $9,431 a year in 1988.
The study found that in 1988, 22 percent of the child care workers surveyed had at least a bachelor's degree, and 44 percent had some college education.
On average, child care workers with some college education and those with a bachelor's degree or more earned less than half as much as comparably educated women in the work force, the study said, and less than a third as much as comparably educated men.

HEADLINE: Freed Rebels Talk of Decades in Pretoria's Prisons

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SOWETO, South Africa, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Walter Sisulu and two of his freed colleagues from the outlawed African National Congress talked today about their 26 years in prison and how their captors had tried at first to break them with hard labor, midnight searches, informers and humiliation.
Mr. Sisulu, who is now 77 years old, Ahmed Kathrada, 60, and Elias Motsoaledi, 65, were among eight political prisoners released unconditionally by the Government on Sunday. They had been sentenced with their comrade, Nelson Mandela, to life imprisonment in June 1964 for conspiring to commit sabotage and overthrow the Government and sent to Robben Island, South Africa's equivalent of Alcatraz, and then to Pollsmoor Prison on the mainland in 1982.
As they related their experiences to a group of American and French reporters in a small hall of Holy Cross Anglican Church near Mr. Sisulu's home, several hundred chanting schoolchildren gathered outside in hope of glimpsing Soweto's newest heroes. 
 
Discreet Talks With Government
Mr. Sisulu disclosed that the authorities started talking discreetly to Mr. Mandela before he was transferred from Robben Island to Pollsmoor in 1982, and that discussions grew more serious after he was moved to a prison farm outside Cape Town last December after recovering from a near-fatal bout of tuberculosis. Mr. Sisulu did not give any details.
But he denied speculation that Mr. Mandela was remaining in prison as part of a deal worked out with the Government that would lead to eventual negotiations. Mr. Sisulu said Mr. Mandela ''would have gladly gotten out with us'' but had put the release of his comrades first.
Mr. Sisulu said negotiations are impossible until Mr. Mandela is freed.
Mr. Sisulu described Robben Island and Pollsmoor as providing the best kind of political education. And the men said they had learned that pressure, whether from inside prison or abroad, was the way to force an end to apartheid. As a result, they said the struggle ''in all its aspects'' - an allusion to guerrilla attacks - and economic sanctions against South Africa should be intensified.
 
Pressure Called Effective
''It really confirmed our belief that the South African authorities do not suddenly undergo a change of heart,'' Mr. Kathrada said. Every concession the Government has made ''has been under some pressure or another.''
Mr. Kathrada said his group had been prepared psychologically for prison because they expected to be arrested at some stage. But when they were deposited on Robben Island, which lies in chilly, shark-infested Atlantic waters off Cape Town, he contended that their captors wanted to break them. ''From the security police to the prison authorities, they tried to instill into our minds that we would be forgotten in a few years' time,'' Mr. Kathrada said. ''They did everything to crush our morale.''
For the first six months, he said, Mr. Mandela and the other prisoners were put to work breaking stones with hammers. Then they were sent to work in the prison's lime quarry, performing hard labor that Mr. Kathrada said lasted more than a decade.
At one point before conditions improved, Mr. Kathrada said, Mr. Mandela and Mr. Sisulu were put on a meager ration of rice gruel as punishment for allegedly not working hard enough.
Mr. Kathrada, who is of Indian descent, said that initially he and the mixed-race convicts were issued long trousers, but black convicts like Mr. Mandela and Mr. Sisulu had to wear shorts, however cold the weather, and were not given socks.
After the day's labor, Mr. Sisulu said, the convicts had to strip naked outside and wash down with cold seawater, even in winter.
Mr. Kathrada vividly recalled one night - he said the date was May 28, 1971 - when the warders, ''many of them very drunk,'' descended on their cells to rouse the convicts, stripped them and forced them against the wall for a particularly rough search in which he said Govan Mbeki, a prisoner released in 1987, nearly suffered a heart attack. But Mr. Kathrada said they were spared physical brutality that was inflicted on less prominent prisoners.
The men insisted that the intended humiliation only stiffened their defiance. ''Because we were so close to the oppressor, it helped to keep us united,'' Mr. Kathrada said. They went on hunger strikes to force concessions. The former prisoners also credited the International Red Cross and Helen Suzman, a liberal white legislator who focused attention in Parliament on the plight of political prisoners, with having improved conditions.
Such pressure, they said, gradually improved their lives in prison. In 1980, after 16 years on Robben Island, they were allowed to read newspapers. They were later permitted radios, although not short-wave receivers for foreign broadcasts, and television and videocasette recorders in 1986.
They tried to keep up with events outside by talking to new prisoners, reading smuggled letters and ''begging, stealing and bribing'' for information. ''Political prisoners give top priority to keeping themselves informed,'' Mr. Kathrada said, but they sometimes went without news for several months.
He said they did not learn about the uprising touched off by Soweto schoolchildren in June 1976 until August. Mr. Motsoaledi said he was upset to learn that two of his children's playmates died in the violence.
 
No Moments of Despair
Mr. Sisulu said he never felt despair in his prison years, ''but there were moments when I felt very much in high spirits.'' He said he was ''inspired'' by events like the 1976 Soweto rebellion and the formation of the Congress of South African Trade Unions and the United Democratic Front, which form the core of the anti-apartheid movement and have links to the African National Congress in exile.
''It was not easy, but we did communicate with the A.N.C.,'' Mr. Sisulu said. His group briefed prisoners who were being freed, to pass along messages to the movement's leadership in exile in Lusaka, Zambia. He said they used a second channel that he could not divulge. And he said they conducted extensive political indoctrination of other prisoners on behalf of the Congress.
The released prisoners sounded occasionally nostalgic for the old camaraderie that bound them together for the last quarter century. ''In prison, the best comes out and the worst comes out as well, because of the deprivation and suffering,'' Mr. Kathrada said. He joked about having to live with Mr. Sisulu's taste for pop music in their last three and a half years as cellmates.
Mr. Sisulu said the ''enriching experience'' of confinement had matured them all. ''There has been never a greater university for political education than there was in prison.''

GRAPHIC: Photo of Walter Sisulu, right, one of eight political prisoners released on Sunday, greeting supporters yesterday in Soweto, South Africa. (AP)

HEADLINE: Salvador's Armed Forces Accused By a Medical Team From the U.S.

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 18

 BODY:
The Salvadoran military has conducted a nationwide campaign of killings, harassment and torture against doctors and health-care workers and attacked guerrilla field hospitals in violation of the Geneva convention, a team of American medical specialists says.
''The arbitrary refusal to allow the delivery of medical services, medicines and other essential goods imperils the health of many Salvadorans,'' wrote the team of seven investigators, whose report was published this week in The New England Journal of Medicine. The team visited El Salvador for a week in June. 
The team concluded that the persecution of medical personnel was part of a campaign to obstruct religious and relief workers in order to undermine support for the guerrillas, whose nine-year-old war against the Government is sustained by a well-organized network of sympathizers.
 
Many Without Health Care
Although the report includes several outdated statistics, it amounts to an indictment of the Government's human rights record and its health-care system. It notes that the Ministry of Health provides little or no health care to the vast majority of people in El Salvador, which has one of the highest infant mortality rates in the hemisphere.
The report found that the Government has actively obstructed medical education and that health care in El Salvador is likely to continue to ''deteriorate disastrously.''
Army commanders could not be reached for comment on the report. In the past, army officials have often accused medical personnel and relief agencies of being little more than rebel fronts but have always denied harassing or obstructing them.
The investigators said they had not found ''any instance of systematic or intentional disruption of health care'' by the rebels despite what they said was a determined effort to document such abuses. But the team noted other types of insurgent human-rights violations and said the rebels' campaign of economic sabotage had frequently prevented Salvadorans from receiving necessary medical care.
 
Hospitals Reported Attacked
The team, consisting of five doctors, a lawyer and a Congressional staff aide, said the Salvadoran Army had attacked several rebel field hospitals and routinely denied doctors and health workers access to battle areas, in violation of the 1949 Geneva convention. The convention calls for the protection of medical personnel and gives the wounded and the sick the right to medical care.
The team found that health-care workers faced long delays in obtaining passes required to visit rural areas. The workers are also routinely turned back at army roadblocks and are rarely allowed to take more than a few doses of medicine into those areas, the report says. In addition, the investigators reported military interference with public health campaigns.
In one case, army troops confiscated vaccines, detained medical personnel and canceled a Government-approved, Roman Catholic Church-sponsored campaign to inoculate 1,000 children in the northern province of Chalatenango, a rebel stronghold, the investigators said.

HEADLINE: Salvador Peace Talks End Without an Accord

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Oct. 18

 BODY:
The Salvadoran Government and guerrilla commanders ended three days of talks in a convent here today without signing any major agreement.
After extending the meeting for a day, the two sides did little more than agree to meet again next month in Venezuela. That is a small but clear step in building confidence between the two sides after nearly a decade of war that has spared few families and created much bitterness.
''It's no great achievement, but it strengthens the peace process,'' Oscar Santamaria, the Justice Minister and spokesman for the Government delegation, said in summing up the agreement. 
Shafik Handal, one of the most senior guerrilla commanders, said, ''It's not something spectacular, but it's a step on the path to a political solution.''
The two sides essentially agreed to disagree. They used about a third of the two-page final communique to list their differences on such fundamental issues as how to define the end of the war, which has claimed 70,000 lives, many of them civilians killed by death squads linked to the Government and the armed forces. The movement at the session was barely the minimum necessary to keep the peace process from falling apart. It was an obvious disappointment to several members of the rebel delegation, who until this afternoon had hoped the communique would include an agreement to prevent human rights abuses and lessen the war's effects on civilians.
''It might appear unspectacular,'' said Gregorio Rosa Chavez, the senior mediator and the auxiliary bishop of San Salvador, ''but we consider it very important for the process of peace.''
The discussion, the first substantive talks in the war, started as tactical maneuvering for political advantage in an election year, then gathered momentum, forcing the two sides to compete for the mantle of peacemaker.
Peace is the only issue that commands a political majority in El Salvador. Despite more than $4 billion in United States aid, the standard of living has plunged dramatically for the vast majority of Salvadorans. Their income has dropped by a third during the decade of war.
The society, which was once terrorized by death squads, has for the first time in this century transferred power from one elected civilian to another. But it remains sharply polarized and repression, although less violent, remains pervasive.
In the first two days of talks, both sides offered proposals that appeared to be more attempts to score propaganda points than serious efforts to find peace.
The Government proposed that all fighting stop today and that the guerrilla army be demobilized in January. But it offered almost no concessions to the rebels and did not address the social and economic issues that led the guerrillas to take up arms.
 
Rebels Offer Plan
The rebels countered with a plan for ''the self-purification and professionalization of the armed forces.''
It was a thinly veiled effort to divide the army and provoke an intemperate response from extremists within the armed forces, which have long ruled the country in a coalition with the oligarchy.
Rebel leaders, in a well-organized press blitz, accused the Government of ''inflexibility'' and threatened to break off negotiations. The Government accused the guerrillas of blocking progress by introducing dozens of obviously unacceptable proposals.
The rebels said the impasse was broken by the approaching end of the discussions and a talk from President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica. He said he called the Salvadoran President, Alfredo Cristiani, and asked him to instruct his delegation to continue the negotiations for a third day. Mr. Cristiani agreed.
''They have to continue to talk,'' President Arias said Tuesday night before meeting with both delegations. ''I know that after 10 years of war it's very difficult to reach peace in a few hours. It's a slow, difficult, complex process.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Drug Strategy Is Attacked at House Hearing

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Administration officials defended their anti-drug strategy for Latin America today before Congressional critics who complained that it was ill conceived and too heavily weighted toward military over economic aid for cocaine-producing countries.
Representative John Conyers Jr., the Michigan Democrat who headed a House Government Operations Committee hearing on the strategy, asserted that a ''phony economic plan'' would not encourage Latin American farmers to substitute other crops for the coca leaf.
Another committee member, Representative Al McCandless, Republican of California, accused the Administration of deceiving the public by using American military advisers in field operations in Latin America, but denying it. ''I would suggest that this thing is going to blow up in your face, in our face,'' Mr. McCandless warned the Administration officials, ''when one of these days one of our military people may be killed in a laboratory raid or something.'' 
He said, for example, that the Border Patrol had helped the military in Peru set up roadblocks, an action that he said was ''certainly a field operation.''
But Richard Brown, a deputy assistant secretary for inter-American security at the Pentagon, replied that the Border Patrol was ''not a part of the active military.''
''It is not our intention to deceive the American public,'' Mr. Brown said.
 
Program Is Defended
He and other officials defended President Bush's drug program as this country's most ambitious effort to combat cocaine in the Andean nations of Peru, Bolivia and Colombia. But they conceded that the effort was complicated by diplomatic, economic and military considerations.
''This is a difficult area,'' said John P. Walters, chief of staff in the Office of National Drug Control Policy. ''There are going to be missteps. There are going to be problems.''
Alixe Glen, a Presidential spokeswoman, said today that representatives from the White House and the three Andean nations would meet on Nov. 20 to work out details of a meeting on drugs that President Bush has agreed to attend.
Mr. Bush last week accepted an invitation from the leaders of the three countries to meet with them, probably within 90 days. No site has been decided upon for the meeting, Ms. Glen said, although some White House aides earlier suggested Jamaica, Barbados or Venezuela.
The drug package announced by Mr. Bush last month calls for $261 million in aid in fiscal 1990 for the Andean countries, which produce virtually all of the cocaine sold in the United States, and a total of more than $2 billion through fiscal 1994. In the first year, the money would go to military aid, but beginning in fiscal 1991 funds would also go for economic assistance.
 
Noncombat Roles
The plan calls for the American military to serve in noncombat roles, with responsibilities like training law enforcement officials on how to go about apprehending drug traffickers and destroying drug-producing laboratories. But lawmakers derided the program today, saying increased military aid must be accompanied immediately by greater economic aid.
Even with a stepped-up military presence in the region, Mr. Conyers said, coca growers will not turn to other crops unless the United States can help ''match them at the market'' with alternatives.
''We cannot give them a couple of boxes of Cracker Jacks and then say we're going to blow your brains out if you don't do better,'' he asserted. ''They're not going to buy into a phony economic plan.''
Administration officials did suggest that they were frustrated at times and were still trying to figure out exact amounts of economic aid to funnel to the three countries and how best to go about it.
''The economics of dope defy logic,'' said Terrence M. Burke, acting deputy administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration. ''And that's why it's hard to grapple with.''

HEADLINE: President Soft-Pedals Flag Measure

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
After advancing a constitutional amendment as the only certain way to protect the American flag from desecration, President Bush has held back from an all-out effort to save the proposal in the Senate, Congressional and Administration officials said today.
As the Senate moves toward a vote on the amendment Thursday amid signs of eroding support, the proposal seems to have fallen victim to changing political tides, White House priorities and the California earthquake.
Mr. Bush has made a point of continuing his own public support for the amendment, making it the initial focus of a White House news conference Friday and repeating his backing in an Oval Office meeting today with Congressional Republican leaders. Further, his Congressional liaison staff has continued to lobby on the issue. 
 
No Personal Calls
But Mr. Bush has not made personal calls to Congress on the issue since his news conference, and John H. Sununu, the chief of staff, has focused on other issues, Administration officials said.
When two conservative Republican Senators, Warren B. Rudman of New Hampshire and John C. Danforth of Missouri, decided to drop their sponsorship of the amendment, they did so without consultation with the White House or any telephone calls afterward, officials said.
''Nobody seems to be muscling people very much,'' said Senator Alan K. Simpson, the Republican whip. ''It's being done,'' he said with a wry smile, ''but in a kind of undefinable way, kind of calmly persistent.''
 
In a Difficult Position
The fight over the flag amendment puts Mr. Bush in a difficult position, putting the President between his ideological side and his political side, as a Republican strategist described it. Having said he thought that the issue was important enough to amend the Bill of Rights, Mr. Bush cannot appear to be dropping it in the face of other political pressures.
''Some things are just not politically expedient,'' the strategist said. ''Bush really holds these beliefs in his heart and expresses them in public, but this guy is picking and choosing his fights carefully, and this just doesn't really seem like one to go to the mat on.''
The fight over the flag amendment has reached a turning point at a bad time for the White House, pitting what Democrats have called an exercise in symbolic politics against pressing legislative issues like the budget deficit and Medicaid financing of abortion. The California earthquake further strained the White House.
 
Bush Cares Very Much
''It's a zero-sum game,'' one Administration official said. ''Bush still cares very much about the flag, but the more time we spend on it, the less time there is for these other things.''
Charles Black, a Republican consultant who works closely with the White House, said, ''The flag is still a critical issue as our national symbol, but with the economic train wreck that is in progress, I'm sure the White House hasn't been able to put it at the top of the list.''
Critics of the proposed amendment say it would curb freedom of speech as guaranteed in the Bill of Rights. The White House says a constitutional amendment is the only sure way to ban desecration of the flag. Administration officials contend that new Federal legislation banning flag desecration that was passed by Congress has the same weaknesses as a Texas statute ruled unconstitutional by the Supreme Court earlier this year.
But some Republicans said today that passage of the anti-desecration statute had taken some of the pressure off Mr. Bush, who took a middle ground by saying he did not like the measure but would allow it to become law without his signature.
 
Wise Not to Press Issue
''The President took the initial correct position and the White House is wise in seeing their issue through,'' said Roger Stone, a Republican consultant. ''But they are also wise in not pressing it, because if you look at the top two or three issues that help form the Bush governing coalition, the flag amendment is just not one of them.''
Another leading Republican strategist, Eddie Mahe, said, ''While the flag may be a gut cultural issue, nobody, including the White House, could suggest that it is of the same level of importance as the budget, or dealing with the earthquake, or even probably the Clean Air Act.''
The new law makes the issue worthless as a campaign brickbat unless the new law is overturned, Mr. Mahe argued.
''At this point, debating the value of a constitutional amendment over a law is kind of like debating the difference between 12 inches and a foot,'' he said.
On Tuesday, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, told reporters he thought that he and other opponents would have far more than the 34 votes needed to kill the amendment in the Senate. It needs the approval of two-thirds of the Senate, two-thirds of the House and 38 state legislatures.
Senator George S. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said today that support for the amendment was ebbing. ''It seeks to force Americans to choose between the flag and the Constitution, when no such choice is necessary,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Number of Nation's Poor Remains at 32 Million for a Second Year

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
The number of Americans living below the official poverty level remained at nearly 32 million people for a second straight year in 1988 even though average individual income reached an all-time high of $13,120, figures released today by the Federal Census Bureau showed.
The number of poor people and the poverty rate last year of 13.1 percent remain well above the levels of a decade ago, when the poverty rate was 11.4 percent and 24.5 million people fell below the Federal poverty guidelines, the figures also showed.
The increasing prosperity of high wage earners and the statistically insignificant gains made by middle- and lower-income Americans widened the gap between the nation's richest and poorest Americans to an all-time level, according to an analysis by Robert Greenstein of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a private research organization.
''There is economic research that pretty conclusively shows that the trend toward growing inequality of household income is paralleled by a growing inequality in the distribution of wages,'' Mr. Greenstein said. He added that the trend began in the late 1960's and accelerated in the late 1970's and early 1980's. 
 
Demographic Changes Reflected
Other economists said the growing gap in income also reflected demographic changes, in particular the influx of women into the work force over the past 15 years and the resulting number of two-income families and the decline in family size with the related increase in unmarried wage earners.
Census data showed, for instance, that the number of family households, usually composed of parents and children, represented 80 percent of all American households in 1970, but declined to 71 percent of all households last year. The figures also showed a sharp increase in the number of nonfamily households, in which unrelated individuals live together or people live alone. The data showed that the incomes of these nontraditional households have been rising at a much faster rate than the incomes of family households.
Family households had a median income of $32,491 in 1988, an increase of 6.9 percent from the $30,382 in 1980. The income of nonfamily households increased by nearly 18.9 percent in that period, from $13,576 to $16,148.
 
Figures on Poverty Rates
The census figures also showed the poverty rate decreasing slightly for whites, blacks and people of Hispanic background. The rate fell from 10.4 percent in 1987 to 10.1 percent in 1988 for whites; from 32.6 percent in 1987 to 31.6 percent last year for blacks, and from 28.1 percent to 26.8 percent for people of Hispanic background. But Census officials cautioned that none of these decreases could be considered a real decline, since the changes were not great enough to compensate for possible statistical errors in data from the survey of 58,000 households nationwide.
The average poverty level for a family of four in 1988, the Census report found, was $12,091, up from $11,611 in 1987.
 
Women at Head of Poor Families
Among the other conclusions in the Census Bureau report were these:
* About 53 percent of all poor families, or 3.6 million of the nearly 6.9 million poor families, are headed by women.
* More than half of the nation's poor were either children under 18 (39.5 percent) or people over 65 (10.9 percent.)
* For the first time since 1982, the average income of American men declined, down 1.3 percent to $26,660.
* The median earnings of women remained constant at $17,610, and over all, women's earnings remained two-thirds that of men, unchanged since 1987 but up from 62 percent in 1982. In addition to presenting the current figures on poverty and income nationwide, the Census Bureau included alternative calculations that would effectively lower the poverty threshold and reduce by about 3.5 million the number of people officially considered poor.
The published calculations immediately provoked criticism from Capitol Hill because such a recalculation could mean that millions of the poor and near-poor would be ineligible for programs like food stamps, free or reduced-price school lunches and Medicaid.
In a letter sent on Tuesday to the White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, by the chairmen of the Congressional budget committees, Senator Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee, and Representative Leon E. Panetta, Democrat of California, said, ''Before any decision to change current eligibility cutoffs, we believe you should undertake a much more comprehensive evaluation of the adequacy of currently defined povery levels.''

HEADLINE: East Germany: What Hasn't Changed

 BODY:
Erich Honecker, the builder of the Berlin Wall, was ousted as East Germany's boss after it became obvious he symbolized an intolerable status quo in a country clamoring for change. But the wall still stands; so does the suffocating political and economic system it is meant to protect.
There are a few rays of hope - very few. The regime no longer reflexively brands those who demonstrate for basic freedoms as ''hooligans.'' And there are peeps of dissent to be heard in the party press and in the appearance of fledgling political parties. But the fall of Mr. Honecker does not mean that East Germany will proceed along the path of reform charted by the Soviet Union, Poland and Hungary. 
For the moment, all it signifies is that an ailing, 77-year-old hard-liner tainted with failure is to be replaced by his 52-year-old protege, Egon Krenz. Unpromisingly, Mr. Krenz has been chiefly concerned with internal security. During a trip to Beijing, he expressed approval for the massacre of students in Tiananmen Square.
Washington and Bonn are thus wise to mute their response until it's clearer which way Mr. Krenz proposes to move. the East German regime has shown no sign of abandoning its fundamentalist Marxism. The regime insists its rusty ideology has given East Germany the highest living standards in the Soviet bloc and an education system that has yielded a sizable elite of engineers, doctors and scientists.
But these successes owe less to Lenin than to the work ethic. Self-destructively, the system that trains engineers won't let them think for themselves about politics. That, as much as economics, explains the embarrassing exodus of nearly 50,000 young East Germans - who have been able to observe on West German television that workers work less under capitalism, and earn more.
Nor is there any sign that East Germany's new leaders are yet willing to tolerate serious scrutiny and dissent. Unlike Hungary, no reform faction has been permitted within the German party, and unlike Poland, no independent political or trade union challenge has been allowed to evolve outside it. Autocracy untempered by dissent has been East Germany's lot since the Nazi takeover in 1933.
Curiously, even sadly, Mr. Honecker liked to think of himself as something of a liberal Communist. He was - but only by comparison with the troglodytes he replaced. He did relax travel restrictions, so that more than a million East Germans were able to visit the West in 1988; nearly all returned. He stopped jamming West German television, and tried in other ways to relax totalitarian controls.
But he could go no further, and ignored the admonition of a visitor named Gorbachev, who remarked on Oct. 7 that ''We have to see and react to the times; otherwise life will punish us.'' Erich Honecker has paid the price, and the message for his successor is written on his wall.
