HEADLINE: When Businesses and Schools Join Hands, Everybody Benefits

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Companies Step In Where the Schools Fail'' (news story, Sept. 26) says that ''perhaps the most far-reaching effort to create a partnership between business and schools is Boston's.''
Although it has attracted less attention than the Boston Compact, New York State has also made major strides in the area of establishing partnerships between the schools and the business community. The Governor's School and Business Alliance (SABA), organized by Mario M. Cuomo in 1986, has as its fundamental goal the improvement of high school graduation rates and the employability skills of our young people.
SABA focuses on communities with high ''at risk'' student populations and forms alliances of businesses, labor unions, community groups and schools to help students develop the skills needed to pursue post-secondary education and careers. Business and labor assist in curriculum development to meet local industry needs. They offer internships, mentors, part-time or full-time work, exposure to career choices in special industry-related institutes and management assistance to school systems.
There are currently 17 local school and business alliances involving more than 25 cities across New York State. SABA's programs have benefited more than 27,000 students; more than 14,000 businesses, 250 community organizations and 130 schools and school districts participate.
 
KRISTEN O. MURTAUGH
Exec. Dir., Governor's School and
Business Alliance Task Force
New York, Sept. 28, 1989

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Goodbye to Glasnost

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
On the night of Oct. 1, in the kitchen of the Hotel Leningrad, cooks and waiters and other workers assembled around a television set and watched, transfixed, as the American Jim Lehrer interviewed Boris Yeltsin for 23 minutes in English, with Russian dubbed in.
What a moment: there was the leading Russian gadfly being questioned on PBS in the U.S. by a skilled and bold interviewer, with the tape rebroadcast in full before tens of millions in the Soviet Union.
Soviet citizens, unaccustomed to the sight of fearless questioning and fairly frank answering, nodded enthusiastically as Yeltsin directly criticized Mikhail Gorbachev, who is not nearly as popular at home as abroad. Yeltsin warned that the Soviet President, by temporizing, was running out of time, and could not long put off a ''revolution from below.'' 
Criticism was being directed - in the most dramatic and forceful public way - not solely at dead or discredited leaders or the ''old thinking,'' but at the man presently at the top.
I was stunned; this appeared to be a whole new stage of glasnost. A Leningrad University student was less impressed: ''You can criticize everything now,'' she said, ''but you can't change anything.''
Still, the use of the Yeltsin PBS tape on television in the Soviet Union seemed a breakthrough. It refuted the contention, so often put forward in this space, that the vaunted glasnost permitted only criticism that served the Gorbachev interest - and that he would crack down on speech that opposed his interest.
Not so fast; the test was soon flunked. Gorbachev henchmen in the Supreme Soviet and in the lapdog press orchestrated a campaign to destroy Yeltsin's reputation, rehashing the charges of drunkenness while in the U.S. and publicizing a midnight spree after his return.
Too many of Yeltsin's supporters like their vodka for this smearing to destroy their hero. Although his political base is Moscow, the reach of television has extended the Yeltsin popularity to other cities; with the rumpled charm of Arik Sharon and the thematic savvy of Jesse Jackson, he appeals to populist resentment.
If the Soviet Union were a democracy, Yeltsin would probably beat Gorbachev in a free election. When a Moscow editor published a poll last week that made this plain, Gorbachev railed at the press generally and told the editor to quit. Farewell, free speech.
According to an elected official who has seen him recently, ''Gorbachev is upset, unstable, unlike himself of a year ago.'' How does this manifest itself? ''He shouts at his friends as well as his enemies, openly, in meetings.''
Is he cracking up or will he crack down? If his past is prelude, the man who replaced the collective leadership with his own cult of personality will harden and darken his persona, clinging to his position as the Soviet Union's first un-Communist President.
The man likeliest to come after the Good Gorbachev will neither be the flaky Yeltsin nor the grim Ligachev, but the Bad Gorbachev: out of patience, out of sorts, but not out of power. Then we would see what Andrei Sakharov feared: a leader with too much authority abandoning the promises that put him in place.
Consider the great mistake that is at the root of his testiness today:
To reorganize the decaying system, Gorbachev had to destroy the Communist Party and replace it with a government hierarchy under his personal control.
To retain power during this transition, Gorbachev had to rely on the Red Army; accordingly, while promising the West arms reduction, he has increased the Soviet military budget in each of his five years.
But that was a Faustian bargain; the immediate cause of the decay of the system was the huge chunk of the gross national product devoted to arms; because Soviet production continues to decline, the percentage spent on arms is getting higher.
Because this price of retaining power through Red Army backing is so crushing, the economy decays faster and class differentiation becomes more vivid. Soon the threatened party apparat will appeal to the underfed and over-50 to topple the new hierarchy.
My guess is that Gorbachev and the K.G.B. will make a deal with the younger Communists, squelch the radicals and dissidents and separatists, and betray the Red Army leaders - forming a new power coalition to muster out millions, put bread on the table and reassert social control.
The high-water mark of freedom of speech in the Soviet Union may turn out to be the night they let the tape be shown of Yeltsin challenging the benevolent dictator.

HEADLINE: Campaign Matters;
For Messinger, Making Friends With Old Foes

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
Ruth W. Messinger was running for higher office well before she decided on the particular office - the Manhattan borough presidency, as it turned out - but she does not seem to be waiting for the election to begin her new line of work.
She has, after all, raised nearly all the money she is allowed under the city's public campaign finance law, far more than a candidate who is virtually assured of election would seem to need. So Ms. Messinger has begun a series of mostly breakfast meetings that, while they may not take place at the Regency, are evidence of some of the major shifts in power that are occurring with this election. They also reveal how some of the newly empowered and some of the entrenched are adjusting. 
As a member of the City Council for almost 12 years, Ms. Messinger has represented Manhattan's West Side, where the political ideology is liberal and small is usually beautiful. But she is meeting these days not only with the community groups that have been in her core constituency but also with real-estate developers and business executives, among others. ''The more institutional players,'' she says, ''in economic sectors that I haven't particularly dealt with.''
The purpose is to give them ''the sense that I'm really open to this kind of dialogue,'' she added the other day, after a breakfast with members of the 14th Street-Union Square Local Development Corporation.
The breakfasts are an outgrowth of more than 350 ''house parties'' Ms. Messinger has been holding in living rooms since July 1987. They helped her learn to hone her answers, broaden her political base and raise lots of money a little at a time. She does no fund raising in her morning meetings -though those who attend may end up on her mailing list - but she does ask people to help her set up other meetings, so that one breakfast begets another.
At the 14th Street association, she spoke of how the borough president's job would change under the new charter plan, with powers to propose budget items replacing the powers to dispose of the budget that the borough presidents now have on the constitutionally defective Board of Estimate. But her message was also laced with concern about the local economy. The people who do business here, she said, deserve ''a better partnership with the city.''
And she told a recent gathering of real-estate appraisers - over lunch, not breakfast -that ''we need to think about the needs of businesses and what government can do.''
Yes, she said, she knew she had a reputation for questioning the tax abatements and incentives offered to businesses by the Koch administration, but she also told the appraisers that ''businesses have to know that the government of this city is not going to tax them out of profitability.''
''I'm learning a huge amount,'' Ms. Messinger said of the meetings, though she also said they have not changed her politics. Or, for that matter, her proposal, which usually comes up, to arbitrate large rent increases faced by small businesses, a form of commercial rent control that some say would discourage investment in the city.
Still, those who have followed her on the Council know her to be a shrewd budget watcher. And if she has not been considered a friend of developers, she maintains that she was never really their foe.
''My role on the West Side, I think necessarily and appropriately, was to talk about a better fit between the resources the city was investing and what developers wanted to do, because there are serious negative economic consequences for developers and for communities to overdevelopment that has no connection to the physical or social infrastructure,'' she said. ''That then got characterized as being opposed to the projects. I wasn't opposed to the projects. I was opposed to the project as presented and mostly as responded to by the city.''
In any event, a few weeks ago, when Mayor Edward I. Koch and several ranking members of his administration met with officials linked to a lawsuit challenging the Columbus Center project and threatening to make the city's already considerable budget problems worse by $250 million, Ms. Messinger was not only in the Mayor's office but on his side, trying to insure that a project she had opposed in its original and much larger form would finally be built.
Robert Esnard, the Deputy Mayor for Policy and Physical Development, who has found himself pitted against Ms. Messinger in the past, says she now has ''a boroughwide perspective.''
''She's looking at a bigger picture, as she will have to as a borough president,'' he added.
Ms. Messinger offers another explanation. ''People are getting a broader impression of me,'' she says.

HEADLINE: HEALTH;
New Measure Finds Growing Hardship for Youth

BYLINE: By DANIEL GOLEMAN

 BODY:
The well-being of children in America has declined dramatically since 1970, according to an index that measures aspects of ''social health'' like infant mortality and drug abuse.
Particularly devastating to the nation's youth have been sharp increases in the numbers of children and teen-agers who are abused, who live in poverty and who commit suicide, the index found.
A separate index measured the social health of the nation as a whole and also showed a sharp decline since 1970.
The latest year for which full figures are available, 1987, ''was the worst year for children in two decades,'' said Marc Miringoff, director of the Fordham Institute for Innovaion in Social Policy and author of the study. The institute, in Tarrytown, is a social policy research center that is part of Fordham University. 
 
Six Critical Problem Areas
The Index of Social Health of Children and Youth, which Dr. Miringoff prepared for the first time this year, compares data for the years back to 1970. It is a composite measure based on figures from what he described as six critical problem areas: infant mortality, child abuse, children living in poverty, teen-age suicide, teen-age drug abuse and high school dropouts.
''The results are particularly discouraging because of the long-term impact on children's lives,'' Dr. Miringoff added. ''These problems are likely to plague society for many years to come.''
The index combines national statistics, most gathered by the Federal Government, for each of the six problems into a single number on a scale from zero to 100. In 1970 the index for children's social health stood at 68; by 1987 it had plummeted to 37. The highest point was reached in 1973, when the index was at 72.
Experts on social policy say the Fordham index is unusual in combining major indicators of children's well-being into a single summary figure, which can be tracked from year to year.
 
Child Abuse Has Soared
As the index declined, the biggest factor was child abuse. By 1987 the reported incidence of abuse was three times that of 1970. Rates of child abuse have worsened steadily each year.
In part, the increase in child abuse rates can be attributed to improvements in reporting, Dr. Miringoff said. But most of those improvements occurred by the early 1980's. ''Child abuse has continually worsened since that time as well, at a troubling pace,'' he said.
Teen-age suicides are another major source of the downturn in the social health index, with the rate of suicide among teen-agers doubling since 1970. ''In 1987, more teen-agers committed suicide than in any other year,'' Dr. Miringoff said.
A key measure, in Dr. Miringoff's view, is the number of children who live below the Federal poverty line, since poverty underlies other problems in health, education and housing. Since 1970, the number of such children has risen by 25 percent.
''One in five of our children now live in poverty,'' said Dr. Miringoff. ''The latest year for which we have data, 1987, was a particularly discouraging one for poverty among children. Since 1970 the only other time the rates were so high was in the recession of 1982-83. But the recent rise in employment rates and prosperity among upper-income families has not helped the lot of the nation's poorest children.''
 
Improvements Cut Off
Two measures that had been improving in recent years, infant mortality and high school dropouts, both took turns for the worse in 1987. While the rate of high school dropouts had been improving for the previous 10 years, in 1987 it worsened slightly.
Despite the publicity that drug abuse has received in recent years, the rate for drug abuse among teen-agers is one of the few bright spots in the data. ''Drug abuse leveled off in the late 1970's, after a sharp increase,'' Dr. Miringoff said. ''While the figures had been dropping during the early 1980's, they leveled off from '85 to '87.''
While this is the first year the Fordham Institute has published an index on children's social health, for the last several years it has published similar figures for the nation as a whole. For the second year in a row, the figures for the social health of the nation were at the lowest level since 1970, according to Dr. Miringoff's report. The index was at 35 in 1987, down from a high of 72 in 1976. It reached 35 once before, in 1982, in an economic recession.

HEADLINE: Tapestries Depict Life In Chile

BYLINE: By RUTH ROBINSON

 BODY:
ISLA NEGRA, a village on the central Chilean coast, is known on two counts: as the home of the poet and Nobel laureate Pablo Neruda and for the striking tapestries made by its women. The work of the Bordadoras de Isla Negra (Embroiderers of Isla Negra), executed in brilliantly colored wool yarns on sackcloth, has achieved international recognition.
Like the poet, the embroiderers, who are wives of fishermen and farmers, take their inspiration from the thundering waters of the Pacific Ocean and the peaceful countryside. 
In the 1960's a group of women, under the guidance of Leonor Sobrino, a longtime resident, started to embroider as a way of augmenting their income during the winter, when there is little economic activity. Their scenes of rural life by the sea are skillfully stitched in rows of chain stitch that completely cover the cloth, resulting in a painterly effect. There is no clear antecedent in Chilean crafts for their work.
''Aside from the income, it has given them a sense of identity,'' said Eduardo S. Vera, a physicist in New York and a son of Leonor Sobrino.
Some 50 embroiderers each produce an average of one tapestry a year. It takes at least four months to complete a work, and often family duties intrude.
Since the first exhibition 20 years ago at the Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes in Santiago, Chile, the embroiderers have been moving in elevated circles. Mar'ia Luisa Alvarez, for example, was included in a show of contemporary still life in 1974 at the Renaissance Society of the University of Chicago, along with artists like Claes Oldenburg, Jasper Johns, Roy Lichtenstein and Andy Warhol. Her tapestry of a rabbit shot by her husband amid fruits is typical of the genre, which depicts something from the everyday life of the artist.
Isla Negra tapestries have been presented to heads of state as gifts, and there have been commissions from organizations like the Ford Foundation. Mr. Neruda, an enthusiastic supporter, organized exhibitions in Paris when he was Chile's Ambassador to France.
Mr. Vera's collection includes typical subjects: a fruit stand by Antonieta Munoz, a wheat-threshing celebration by Elena Perez Catalan and a fanciful portrayal of Christopher Columbus crabbing by Francisca Llanca. Atypical is a ski scene by Elsa Araya Castilla. The naive work shows a disregard for the rules of perspective and proportion. A butterfly is larger than the villagers nearby; a threshing scene is depicted within a circle as though seen from above.
The embroiderers have formed a cooperative that supplies the yarn, available upon occasion in as many as 900 different tones, and controls the quality. An authentic Isla Negra embroidery can be identified by the trademark I.N., the initials of the embroiderer and the stamp ''Bordadoras de Isla Negra.''
At the cooperative in Isla Negra, the tapestries sell for around $150; $100 a month is an average worker's salary in Chile. Ninety per cent of the price goes to the artist, the remainder to the cooperative for the purchase of supplies.
The Isla Negra Foundation, established in 1981 to support the group, and to document and preserve the work, is collaborating with the American University in Washington and the University of Chile in Santiago on a half-hour documentary of the women's work. The long-term goal is for a small museum to house the foundation's collection. Further information on the foundation may be obtained from Mr. Vera at 329 West 88th Street, New York, N.Y. 10024.

HEADLINE: Cabaret Convention Ponders a Disturbing Future

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
Is there a place for cabaret in today's age of mass entertainment? That is the question being pondered this week on the stage of Town Hall, where a Cabaret Convention is holding a series of discussions and gala concerts that will continue through Sunday.
The convention, which brings together performers and nightclub owners from New York along with representatives from the San Francisco Bay area and from London, was organized with $50,000 from the Mabel Mercer Foundation. Established in 1985, a year after the death of Miss Mercer, the legendary chanteuse whose music epitomized the cabaret spirit, the foundation was created specifically to promote the field of cabaret and to keep alive the memory of the singer, who was a close friend of its founder and executive director, Donald Smith.
The events began on Tuesday with the first of three afternoon panel discussions on the Town Hall stage. Flanked by banners portraying the convention logo - a G clef in a martini glass - a group of performers, club owners and journalists addressed everything from the shaky economics of cabaret to the indifference of television talent coordinators, from singers they perceive as cabaret-oriented to the negative connotations surrounding the very term cabaret. 
 
'A Bad Image in People's Minds'
''The word cabaret conjures up a bad image in people's minds,'' said Erv Raible, the owner of the Greenwich Village club Eighty-Eight's. ''The press is always portraying cabaret as a dying art form. And nobody wants to go see something that they think is about to die.''
Although New York City still has an active nightclub life, the struggle elsewhere to keep cabaret afloat is not being won, representatives from the San Francisco area and London said. Barbara Bladen, a critic for The San Mateo (Calif.) Times, cited the decline in alcohol consumption in the Bay Area as a reason for the decline in nightclub attendance. And Gerald Nachman, a critic for The San Francisco Chronicle, cited a lack of professional show business institutions in the Bay Area as a reason for cabaret's being what he called ''the worst-marketed art form.''
''San Francisco, a city that takes pride in its cultural sophistication, has no full-time cabaret,'' he said. ''The audience pool is down to a puddle.''
 
Conditions in London: Grim
The situation is just as bleak in London, said Robert Cushman, a London producer of radio specials that focus on American popular song and American cabaret performers. He pointed to the 1930's and the heyday of Noel Coward as the peak era for cabaret entertainment in England and said that today London doesn't have a single cabaret.
''I think it will always be economically and sociologically a very fragile form,'' Mr. Cushman added. He went on to suggest that cabaret was the kind of rarefied art form that is normally supported by government subsidy.
It was generally acknowleged by the panel that except for a handful of performers like Bobby Short and Michael Feinstein, most cabaret artists, even those near the top of the field, have a hard time of it economically.
''It's hard to make a living, to pay the rent, the groceries and insurance policies, but if you really love it it's your life,'' said Julie Wilson, who is playing an extended engagement at the Cafe Carlyle.
''Today, people are so hung up on the boob tube,'' Ms. Wilson said. ''When they come in, they treat you like a television and forget that you're a living, breathing creature who needs stimuli. This is the only business that can give you the personal touch.''
 
Brightness Amid the Gloom
The opening day of the convention was not without its upbeat moments. Several panelists pointed to the popularity of one-man shows on Broadway by Mandy Patinkin and Mr. Feinstein as demonstrating the existence of a potentially huge audience for cabaret-style entertainment. The problem, they acknowledged, is getting that audience to go to clubs.
With Mr. Feinstein, Mary Cleere Haran, Karen Mason and Bart Howard among the dozen acts performing at Town Hall on Tuesday evening, the talent overflowed at the first of the convention's four gala concerts. The galas, the last two of which are tonight at 6 o'clock and Sunday at 4 P.M., feature a cross-section of the best cabaret singers from New York and San Francisco, each performing two or three songs, for a bargain ticket price of $5.
Along with the Cabaret Comes to Carnegie concerts at Weill Recital Hall, which are also produced by Mr. Smith, and which opened last night with Elisabeth Welch, these shows are bringing a greater concentration of cabaret talent to New York's stages than the city has seen in many years.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

THE MARKETS
 
Investment bankers postponed two ''junk bond'' offerings totaling more than $1.2 billion because of volatile conditions in the high-risk, high-yield market. And Kohlberg & Company said Drexel Burnham Lambert, which was ''highly confident'' it could raise $75 million in financing for its buyout of Colorado Prime last summer, was unable to finance the deal through junk bonds. [Page D1.] 
 
Secondary stocks showed more strength than the blue chips as the market regained stability after its recent volatility. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.92 points, to 2,643.65. [D1.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in slow trading. [D19.] The Resolution Funding Corporation said it would auction $4.5 billion worth of 30-year bonds next Wednesday. [D19.] Yields of money market mutual funds fell for the week. [D10.]
 
The dollar ended weaker against key foreign currencies after a mixed performance overseas. [D22.] Copper futures prices slipped to their lowest point this month. [D22.]
 
COMPANIES

 
Philip Morris reported a strong third quarter, as net income rose nearly 21 percent to $748 million, or 81 cents a share. [D1.]
 
AMR ''has not been, and is not, for sale,'' its board said. It also reported a 9 percent drop in earnings and called them disappointing. [D1.] A House committee voted to give the Transportation Department authority to forestall big airline takeovers, but the Bush Administration threatened to veto the bill. [D5.]
 
Efforts continued to reassemble a deal for UAL, the parent of United Airlines. [D5.] The unsecured creditors of Eastern Airlines voted unanimously to have their financial advisers examine alternatives to management's bankruptcy reorganization plan. [D5.]
 
Drug companies reported mixed third-quarter earnings, in line with expectations. Schering-Plough reported a 20.8 percent gain, and American Home Products a 10.6 percent rise; earnings at Pfizer were flat. [D8.] BellSouth earnings slipped 3.6 percent to $404.4 million; Ameritech's were up 2.8 percent to $289.1 million. [D9.]
 
Shearson Lehman Hutton reported earnings of $66 million, or 64 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $3 million a year ago. [D8.] The New York Times Company's profits rose to $210.8 million, or $2.68 a share, including an after-tax gain of $193.3 million, or $2.46 a share, from the sale of a cable television system. That compared with $26.7 million, or 33 cents a share, a year earlier. [D20.]
 
Deloitte Haskins & Sells's British affiliate said it would sue ''to prevent the unauthorized use'' of the Deloitte name worldwide after the American firm merges with Touche Ross. [D11.]

Housing construction fell for a second consecutive month in September, declining to the weakest pace in seven years. [D2.]
 
The Treasury formally notified Congress that it would like to have an increase in the national debt ceiling in place by Oct. 24 to permit planning for Treasury bond auctions and avoid a default on Government obligations when the ceiling expires on Oct. 31. [D18.]

The U.S. and Mexico will eventually negotiate a free-trade pact similar to one that went into effect with Canada on Jan. 1, Commerce Secretary Mosbacher predicted. [D9.]

HEADLINE: Housing Construction Fell 5.2% in September

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Housing construction, buffeted by rising mortgage rates, fell for a second consecutive month in September, declining to the weakest pace in seven years.
The Commerce Department said today that construction of new homes and apartments dropped 5.2 percent after a 6.2 percent August decline. The August figure is a revision from a 5 percent drop reported last month. 
September's figure put the seasonally adjusted annual rate of home construction at 1.26 million units, the slowest pace since October 1982.
Many analysts attributed the September decline to builders' concerns about high levels of unsold homes and worries that rising mortgage rates during the month might further crimp new-home sales. Because much of the decline occurred in the South, some analysts suggested that Hurricane Hugo affected construction in that area.
 
A Call for Lower Rates
David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, said the weakness in housing demonstrated the urgent need for the Federal Reserve to push down interest rates to keep the economy from toppling into a recession.
Many analysts said they saw signs that the central bank had begun a series of small credit-easing moves. They noted that a closely watched indicator of Federal Reserve intentions, the overnight Federal funds rate, has dropped about a quarter of a percentage point, to 8 3/4 percent, since last Friday's stock market plunge.
The Federal Reserve pumped an estimated $1.5 billion into the banking system today, the third consecutive daily cash infusion since Friday's market turmoil.
While the Federal Reserve's efforts were aimed at reassuring skittish financial markets about plentiful reserves for emergency loans, analysts said the Fed was likely to keep interest rates at lower levels because of the weak housing construction and other signs of a slowing economy.
 
A Dip in Mortgage Rates
Fixed-rate mortgages, which climbed as high as 10.22 percent in early September, have fallen slightly in October and now stand at 9.95 percent, according to a weekly survey by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
So far this year housing construction is running 6.2 percent below a year ago, with downturns posted in six of the last nine months.
For September, construction of single-family homes fell by 2.1 percent, to an annual rate of 971,000 units, the second consecutive month that the rate has been below one million. Construction of multifamily units was down 14.1 percent, to an annual rate of 292,000 units.
In a disturbing sign for the future, permits for new units dropped as well in September, falling 2.4 percent, to 1.30 million units.

HEADLINE: Mosbacher Sees a Free-Trade Pact With Mexico

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher predicted today that the United States and Mexico would eventually negotiate a free trade agreement similar to one that went into effect with Canada on Jan. 1, and said the two countries had already discussed the subject informally.
''We should not try to push them too fast, too hard, but they are interested, extremely interested, in moving toward this - they want to take it a step at a time,'' Mr. Mosbacher, once a Texas oilman, told the Senate Banking Committee.
To be sure, the subject of broader agreements with the United States is still a politically sensitive one in Mexico, which has a long history of distrust of its northern neighbor. 
A free trade agreement could be a hard sell in the United States as well because of American labor and business sensitivity over competition arising from cheap Mexican labor.
 
Seminal 1987 Accord
Earlier this month Mexico and the United States signed less far-reaching agreements intended to enlarge mutual trade and investment, broadening a seminal 1987 accord providing for talks on trade disputes.
The Canadian free trade arrangement, which took more than two years to conclude, calls for elimination of tariff barriers by the year 2000, along with reduced barriers to trade in financial and other services and greater investment freedom.
Mexico is the third-largest trading partner of the United States, after Canada and Japan.
Today's statement by Mr. Mosbacher marks the first time the Bush Administration has openly acknowledged that it holds out similar prospects in its relations with Mexico.
The talks about a hemispheric economic union, in which goods would move freely without tariff barriers, have been spurred by the policies of greater openness in trade and investment by Mexico's President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and his predecessor, Miguel de la Madrid.
 
'Serious Possibilities'
''A few years back a free trade zone with Mexico was discussed only by romantics, but now it really has serious possibilities,'' said one American business representative, William T. Archey, the international vice president at the United States Chamber of Commerce.
The minister for economic affairs at the Mexican Embassy here, Manuel Suarez-Mier, said that ''at this stage'' his Government was ''not prepared to undertake any bilateral free trade negotiations with anyone.''
''We still are trying to catch our breath after the fullest and deepest opening that any country has accomplished in history,'' he said.
Before the de la Madrid administration, Mexico had pursued policies of economic and trade nationalism. The first sign of the shift came in August 1986, when it joined the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world's free trade charter, to which nearly 100 other nations subscribe.
 
Debt Crisis Hearings
Mr. Mosbacher's comments were made during a Senate hearing on the impact of the Latin American debt crisis on American trade. The hearings included testimony on the effect on United States businesses of Latin America's import curb, intended to husband the debtor countries' money so they will be able pay interest on loans.
''In one country after another major projects have been postponed or canceled because the Government did not have the money to pay for them,'' said Fred R. Jones, vice president and treasurer of Combustion Engineering Inc.
Largely because of the contraction in its Latin business, this big capital equipment supplier had to cut overall employment from 47,000 to 30,000, Mr. Jones told the lawmakers.

HEADLINE: British Unit Challenges Deloitte's Merger Plan

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
Deloitte Haskins & Sells's British affiliate, which had previously rejected the accounting firm's proposed merger with Touche Ross, said yesterday that it would sue ''to prevent the unauthorized use'' of the Deloitte name worldwide.
Deloitte's British roots go back to 1845, and its name is well known throughout the world. It received priority when the British firm of Deloitte & Company joined the American firm of Haskins & Sells in 1978. 
The architects of the Deloitte-Touche merger had agreed to call their worldwide firm Deloitte Ross Tohmatsu. Tohmatsu is Touche's Japanese affiliate. The merger has been ratified by partners of the firms in some countries, including the United States and Japan, but the deal has not been completed.
The threatened lawsuit is viewed by some as a setback for completion of the deal. Completion is not expected before Dec. 1; the original date had been Nov. 1.
Earlier this month, Deloitte's British affiliate decided to join Coopers & Lybrand, rather than the Deloitte-Touche combination. The affiliate said yesterday that it had begun legal proceedings against Deloitte's American firm and Touche's British affiliate.
Deloitte's affiliates in the Netherlands and the Channel Islands have also decided to join Coopers. The British and Dutch affiliates, Deloitte's second and third largest, contributed more than $500 million in revenues last year, which would be 14 percent of the $3.8 billion combined worldwide revenues of Deloitte and Touche.
''If the goal of most of these mergers is to have no more than 10 percent fallout, as they all say when they get into them, then you might consider this a not-so-successful merger,'' said Thomas LaFreniere, editor of the International Accounting Bulletin.
John Bullock, a senior partner of Deloitte's British firm, said in a statement, ''This course of action was very much a last resort.'' He cited his firm's inability to obtain assurances from either defendent as to how they might use the name.
In a statement, Deloitte said it had not been served with, nor had it seen any, papers filed by its British arm. But based on the affiliate's public comments, ''We believe their action to be without merit,'' Deloitte said.
Touche Ross officials in the United States did not return telephone calls seeking comment.
A senior Deloitte partner in the United States said he doubted that the litigation would undermine the merger in those countries where it had been approved.
Others like Michael J. Wolff, however, were less sure. A former Touche partner who now heads strategic marketing at Richard A. Eisner & Company, a large regional accounting firm, Mr. Wolff said that the defections were especially troubling since both firms pursued the merger largely to pool resources for the economic unification of Europe.
Without the British and Dutch affiliaties, he said, it would seem the merger would bring ''more grief than opportunities.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Steady; Trading Slow

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed yesterday in slow trading, despite a report that showed housing starts were at their lowest level in more than five years.
Although the report was weaker than economists had expected, the market response was positive, and prices moved higher.
But those gains soon eroded, as dealers pondered the potential implications for the credit markets of the California earthquake and braced themselves for a coming rush of new securities.
 
Two Auctions Scheduled
Yesterday the Treasury said it would sell $10 billion worth of two-year notes on Tuesday. Separately, the Resolution Funding Corporation announced it would auction $4.5 billion of 30-year bonds on Oct. 25. 
The Resolution Trust sale comes on the heels of Wednesday's $2 billion sale of bonds by the Tennessee Valley Authority. Underwriters said 5 to 10 percent of those bonds remain unsold, but market participants said the issue was struggling yesterday.
''There is plenty of supply in the long end,'' one government bond trader said. ''The short end of the maturity curve is trading O.K., but long rates might have to back up a little from here to get these bonds sold.'' 30-Year Bond at 101 By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 101, unchanged on the day, to yield 8.03 percent.
Prices of shorter-term Treasury note issues were only marginally better. In late trading, the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 29/32, up 2/32, to yield 8.01 percent. And the 8 1/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 101 1/4, up 1/32, to yield 7.93 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were little changed. By late in the day three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.49 percent, down a basis point, or a hundredth of a point. Six-month bills were unchanged, at a discount rate of 7.51 percent.
Early in the session, worries abounded about the earthquake. Traders speculated that in order to honor earthquake-related claims, insurance companies would be big sellers of Treasury securities. And market participants were on the lookout for any problems in the California financial system, since the ability of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco to conduct normal operations was unknown.
 
Worries Prove Unfounded
Yesterday at least, the worries proved unfounded.
''There was some selling of long securities early in the day,'' one government bond trader said. ''But then we started getting reports that the amount of damage is around $1 billion. That is a large number, but a $1 billion loss does not produce a lasting change in the securities market.''
Francis H. Schott, senior vice president and chief economist at the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, said: ''In the case of the property and casualty companies, most of the risk has already been spread to insurance companies worldwide. I don't think the earthquake per se would make anyone change their investment policy.''
 
Fed Bank Functioning Normally
Donna Drake, a spokeswoman for the Los Angeles branch of the San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank, said that while the volume of transactions flowing through the San Francisco office was somewhat lower than normal, the bank was functioning normally.
''Operationally, the Fed is up and running,'' she said. ''There have been no problems at all. The bank has its own emergency backup power, and when the power went off the backup kicked right in.''
The overnight Federal funds rate, which might have moved erratically if a disruption in the bank's check-processing capabilities had been impaired, traded in a narrow range of 8 3/4 to 8 5/8 percent yesterday.
Participants in the tax-exempt municipal bond market said that prices of outstanding California securities dipped by anywhere from three-eighths of a point to three-quarters of a point, depending on the issuer.
 
California Moves Dismissed
''Those moves aren't really indiciative of anything,'' one municipal bond trader said, ''because there is not a lot of California paper around. The $450 million issue that the State sold last week got gobbled up. It's not like somebody came in and sold a $100 million portfolio of bonds.''
Prices of most secondary municipal issues fell by about a quarter of a point in quiet trading, dealers said.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company of Maryland priced a $50 million offering of 8 percent debentures through an underwriting syndicate led by Morgan Stanley & Company.
The debentures, which mature Oct. 15, 2029, carry a ''put,'' or price guarantee, to investors on Oct. 15, 1996. The debentures were priced at $99.68, to yield 8.06 percent, 8 basis points above the prevailing yield on seven-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The issue, which is noncallable for life, is rated AA-3 by Moody's Investors Service and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: Move Seen on Oil Stockpile

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
The Bush Administration will stop buying Mexican oil for the United States emergency stockpile early next year, ending an eight-year supply link aimed in part at aiding the debt-ridden Mexican economy, people close to the situation said today.
The Administration and the Mexican state oil company, Pemex, agreed that an existing supply contract expiring on Nov. 30 would not be renewed, said an Energy Department staff member who asked not to be identified. 
Additional Mexican oil will be purchased for three months beyond the contract's expiration to satisfy a minimum volume requirement, he said. The arrangement is to be announced next month, according to an internal Energy Department memorandum.
Starting in December, the Energy Department will meet its stockpile needs by soliciting bids for short-term supply deals with domestic and foreign suppliers - the usual practice before the Mexican contracts started in 1981.
In August 1982, at the height of Mexico's foreign debt crisis, the Reagan Administration agreed to pay Mexico $1 billion in advance for oil to be put in the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.
The decision to end contract purchases from Mexico is in part the result of a growing constraint on Mexico's ability to produce enough high-quality Isthmus crude to meet both export and domestic demand, the person at the Energy Department said.
The reserve, started in 1975 after the Arab oil embargo, is intended to give the United States enough emergency supplies to weather any future disruption of oil imports.

HEADLINE: Resolution Funding in $4.5 Billion Bond Sale

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Resolution Funding Corporation, established by Congress last summer to finance the bailout of the nation's savings and loan industry, announced yesterday that it would auction $4.5 billion worth of 30-year bonds to the public next Wednesday.
The offering is the first of what are expected to be quarterly sales of bonds until the corporation's $50 billion in borrowing authority is exhausted. The first $20 billion was borrowed by the Treasury Department in the third quarter. 
Although Congress has authorized $50 billion for the bailout, experts in and out of Government have said that to solve the savings and loan problem Resolution Funding will ultimately sell far larger amounts of bonds.
William L. Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, voiced those sentiments when he testified before Congress on the savings and loan bailout package earlier this month.
 
Good Reception Expected
Credit market participants, who earlier in the week speculated that the offering might include some 40-year bonds, said that the offering held no surprises and that the issue should sell well.
''The auction will go well, even if the dealers won't make as much money as they would on a negotiated deal,'' said William N. Griggs, a managing director at Griggs & Santow Inc., a financial consulting concern. ''When all is said and done, I expect that the issue will sell at a premium over 30-year Treasury bonds of about 25 basis points.'' A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In when-issued trading after the announcement, the bonds were offered at a price to yield 8.22 percent.
Unlike Treasury securities, the corporation's bonds are not explicitly backed by the full faith and credit of the United States Government. But in effect the securities do carry a de facto guarantee.
 
Backed by Zero-Coupon Bonds
Before issuing its bonds, the corporation will purchase zero-coupon Treasury securities directly from the Treasury. The principal amount at the maturity of the zero-coupon securities will equal the principal amount of Resolution Funding obligations.
''The lack of a guarantee is purely a legal formalism,'' said Louis v. B. Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates. ''In effect, there is a separate guarantee from the Treasury on the principal repayment and interest coupons.''
To explain the different format and to drum up interest in the securities abroad, representatives from the corporation held meetings last week in London and Tokyo with potential investors.
A similar session was held in New York on Friday, a gathering that Mr. Crandall said was hastily prepared.
''At the last minute, they put together a very hurried meeting for New York dealers,'' he said. ''It wasn't very smart of them to do that.''

HEADLINE: Times Co. Profit Bolstered By Special Gain in Quarter

 BODY:
The New York Times Company yesterday reported third-quarter earnings of $210.8 million, or $2.68 a share, compared with $26.7 million, or 33 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. Revenues came to $415.3 million, up 6.4 percent from $390.5 million a year ago.
The results for this year's third quarter included an after-tax gain of $193.3 million, or $2.46 a share, from the sale of the Times Company's cable television system and another $1.1 million in discontinued operations. Excluding that gain, earnings from continuing operations dropped for the quarter by 34.9 percent, to $16.4 million, or 21 cents a share, from $25.2 million, or 31 cents a share. 
Times Company executives attributed the decline in earnings from continuing operations to expenses from the acquisition of three magazines, lower earnings from the forest products group and a decline in advertising linage at The New York Times. These problems are expected to continue to hurt earnings in the near future, the company said.
''While the fundamentals of our business are strong, there are several factors which will cause the company's earnings from continuing operations to be down both this year and in 1990,'' said Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the company's chairman and chief executive.
 
'Softness in Advertising'
Mr. Sulzberger said that a continued ''softness in advertising'' brought on by the weakness of the New York region's economy would most likely continue to reduce earnings. Advertising linage at The Times for the third quarter declined by 8.7 percent, to 23.6 million lines.
The acquisition of three magazines - McCall's, Golf World and Sailing World - reduced earnings by about 7 cents a share in the latest quarter. The write-offs of certain assets acquired with the magazines are expected to reduce earnings by about 9 cents a share in the fourth quarter and 24 cents a share in 1990.
Mr. Sulzberger said earnings had also been affected by an oversupply of newsprint, which has depressed its price, and a strong Canadian dollar, which lowered the value of the company's newsprint interests held in its forest products group.
The Times's new printing plant in Edison, N.J., is expected to begin operating in 1990. Mr. Sulzberger said that move would involve heavy start-up and depreciation costs. He added that the Edison operation should ultimately result in increased revenues and labor savings, but that those benefits would not be realized ''until after a break-in period.''
 
Newspaper Group Gains
In the newspaper group, which consists of The Times, 35 regional newspapers and a one-third interest in The International Herald Tribune, operating profits for the quarter increased to $34.9 million from $34.5 million. The company attributed the gain to a strong performance by the regional newspapers, lower newsprint costs and budget tightening.
The circulation of The Times for the six months ended Sept. 30 reached a record high of 1,068,000 copies on weekdays, up 2.8 percent, and 1,628,100 copies on Sundays, up 1.7 percent. Sunday circulation for the regional papers in that period was up 3.7 percent, to 833,500, while weekday circulation rose 3.9 percent, to 853,600.
The magazine group, which consists of 17 publications, reported an operating loss of $4.5 million for the quarter, in contrast to an operating profit of $2.5 million in the 1988 quarter. Excluding the costs related to the acquisitions of the three magazines, the group's operating profit would have advanced over the results in the 1988 quarter, the company said.
Operating profits in the broadcasting and information services group increased to $2.6 million in the quarter, from $2.5 million a year ago. A factor in the increase was higher local advertising revenue at the company's television stations.
Equity in earnings in the forest products group dropped 58.7 percent, to $2.6 million from $6.3 million.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Weaker in U.S. While Gold Prices Advance

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended weaker yesterday against key foreign currencies after a mixed performance overseas.
Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $368.70 an ounce, up $1.30 from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold of $367.70 an ounce, also $1.30 higher. 
Currency dealers said the dollar sank in overnight trading on news of the earthquake in California, but it regained some ground on the strength of the stock market.
Robert Ryan, senior currency trader for the Bank of New York, said an unconfirmed report that the Federal Reserve moved to buy dollars early in trading also helped support the dollar. However, most dealers dismissed those rumors.
Traders said the market was awaiting today's release of Consumer Price Index figures for September, hoping they would shed more light on the direction of the economy and inflation.
 
Dollar Declines in Japan
In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar fell to a closing 142.10 Japanese yen, from 142.25 yen Tuesday. It traded at 141.40 yen in London and New York, compared with 142.70 in New York Tuesday. The dollar was lower against the British pound. Sterling bought $1.5880 in London, up from $1.5835 late Tuesday. In New York, the pound was worth $1.5922, up from $1.57575.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.8485 West German marks, down from 1.8672; 1.6243 Swiss francs, down from 1.6365; 6.2810 French francs, down from 6.3475; 1.17335 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17555, and 1,362.00 Italian lire, down from 1,400.00.
Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex silver bullion for current delivery closed at $5.105 an ounce, higher than Tuesday's bid of $5.102. Silver fell in London to $5.11 an ounce from $5.12.

HEADLINE: A Body for Better Men to Beat On

BYLINE: By PHIL BERGER

 BODY:
Dave Jaco sometimes works on short notice.
That's not unusual for that species of fighter used for building the records of rising young attractions. In the boxing business, they are known simply as opponents.
Jaco, a heavyweight who lives in Sarasota, Fla., is an opponent. 
At the age of 34, he has no illusions of competing for a world title.
In January 1986, when Jaco fought a hot young contender named Mike Tyson, it was, as it so often is, a last-minute call that summoned him to the ring. At the time, Jaco was in Atlanta, earning $50 a day, plus meal money, as a sparring partner for Tim Witherspoon, who was training for a World Boxing Association heavyweight title fight against Tony Tubbs.
 
Vicious Reputation
''Tyson had just made the cover of Sports Illustrated,'' Jaco recalled. ''Kid Dynamite, they called him. And because of the reputation he was getting as a vicious puncher, the promoter was having a hard time finding a guy to fight him. Nobody wanted to get in the same ring with Tyson. They offered me $5,000 to fight Tyson. Five grand sounded like a lot. Back then I was always behind on child support for my twin boys, Adam and Aaron. I took the fight. I didn't care. I'd been in tough fights a lot of times before.''
The bout, fought in Albany, ended quickly.
''I got decked three times in the first round,'' Jaco said. ''The third time I went down, the bell ending the round rang. I went back to my corner, talking to myself: 'What are you doing? The guy is knocking the stuffing out of you.'
''That's when the referee told me the fight was over. Three knockdowns ends a fight. At that point, I thought I'd been down only twice. 'No,' my corner man said. 'You were down three times.' That tells you about Mike Tyson's punch.''
Since Tyson knocked him out, Jaco has been stopped often. Tony Tucker, Johnny Duplooy, Mike Evans, Gary Mason, George Foreman, Alex Stewart and, most recently, Tommy Morrison, all beat Jaco by knockout. #37-Second Bout For the fight against Morrison, Jaco was contacted 48 hours before the match after Morrison's original opponent, Danny Sutton, canceled. For a $2,000 purse, Jaco trekked from Sarasota by car and, when the car broke down, by plane, to Jacksonville, Fla., a trip that quickly seemed not worth the bother.
Jaco lasted 37 seconds of the first round against Morrison, who knocked him out with a powerful left hook. After the 6-foot-6-inch, 201-pound Jaco was counted out, he crawled two paces to his corner on his knees before his second could get to him and help him to his stool.
Jaco holds a 1985 victory over Tyson's next opponent, Donovan (Razor) Ruddock: it is Ruddock's only defeat. But even Jaco, whose record is 21-17 (18 knockouts), acknowledges that lately he has been merely a body for better men to beat on.
''But even though I'm a common opponent,'' Jaco said, ''I don't go in there thinking I'm a loser. Promoters know I don't go down with a phantom punch. Every time Tyson knocked me down, I got up.''
Jaco's boxing odyssey began relatively late. He was 24 years old when he was laid off from his $300-a-week job as a pipefitter at Interlake Steel in Toledo, Ohio, in 1979.
''It came at a bad time,'' Jaco said. ''I felt kind of, like, lost. I was hurt from a divorce and the fact that my wife got custody of the boys. I had no job, just $180 a week unemployment.''
 
Discovered a Knack
When a friend who was an amateur fighter suggested Jaco join him for a workout, Jaco discovered he had a knack for the sport. It led to his competing in Tough Man contests in Pontiac, Mich., and Toledo (he won the Ohio event), and that in turn nudged him to a pro boxing career in 1981. Although he had no amateur fights, Jaco won his first 12 bouts as a pro.
''I was 25 years old and still unemployed,'' Jaco said. ''At that time, boxing was a kind of dare. As I won my first 12 fights, I developed a bit of a following, 30 or 40 fans who'd travel to where I fought.''
Jaco's first loss, a first-round knockout in June 1983, was to Carl (the Truth) Williams for a purse of $3,000. Other losses followed, too regularly to suit Jaco. But when he got custody of the twins, he kept fighting for money he could add to the $350 weekly paycheck he draws as a delivery driver for a Sarasota appliance company. The $10,000 he earned for fighting Foreman, and getting knocked out in one round, in December, was his best payday as a professional.
''When I started out, I figured maybe one day I'd become a contender,'' Jaco said. ''These days, I give it my best. But I'm always rusty. My timing is off. I have a fulltime job. I just can't devote myself like you have to.''
 
Trips to Emergency Rooms
Through boxing, Jaco has traveled the world: Dusseldorf, West Germany; Budapest, Hungary; Windsor, England. And he's also been to the emergency room of more than a few hosptials.
''I've had 65 stitches, a broken cheekbone, a fractured nose, a fractured bone in my eye and fractured ribs,'' Jaco said.
The toll of hard times has him talking lately of ending his fight career.
''It's too easy to get hurt,'' Jaco said. ''With my boys to raise - they're 12 years old now - I'm figuring to fight one more time this year, on the live card to the Leonard-Duran closed-circuit show here in Sarasota, and then retire so I can concentrate on them.
''I want to make sure they grow up right. The world is so corrupt. And things happen. Like their friends know I'm a fighter, so the boys are expected to be that way. I have to tell them: 'You don't make friends being mean.' Just because your dad is on TV, and gets beat up, doesn't make you any meaner.''

HEADLINE: A BROAD PROGRAM OF AID TO POLAND IS VOTED BY HOUSE

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to set up a major new program to support democracy, private enterprise and the development of a free-market economy in Poland.
The legislation would establish a similar but smaller program for Hungary.
The bill, which was strongly supported by both Democrats and Republicans, would permit the spending of up to $837.5 million in aid to Warsaw and Budapest over the next three years.
 
The President Acquiesces
President Bush acquiesced in the bill while expressing reservations about its cost. He has proposed a much more modest program of aid totaling $455.5 million. 
The bill was approved by a vote of 345 to 47. It was supported by 217 Democrats and 128 Republicans, and opposed by 13 Democrats and 34 Republicans.
Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the chief deputy whip for House Democrats, declared: ''We have poured trillions into a nuclear and conventional arms race with the Soviet Union. We can surely afford millions to support the fragile experiments in democracy in Eastern Europe.''
The size of the majority supporting the bill reflected in part the effectiveness of lobbying by Polish-American groups in and around big cities like Chicago, Detroit, Philadelphia and New York. Mr. Bonior's paternal grandfather came to the United States from Poland, and as a child Mr. Bonior learned to speak Polish as well as English. His Congressional district, in the suburbs of Detroit, includes many Americans of Polish ancestry.
 
Excitement Over Recent Change
House members argued that the United States had an extraordinary chance to promote democracy in Poland and Hungary and that the opportunity might be lost if Congress did not move swiftly to provide more aid than Mr. Bush had requested.
The debate was marked by excitement over the changes taking place in Poland and in Hungary, where the Communist Party has adopted a platform calling for free markets and free elections.
Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois, said Congress was writing a new foreign policy for the ''post-Marxist era.'' Representative Donald E. Lukens, Republican of Ohio, declared: ''Socialism as an economic theory is dead. Long live the free market.''
In September, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved a bill to provide up to $1.25 billion in aid to Poland and Hungary over three years. It appears likely that some version of the legislation will become law, with the precise amount of aid to be decided through negotiations between the House and the Senate.
 
Dispute Over Shipping
The only issue that provoked bitter debate in the House today was a proposal to waive a Federal law under which 75 percent of American food aid must be carried in American-flag ships. Supporters of the waiver said the cargo preference provision would increase the cost of shipping and thereby reduce the value of food that could be delivered to Poland.
The bill earmarks $125 million for food aid to Poland this year. Representative Tom Tauke, Republican of Iowa, estimated that 30 percent of that money would be spent for shipping and transportation of surplus commodities.
Representative Marcy Kaptur, Democrat of Ohio, offered an amendment to reduce the cargo preference requirement so that only 50 percent of the food aid for Poland would have to be carried in American-flag ships. The House rejected her proposal by a vote of 228 to 170.
More than 85 percent of the aid in the House bill would go to Poland, where a Solidarity-led Government took office in September. Poland's population of 38 million is more than three times that of Hungary.
The bill would provide $200 million to foster private enterprise, including small businesses and farms, in Poland and Hungary; $200 million in loan guarantees and insurance to finance the export of American goods and services to Poland, and another $200 million to promote long-term economic growth and stability in Poland.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said Monday that the United States was prepared to provide Moscow with advice and technical assistance to help restructure the Soviet economy and society. But in debate on the House bill today, Democrats said the Administration seemed grudging in its response to changes in Eastern Europe.
Representative Howard Wolpe, Democrat of Michigan, said the Administration's actions ''fall short'' of its oratorical commitment to democracy in Poland and Hungary. Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, said the Administration ''sat idly by'' when Poles were trying to replace their Communist rulers.
In an official statement of Administration policy, the White House said that ''President Bush has taken the lead in supporting reform in Poland and Hungary and has worked with Congress to insure that comprehensive legislation is enacted on an urgent basis.'' But it said, ''The Administration has reservations about the excessive funding levels contained in this legislation and also has various constitutional concerns.'' The Administration did not specify its constitutional concerns.
 
Help for Private Businesses
The House bill calls for the creation of a Polish-American enterprise fund and a Hungarian-American enterprise fund to channel Federal money to private businesses in Eastern Europe. Of the funds provided by this section, $160 million is for Poland and $40 million for Hungary.
The bill would also permit the United States Environmental Protection Agency to spend up to $10 million to reduce pollution of the air and water in Poland. In addition, the bill would provide $30 million to help Poland modify its boilers, furnaces and industrial equipment to reduce pollution from the burning of coal.
The bill also encourages educational and cultural exchanges, providing up to $10 million in scholarships for Poles and Hungarians to study in the United States. It would also provide $5.5 million for Polish-American cooperation in science and technology, with $2.5 million for similar projects between Hungary and the United States.

LENGTH: 1196 words

HEADLINE: U.S. May Yield on Philippine Bases

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA

 BODY:
American officials are prepared to negotiate an entirely new military bases agreement with the Philippine Government that will acknowledge increasing Philippine concerns about sovereignty, Western diplomats say.
The agreement is expected to include joint-use arrangements like those common for American military bases in NATO countries and Japan.
The Americans ''are prepared to discuss a relationship that is more fundamentally equal'' and puts both country's armed forces ''side by side,'' a diplomat said, so long as American operational flexibility remains.
 
Plan to Share Clark Air Base
Technically, the bases are already jointly operated, with Filipino and American base commanders. But Philippine military activity at the bases is negligible. As an example of the change proposed by the Americans, the diplomat said, a second runway being built at Clark Air Base and scheduled to be finished in early 1991 would allow the Americans to invite the Philippine Air Force to move its main installations to Clark. 
''These are the last two major bases that haven't moved to joint use,'' the diplomat said. ''This is the last basing agreement to be updated.'' For Filipinos sensitive to sovereignty, this, too, seems an insult.
The two major bases are Clark Air Base and Subic Bay Naval Station, among America's largest overseas installations, and there are four smaller ones, including a spot devoted to rest and recreation. Subic Bay has been a Navy base since 1904, and Clark became a permanent military base in 1903.
Clark is the only major American tactical air base in Southeast Asia, but it would be more easily and cheaply replicated than Subic, which can support combat operations of several carrier battle groups and logistics for naval operations throughout the Western Pacific and Indian Oceans.
 
U.S. Looking for a New Agreement
Negotiations to extend American access to the bases are the hardy perennials of Philippine diplomacy. Almost as soon as an agreement is signed, the Manila Government begins prodding Washington to renegotiate.
Rather than fight with the Filipinos over when the current base agreement expires, the Americans will seek to have a new agreement in place beforehand. Manila says the expiration date is Sept. 16, 1991, according to the 1987 Philippine Constitution; Washington says it is 12 months later, citing the agreement text, which specifies a year's notice before abrogation.
President Corazon C. Aquino, who will visit Washington next month, has agreed that talks will begin this December in Manila. While her advisers say she favors a continued American military presence, her active support for any new agreement - regarded as crucial by the Americans -will depend on its terms, political as well as financial.
Base-related American aid is now $481 million a year, and Washington has pledged a further $200 million a year as its contribution to an assistance plan involving other aid donors like Japan. Philippine officials say they will ask for an increase when the negotiations begin in December but have not settled on a figure.
 
Surging Anti-Base Sentiment
But anti-base sentiment is growing, especially among city dwellers and the elite - most dramatically expressed by a Senate resolution that calls for the removal of the bases in 1991 signed by 12 of 23 senators.
Even the ground for the debate has shifted considerably, American officials say. Previous base talks - there have been a long series since the original, much-modified agreement of 1947, when the United States granted the Philippines its independence - have concentrated on rights, jurisdiction, perquisites and money, with extension a given. But today the boundaries of the debate range from immediate removal of the bases in 1991 to the negotiation of a final extension, to allow a sensible and economically efficient phaseout.
Senator Rene V. Saguisag, an Aquino backer who thinks that the bases are outdated and that the American presence here maintains Filipino immaturity, says: ''The debate has shifted from Stars and Stripes forever to 5 or at the most 10 years. We're talking of outright termination or of a limited extension only.''
While Washington wants a 15- or even a 20-year ''transition,'' many Filipinos who are pro-base think five years is long enough. Even the pro-American right wing and the Philippine military favor a final extension of 5 or 10 years.
Fidel V. Ramos, the Defense Minister and a potential presidential candidate, says he wants the bases out by 1998, the 100th anniversary of the Philippines' fall from Spanish to American control.
 
Balancing Force in Region
The other countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, while formally committed to making the region a zone of neutrality and thus unhappy about the military presence of a foreign power, nonetheless regard the Americans as a relatively benign balancing force, keeping the Russians, the Chinese as well as the Japanese in bounds.
Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore has been explicit about the need to keep the Americans in the region, and has tried to help the prospect along by offering to have American military bases in Singapore. But Singapore can offer nothing that begins to replace the Philippines bases, and no other Asean country is likely to.
Faced with complaints about limited sovereignty from Filipinos, American officials tend to respond with paeans to the two countries' long relationship and with a recitation of economic benefits: the bases are the country's second-largest employer after the national Government, providing jobs for nearly 80,000 Filipinos; they contribute over $1 billion a year to the economy, contribute 4 to 5 percent of the gross national product and effectively represent the country's eighth-largest trading partner.
Subic and Clark have also spawned strips of cheap restaurants, bars and brothels, and while American officials rarely mention these indirect economic benefits, some Filipinos consider them important, however degrading.
 
'Slaying the Father Image'
But the economic arguments are regarded as less important to many Filipinos than the issue of nationalism and sovereignty, a feeling that seems to cut across the political spectrum.
Senator Saguisag, a leftist who was Mrs. Aquino's spokesman, says: ''So long as we depend on Uncle Sam, we'll never lose our political adolescence. We can't be one-tenth colonialized and nine-tenths free.''
Mrs. Aquino's Foreign Minister, Raul S. Manglapus, a longtime nationalist, says Manila ''must slay the father image'' to grow up.
Leticia Ramos-Shahani, a former United Nations diplomat and chairwoman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, worries about economic disruption and thus favors a final phaseout of five years. But she can be caustic about the United States, saying that Americans rarely take Filipinos seriously and patronize them.
''America's only colony is the weakest economic performer in Asia,'' she said. ''The economic foundation you helped to establish in Taiwan, South Korea and other places was not done here. It's an indictment and the United States has to deal with that.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Officials Look to Policy on East Germany as Next Big Challenge

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is reviewing American policy toward East Germany, seeking a balance of encouraging democratization there without also fostering a pell-mell movement toward reunification of Germany that would threaten both Moscow and America's NATO allies.
The replacement of Erich Honecker as head of the Communist Party and growing internal pressures for change in East Germany have strengthened the perception among Administration officials that the way they respond to developments between East and West Germany could become their next major foreign policy challenge. It is not one that everyone welcomes.
''With Poland and Hungary we can encourage reform and self-expression without feeling it is in any way inconsistent with American interests,'' a senior policy maker said. 
''But when you support the same things for East Germany you are knowingly accelerating a process which would make the ultimate reunification of Germany more possible. The more similar East Germany is to West Germany the more easy it will be for the two to fuse. The more different they are, the more difficult it will be. Which do we really want?'' For several decades the United States had a very simple policy toward East Germany: The Berlin wall should be removed and East and West Germany should be peacefully reunited. But Washington assumed this was unattainable -and preferred it that way.
''The situation we have had with the Germanys for 45 years has been unnatural but stable,'' said Herbert S. Okun, a former United States Ambassador to East Germany. ''Now that we are moving toward a situation that is more natural the question is how do we preserve the stability.''
 
Three-Dimensional Policy
A range of senior officials said the Administration is evolving a policy on East Germany that has three basic dimensions. On one level, the Administration has decided that it both can and should continue to encourage gradual change in East Germany.
It should do this, officials say, because only an East German government based on more free market and democratic foundations can prevent a popular explosion. Such an explosion, these officials fear, would almost certainly provoke a domestic crackdown or Soviet intervention.
Administration officials believe they can afford to encourage change in East Germany because they consider the prospects for reunification remote at this time.
The Administration is operating on the unstated assumption that the Soviet Union will not allow a merger of East Germany into West Germany, given the fact that it serves as the strategic anchor of the Warsaw Pact.
 
Conditions on Reunification
But Administration officials say they would be foolish simply to assume that German reunification is impossible, which brings up the second dimension of East Germany policy: For the first time, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has begun to talk publicly about the conditions under which Washington would be ready to see German reunification.
Mr. Baker uses the word German ''reconciliation'' instead of ''reunification,'' partly to avoid European anxieties and to convey the message that such a merger must be voluntary and take place on Western terms.
A secondary motive in Washington's support for integration of the European Community in 1992, a senior Administration official said, ''is to insure that West Germany has a strong anchor in laws, commerce and values in the West so that if and when it is drawn east it does so on the basis of being fully integrated into the Western economic and political union.''
This underscores the third dimension of American policy: work closely with Bonn. West Germany is the only NATO member with the economic and political resources, and the penetration of East German society, to promote the kind of evolutionary change in East Germany that would prevent a political collapse, or a popular explosion.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Is Quayle Out of Tune On U.S. Soviet Policy?

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Vice President Dan Quayle went to California this week. Because he was there when the earthquake struck, he had a golden opportunity to generate some favorable publicity for a change, to show himself capable of reacting to events quickly and effectively.
Instead he managed to generate further controversy.
Speaking with reporters in San Francisco on Tuesday, Mr. Quayle dismissively referred to Mikhail S. Gorbachev as General Secretary and not as President of the Soviet Union. And he condemned the idea that the United States might help with the Soviets' attempts at political and social reforms. 
''Let them reform themselves,'' he commented.
''The United States does not pin our hopes on one man,'' the Vice President said in a speech in Los Angeles the same day. ''The Soviet Union remains our potential adversary.''
All of which might sound normal enough coming from a conservative Republican from Indiana. Except that he is now the Vice President in an Administration whose policy toward Moscow is considerably more accommodating, and except that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, in a speech in New York the night before that was widely advertised as a restatement of basic United States policy, had said Washington was ready to dispatch experts to the Soviet Union with advice and technical assistance on overhauling the Soviet economy.
Perhaps Mr. Quayle hadn't got the message from the Baker speech, or perhaps he had got it, didn't like it and decided to challenge it.
If either of those hypotheses is true, it shows a disarray in the Administration that goes considerably beyond recent conflicts involving the environment and a program that provides expanded medical benefits for the elderly.
American policy toward the Soviet Union is, after all, the linchpin of American foreign policy in general; most people would say it is not a fit subject for an open argument between two senior officials, both of whom supposedly speak in the name of President Bush.
The Washington Times, one of the few Eastern newspapers to pay much attention to Mr. Quayle's remarks, quoted an aide as saying Mr. Quayle was playing ''the bad cop'' against Mr. Baker's ''good cop,'' and said his comments constituted a direct rebuttal to the Secretary of State's speech in New York.
But there is another possibility. Mr. Quayle was chosen by Mr. Bush as his running mate primarily to reassure the conservative wing of the Republican Party, which has always suspected Mr. Bush of being a closet moderate. Perhaps Mr. Quayle's statements were intended by the White House as further reassurance that Mr. Bush is ''reliable'' whatever Mr. Baker might have to say.
If that is the case, it opens the Administration to charges of cynically playing penny-ante politics in a highly sensitive policy area.
David Beckwith, Mr. Quayle's press secretary, failed to return telephone calls seeking clarification of the Vice President's motiviation.
After the earthquake Tuesday evening, Mr. Quayle returned to Northern California, where he inspected the damage from a helicopter, visited the hard-hit Marina district near the Golden Gate Bridge and then met with officials in Alameda County, east of San Francisco, to discuss the need for Federal assistance. Mayor Art Agnos of San Francisco, a Democrat, said he planned to meet the Vice President later.
But Mr. Quayle never showed up for their conference, prompting Mr. Agnos to issue this criticism: ''I understand he was in the Marina and in the shelters and then left. If he did so without visiting the Mayor, I have real questions about what he was doing here. It may have been just a publicity stunt.''
By today the Vice President was back in Washington to meet with Mr. Bush. Asked about the Mayor's comment, he replied, ''I think that's very unfortunate to take that kind of shot at a very difficult time. I was there to help people. We're going to make sure we do the best that we can to help the people in San Francisco.''
The White House defended Mr. Quayle, asserting that Mr. Agnos had declined an invitation to join a group of small-city mayors meeting with the Vice President. But it also announced that Mayor Agnos was one of the officials who would accompany Mr. Bush on his visit on Friday.
