HEADLINE: THE CALIFORNIA QUAKE: COMMERCE;
Businesses in Bay Area Hope for a Quick Return To Life Almost as Usual

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 19

 BODY:
It was business almost as usual today in the Bay Area as the banks opened for business, the hotels began restocking food and the computer chip producers operated at full speed.
To be sure, some problems remained. Many office buildings in San Francisco were still shut, awaiting the full restoration of power. Lines for gasoline formed at some service stations. 
But less than 48 hours after Northern California was shaken by a strong earthquake, economists and company spokesmen said they were optimistic that the long-range impact on private businesses would not be large.
They acknowledged that the closing of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge will make their employees' commutes more difficult. But they said they do not anticipate problems with either receiving materials or shipping products out of the area. They also noted that with the exception of Santa Cruz, near the epicenter of the quake, and the Marina district in San Francisco, the greatest physical damage was to public property.
 
'Snap Back Quickly'
''We were sort of comforted when we sat down and added things up,'' said Frank McCormick, vice president and senior economist for the Bank of America. ''So much of the area survived so well that the damage is relatively limited,'' he said. ''I expect the economy to snap back quickly.''
Mr. McCormick said the reconstruction of the Bay Bridge and the collapsed section of the Nimitz Freeway in Oakland will be ''a boon to private companies contracted to do the work.''
''There will probably actually be an increase in hiring in the Bay Area and an increase in wage income,'' he said, although he added that this will be offset by the loss in private wealth caused by damage to homes and small businesses.
The contrast in mood with a day earlier was marked. On Wednesday the lines of ashen-faced tourists awaiting airport buses outside darkened hotels seemed to bode ill for the city's tourism. But today tourist industry officials said they were confident that business levels would return to normal fairly quickly.
 
Some Cancellations at Hotels
''There was a mass exodus yesterday,'' said S. Dale Hess, vice president of public affairs for the San Francisco Convention and Visitors Bureau. ''We've got a lot of cancellations in the hotels,'' he said. But while three or four conventions have been canceled, at least one is still on, and the hotels are all up and running again, he said.
''We're going to have our ups and downs between now and the end of the year,'' Mr. Hess said. ''Some people are jittery and will use the quake as an excuse to do something different.''
''But then it will fade,'' he added. ''In the long run this doesn't affect our ability to be a major tourist attraction.''
He said the Gray Line's bus tours of the city would resume Friday. The Red and White Fleet's Bay Cruise service continues, he said, although with reduced frequency because some of its boats have been pressed into service as ferries between San Francisco and Oakland. The cable cars are operational but not running because traffic signals remain out along their routes. The San Francisco Symphony will perform as scheduled Friday night, although tonight's performance was canceled.
The high-technology Silicon Valley, to the south of San Francisco, emerged relatively unscathed, even though it was closer to the center of the quake.
The major semiconductor fabrication plants were all running by Wednesday, having shut down for only one or two shifts immediately after the quake hit. The three leading computer chip companies all said they anticipated no problems in receiving materials or shipping finished products.
 
'We Were Lucky'
''We were lucky in that Silicon Valley's buildings are really new, the vast majority less than 15 years old and many newer than that,'' said John Greenagel, a spokesman for Advanced Micro Devices in Sunnyvale. ''They're built not only to earthquake codes, but also to avoid vibration altogether,'' he said. ''They're more like bomb shelters.''
In fact, the fabrication plants fared better than office structures. Barbara Krause, a spokeswoman for Apple Computer, said the company was able to take orders and build and ship products and parts as usual. But she said some administrative buildings suffered structural damage, either from the quake itself or from sprinkler systems activated by the quake.
Nor did the quake cause any serious shutdowns in computer systems. Wells Fargo & Company said its computers, in downtown San Francisco, were up by 1 A.M. on Wednesday morning. About 92 percent of Wells Fargo's automatic teller machines were operating today. The only ones still down are in hard-hit areas, like Santa Cruz and the financial district of San Francisco.
The Bank of America, a subsidiary of BankAmerica Corporation, said all but 10 of its branches are open, and all systems are up and working. About 1,250 of the bank's 1,500 California automatic tellers are working.
Ron Supinski, a spokesman for the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, said that cash remained available after the quake, but that banks had difficulty getting armed carriers Wednesday because of a lack of drivers. ''We get a sense of urgency from banks who want to have enough money for weekend openings,'' he said. ''But we get no sense of a critical situation in the supply of currency. Most of these banks have their own cash vaults.''
And although motorists in some areas experienced lines at gas stations, the Chevron Corporation said shortages were limited to areas where closed or damaged roads have caused limited access. The company's refinery, across the bay from San Francisco in Richmond, and its pipelines throughout the Bay Area are operating at normal capacity.

HEADLINE: About Real Estate;
Builder's Plan Cuts Down Payments

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

 BODY:
One factor holding back home ownership in New York City, as in other parts of the country, is the difficulty many would-be buyers have in amassing enough savings for a down payment.
Now Martin Berman, a Staten Island developer and a principal in B&B Builders, has found a way around the problem by borrowing a technique from the big commercial real estate deal makers in New York City: He is offering land leases.
By offering to sell a house alone, and rent the land under the house to the buyer, he hopes to lower the down payment to a level more people can afford.
''The down payment is the biggest problem we have in the first-home market,'' said Mr. Berman, whose development, called Estates at Oakwood, is at Clark Avenue and Amber Street in the Richmond/Oakwood section of Staten Island. 
''We have two-income couples walking through the door that have earnings of $75,000,'' he said, ''but they haven't been able to accumulate a down payment. They've been paying very steep rents in the city and money has been flying out the door for them.''
Instead of selling house and land together for $150,000, Mr. Berman is offering three-bedroom town houses for $90,000 plus an annual land rent of 6.5 percent of the $60,000 price of the land, or $325 a month.
There is a $12,000 difference between the $30,000 down payment needed for a $150,000 house-with-land deal and the $18,000 needed for a $90,000 deal on the house alone. That $12,000 is an important sum for a couple living in one of the most expensive, and therefore most savings-resistant, cities in the country.
Mr. Berman is offering his houses for spring occupancy. Those who lease the land have an option to buy it at any time. The price of the land will be adjusted annually according to the Consumer Price Index, which is generally used to indicate the nation's rate of inflation.
Since land in the city has generally risen in value faster than the rate of inflation, that sounds like a good deal, even though the rent payments on the land are not deductible from taxable income as mortgage payments are.
''I don't have any desire to collect rents on land for 40 years,'' he said. ''We're builders and we want to sell houses, so I assume that the majority of our customers who lease the land will eventually opt to purchase it.''
The builder agreed that the tax logic, for once thing, would certainly encourage a home buyer to acquire the land as soon as possible.
A 10.5 percent, 30-year fixed-rate mortgage of $120,000 on the full price for land and house would cost $1,098 a month, of which about 95 percent, or $12,500 on an annual basis, would be deductible from taxable income in the first years of the mortgage. If the buyer was in the 28 percent bracket, the net monthly cost of carrying the house would be $800.40 after taxes.
For a $78,000 mortgage on the house alone, the monthly payments would be $713 for the loan plus $325 for the land rent. If 95 percent of the $8,556 in annual mortgage costs were deductible as interest, then the net after-tax monthly cost would be $488, plus the land rent, or $813 - more, under this tax scenario, than the cost of the house and the land together. Nevertheless, the deal would make sense for a buyer who could not make the larger down payment.
Estates at Oakwood is a nearly completed development of some 500 one- and two-family houses and town-house rows put up by several builders on former cemetery land - never used for burials, the developers hasten to add. The tract is flanked by the United Hebrew Cemetery to the north and Valhalla Burial Park, also known as Oceanview Cemetery, to the south.
The houses, which have garages, are of traditional colonial design, with clapboard siding and peaked roofs with dormers.
Mr. Berman's three town-house designs follow the clapboard approach, but with brick facing on the ground floor surrounding the entrance and the garage. In the model dwellings completed, the second-floor living rooms have small balconies overlooking the street.
Much of the tract is heavily wooded, and it has been left undeveloped under guidelines of the South Richmond Special Zoning District. The use of dead ends and loop streets adds to the project's rural look.
But dollars-and-cents reality, more than appearance, drives the housing market in today's real estate economy, Mr. Berman said.
''It is no surprise and no secret that we are experiencing a soft market right now,'' he said. ''This land-lease idea is something that we thought about for a number of years, but it was not necessary in the past.''

HEADLINE: We Already Know the Folly of Decriminalized Drugs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It seems to me that the spate of pro-legalization articles that have appeared recently in The Times are founded on a misconception, namely that drug use has not already been decriminalized. Drug use underwent a de facto decriminalization in America some 20 years ago. From the Hollywood celebrity publicly snorting coke at a party to the teen-ager smoking marijuana in front of his high school, Americans have ceased to worry about criminal penalties for drug use. It is the failure of decriminalization that we are living with now. 
Prohibitions against drug use are not founded in some abstract and hypocritical morality, as is often implied. Advocates of legalization seem curiously unable to distinguish gradations in human behavior. The argument that it is impermissible to outlaw drugs because people are legally ''addicted'' to coffee or aspirin is the ludicrous extension of a feeble train of thought. Teen-agers are not prostituting themselves in Times Square to buy another bottle of aspirin, nor are men and women destroying their families for the sake of another cup of coffee. It is not merely the sale and distribution of drugs that is destroying lives. It is the effects of the drugs themselves and the things that people do under their influence that are the real hazards to the lives and happiness of millions of our citizens.
I suggest we try actually enforcing penalties for drug use and see if that has any effect before we give up and turn our society into a drug bazaar. Or possibly we should simply admit what A. M. Rosenthal perceptively argued in his column of Sept. 26, that the lives currently being destroyed by drugs are not lives most Americans consider important. Mr. Rosenthal's analogy of drug use to slavery was a particularly apt one. Slavery was defended by many citizens as being an economic necessity, while abolitionists were ridiculed as moralizing meddlers or naive idealists.
However, even if charity and morality do not compel us to abolish this new form of slavery, prudence should, for we must remember that throughout history the well-off have never succeeded in finding a refuge remote enough to protect them from the results of the injustices they have inflicted upon the poor. Our society is creating a class of slaves who have been stripped by drugs of pity, hope, love, kindness and even fear, and I think that their retribution will eventually fall on all of us.
 
ELIZABETH GESSNER
 New York, Sept. 28, 1989

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Waiting for the Big One

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
''The big one'' has not yet hit the San Francisco Bay Area, the experts tell us, or southern California. That's small comfort to the thousands bereaved or devastated by a 6.9-magnitude earthquake, but it's a clear warning even to those Americans who live nowhere near the San Andreas Fault.
It's a warning for all of us because an earthquake can happen anywhere and is always unexpected by the public - maybe it'll happen next year, or even next month, but not now. In areas not considered earthquake-prone, moreover, citizens are less likely to be prepared and are thus the more vulnerable. 
But there's a practical lesson in the Bay Area disaster, too, particularly in the collapse of the Nimitz Freeway. We need not wait helplessly for the big one; earthquake damage can be reduced significantly by adequate preparation.
More than 60 years ago, Frank Lloyd Wright's Imperial Hotel survived the great Tokyo earthquake, because of a pioneer design that made the structure more flexible than was then customary. This week, skyscrapers in San Francisco merely swayed because they were built, with the San Andreas Fault in mind, on the same flexibility principle.
The Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, 40 miles from San Francisco, reported no damage, owing to an external steel reinforcement system built after an earthquake nine years ago. The Stanford Linear Accelerator Laboratory at Palo Alto also escaped damage, having been built to move in one piece under earthquake pressure, rather than breaking apart.
Some older, perhaps stronger but more rigid buildings collapsed. The Nimitz Freeway, for example, was described by Paul Goldberger of The New York Times as ''nearly prehistoric by today's standards.'' It was built between 1949 and 1954, before earthquake resistance became part of structural design.
Any number of older highways, bridges and public works throughout the nation, like the Nimitz Freeway, are structurally deficient or worn out. Such weaknesses have been amply demonstrated in the collapse of bridges on the New York Thruway, on an Interstate Highway in Connecticut and elsewhere.
Aging infrastructure is a problem in itself - witness the water main breaks that plague New York and other older cities. An earthquake shaking such an unprepared city would cause unimaginable damage to gas mains, sewage systems, underground power and communications lines, ancient bridges and roadways.
Even without natural disasters to accelerate the problem, ''America's infrastructure is crumbling,'' the engineer Frank T. Callahan said in a recent interview with The Times. As president of a design company in Texas, he estimated that more than 40 percent of the nation's bridges are structurally deficient, or obsolete, and that 60 percent of its 2.1 million miles of paved roads require renovation.
A major reason is postponement of maintenance to save money. The Federal Government, for shameful example, has refused to spend an accumulated $29 billion in user fees for highways and other projects, in order to make the budget deficit appear smaller. Growth in its overall maintenance expenditures has been sharply reduced since the 1960's, though the infrastructure to be maintained is older and more extensive now than then.
Mr. Callahan believes that eventually it will cost about $3.3 trillion to solve the infrastructure problems caused by inadequate maintenance spending - a penny-wise but pound-foolish policy, whether or not another earthquake ever shakes a major American city.
That's in addition, of course, to the new and improved facilities - urban services, airports, highways and (I would add) rail lines - that a growing and mobile population inevitably will demand. Nothing is more vital to Americans now or in the future than the redemption, maintenance and expansion of the infrastructure that makes a modern nation-state possible.
It's idle to ask where the money to pay for a vast building and repair program can be found. It's available, of course, in the enormous wealth of America, if only President, Congress, the states - and the public - will decide to spend it that way.
Deficit spending? Yes, but with demonstrable payoff - in jobs, rising purchasing power, decreases in unemployment costs and perhaps in crime, new enterprises, improved technology, the adequacy of the infrastructure and the resulting economic gains, enhanced tax revenues - not to mention earthquake resistance.
I'd call that investment, of the kind that in the Interstate Highway System changed the nation and its economy forever.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Speaking Blasphemy

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
The issue is not perestroika. The issue is not Mikhail Gorbachev.
The issue is how to move above and beyond Soviet Communism, crippled but still struggling to survive, to a free life for all who suffered for so long and still suffer today. The issue is zavtra - tomorrow. 
But through his own brilliance and the mental flabbiness of the West, Mr. Gorbachev has been able to hide those real issues. It is one of his greatest triumphs - and is taking place right now - in the West, while Western leaders and intellectuals cheer, yawn, fawn or stare, uncomprehending.
He has managed to set the agenda, define the issues, proclaim the goal and limit the participants in what should be one of the great political discussions of the 20th century.
''We want perestroika to succeed,'' says Secretary of State James Baker.
He is strewn with petals. At last he seems to be following the path of righteousness as laid out by Mr. Gorbachev and trodden by so many American journalists, academics and politicians, who feel that to stray from it is unpatriotic and blasphemous.
What is perestroika that we should worship it?
Perestroika is not a religion. It is not even a plan. It is a hope - the frantic hope of the Gorbachev Politburo that ways can be found to prevent total economic collapse while making sure the system of state socialism and Communist Party paramountcy survives.
But to hope to put breath into the Communist system, Mr. Gorbachev needs help from the West. He needs to spread Western technological knowledge within the information desert that Communism made of the Soviet Union.
Even more he needs the acquiescence of a people who detest the Communist system for giving them nothing but a bare existence after 70 years of hardship and sacrifice under tyranny.
He and his Politburo opened windows to new thoughts and allowed political and intellectual freedoms greater than anybody had thought possible in the Soviet Union. This permitted the peoples of captive Eastern Europe to strike out for their own freedoms.
For this Mr. Gorbachev has been important to the world. But now this is a key issue: Shall the West commit itself to the Gorbachev tomorrow as long as it envisions the preservation of Communism - a system in which a party and a few men will always control the levers of real power?
To decide that the United States is committed to perestroika, as Mr. Gorbachev defines it, is to decide that the preservation of the Communist system is also the American goal.
That is an obscene thought. Even so, it will not work. Western help would be pouring water into the sand, as Andrei Sakharov put it. The system is too sick, the people's opposition to it too strong.
One argument for strong Western support of Mr. Gorbachev is that something fearful might follow him. That may turn out to be the Gorbachev we are already glimpsing - preventing strikes, calling out the troops, furiously denouncing press criticism.
But yes, it is likely that inside the Soviet system there are far more dangerous men, men who would try to replace Mr. Gorbachev with a return to Stalinism. Certainly, which is exactly why we should listen to the voices of those in the Soviet Union who want neither Stalinism nor Gorbachevism.
They feel in any Communist system there is always the danger of the ''good'' dictator being replaced by the evil dictator - or suddenly turning into one himself. They do not want Communism to be put on an international respirator. They want it to die, so they can breathe free.
The West acts as if these people do not exist - the tens of thousands who spent decades in political jails for speaking of freedom and the men and women in small groups now trying to coalesce into the Democratic Alliance.
Washington and American foundations should be searching out these people, helping them get an audience at home, inviting them to the United States. Americans should have a chance to hear from Soviet citizens who do not think it their duty to save Communism through some kind of reform. Then maybe we won't think that either, Mr. Baker.
The United States certainly should not try to tear down Mr. Gorbachev. If rebellion is mounted against the Communist system he wants to preserve, it will be by his countrymen, not us.
But surely we have one duty - not to ally ourselves against those who have other dreams of how to get from today to tomorrow, and what zavtra should be.

HEADLINE: Plan Would Reassign Power on Land Use

SERIES: CITY CHARTER: THE VOTER'S TURN - FOURTH OF SIX ARTICLES

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Since land is to New York City what oil is to Houston, it is not surprising that changes in the regulation of land use proposed by the Charter Revision Commission have divided planners, developers, environmentalists and many others.
The commission has proposed a system for governing the use of public and private land that mirrors the outline of the current system but with the City Council generally substituting for the Board of Estimate as the final arbiter.
There are some differences, though, and opponents say they represent major flaws in the charter plan. The commission and its supporters contend that the proposal would improve the way the city oversees the use of its most precious resource. 
Most land-use and zoning initiatives currently go through a public review known as ULURP, an awkward acronym for Uniform Land-Use Review Procedure. Community boards first take an advisory vote on most proposals, after which the initiatives go to the Planning Commission. Then the Board of Estimate takes final action, approving, disapproving or modifying the proposals. The Planning Commission has seven members, all appointed by the mayor. The Board of Estimate includes the three citywide officials - the mayor, Council president and comptroller - and the five borough presidents.
 
New Commission
The charter commission has proposed abolishing the board and giving most of its major zoning and land-use powers to the Council. The plan also calls for the creation of a new 13-member planning commission, with seven members appointed by the mayor, one by the Council president and one by each borough president.
Under the proposal, many zoning and land-use matters would be reviewed by the planning commission and would then go automatically to the Council for final action. These would include zoning changes, urban-renewal plans and the sale of some city-owned residential property.
Other matters, particularly the selection of sites for incinerators, shelters for the homeless and other municipal projects, would be reviewed by the planning commission and then would go to the Council only under limited circumstances. If the affected borough president and community board objected to the planning commission's decision, they could appeal it to the Council. The Council could also decide on its own, by a majority vote, to review a planning commission decision.
The new charter would also require the planning commission to devise rules to assure that neighborhoods receive their fair share of city projects, both desired ones like playgrounds and libraries and unwanted ones like jails and drug-rehabilitation centers.
Each year, the mayor would provide a new citywide ''statement of needs'' that would list all proposed city projects and indicate in which boroughs they would be placed.
Borough presidents could then propose specific sites for the projects slated for their boroughs. If the mayor later chose a different site, his proposal would require approval by 9 of the 13 members of the new planning commission, two more than an ordinary majority.
The goal is to foster compromise and avoid the passionate, divisive debates that have accompanied proposals for AIDS centers, shelters, incinerators and other municipal uses in recent years.
Proponents of the revised charter contend that it strikes a fine balance. The Council would resolve major or controversial land-use decisions, but it would not be overwhelmed by thousands of less significant matters that the much smaller Board of Estimate now resolves.
''The Council has to be policy oriented or solving political controversy,'' said Eric Lane, the charter commission's executive director. ''If you would give the Council all these decisions, they would either pay no attention to each item, or there would be log rolling all over the place.''
 
Questions of Democracy
The land-use proposals are being opposed passionately by people divided into two camps. One faction contends that it is not democratic enough because too many matters would be decided solely by the planning commission, an appointed body.
The other asserts that the plan would be too democratic. Too many elected officials, or their representatives on the planning commission, would get to rule on zoning and land use, they say, making it difficult to get disputed projects approved.
Critics in the first group think all land-use matters should go to the Council for final action. ''That's the critical issue,'' said Marcy Benstock of the Clean Air Campaign.
Ms. Benstock and other environmentalists contend that the mayor, with seven appointees, would dominate the new planning commission. They also argue that the City Council would not often take jurisdiction over difficult land-use issues if it could avoid doing so.
 
Loss of Perspective
''You're giving one person, the mayor, control over all the real estate in the city,'' Ms. Benstock said.
Other opponents, including some planners and developers, say the proposal would give the Council too much power over land use, encouraging parochialism. They say a large political body like the Council would find itself unable to approve the municipal projects that answer citywide needs but are opposed by neighborhoods.
''The concern is that it's going to be impossible to get anything done,'' said Willa Appel, executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council.
''What has happened essentially is that the citywide perspective in land use has been pretty much eliminated,'' said Ms. Appel, who contrasted the proposed charter with the current government structure, in which the mayor appoints the entire Planning Commission, and the three citywide officials have a 6-to-5 voting majority on the Board of Estimate. (Each citywide official has two votes, and the borough presidents have one each.) 'Localized and Parochial'
''We don't want to be critical of the Council, but by its nature it is a different body,'' Ms. Appel said. ''Members represent their local constituencies, and their concerns are by nature going to be more localized and parochial. For a city to function, you've got to be able to site facilities that people don't want, and that includes low-income housing and jails and sanitation facilities.''
Mr. Lane, the commission's executive director, said major or controversial proposals would be decided by the Council, and less politically charged matters would be resolved by the planning commission, whose membership would be more diverse.
''We have democratized the planning commission a certain amount without politicizing it entirely,'' he said.
Mr. Lane said he believed the Council would be able to withstand local pressures and would decide where to place undesired projects. ''We have faith in the democratic process,'' he said. ''We think the Council will want to make the city work.''
 
NEXT: Other new committees, boards and reporting requirements that are part of the proposed charter.

HEADLINE: WEEKENDER GUIDE

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:

'IMAGES OF HAITI'
The culture, politics and people of Haiti are the subject of a film and video series this weekend at Hunter College, Lexington Avenue and 68th Street, in Room 615 of the West Building. This three-day ''Images of Haiti'' festival, presented by the Haiti Support Committee, will include more than 20 rarely seen works made in English and French from the 1930's to the 80's. It will open tonight at 7:30 with ''The Comedians,'' a 1967 movie by Peter Glenville (starring Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor) based on Graham Greene's novel about life under the former Haitian dictator Francois (Papa Doc) Duvalier. Tomorrow and Sunday, there will be 10 programs, at 11 A.M. and at 1:30, 3:30 (3:45 on Sunday), 6 and 8:30 P.M., each of which will include several short films. Highlights include Maya Deren's ''Divine Horsemen,'' a dreamlike 1951 study of voodoo (tomorrow at 11 A.M. and Sunday at 8:30 P.M.); Jonathan Demme's ''Dreams of Democracy,'' a 1988 musical documentary (to be shown tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. with a Barbara Walters interview of Duvalier), and Jacques Godbout's ''North-South Monologue,'' which examines Haiti's economic relationship with the United States (tomorrow at 3:30 P.M.). Admission is $5 the first time and $3 thereafter except tonight, when the $10 admission includes refreshments. Information: 781-5157. 
 
HUDSON GUILD BOOK FAIR
Books by the tens of thousands, at a fraction of their original cover price, are for sale this weekend at the annual Hudson Guild Book Fair, at 441 West 26th Street. The fair, which benefits the many programs of this Chelsea social-service agency and settlement house, will include hard covers and paperbacks, records and foreign-language books, at prices ranging from $2 to $5 (except for a few more-costly first editions and books signed by their authors). Hours are 1 to 8 P.M. today, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. tomorrow and noon to 5 P.M. on Sunday. Admission is free. Information: 760-9800.
 
CLASSIC ARCHITECTURE
The work of Alexander Jackson Davis - the 19th-century American architect who designed the state capitols of Illinois, Indiana, North Carolina and Ohio, and the lower Manhattan Greek Revival structure now known as Federal Hall National Memorial - is explored in an exhibition at Federal Hall that will remain on view through Dec. 29. The show includes about 60 drawings, lithographs, photographs and manuscripts relating to the public buildings and residences that Davis designed between the 1820's and the 70's, as well as his studies of antique Greek architecture. The exhibition, in the building's rotunda, is presented by Historic Hudson Valley, an upstate preservation group. Hours are 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., Mondays through Fridays. Admission is free. Federal Hall is at 26 Wall Street. Information: 264-8711.
 
Saturday
 
INTERNATIONAL DANCE
A round-the-world tour of ethnic dance will be offered at the Brooklyn Y.W.C.A. on Saturday at 7 P.M., when the Y holds its eighth annual International Dance Festival. Spanish flamenco will be performed by Manolo Rivera, a dancer with the New York City Opera, while jigs, reels and strathspeys will be danced by the Royal Scottish Country Dance Society. Other participants will be the Paik Jung Min Dance Troupe doing Korean flower, mask and fan dances; members of the Young People's Chinese Cultural Center doing chopstick dances, and performances by the Ballet Folklorico Mexicano de Nueva York, the Limbora Slovak Folk Ensemble and the Brooklyn-based African-dance company the Calabash Dance Theater. The Y is at 30 Third Avenue in downtown Brooklyn. Tickets are $10, or $5 for children, students and the elderly. Tickets for an additional $5 entitle holders to a meet-the-artist champagne reception after the performance. Information: (718) 875-1190.
 
COLDEN CENTER SEASON
The violinist Pinchas Zukerman, accompanied by the pianist Marc Neikrug, will open the 28th season of the Colden Center for the Performing Arts at Queens College on Saturday night at 8:30. The concert's far-reaching program is to include Stravinsky's ''Suite Italienne,'' Beethoven's Sonata No. 10 in G and Toru Takemitsu's ''From Far Beyond Chrysanthemums and November Fog,'' as well as several works by Robert Fuchs. Tickets are $17 and $15. During its seven-month season, the center will also present Andre-Michel Schub, on Nov. 11; Andre Watts, on Jan. 6; Jean-Pierre Rampal, on Feb. 24; the Kronos Quartet, on May 6, and the Los Angeles Philharmonic, on May 19. Colden Center is near Exits 23 and 24 of the Long Island Expressway in Flushing. Information: (718) 793-8080.
 
CENTRAL PARK HOEDOWN
Country life New York City-style will be featured during a free ''harvest festival'' in Central Park on Saturday from noon to 4 P.M. This fall hoedown at the 72d Street Band Shell will include square dancing to music by the Fretted Instruments School of Music, country music, and free hayrides through the park, as well as apples, pumpkins and cider for children. Information: 360-1330.
 
MUSIC OF COLUMBUS'S TIME
Late-medieval Celtic folk music from Galicia, in northwestern Spain, will be heard at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, on Saturday at 8 P.M. The Milladoiro Group, a seven-member ensemble that performs traditional and modern Galician, Irish and British music, will focus on music that might have been played at the time of Christopher Columbus's first voyage in 1492. The group uses such ancient and modern instruments as the ocarina, hurdy-gurdy, harp, bagpipes, Celtic harp and bouzouki. Tickets are $15 and $10. Information: 662-2133.
 
Sunday
 
INDIAN FESTIVAL OF LIGHTS
In the epic Indian tale the Ramayana, the Hindu god Vishnu is reincarnated as Lord Rama and saves his people from the forces of evil. This legendary drama is traditionally celebrated in India with the annual Deepavali Festival, or Festival of Lights. Two years ago, this festive tradition was brought to New York by the Association of Indians in America, and on Sunday from noon to 7:30 P.M., the third Asian Indian Deepavali Festival will again be held at the South Street Seaport. Indian music and dance will be performed outdoors throughout the day, while traditional crafts and cooking will be demonstrated on the Seaport's plazas and piers. Children may take elephant rides at Burling Slip and paint a 12-foot effigy of the evil 10-headed king Ramana. A film on India will be shown in the Seaport's Trans-Lux Theater at 3:30 P.M. The festival will culminate in a fireworks display at 7 P.M. All events are free, except for the movie, which costs $5.25; $4.25 for children. Information: 669-9424.

 BODY:

International
South Africa reached an agreement with its creditor banks to defer repayment of $8 billion of its foreign debt. Bankers said the action was inevitable, but some of South Africa's critics reacted with surprise and outrage. [Page D1.] Leaders of the Commonwealth searched for new ways to put pressure on Pretoria. [D6.] Bankers said they had little choice but to defer payments because of an approaching deadline. [D6.] 
 
The Economy
Consumer prices rose a modest 0.2 percent in September, cut-ting the nation's inflation rate so far this year to the same 4.4 percent posted for 1988. [D1.] Social Security recipients will receive a 4.7 percent increase in January, the largest annual cost-of-living adjustment in seven and a half years. [D5.]
House and Senate budget negotiators began reconciling major differences in their plans for reducing the budget deficit. [D17.]
 
 
 
Markets
Stock prices moved up broadly, reacting to encouraging inflation news and to indications that the Fed may be willing to allow interest rates to fall further. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 39.55 points, or 1.5 percent, to 2,683.20, after briefly trading above 2,700. [D1.] Shares sold short and not yet covered fell 4.3 percent on the Big Board in the four-week period ended Oct.13. [D16.]
Investment bankers postponed a $220 million ''junk bond'' offering, and bankers at another firm sweetened the offer on a $475 million issue to attract reluctant investors. [D6.]
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved generally higher, buoyed by a better-than-expected report on inflation. [D12.]
Signs of a large Soviet purchase of corn pulled futures prices up sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade. [D13.] The dollar finished mixed against major foreign currencies. [D13.]
 
 
 
Companies
British Airways will not participate in a buyout of UAL at this time, its chairman said. [D1.] Japanese bank officials said they were taking a deliberate approach on whether to help finance takeovers in the U.S. [D2.]
MCA and Paramount are planning a fifth television network, industry executives said. [D1.]
A.T.&T. reported a 19 percent increase in third-quarter net, but four regional Bell telephone companies had mixed results. [D1.]
American Express reported increases of more than 20 percent in its third-quarter revenue and operating profit. [D3.]

B.A.T. shareholders overwhelmingly approved the company's plan to sell some $6 billion worth of operations and to buy back as much as 10 percent of its stock. [D4.]
Warner has asked for a preliminary injunction in a Los Angeles Court that would stop two producers from working for Sony. [D17.]
Ford will discontinue imports of the Scorpio luxury sports sedans from West Germany because of poor sales. [D4.]
Pioneer Electronics will pay $200 million for Discovision Associates, a laser audio and video technology company. [D4.]

HEADLINE: A.T.&T.'s Income Rises 19%; 'Baby Bell' Profits Are Mixed

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

 BODY:
Reflecting the continued strong growth in long-distance calling, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday reported a 19 percent increase in its third-quarter earnings.
But four of the regional ''Baby Bell'' telephone companies reported mixed results for the third quarter.
Net income fell 14.8 percent at the Nynex Corporation, 8.9 percent at U S West Inc. and 12.6 percent at the Pacific Telesis Group. Still, it rose 6.5 percent at the Bell Atlantic Corporation. 
A.T.&T., the nation's largest long-distance company, said it had earned $699 million, or 65 cents a share, in the third quarter, compared with $587 million, or 55 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose about 1 percent, to $8.9 billion from $8.8 billion.
Analysts said A.T.&T.'s increase in earnings was in line with their estimates and reflected the high growth and operating margins of the $50 billion long-distance telephone industry. A.T.&T.'s two main competititors, the MCI Communications Corporation and the U S Sprint Communications Company, have also reported substantially higher earnings for the third quarter.
A.T.&T.'s shares gained 87.5 cents yesterday to close at $43.375 on the New York Stock Exchange. The analysts predicted that A.T.&T. would earn about 65 cents a share in the fourth quarter, $2.50 a share for 1989 and $3.05 for 1990.
A.T.&T. said sales of long-distance services had risen 6.4 percent and calling volume had risen 5 percent in the third quarter, mainly because of an increase in business and international calling. The company said revenue growth from pay telephones, operator services and residential customers slowed in the quarter because of increasing competition from other companies. But it said higher revenues from installation, maintenance and finance services had contributed to the quarter's increase.
A.T.&T.'s product sales fell 3.6 percent in the quarter, mainly reflecting low demand for network-switching equipment, price competition and strikes at some regional Bell companies, A.T.&T. said.
The company also said price cuts on some telecommunications products had reduced profit margins. A.T.&T.'s operating margin was 13 percent in the quarter, compared with 11 percent in the 1988 quarter. Operating income rose 18 percent as a result of an increase in service revenues and a decrease in the cost of service. Expenses as a percentage of revenue held constant at about 35 percent, A.T.&T. said.
''While these earnings are strong, they are also a mixed bag,'' said Jack Grubman, an analyst with Paine Webber Inc. ''It is very rare these days that a blue-chip stock would have earnings up 18 percent. That is due mainly to the strong growth in long-distance, which we expect to continue. But when you look at their products sales, it's a different, disturbing, horrible story.''
A.T.&T. also announced yesterday that it would offer a sweetened pension plan to encourage early retirements. It said the plan would double to 34,000 the number of managers eligible to retire with pension payments. Managers who retire before Dec. 30 will receive an additional 15 percent on their monthly pension for up to five years or until they reach age 65.
 
Nynex
Nynex, which serves New York and New England, said its net income fell to $288.7 million, or $1.47 a share, in the third quarter, compared with $338.9 million, or $1.72 a share, in the 1988 period. Revenue rose 4 percent, to $3.31 billion, from $3.18 billion.
Nynex attributed the earnings decline to ''significantly higher Federal and state taxes and higher interest costs.'' It said its expenses had risen $119 million because of costs associated with acquisitions and growth in its nonregulated operations.
Also, Nynex said, a strike by 60,000 employees had reduced installations of telephone service.
''Our net income is not where we would want it to be at this point,'' said William C. Ferguson, Nynex's chairman. ''This deviation from our past growth patterns is caused largely by lower earnings at New York Telephone. A continued softness in the New York City area economy and intensifying competition, particularly in the private-line market, have had an impact on earnings.''
Nynex's shares gained $1.625 to close at $81.125.
 
U S West
U S West, which provides local service to states in the Rocky Mountain region, said its profits fell to $258.1 million, or $1.39 a share, in the third quarter, compared with $283.2 million, or $1.55 a share, in the 1988 quarter. Revenue fell 4.3 percent, to $2.32 billion from $2.43 billion.
Jack MacAllister, chairman and chief executive, said the 1989 third-quarter results were not fully comparable with last year's results because of a one-time charge resulting from a rate settlement in Minnesota.
U S West's shares gained 75 cents to close at $71.25.
 
Bell Atlantic
Bell Atlantic, based in Philadelphia, said its earnings had risen to $363.2 million, or $1.82 a share, in the third quarter, compared with $341 million, or $1.72 a share, in the 1988 quarter. Revenue rose 5.6 percent, to $2.9 billion, from $2.8 billion a year earlier.
Raymond W. Smith, chairman and chief executive, attributed the earnings increase to strong growth in business access lines and telephone use. Mr. Smith said improvements at Bell Atlantic's unregulated businesses, like cellular mobile telephones, financial services and real estate, had added to the growth.
Bell Atlantic's shares gained $1.50 to close at $100.625.
 
Pacific Telesis
Pacific Telesis, based in San Francisco, said that its third-quarter earnings fell to $278 million, or 68 cents a share, compared with $318 million, or 75 cents a share, in the 1988 quarter. Revenue slipped slightly to $2.37 billion from $2.38 billion.
Sam Ginn, chairman and chief executive, said the company's cellular phone unit had experienced sharp growth and contributed $16 million to the third-quarter profits, compared with $5 million in the 1988 quarter.
Pacific Telesis's shares gained 87.5 cents to close at $45.50.

HEADLINE: Pretoria and Banks In $8 Billion Debt Pact

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 19

 BODY:
In what the Government described as one of its most significant achievements this year, South Africa and foreign banks have reached an agreement to defer repayment of a large part of the country's debt.
Bankers said the action was inevitable, but some of South Africa's critics reacted with surprise and outrage.
The governor of the South African Reserve Bank, Chris Stals, disclosed today that $8 billion in Western bank loans due next June would be refinanced.
 
Credibility Restored
The announcement suggested that South Africa had restored its credibility among bankers, and it appeared timed to coincide with the Commonwealth summit meeting in Malaysia, at which sanctions against Pretoria are being discussed.
At the Commonwealth meeting, Prime Minister Bob Hawke of Australia proposed a plan today to intensify financial pressure on South Africa, calling for banks to impose tougher conditions on day-to-day trading loans, limiting the term of the loans to 90 days. He also called for the International Monetary Fund to explore a supportive financial package for Pretoria dependent on structural political reform. 
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said financial inducements could help persuade Pretoria to make needed changes.
At the same meeting, Canadian officials suggested that the Commonwealth hold off on new sanctions for six months to encourage Pretoria to release Nelson Mandela, the black political leader, lift a four-year-old state of emergency and pass legislation to dismantle apartheid.
Anti-apartheid leaders had hoped that the outstanding loans would make the Government of the white minority vulnerable to economic pressure from the West. Critics of South Africa have been urging Western bankers to call in the loans, seeking to precipitate a reprise of the financial crisis that developed in 1985 when banks demanded that up to $14 billion be repaid.
In response to the debt announcement, Anglican Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu said today that while he needed expert advice to study the full implications, he thought that the banks had colluded with the Government to help it escape pressure.
''I deplore the collaboration of the banks with the evil system prevailing in South Africa,'' Archbishop Tutu said. ''They give capitalism a bad name and as they close off peaceful avenues for bringing about fundamental change in South Africa, they increase the prospects of violence.''
In Washington, Representative Howard Wolpe, Democrat of Michigan, chairman of the subcommittee on Africa, said in an interview: ''I'm very disappointed with response of the banking community. This action represents an enormous boost for the defenders of apartheid. At the time that pressure is being mounted to bring about negotiations, this action is taken that substantially reduces that pressure.''
In a series of meetings with the bankers in Western Europe and the United States over the last two months, Mr. Stals and other officials negotiated what is effectively a three-and-a-half-year extension of the loans that are due in June 1990. The officials were believed to have cited President F. W. de Klerk's recent promises of political change to persuade the bankers that punitive measures were unnecessary.
Finance Minister Barend J. du Plessis called the refinancing by Mr. Stals and his team ''one of the most important events in South Africa this year, especially as far as the economy is concerned.''
Under the agreement, South Africa will repay $1.5 billion to lender banks over three and a half years from June 1990 to December 1993. This amounts to 20.5 percent of the $8 billion in the ''net'' of loans affected by a freeze of South Africa's debt liability. The net refers to a freeze on loans that could not automatically be rolled over because of Western economic sanctions.
Repayment of the remaining $6.5 billion will not have to be negotiated until 1994. South Africa reportedly owes an additional $12 billion in loans not directly affected by the freezes. Of that amount, at least half is estimated to have been converted from short-term credits to longer-term obligations.
 
Longer Deferment Than Expected
One economist here said he was surprised that the Government managed to get a 42-month extension, since the expectation was that the banks would grant no more than a year.
According to information from the United Nations Commission on Transnational Corporations, made available by the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa, South Africa owes $21 billion over all, of which $14.5 billion is commercial bank debt.
The two United States banks that were on the committee that negotiated the deal with South Africa are the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation and J. P. Morgan & Company. A spokesman for Citicorp said it was not on the committee. Citibank is not part of the new $8 billion rescheduling agreement. That is because in 1987, during the last rescheduling, Citibank converted its short-term credits to 10-year loans.
The chairman of the committee is National Westminster Bank. Other European banks on the committee are: Barclays, Standard Chartered, Credit Lyonnais, Banque Indosuez, Dresdner Bank, Deutsche Bank, Commerzbank, Credit Suisse, the Swiss Bank and United Bank of Switzerland.
In his statement today, Mr. du Plessis stressed that the phased repayment of the $1.5 billion in loans maturing next June would still be painful.
''All South Africans must realize that the country faces tough times in the next four years in which we have to repay $8 billion in foreign debt,'' Mr. du Plessis said. ''It is an unnatural state of affairs having to export such a large amount of capital to repay debts,'' he said, referring to the nation's total liability.
''The only way South Africa could deal with the issue is to follow very strict monetary and fiscal policies in an attempt to maximize growth within these restrictive parameters,'' the Finance Minister said.
He did not say what these policies would be, but they seemed likely to include further curbs on Government and consumer spending and new surcharges on imports. South Africa's inflation rate exceeds 15 percent and its prime rate for loans rose earlier this week to 21 percent. Its economic problems are not caused exclusively by Western sanctions but reflect outside factors like the drop in the world price of gold, an important export. So far, South Africa has managed to repay its debts, in good part because it continues to run a trade surplus with the rest of the world.
 
First Payments Modest
The new arrangement is structured so that the first installments of the $1.5 billion to be repaid will be relatively modest, because $2 billion more in foreign loans outside the net will be due in the first six months of 1990. Mr. Stals said this repayment would increase total debt liability next year by only $100 million.
The subsequent installments will double to 3 percent of the total principal every six months as the pressure of other loans declines, with a last installment of 1.5 percent due in December 1993.
South Africa has an additional $7 billion to $9 billion in loans maturing outside the net during the agreement, according to Nallie Bosman, the managing director of the United Bank here. Mr. Bosman was quoted by the South African Press Association as estimating that about $2.5 billion a year would have to be repaid in this period.
Mr. Stals did not disclose the rate of interest South Africa would pay on the maturing loans after their extension, but he and Mr. du Plessis said nothing to indicate that it would be substantially higher.
 
Strain on the Country
The refusal of some Western banks to renew their loans to South Africa in 1985 imposed severe strains on the country's balance of payments. The South African rand fell sharply against the dollar. The Government declared a four-month moratorium on debt repayment and the stock and foreign exchanges had to close for four days. The crisis precipitated a capital outflow amounting to $11 billion over the next four years.
With this lesson, South African officials have tried to diminish the country's vulnerability. Mr. du Plessis told Parliament in May that South Africa had reduced its total foreign debt in real terms from $24 billion in September 1985 to $18.5 billion at the end of 1988.
''I am relieved we no longer face a crisis in June 1990, but this does not mean there is less pressure on the balance of payments,'' Mr. Stals said tonight. ''We will meet our new commitments as we did the previous ones - with difficulty.''

HEADLINE: Dow Rises By 39.55 in Wide Gain

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stock prices moved up sharply yesterday as traders reacted to encouraging inflation news and to indications that the Federal Reserve might be willing to allow interest rates to fall further.
On the second anniversary of the 1987 stock market crash, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 39.55 points, or 1.5 percent, to 2,683.20, and encouraged some traders to believe the market was ready to make a prolonged recovery. For a few minutes after 3 P.M., the Dow was up more than 60 points, above 2,700.
The bellwether indicator had plunged more than 190 points on Friday before bouncing back 88 points on Monday. On Tuesday, it lost only about 18 points and gained almost 5 points Wednesday. 
 
Volume Advances
Volume on the Big Board rose to 198.1 million shares, from 166.9 million shares on Wednesday.
While the increase in the Dow was less than half that on Monday, yesterday's rise was far more broadly based, with 1,235 shares advancing on the New York Stock Exchange and 355 falling.
The strength extended to secondary issues. On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index gained 4.74 points, to 382.81. In over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index jumped 7.52, to 470.80.
Traders said that when the Federal Reserve Bank executed four-day matched sales yesterday, and thereby drained reserves from the banking system, the Federal funds rate remained at 8.75 percent instead of rising. They said the market immediately interpreted this as a signal that the central bank was tolerating a further decline of credit beyond the easing it extended when the stock market fell.
 
C.P.I. Lower Than Expected
The Department of Labor reported that the Consumer Price Index for September was up two-tenths of 1 percent, less than the expected four-tenths of 1 percent. At the same time, inflation-adjusted earnings rose three-tenths of 1 percent.
''The lower-than-expected C.P.I., aided by a strong bond market and program trading activity, pushed the market to new post-Friday-the-13th recovery highs,'' said Jack Barbanel, president of First Global Management of Princeton, N.J.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 5.37, to 347.13, while the Big Board composite index added 2.85, to 192.17.
''The C.P.I. was better than expected, which gives some hope that the Fed will ease its monetary policy,'' said Harold A. Mackinney, head of the investment policy committee at the Fleet Financial Group in Providence, R.I. ''There are $350 billion in money market funds, and with interest rates declining, money is looking for a permanent home.''
He said that currently the stock market, as measured by the Dow, was selling at only 11 times earnings. ''This is a modest multiple with the inflation rate only about 4.5 percent,'' he added.
In apparent dividend-capture plays, Puget Sound Power and Light was the most active issue, unchanged at 21 3/8, on a volume of nearly 4.2 million shares.
Dow components with strong gains included Philip Morris, up 1 1/8, to 44 1/2, and A.T.&T., up 7/8, to 43 3/8.
The Dow Jones transportation average dropped 15.64 points, to 1,263.51, as U.A.L., parent of United Airlines, fell 1 5/8, to 190 1/8, while A.M.R., holding company for American Airlines, slipped 5/8, to 73 3/8. Both airline shares fell rapidly early in the week after takeover bids evaporated.
But some other takeover stocks that had suffered showed signs of revival. Walt Disney, the subject of speculation but no bid, jumped 4 points, to 124 1/8, while Holiday, which is restructuring, gained 1 7/8, to 73.
Mr. Barbanel said that ''technology stocks had a particulary good day.'' I.B.M. rose 2 3/8, to 104 1/8, on the announcement of a $1 billion stock buyback plan, while Compaq gained 4 5/8, to 111 1/8, on the news that it was introducing new products.
''The market acted superbly today, benefiting from the low C.P.I. numbers and the feeling that the Federal Reserve will find it easier to loosen credit,'' said Edward P. Nicoski, a technical analyst at Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood in Minneapolis. ''The I.B.M. share repurchase also helped.''
Mr. Nicoski said that there also was a strong belief on the exchange floor that option expirations today would have a positive impact on the market.
In over-the-counter-trading, Valley National, Arizona's largest bank-holding company, plummeted 5 3/4, to 18 1/2. The company said it was suspending its quarterly dividend after taking a write-off to reflect the declining value of its real estate portfolio.

HEADLINE: Prices Rose Modestly Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GRAND ISLAND, Neb., Oct. 19

 BODY:
Consumer prices rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in September, cutting the nation's inflation rate so far this year to the same 4.4 percent posted for 1988, the Labor Department reported today.
Scrutiny of the monthly price data discloses wide regional and local variations, and here in the prairie country, for example, inflation in the last year, as measured by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, is just 3.2 percent. That is more than a full percentage point below the national average.
Last Friday's report of sharply higher producer prices may have contributed to that day's plunge in the stock market. But today's report was somewhat better than expected, and securities markets rallied, with the Dow Jones industrial average ending the day up 39.55 points, or 1.5 percent, at 2,683.20. 
The Government also said today that Social Security payments, which are adjusted for inflation, would rise by 4.7 percent in January, the largest annual cost-of-living increase in seven and a half years. [Page D5.] The Government uses national statistics like the Consumer Price Index to calculate such cost-of-living adjustments, and all recipients nationwide receive the same increase.
But for individuals, their own experience may tell them things are substantially better or worse than what they see on television or read in national publications.
Here in Grand Island, for example, price increases are far below the 5.6 percent inflation rate faced by residents of cities in the Northeast with populations between 50,000 and 500,000.
To be sure, Robert A. Morris, the president of the Overland National Bank here, complains of high property taxes, partly the result of low population. And Vickie Purdy, who works at the Casual Corner apparel chain, says that reasonably priced fresh fish can be unobtainable. But Grand Island residents also know that the cost of housing here bears little relationship to that in big urban centers.
 
Houses Below $50,000
Coad Miller, a salesman for Home Real Estate, said the average price of a house here is less than $50,000. He also said it was easy to find homes that make good investments, with rents exceeding mortgage interest, taxes and insurance.
Housing costs have climbed a scant 1.9 percent during the last 12 months in the Government's sample of small Midwest cities, which covers Fort Dodge, Iowa, and Kennett and Mexico, Mo., in addition to Grand Island. That compares with a 3.7 percent increase for the nation at large.
As for food, you can buy hamburger at the local Econofoods for $1.39 a pound, but Grand Island's advantage over the rest of the nation is rather narrow. But a ticket to a movie at the Conestoga Mall is only $4.25, and inflation in entertainment costs has been 1.3 percent in the last 12 months, compared with 5.4 percent nationally.
Transportation costs have risen at exactly the 3.6 percent national rate. Gasoline prices within a few miles of Interstate 80 are the same as in other regions, and local car dealers keep their prices in line with those in Lincoln and Omaha.
 
Competing With Bigger Cities
Wes Westerby, who manages Cornhusker Toyota, said some of his expenses, like his real estate costs, were low, but he passes those savings along to his customers because, with the ease of travel in the Midwest, they can go elsewhere to shop.
''You've got to compete with the bigger cities,'' he said.
Grand Island is also an example of how extraneous occurrences can affect local inflation rates. Mr. Morris, the banker, said that after a tornado devastated this city of 38,000 in June 1980 there was a rebuilding boom and inflation in the early 1980's did not fall as rapidly here as it did elsewhere.
Today's national figures showed September price movements little changed in most categories, with housing, which accounts for 42 percent of the Consumer Price Index, up by one-tenth of 1 percent, the lowest rise since April.
Nearly two-thirds of last month's inflation was in the price of clothing, reflecting the introduction of fall and winter lines.
 
Vegetable Prices Drop
Food was up two-tenths of 1 percent for the second straight month. The smallest increase this year for cereal and bakery products and a sharp drop in fresh vegetable prices helped offset a 1.4 percent jump in dairy products, the biggest since May 1980.
Transportation costs fell five-tenths of 1 percent, the fourth decline in a row, on a 2.2 percent drop in gasoline prices, lower automobile finance charges and lower prices for both new and used cars.
A 1.7 percent leap in apparel prices, following three straight declines, and a hefty eight-tenths of 1 percent rise in medical costs had a limited effect on the index because the weight of each element in the index is only about 6 percent.
Medical care, however, has now climbed at a 9.2 percent rate during the last three months and 8 percent during the last year.
 
Comparison With Past
The index covering urban consumers now stands at 125. This means that a basket of goods and services that cost $10 in the base period of 1982-84 now costs $12.50.
Before rounding, the index rose 0.1606426 last month, which translates into an annual inflation rate of 1.9 percent.
The index covering all urban wage earners and clerical workers also rose two-tenths of 1 percent in September, bringing the 12-month increase to 4.3 percent.
For Grand Island and the three other small Midwest cities in the survey, the September increase was six-tenths of 1 percent, but a Labor Department official said this was not significant because the series is not adjusted for seasonal variations.

HEADLINE: Japan Banks Turn Cautious on Lending for U.S. Buyouts

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Japanese banking officials have become extremely cautious about making loans for American leveraged buyouts.
Even before British Airways announced that it would not participate, for now, in attempts to buy the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, officials at several major Japanese banks said they were taking a deliberate approach on whether to help finance any new UAL proposal.
After last week's collapse of a proposed $6.75 billion buyout of UAL, the investment group, which included the pilots' union and management of UAL, has been trying to organize another bid at a lower price. A number of banks, including American and Japanese institutions, had balked at the first deal because the interest rates and fees were too low. 
''In principle, if we see a good deal we'll participate on a case-by-case basis,'' said Kirk Yamaguchi, deputy head of the Bank of Tokyo's overseas corporate finance department. ''But to a certain degree it is true that we have become more reluctant. We're being more cautious.''
Mr. Yamaguchi added that his bank, which agreed to lend several hundred million dollars for the first buyout effort, was now sitting on the fence.
Yoh Kurosawa, deputy president of the influential Industrial Bank of Japan, said: ''We are a little fed up with these kinds of deals. We've been more cautious about LBO's in general because we just don't want to build up too heavy an exposure.''
Senior officials at the Ministry of Finance and the Bank of Japan deny putting pressure on the banks to slow their lending to American leveraged buyouts, but they have spoken approvingly in the last few days of the new sense of prudence.
''Banks must carefully weigh risks involved in each case,'' said Satoshi Sumita, governor of the Bank of Japan, at a press briefing. ''Although each bank has the right to make a loan or not, I expect them to fully understand this point and to refrain from extending excessive loans.''
Several banks and Government officials emphasized that this sort of lending had not stopped. For instance, in the recent buyout of NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines, Japanese banks provided nearly 40 percent of the $3.35 billion in bank loans.
The officials and bankers cite a number of reasons for the sudden caution. For one, the banks have seen their loans in this area jump from close to nothing to billions of dollars in the span of a few years. Also, there have been several well-publicized cases recently in which companies that were bought out have had trouble meeting their financial obligations.
To be sure, the Japanese banks are not alone, and they bristle at criticism that they caused the UAL deal or any other transaction to come apart.

LENGTH: 372 words

HEADLINE: COMPANY EARNINGS;
BankAmerica Profit Rises by 33.7%

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Continuing its comeback, the BankAmerica Corporation, one of the nation's largest banks, said yesterday that third-quarter net income rose 33.7 percent, to $254 million, or $1.16 a share, from $190 million, or 97 cents a share, in the corresponding 1988 period.
A. W. Clausen, the bank's chairman, said the big jump in profits was primarily a result of a ''strong performance in the fundamental area of our business, particularly consumer and residential mortgage loans.''
Mr. Clausen had been chairman of BankAmerica through most of the 1970's until 1981, when he left to head the World Bank. Upon his return as chairman in 1986, the San Francisco-based bank was faltering, hurt by delinquencies on mortgage and third world loans, particularly to Brazil, a major borrower. 
 
Cost-Cutting Cited
Analysts attributed the third-quarter rebound in earnings to such things as cost-cutting, new managers hired by Mr. Clausen, and more careful lending. ''The results have been quite impressive,'' said Thomas Brown, first vice president of the Paine Webber Group.
Brazil helped the process. For the third quarter, the bank collected interest income on Brazilian loans of $5 million compared with no payments from Brazil in the 1988 quarter. Nevertheless, Brazilian interest payments that came due but were not paid totaled $70 million for the quarter.
Partly for this reason, BankAmerica increased its provision for credit losses to $170 million, from $110 million in the 1988 quarter. ''There have been rumblings that the Brazilian economy could be in an upward trend, and that sends a hopeful message,'' said Gary F. Hovis, a bank analyst for Argus Research Corporation.
Non-interest income in the third quarter was $462 million, up from $400 million in last year's third quarter. Some $42 million of the $62 million increase came from fees and commissions. At the same time, noninterest expense rose to only $921 million in the quarter compared with $890 million in last year's third quarter.
The various factors, along with increased capital and reserve levels, combined to produce ''strong rates of return of more than 1 percent on average total assets and more than 22 percent on average common equity,'' the bank said.

HEADLINE: Inflation Outpaces Pay

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Workers' earnings rose 3.5 percent in the year ended Sept. 30, failing to keep pace with the rate of inflation in the same period, the Labor Department said today.
With consumer inflation running at a 4.3 percent rate for the 12 months ended in September, real earnings actually fell by eight-tenths of a percent, the department said. 
Real earnings have been falling nearly unchecked since March 1987, mainly because of a shorter average workweek.
As measured in 1977 dollars, average weekly earnings for industrial and service employees fell to $166.83 in September from $168.10 a year ago.
Real earnings fell in many industries in the last year, including construction, manufacturing, transportation, and wholesale and retail trade. These were offset by rising wages in finance, insurance and service industries.
Economists said earnings have been falling because of a gradual shift in the economy to service-sector jobs, where wages are lower on average than in manufacturing and where the workweek is shorter.
In September, average weekly earnings rose by five-tenths of a percent from the prior month, slightly more than the two-tenths of a percent rate of inflation reported by the department earlier today.
Before taking inflation into account, weekly earnings averaged $338.67 in September, compared with $335.04 in August and $327.12 in September 1988, the department said.

HEADLINE: Social Security Payments To Increase 4.7% Next Year

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
The nation's 38.9 million recipients of Social Security payments will receive a 4.7 percent increase in January, the largest annual cost-of-living adjustment in seven and a half years.
The adjustment will increase the average benefit check by $25, to $566 a month, the Social Security Administration said today.
For someone who retires at age 65 in 1990, the maximum monthly benefit will be $975, up from $899 this year. 
 
Reflection of Inflation
The raise, announced after the Labor Department released its consumer price report for September, reflects the inflation rate for urban wage earners and clerical workers from the third quarter of 1988 through the corresponding period this year.
The increase will show up in checks delivered Jan. 3, representing benefits earned for December.
The Government also announced that the maximum amount of earnings subject to the Social Security payroll tax will rise next year to $50,400 from $48,000.
Only about 10.4 million of the 130 million workers subject to the payroll tax had earnings that exceeded the wage base this year, the Social Security Administration said.
All workers and employers, however, face higher payroll taxes next year, since the tax rate rises from 7.51 percent to 7.65 percent, an increase that was approved by Congress in 1977.
The two changes - a higher wage base and a higher tax rate - mean the maximum tax on employees will rise $250.80, to $3,855.60, in 1990. Employers match their workers' contributions.
 
Higher Rate for Self-Employed
Tax rates for the self-employed rise from 13.02 percent this year to 15.30 percent in 1990, when half of the taxes can be deducted as a business expense. The wage base is the same as for other workers.
Next year's increase in benefits will be the biggest since a 7.4 percent raise in July 1982, when high inflation rates produced bigger cost-of-living adjustments. Benefits rose 4 percent in 1989.
The Social Security Administration gave these examples of how the benefit increase will affect average monthly benefits:
* Elderly couple, both getting benefits: up $43, to $966.
* Widowed mother and two children: up $53, to $1,173.
* Elderly widow living alone: up $24, to $522.
* Disabled worker, spouse and children: up $44, to $975.
* All disabled workers: up $24, to $555.
Of the 38.9 million people receiving monthly Social Security benefits, 62 percent are retired workers, 7 percent are disabled workers and 31 percent are spouses or children of retired, disabled or deceased workers.

HEADLINE: Money Fund Assets Surge

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Assets of the nation's 473 money market mutual funds surged by $6.07 billion in the latest week to a record $356.1 billion, reflecting investors' moving out of stocks and into more stable investments after the stock market plunge last Friday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
It was the biggest rise in assets since the week of another large decline in stock prices, Jan. 13, 1988, when assets rose by $7.62 billion. 
The latest influx came as fund assets were already at a record total of $350.03 billion set the previous week. The institute originally reported that figure as $349.37 billion but revised it upward.
Jacob Dreyer, chief economist and senior vice president of the Washington-based mutual fund trade group, attributed the latest rise to investors' seeking safe havens for their money after the Dow Jones industrial average fell 190 points last Friday.
The biggest weekly rise in fund assets, $9.64 billion, came in the week ended Oct. 21, 1987, when the stock market collapsed. The Dow average fell a record 508 points on the Monday of that week.
The institute said that in the latest week, assets of 235 general purpose funds rose $2.53 billion, to $116.56 billion.

HEADLINE: Bankers Say Refinancing Is Needed to Avert Defaults

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
Bankers affiliated with the South Africa debt agreement said yesterday that the main reason the nation's creditors agreed to refinance $8 billion was that the loans were coming due on July 1 and would have to be rescheduled sooner or later.
They said they had negotiated the most onerous repayment terms they could get without forcing the South African Government to default on their loans.
If that had occurred, bankers pointed out, the South African Government would have simply kept the money it had borrowed - an outcome, they said, that would serve neither the anti-apartheid groups nor the banks' purpose. 
''The banks feel they have negotiated as about a tough a deal as they can,'' said one British banker who would speak only if he was not identified. ''As far as the banks' economists are concerned, it is just about tough as it could be without causing South Africa to say, 'We can't sustain those payments.' ''
 
Some Groups Not Impressed
But some anti-apartheid groups were not impressed. ''This was a relatively sweet deal for South Africa,'' said Donna Katzin, director of the South Africa program at the Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility in New York. The agreement was reached, Ms. Katzin said, after only brief negotiations, and eight months before any agreement actually needed to be signed.
Ms. Katzin said by agreeing to the rescheduling now, the banks have undermined the Bush Administration, which had given South Africa until February to put executive changes into effect, and until June to implement parliamentary changes.
''The banks could have waited, but they didn't,'' Ms. Katzin said.
John J. Simone, an executive vice president of Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, said he thought that the agreement was in keeping with the aspirations of the anti-apartheid groups. ''We negotiated to get them to pay the largest amount in the shortest period of time,'' he said.
When the South African representatives first contacted the banks with their restructuring proposal, they reportedly offered to pay about $1 billion over a period of about five years. The banks final agreement calls for them to receive $1.5 billion over three-and-a-half years.
 
Questions on Rates Charged
Though bankers would not give any details on the interest rate that South Africa received, bankers said it was unchanged from the previous agreement.
''The rates are relatively high,'' said the British banker. ''They are penalty rates of interest.'' When banks have renegotiated the terms of loans to Latin American countries, by contrast, they often reduce the interest rates they charge.
''I think there's a false perception of what power the banks have,'' said Mr. Simone. ''We're getting a better deal from South Africa than from almost any other developing country.''
Although the banks have been under constant pressure from anti-apartheid groups and some British Commonwealth ministers, there was apparently no pressure exerted by the governments of the leading industrialized countries.
