HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Generally Rise

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved generally higher yesterday, buoyed by a better-than-expected report on inflation and by purchases of as much as $2 billion worth of 30-year bonds by a large Japanese investor.
A report showing that consumer prices rose by an unexpectedly modest two-tenths of a percent last month helped to push bond prices higher early in the session, as did a release disclosing that initial unemployment claims rose sharply.
But traders said the bulk of the market's move took place on the heels of two separate $1 billion bids for bonds. While such buying is not unusual, market participants said these purchases were different because they were so openly displayed. Generally big blocs are bought more discreetly, they said. 
 
Support for Market Seen
''This guy has been on the screen with his bids since 10 or 11 o'clock this morning,'' said Neil Dubrow, a vice president at Voute, Coats, Stuart & O'Grady, a bond trading firm in Greenwich, Conn. ''Even though the inflation report looked good, the bond market would have gone down quite a bit had it not been for this buyer.''
Market participants said it was rumored that the buyer was Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru International Inc., a Japanese brokerage house. The firm was believed to be buying the bonds for the Daichi Kangyo Bank, the world's largest commercial bank.
Eishi Wakabayashi, an executive vice president at Nippon Kangyo, confirmed that the firm had bought ''substantial amounts'' of bonds, but declined to comment on who the customer was.
Aside from the big purchase, the session was highlighted by a signal from the Federal Reserve Board that its worries about the possibility of another big stock decline have abated.
 
Surprise Move by Fed
Yesterday the Fed surprised credit market participants by draining reserves from the banking system at a time when the Federal funds rate was trading at around 8 3/4 percent. In the days immediately after last Friday's huge slide in the equity markets the Fed's actions suggested that the central bank was adding reserves to the system.
''The Fed's operation suggests they are comfortable with an 8 3/4 percent funds rate,'' said Darwin L. Beck, a money market economist at the First Boston Corporation. ''It is a signal saying that the stock market problem is over, and things are back to normal.''
The Fed's action had an adverse effect on short-term bills and Treasury note issues.
By late yesterday, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.54 percent, up five basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates rose by three basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.55 percent.
In the secondary Treasury note market, the 8 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 29/32, down 1/32, to yield 7.86 percent.
Intermediate and longer-term issues were buoyed by the inflation report and the Japanese purchases.
In late trading, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 101 7/8, up 26/32, to yield 7.95 percent. And the 8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 3/8, up 14/32, to yield 7.94 percent.
 
Little Effect on Auction
The Fed's open market activities had little effect on yesterday's auction of $9.75 billion worth of one-year Treasury bills.
The new bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.35 percent, down from an average rate of 7.61 percent at last month's sale. It is the lowest rate on a new one-year Treasury bill since the June 30, 1988, auction, when the bills sold at an average rate of 7.04 percent.
Although yesterday's price moves may have been distorted by the big Japanese purchase, analysts said that the consumer price figures and other recent economic data were providing a positive underpinning for the bond market.
''The good news is building, and we are approaching another down move in yields,'' said Edward J. Hyman Jr., vice chairman of C. J. Lawrence Morgan Grenfell. ''Starting with the current quarter, we are moving into a period where we will have virtually no growth.'' Mr. Hyman said he expected the economy to stay in that very slow to no-growth mode for the next year.
Elsewhere, prices of secondary investment-grade corporate bonds moved higher along with Treasury issues. Dealers said prices of most issues rose by about half a point.
 
Dillard Issue
Dillard Department Stores was among the companies offering new debt yesterday, with an issue of $50 million of 9.5 percent debentures through an underwriting syndicate led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The debentures, which mature Oct. 15, 2001, were priced at par, or $100. The 9.5 percent coupon was 1.53 percentage points over the yield on the 8 percent 10-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.
The issue, which is noncallable for life, is rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's.
Prices of secondary tax-exempt municipal bond issues rose by 1/8 point to 1/4 point yesterday, despite the offering of $150 million of high-grade issues on a bid-wanted basis.
The seller of the bonds was rumored to be a large New England bank seeking to help clean up a problem real estate portfolio.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that two of the three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Oct. 9. The most basic measure, M-1, fell by $3.3 billion.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Mixed Results Despite Data on U.S. Prices

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed against major foreign currencies yesterday at the end of an uneventful session.
Gold prices eased in the United States after posting scattered gains and losses overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $367.10 an ounce, down $1.60 from Wednesday.
Currency dealers in financial centers around the world temporarily sold dollars after the Commerce Department reported that the Consumer Price Index went up a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in September. But the unexpectedly small inflation rate had little lasting effect on currency trading.
Speculation about the chances for lower interest rates circulated in the markets and tended to temper any urge to buy dollars, dealers said. The low inflation reading could give the Federal Reserve Board greater leeway to ease monetary tightness, leading to lower interest rates.
''There was no real direction in the market,'' said Siobhan Lackey, an assistant on the foreign exchange desk of Bank Julius Baer & Company. ''There wasn't that wild of a reaction to the inflation news.''
By the end of New York's trading day, the dollar was quoted at 142 yen, up from 141.40 yen late Wednesday. And a pound fetched $1.5975, vs. $1.5922 on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Wednesday's quotes, included: 1.8500 West German marks, up from 1.8485; 1.6205 Swiss francs, down from 1.6243; 6.27895 French francs, down from 6.2810; 1.17405 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17335, and 1,360.95 Italian lire, down from 1,362.00.
On the Comex, silver bullion for current delivery closed at $5.08 an ounce, down from Wednesday's settlement of $5.105.

HEADLINE: Caterpillar Net Tumbles 43.2%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 19

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc.'s third-quarter earnings tumbled 43.2 percent because of a sales slump that has forced the company to place about 325 employees on indefinite layoff, the company said today.
Plants in East Peoria, Mossville and Mapleton, Ill. will be affected by the layoffs announced today, but Caterpillar, a leading manufacturer of earth-moving equipment, did not announce how many workers at each plant would be idled. 
Caterpillar also said a plant in York, Pa., will shut down operations involving about 175 workers for a total of four weeks in November and December.
 
The layoffs are necessary
''to keep production in line with demand,'' the company said in a statement.
Caterpillar attributed its sales decline in part to higher interest rates, which led to reduced construction activity and discouraged purchases of replacement equipment, particularly in the housing sector.
Caterpillar said it earned $108 million, or $1.07 a share, for the three months ended Sept. 30, compared with $190 million, or $1.87 a share, for the corresponding period a year ago.
Revenue fell 5.4 percent, to $2.64 billion from $2.79 billion, as equipment sales declined 5.8 percent, to $2.58 billion from $2.74 billion.
The company said its earnings also reflected an $11 million provision for bad debts on Latin American receivables.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Debate Begins on Reducing Budget Deficit

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
House and Senate budget negotiators today began what promises to be a slow process: reconciling major differences in their plans for reducing the fiscal year 1990 budget deficit and repealing $16.1 billion in automatic spending cuts that took effect on Monday.
The automatic cuts, which the law required after Congress failed to meet an Oct. 16 deadline for having a deficit-reduction plan in place, imposed across-the-board reductions in a wide array of domestic and military programs. Today's session was devoted to speechmaking, because the 10 subconference groups that have jurisdiction over various portions of the deficit reduction plans will probably not meet to begin their work until Tuesday.
While the budget negotiators fenced, two senior Republicans on the Senate Finance Committee outlined the latest version of a proposal to lower the capital gains tax they hope to attach to a bill raising the ceiling on the national debt. 
Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the ranking Republican on the committee, and Senator William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, said their plan had the backing of the Administration and the support of more than half of the Senate.
 
Boren Abandons His Plan
Senator David L. Boren, an Oklahoma Democrat who had been planning to introduce a more generous capital gains tax cut plan, said he had abandoned that idea and would support the Packwood-Roth proposal, although he will not sign on as a co-sponsor. Mr. Boren and Mr. Packwood said that capital gains tax cut supporters in the Senate remained two to five votes short of the 60 votes that would be needed to overcome a filibuster by opponents of a gains cut.
The plan would reduce capital gains taxes for corporations as well as individuals, providing larger tax breaks the longer assets were held. It would also allow individuals to set aside $2,000 a year in an individual retirement account and to make tax-free withdrawals at the time of retirement.
The lower capital gains tax rates for individuals would apply to assets sold after Oct. 1, 1989. If individuals chose not to take the reduced capital gains rate, they would have the option of lowering their capital gains tax by excluding the portion of their profit solely attributable to inflation.
Individuals who held their assets at least one year could exclude up to 5 percent of their profits from tax, while those who held their assets at least seven years could exclude 35 percent, lowering their capital gains tax rate to 18.2 percent. Corporations that held their assets for at least three years would pay a capital gains rate of 33 percent, while those holding assets at least 15 years would pay a gains rate of 29 percent.

HEADLINE: Gephardt Offers an Agenda

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Declaring that his party had been ''dealing with the thread and not the fabric'' of the economy, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader, outlined today ''a new Democratic agenda for investment and economic growth.''
In a speech at the National Press Club, Mr. Gephardt seemed to be offering a yardstick against which the party's economic positions could be measured in the years ahead. 
He stressed that the party should promote investment, honor work, focus on the long term, encourage fairness and check concentrations of economic power - and he acknowledged in the question period after the speech that his colleagues might disagree over whether particular legislative measures fit the framework.
Mr. Gephardt gently suggested higher taxes on the wealthy and less spending by the military, but he was more emphatic about where he wanted to spend money and on the need to reduce the budget deficit.
He said he and other leaders would offer concrete proposals to fill in the outline next year.
The Missouri Congressman said his speech grew out of the turbulence last week on Wall Street and the Democratic leadership's loss last month of the House vote cutting capital gains taxes.

HEADLINE: After 20 Years, Philippine Insurgency Falters

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANILA

 BODY:
After 20 years, the largest indigenous Communist insurgency in Southeast Asia has stalled because of factionalism, purges, declining campus recruitment and the capture of some important leaders, diplomats and Philippine officials say.
''It's much too early to say the Government is winning,'' said a senior Western diplomat. ''But the insurgency has stopped growing. It's more containable now, though it still can strike almost anywhere in the country.'' 
The diplomats say the Government's gains are undeniable and encouraging. But they quickly add that the Philippine military and Government are not so much winning the war, as the insurgents are losing it by default, failing to adjust their program and practices to changing circumstances.
 
Factionalism and Infiltration
Political experts say the emergence of a popular President, Corazon C. Aquino, as the result of a revolution, however bourgeois, did much to thwart the Communist Party, its New People's Army and associated front organizations. Internal divisions between the old-line Maoists, who favor political action, and the so-called Sandinistas, who favor militancy and armed struggle, are said to have become much sharper.
Factionalism and infiltration by the Government have led to purges and the killing of cadres, whose shallow graves have been used as propaganda by the Government. With the capture of a number of Maoist leaders, Government officials say the balance seems to favor the militants.
Army officers are optimistic, saying they will defeat the insurgency by 1992. Gen. Roman Gavino, deputy chief of intelligence, told diplomats at a briefing this month that 8 members of the Communist Party's Central Committee and 34 regional leaders have been killed or captured this year.
 
Major Rebel Strongholds
He asserted that rebel casualties in the 23,000-member New People's Army are up over 40 percent and that guerrilla attacks are down 11 percent, while Government-initiated operations are up 16 percent. Military figures on the insurgency, however, have often in the past been found to be incomplete or misleading.
Even Western diplomats sympathetic to the army point out that the insurgents maintain major strongholds in such significant areas as the highly populated Panay and Negros islands; the Bicol region, and Cagayan Valley, where they retain the initiative against the military. In addition, the rebels retain significant if somewhat reduced strength in the country's second largest island, Mindanao, and in Bataan, a province near Manila.
The rebels have also shown that they can strike almost at will in urban areas, and they have announced their intention to attack United States Government employees and other Americans connected with the Philippine anti-insurgency campaign. Just last month, two American employees of a United States military base were killed by gunmen later identified by the Philippine Government as Communist guerrillas. On the same day, a member of President Aquino's guard was slain by rebels near the presidential palace.
In April, Col. James N. Rowe was slain by rebels in an ambush in suburban Manila. Colonel Rowe was the commander of the ground forces division of the Joint United States Advisory Group, which administers American military aid to the Philippines.
 
An Army With a Spotty Record
Out in the countryside, where the war is mostly fought, the performance of the Philippine Army is considered spotty, with an officer corps of uneven quality and probity, still politicized and divided over loyalties to personalities. Some young officers also remain restless, and despite the failure of the last coup attempt in August 1987, they still gather to listen to its leader, former Col. Gregorio B. Honasan, who has escaped recapture even though he has been seen speaking to business groups in Makati, an affluent Manila suburb. But most diplomats regard prospects for another coup as remote.
More important, the continuing failure of the civil administration to work well in tandem with the military and to provide needed social services and aid to citizens whose lives have been disrupted by the war, is undermining the Government's strategy of political, civil and economic development.
A major military operation this May in Negros forced the evacuation of 35,000 civilians who were poorly cared for by unprepared civilian authorities. At least 50 children died from measles, diarrhea and pneumonia, and the domestic criticism was harsh. The army said it considered the Negros operation a model, but it has not tried a similar operation since.
 
Gains From a 'Dirty War'
Some of the Government's gains have come from army practices associated with a ''dirty war,'' a code phrase for intensive surveillance, harassment and assassination of civilians. Leftist organizations that the Government and army regard as Communist fronts have been intimidated or disrupted, and some of their members reportedly kidnapped or killed.
Officials say these deeds are done by right-wing extremists or the private armies of landlords and have nothing to do with the Government or the army. But Philippine church and human rights groups as well as world organizations like Amnesty International have strongly criticized the Government and the army for human rights abuses. Philippine officials say it is the insurgents who are producing the mass graves.
In the longer run, the officials acknowledge, any lasting victory over the insurgency will be based on economics, not troop movements or political convictions. ''In this war, it is not really the hearts and minds that are important. It's the stomach,'' said Rafael Ileto, national security adviser to President Aquino and a former Defense Minister. ''The economy has to feed people three times a day. The military can't do it.''
 
Low Rate of Growth
The Aquino Government has tried to stabilize the economy. This will be the third consecutive year of over five-percent growth in the gross national product.
But this rate of growth is the lowest in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and half that of Thailand, Singapore and Malaysia. In addition, the Philippines retains a feudal structure in much of the countryside that most of the rest of the region has long discarded. New wealth in the big cities, like Manila and Cebu, is simply not trickling down to the peasantry on the sugar estates, and old patterns of poverty, inequality, landlessness, joblessness, injustice and corruption offer fertile ground for the guerrillas.
In addition, the annual population growth rate is between 2.5 and 3 percent, meaning that economic growth of even 5 to 6 percent a year is substantially eroded. Senator Leticia Ramos-Shahani, an Aquino supporter, thinks the need for better population control is the central problem for the country's future. Other politicians and diplomats say that Mrs. Aquino, a devout Roman Catholic, will not associate herself with the issue.
''The Government isn't losing the war, but to win it requires a radical overhaul of social programs, a crackdown on corruption and a transfer of some money to the countryside,'' a Western diplomat said.
Another diplomat said: ''The economy is better, but it's still sick. With this birth rate, the poor will grow and grow, and there's very little sign of money filtering down, as in Thailand. If the economy keeps on this way, the insurgency will come back with a vengeance in five years or so.''

HEADLINE: Reagan Urges Japan to Look Past Its Success

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Former President Ronald Reagan began a nine-day visit today by offering a gentle nudge to Japan to open its markets to more imports and take greater responsibility for foreign assistance to the poor countries of the world.
''Japan has responsibility for more than its own success,'' Mr. Reagan said at an arrival ceremony at Haneda Airport. ''Japan must anticipate and respond to the challenges and demands from the other countries of the world.'' 
He suggested that Japan emulate the American example of achieving both economic and military strength ''while at the same time being a major aid donor, championing free trade and supporting mutual security relationships.''
''So, too,'' Mr. Reagan added, ''can Japan maintain its own impressive success and still open markets and take on other global responsibilities.''
 
A Sympathetic Audience
The Japanese are expected to listen carefully to the former President, whom they continue to respect. Many see him as a symbol of a time when American-Japanese relations were less contentious than they have been in recent months.
The former President's arrival marked one of his few public appearances in recent weeks, and it was immediately noticed that his hair, which had been shaved off for brain surgery he underwent last summer, was growing back gray.
For many years, Mr. Reagan fended off comments about his dark head of hair, denying that it was dyed. In fact, his hair has long been flecked with gray, and a staff member said it was growing back with the same amount of gray that it has had in recent years.
Mr. Reagan and his wife, Nancy, are here as guests of the Fujisankei Communications Group, which is spending $6 million to $8 million on the couple's visit. That sum includes a payment of roughly $2 million to the Reagans themselves.
Although the size of the payment has raised some eyebrows, the visit is generally being portrayed positively in the Japanese press.
The former President was accompanied by a longtime friend and colleague who helped negotiate the trip, Charles Z. Wick, the former director of the United States Information Agency.
After arriving this afternoon on a chartered jet with spouses and dependents of United States military personnel stationed in Japan, Mr. Reagan left immediately for a mountain resort, Hakone, where he plans to rest for the weekend at the guest house of the family that owns the Fujisankei group.
He is to attend a special ''friendship concert'' in Yokohama on Sunday and to meet with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and Emperor Akihito on Monday and Tuesday. After the two days of official meetings, he will take part in a round of activities for the benefit of the company sponsoring his visit.

GRAPHIC: Former President Ronald Reagan and his wife, Nancy, being greeted by well-wishers yesterday after arriving in Hakone to begin a nine-day visit to Japan. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Bush Urged to Take Lead on Eastern Europe

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Pressure is increasing on the Bush Administration to show more leadership in helping Poland and Hungary shed their Communist economic systems.
''History will judge us by whether we have taken the opportunities which emerge from these reforms for the whole of Europe,'' the West German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, told an East-West security conference here yesterday, as the United States Senate passed an $837.3 million aid package for Hungary and Poland that was almost twice as much as President Bush had requested.
Secretary of Commerce Robert A. Mosbacher told Mr. Genscher and the others assembled here later, ''We want the bold programs of market development and political freedom in Hungary and in Poland to succeed.'' Then he added, in effect, that those countries and the Soviet Union were on their own. 
The West should maintain its security controls on exports of technology to the East European countries, he said, and should not engage in a reckless round of lending or subsidized investments there.
 
'Marshall Plan or Martial Law'
''My advice to them is, 'Take the plunge! The water is fine,' '' he said, meaning to sound positive. Instead, what many of the assembled officials and scholars from the Atlantic to the Urals understood was something more like ''Sink or swim.''
''Our dilemma now is Marshall Plan or martial law,'' said Dariusz K. Rosati, director of foreign trade research in Warsaw, today, saying that the new non-Communist Government of Tadeusz Mazowiecki risked losing all popular support within three months if it took the harsh measures needed to control a soaring inflation rate, which Mr. Rosati estimated at between 5,000 and 6,000 percent annually.
''This Government deserves support,'' said Karol Szyndzielorz, a Polish journalist, but he described Mr. Mosbacher's words as ''a show of impotence, a pretext for doing nothing.''
President Bush has encouraged European leaders to take the initiative in helping East European nations, and the economic summit meeting of industrial democracies last July asked the European Community's executive commission to coordinate Western economic aid to Hungary and Poland.
 
Association Is Recommended
Last month the commission recommended a $660-million package for this year and next, which will be discussed by a meeting of the 24 participating donor countries in Brussels in November. A senior NATO diplomat said that eventually the United States would have to take the lead.
Some Western Europeans, like Mr. Genscher, would like to create a framework for associating Poland and Hungary with the economic institutions of the European Community. ''I didn't hear an operative plan to do that,'' a former senior West German diplomat said after his speech yesterday.
A West German banker, sitting in an office high above Frankfurt this afternoon, mused that what Poland needed first of all was detailed, expert advice on how to restore the value of its currency. ''But then you need goods you can buy with it,'' he added.
Poland has asked for a $1 billion stabilization fund, to which the Bush Administration has contributed $200 million, and Mr. Mosbacher encouraged all the Western countries to contribute.

HEADLINE: Life Isn't Always a Cabaret

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
It was only two weeks before the Oct. 3 opening night of his cabaret act at the Ballroom in Manhattan that Jeff Harnar left his job as a singing waiter in Mrs. J's Sacred Cow, a restaurant on the Upper West Side.
''I needed to rehearse,'' the 30-year-old singer explained the other day, recalling the anxieties of bringing ''Carried Away: Jeff Harnar Sings Comden and Green'' to the smart nightclub in Chelsea.
The fact that Mr. Harnar, a critically praised singer, has had to work as a singing waiter illustrates the marginal economics of life in today's cabaret. After its three-week run ends Sunday there is no certainty that Mr. Harnar will not soon have to go back to being a singing waiter despite the rave reviews and the excited audiences. Although he is considering taking his act to San Francisco and Los Angeles, there are no firm plans. And beyond those possible West Coast dates, the future is cloudy. 
''I don't know what is going to happen after next week,'' Mr. Harnar said. ''I may have to go back to waiting tables. I have to have a faith that if I continue to keep putting out good work that the phone will ring.''
In ''Carried Away,'' Mr. Harnar and his accompanist, Alex Rybeck, string bits and pieces of more than two dozen songs with lyrics by the veteran team of Betty Comden and Adolph Green into zany medleys that illustrate the notion of being carried away with love, show business and the general buzz of city life.
 
Love and Small Change
Were this the early 1960's, Mr. Harnar might well be singing on a Broadway stage instead of in a club. Vocally, his baritone recalls the young Larry Kert, while his boyish enthusiasm evokes Robert Morse in musicals like ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying'' and ''Take Me Along.''
But because there so few new musicals nowadays, Mr. Harnar, who grew up in a lot of places, including California and Chicago, dreaming and planning for a career in musical comedy, has had no choice as a performer other than to forge a shaky niche in the insular cabaret world. It's a world where performers do it mostly for love and small change and from which there are no easy stepping stones to the next level of show business success.
Mr. Harnar first won favorable notice two years ago when he gave a series of performances at the Greenwich Village club Eighty Eight's. Last March, he was voted best male performer by the Manhattan Association of Cabarets, an organization made up of performers, club owners and cabaret critics. ''Carried Away,'' which also originated at Eighty Eight's, moved to the more glamorous Ballroom after Margaret Whiting, a friend of Greg Dawson, who manages the Ballroom, recommended he catch Mr. Harnar's act.
''I came to New York in 1979 hoping to be on Broadway,'' Mr. Harnar recalled the other day. ''The first cast album I ever bought was 'How to Succeed in Business.' I wanted to play the Robert Morse part. That was the Broadway I thought I would find. I had transferred from Southern Methodist University in Dallas, where they had a wonderful theater program, to N.Y.U.''
 
'I Sang Too Old'
Mr. Harnar quickly discovered that the musical comedy world was smaller and less welcoming than he had imagined. And after two years of responding to scores of casting calls, he became discouraged.
''I was told that I sang too old for someone so young and that there were no juveniles who were baritones - they were all tenors,'' he said. ''I finally decided there was nothing for me to do here. Phyllis McGuire hired me to be the houseboy and major domo in her five-story townhouse. It was right when the McGuire Sisters were beginning their comeback. And I watched them going through the same dynamics trying to re-establish their careers that I was going through as a newcomer. But during the two years I worked for her, I got bitten by the bug again. I decided that if there wasn't going to be a Broadway vehicle, I would do my own thing, and I began creating a persona for Jeff Harnar, the cabaret singer.''
Mr. Harnar teamed up with Mr. Rybeck, a young pianist and aspiring theater composer who has been his accompanist ever since, and in 1983 they put together an act that played in two clubs, both of which no longer exist. Discouraged from a lack of response, Mr. Harnar waited three more years before he went back to performing. In 1987, he and Mr. Rybeck created a second act that opened at Mr. Sam's, another defunct cabaret, on the Upper East Side, took it to Don't Tell Mama in the theater district, and went from there to Eighty Eight's. Though the act won favorable notice, Mr. Harnar's friends commented that it seemed a bit too introspective and laden with ballads.
Heeding their advice, he came up with the idea for an upbeat show of Comden and Green songs. He got the idea from looking at the jacket of an album called ''A Party With Comden and Green,'' a recording of the autobiographical show of their own material that the team first performed in the 1950's and revived on Broadway in 1977. Through the Broadway producer Barry Brown, who was both a supporter of Mr. Harnar and a friend of the lyricists, Miss Comden and Mr. Green were approached for their permission.
 
'I Was Heartbroken'
''Their first reaction was to discourage the project,'' Mr. Harnar said. ''Since they are also performers, they thought I wanted to do their club act. It felt to them that I was stepping on their toes. I was heartbroken.''
The team agreed, however, to accept a telephone call from Mr. Harnar to let him plead his case.
''Where their show is a historical look at how they wrote all the material, mine was an evening with Jeff Harnar in which I used their patter songs in totally different contexts,'' he said. ''They listened to me for 15 minutes as I went through pages and pages of notes. I knew the tide was turning when Adolph Green asked what were some of the ideas I had for the material, and I told him I wanted to do 'Never Never Land,' from 'Peter Pan,' as a doo-wop number with my two invisible brothers.''
Miss Comden and Mr. Green gave their blessing.
''After the show opened, their first take on it was that they were shocked to see so many of the songs used out of context,'' Mr. Harnar said. ''But after a weekend had passed, they told me, 'It's a lovely evening. We don't want you to change a thing about it.' ''
In spite of the uncertainties of his business, Mr. Harnar has already begun work on his next cabaret act, offering only a hint at the content. ''I'm in love with the 50's musical,'' he said. ''To me, the post-World War era was a very creative time when America really tried to be happy.''

GRAPHIC: Jeff Harnar in ''Carried Away: Jeff Harnar Sings Comden and Green.'' (The New York Times/Angel Franco)

HEADLINE: Changing the Color of Money Won't Stop Corruption

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Donald T. Regan suggests America's drug problem can be cured simply by changing the color of money (Op-Ed, Sept. 18). But that idea was tried before and failed dismally.
Our last currency conversion took place during the spring of 1970. The reasons for changing the color of currency then were the same reasons Mr. Regan suggests for doing it now. However, changing the color of American Military Payment Certificates failed back in crime- , drug- and corruption-infested South Vietnam in 1970 because the American high command didn't appreciate that the major element in the ''evil triad'' paralyzing our war effort was neither crime nor drugs, but corruption. 
Used as cash by the American military, the payment certificates replaced the greenback for two reasons: so as not to disrupt the South Vietnamese economy by flooding it with highly valuated American greenbacks, and to prevent the North Vietnamese and the last Vietcong remnants from obtaining an internationally accepted currency to purchase more advanced weapons, support and medical equipment.
But as senior military command and intelligence officers became aware that South Vietnamese drug lords, black marketeers, commodity brokers and enemy arms merchants possessed more payment certificates than American military personnel, a secret plan was hatched to change the color of the certificates abruptly and render impotent the entire ''evil triad'' pyramid: from the politicians and generals at the top who sold stores of spent brass bullet casings back to the U.S. Government, to the street urchins and barrack maids at the bottom who sold marijuana, cocaine, hashish and heroin on our military bases.
Planning for the conversion was kept from military personnel below the rank of division commander. Or so it was intended. As American G.I.'s awoke in the morning and received surprise orders to report to hastily built currency exchanges to replace their color-canceled M.P.C. bills, millions more of the new bills were already in the hands of South Vietnamese brothels than in American currency exchanges. Those of us who worked as liaison with the South Vietnamese Army discovered the night before that many of the lower-ranking Vietnamese soldiers, fronting for their generals or civilian merchants, possessed huge, hand-sized rolls of freshly printed M.P.C.
Was the conversion a failure? The true goal, it seemed, was not to eradicate the evil triad completely but to replace the uncooperative cartels that had become too wealthy and powerful for the American and South Vietnamese high command to negotiate with, with new cartels that promised to work more closely with our war effort. At that late stage in the war, corruption was an accepted basis for a growing, or at least surviving, South Vietnamese economy.
The new cartels, amply supplied with the brightly colored payment certificates, helped American officials buy back tons of black-market PX goods and military and medical equipment, thereby reducing the supplies that would otherwise have ended up in the hands of the enemy, who were caching tons of M.P.C.-purchased munitions along the Cambodian-Vietnamese border to prepare for invasion. Many of the supplies American officials failed to reclaim during the weeks following the M.P.C. conversion were recaptured during the Cambodian offensive.
Was the conversion a success? No. Drug use among G.I.'s continued to soar during the two remaining years of American military involvement. Munitions continued to flow into North Vietnamese caches across the border. And American law enforcement and intelligence morale sank to deeper depths.
Corruption among both South Vietnamese and American profiteers seemed a more potent enemy than the American high command had anticipated. Corruption here at home would spell failure in changing the color of American money.
 
PHILL COLEMAN
 Redondo Beach, Calif., Oct. 2, 1989
 
The writer operates the Vietnam Data Resource and Electronic Library as a public service.

HEADLINE: Redefining Comptroller, Council Head

SERIES: City Charter: The Voters' Turn -- Fifth of six articles.

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
While the broad outlines of a new municipal government were the central concern of the New York City Charter Revision Commission, the panel also proposed dozens of small but significant changes in city government.
The nearly 400 pages of the proposed charter, which will go to the voters in a referendum on Election Day, Nov. 7, are filled with new committees, boards and reporting requirements that the commission believes would improve the responsiveness and fairness of municipal government.
Critics say many of these additions would be expensive and unnecessary, adding to the size of the bureaucracy and slowing down government rather than speeding it up. The commission contends that many of the proposed changes would save money in the long run and would make the government more efficient. 
 
A Municipal Watchdog
One consequence of the panel's most significant proposal - to abolish the Board of Estimate - was the need to redefine the roles of the board's eight members: the mayor, the Council president, the comptroller and the five borough presidents.
The Council president and comptroller currently derive much of their power from their seats on the board. The commission decided that the two officials should have their executive roles strengthened and clarified, since the board's demise would put an end to their legislative authority.
Under the commission's plan, the Council president would function as a municipal watchdog, attempting to resolve complaints from citizens and overseeing several areas: the compliance of city agencies with the new charter, the response of city agencies to requests for information from the public and the agencies' handling of complaints about city services.
The Council president would also appoint one member of a new 13-member City Planning Commission and would head a new commission on public information. In addition, the president would monitor the overall delivery of city services and could recommend legislation to the Council to correct broad problems in municipal services.
The Council president would continue to be first in the line of succession should the mayor die or become disabled. Despite the title, the Council president is primarily a figurehead in the Council. Like the vice president in the United States Senate, the Council president presides over the Council and casts a vote in case of a tie, but the Council is run by the majority leader.
Some members of the charter commission contended that the office of Council president should be eliminated, because it would have little purpose without a seat on the Board of Estimate. They said the Council president's proposed new roles would conflict with the Council members' own oversight responsibilities.
But a majority of the commission decided that the city needed alternative voices because it is so dominated by one political party, the Democrats. The commission chairman, Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr., said it was important to retain the position because the city needed ''a person independent of the mayor with a citywide constituency who will worry about service delivery.''
 
Role of the Comptroller
There was less debate about the proposed role of the comptroller, who would have a clear mandate as the city's chief auditor and fiscal monitor to review the performance of city agencies and city contractors. The comptroller would also report annually on the mayor's revenue estimates and proposed budgets and on the state of the city's economy.
Under the new charter, the comptroller would also have the power to halt temporarily the awarding of a city contract that he believed to be corrupt. The mayor would have to respond in writing to the comptroller's objection, and the mayor would be required to make the final decision on whether to grant the contract.
The comptroller would name two of five members to a board that would set policy on city contracts, and would sit on a committee that would award franchises like commuter bus lines.
The franchise committee would also include four representatives of the mayor and one borough president. The votes of five of the six members would be needed to award a franchise.
 
Independent Budget Office
The charter plan offers many other new boards and committees. It proposes an independent budget office to evaluate city finances, the mayor's estimates of revenues and the mayor's budget proposals, and to serve as a counterbalance to the powerful Office of Management and Budget.
To assure the independence of the new office, the charter proposes that its director be appointed to a four-year term by a committee consisting of the Council president, the comptroller, one borough president chosen by all five borough leaders and one Council member selected by the Council.
Nathan Leventhal, the charter commission's secretary and a former Deputy Mayor, said the new budget office was one of the panel's most important innovations.
Mr. Schwarz said the office ''enhances the ability of all the players to play with a full deck.'' He added, ''We think it is one of the things that will lead to savings in the overall budget.''
 
Political Jobs Barred
The charter also proposes to bar the city's elected officials and senior administrative officials from holding the posts of county leader or state committeeman in political parties. Except for Council members, all elected and top appointed officials also could not be political district leaders.
The charter plan calls, too, for these new programs and agencies:
* A commission, chaired by the Council president, to regulate city practices on public access to information. The mayor would be required to keep city contracts and related information centralized and on computers, and to make the information available to the public.
* An Office of Economic and Financial Opportunity to help businesses owned by women and minorities compete for the more than $5 billion a year in city contracts.
* A deputy executive director in the Department of City Planning to coordinate long-range planning.
* The payment of interest when city agencies are late paying bills to companies and nonprofit groups doing business with the city.
* A commission to monitor efforts by city agencies to provide equal employment opportunities to minorities and women.
 
Attention to Planning
The charter would also require new reports on many subjects. Among them would be an annual report from the mayor giving statistical information on social, economic and environmental conditions in each of the city's 59 community districts. The report would address matters like infant mortality and infectious diseases, and it would cite national statistics and standards to place local concerns in context.
Mr. Schwarz believes the report would contribute greatly to the debate over the city's budget priorities.
''We've tried to increase the attention given to planning and the general effort to address the city's problems in a systematic sense and at the outset,'' he said, ''instead of the relatively overbalanced emphasis now on ad hoc disputes, individual disputes, resolved at the last minute.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, OCTOBER 21, 1989

 BODY:

 
 
Markets
 The stock market completed its best week in 16 months after a frightening plunge at the end of the previous week. The Dow Jones industrial average ended at 2,689.14, up 5.94 points for the day and up 119.88, or 4.7 percent, for the week. The Dow had fallen 190.58 points, or 6.9 percent, on Oct. 13, but a growing number of investors overcame their anxiety and decided the plunge was a fluke and a buying opportunity. [Page 33.] A $475 million ''junk bond'' issue of Chicago and North Western was finally sold by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, but the terms had to be sweetened because of disarray in the high-yield bond market. The coupon was increased to 14.75 percent and bondholders were given 10 percent of the stock in the company. [43.] Copper futures prices dropped to new lows for the month with the end of a three-and-a-half month strike at a large Canadian mine and the reopening of Mexico's biggest mine. [41.] The dollar ended higher in New York, after mixed results in overseas markets. Gold prices were little changed. [41.] Treasury note and bond prices eased in a dull session without any significant economic or market news. [36.] 
 
 
 
Companies
 The pilots, flight attendants and top executives of United Airlines will submit a revised bid for UAL, the parent of the airline, said a union leader who refused to say how the group will replace the $750 million that was to be put up by British Airways. The British carrier withdrew from the deal after financing for the original $6.75 billion buyout collapsed. [33.] One arbitrager who holds 50,000 shares of UAL stock says she is keeping her investment because she is confident the deal will be put back together. [33.] British Airways completed a stock issue that it had planned to raise money for the UAL deal, although it says it will not join the new bid now. [34.] The American affiliate of Qintex Australia filed for bankruptcy protection after the parent company failed to provide a debt payment due this week. The filing was another indication of mounting pressure on the parent company after the collapse of the company's bid for MGM/UA Communications. [33.] Texas Instruments reported a 30.6 percent drop in profits for the third quarter. The company attributed the decline to weaker prices for memory chips. [33.] Apple Computer said earnings rose 49.3 percent in the third quarter, but almost all of the increase was from a gain on the sale of a 16.4 percent stake in Adobe Systems. [35.] Texaco will acquire Tana Production, an oil and gas concern, for $476.5 million in cash and stock. [35.] First Interstate Bancorp will report a $16 million loss for the third quarter because of its Arizona subsidiary's problems with the depressed real estate market in the state. [35.]
 
 
 
The Economy
 Despite predictions that takeovers are on the wane, three big merger proposals were made this week in retailing and related fields. The deals involve the American subsidiary of L. J. Hooker, 41 warehouse stores of Pace Membership Warehouse Inc. and most of Farley Inc.'s Cluett, Peabody subsidiary. [37.] A former marketing executive of the Sperry Corporation admitted in court that he initiated a bribery scheme in which a Navy official was paid $400,000 for helping Sperry compete for an electronics contract. The guilty plea was the latest of more than 20 convictions stemming from the Justice Department's investigation of fraud in military procurement. [44.]
 
 
 
Today's Columns
 Offers of easy credit are like manna from heaven, but they send up a warning flag, a financial counselor says. Your Money. [34.] Campbell Soup obtained a patent on a new way to grow shiitake mushrooms, which are prized for their strong flavor and almost meaty texture. The process cuts the time to about 3 months, from up to 18 months under natural conditions. Patents. [34.]

HEADLINE: Dow Up By 4.7% For Week

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
The stock market yesterday completed its best week in 16 months with a mixed performance, although futures-related buying at the close pushed the Dow Jones industrial average to a small gain.
New York Stock Exchange volume was the lowest of the week, at 164.8 million shares, but pushed the weekly total to 1.17 billion, the first total over one billion since 1987.
The recovery was aided by good inflation news on Thursday, but analysts said it mostly represented a willingness of investors large and small to believe that the plunge in prices the previous week was a fluke and presented a buying opportunity.
 
6.9% Fall Previous Friday
 On the previous Friday, the Dow fell 190.58 points, or 6.9 percent, after the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, said it had been unable to arrange financing for a leveraged buyout at $300 a share. During that week, the Dow fell 7.8 percent, the worst weekly showing since the 1987 crash. 
''It appears that the ghost of 1987 has been exorcised,'' said Gene Jay Seagle, chief technical analyst at Gruntal & Company, after the Dow closed the day up 5.94, to 2,689.14. For the week, the Dow, the most closely watched measure of the market's movement, rose 119.88 points, or 4.7 percent, the best weekly showing for the index since it rose 5.9 percent in the week ending June 3, 1988.
UAL plunged 21 5/8, to 168 1/2, yesterday, bringing its total loss for the week to 111 1/4, or 39.8 percent. British Airways, which had been an investor in the previously planned buyout, said that it did not intend to participate in any new deal for UAL. AMR, parent of American Airlines, dropped 2 1/2, to 70 7/8, bringing its total weekly loss to 27 3/4, or 28.1 percent. Earlier in the week, Donald J. Trump, the developer, withdrew his offer to buy AMR.
 
Transportation Average Down
 The Dow Jones transportation average fell 32.71, to 1,230.80, bringing its total weekly loss to 175.49 points, or 12.5 percent. It was the worst week for the average since the 1987 crash, but the decline was deceptive. Of the 20 stocks in the index, 12 were up for the week and just six down, and the index would have shown a gain of about 22 points but for the action of the two large airlines.
Declines on the Big Board yesterday outnumbered advances by 829 to 662, despite the late rises in some stocks connected to the expiration of October stock index futures and options.
Traders said most of the program trading involving the expired October stock options and index futures took place on Thursday afternoon and early yesterday, thus removing pressure on equities yesterday.
Under Big Board rules, order imbalances relating to the expiration of futures and options are announced at 3:30 P.M. to draw in offsetting orders. All the imbalances yesterday were on the buy side, the largest being a 420,900-share imbalance in Exxon, which rose 3/8, to 46 1/8. While the imbalances did not have a major impact on prices, they helped push up the Dow more than 7 points in the final half-hour.
''So far, the market is not showing much sign of the panic carry-over that we had two years ago, especially since we survived Oct. 19th,'' said Mr. Seagle of Gruntal, referring to the second anniversary of the 1987 crash, when the Dow fell 508 points, or 22.6 percent.
''Investors have been through this before and are beginning to realize that recent program-driven markets call for sharper moves than before,'' he said. ''It is probable that the decline on Friday will prove to have been a 'normal' intermediate correction, just as Oct. 19, 1987, was the beginning of a foreshortened bear market.''
 
S.&P. 500 Off 0.03, to 347.16
 In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slid 0.03, to 347.16, while the Big Board composite index eased 0.05, to 192.12. Each index turned in its best week in 16 mohths.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index dipped 0.24, to 382.57, while in over-the-counter trading the Nasdaq composite index slipped 0.13, to 470.67. Both indexes were up for the week, but by far smaller margins than the indexes of large stocks.
Marsh & McLennan jumped 1 1/4, to 81. Insurance stocks rose for the third day in a row on expectations that the price-cutting war in the industry was near an end in the aftermath of the San Francisco earthquake.
Philip Morris was the most active stock, slipping 1/8, to 44 3/8, on a volume of 2.5 million shares. Other active blue-chip issues included A.T.&T., up 1/8, to 43 5/8; Chevron, up 5/8, to 66 7/8; Bristol-Myers, off 3/4, to 52; I.B.M., up 1/4, to 104 1/4; Citicorp, off 1/4, to 31 7/8, and General Electric, unchanged, at 56 5/8.
In over-the-counter trading, Groundwater Technology slumped 6 1/4, to 24. The company reported that earnings per share in its fiscal second quarter could fall to as much as 20 percent below last year's level.

HEADLINE: Treasury Notes and Bonds Decline

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Treasury note and bond prices eased yesterday in lackluster trading. Dealers attributed the dull session to the absence of any significant economic or market news and the usual caution that precedes a week in which a large amount of debt is scheduled for sale.
On Monday, for example, the regular weekly Treasury bill auctions will total $15.6 billion, up $400 million from the previous auctions and the largest such offerings since December 1986. The next day, $10 billion of new two-year Treasury notes are scheduled for auction, the largest amount since April 1987. 
Because the bill issues will be roughly $1.55 billion larger than those maturing, it will enable the Treasury to raise that much new cash.
 
Bill Rates Unchanged
 The discount rates on outstanding Treasury bills, however, were virtually unchanged, despite the Federal Reserve's moves to drain more reserves from the banking system through weekend matched sales of bills and other short-term Treasury issues. The late-morning draining hardly budged the key Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for temporary loans.
The funds traded at 8 11/16 percent almost all day. Meanwhile, the discount rates on current Treasury bills closed virtually unchanged on the day, with the three-month issue at 7.57 percent, the six-month bill at 7.56 percent and the one-year bill at 7.35 percent.
''It seems that with the stock market stabilized, the Fed has set a funds goal at between 8 5/8 and 8 3/4 percent for the time being,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds. ''But the fixed-income market's focus today was on the first auction of $4.5 billion of 30-year Refcorp bonds on Wednesday. At the moment, there seems to be little interest in these bonds shown by the targeted markets, which are the pension funds and Japanese institutions.''
Yesterday, the bonds of the Resolution Funding Corporation, which was created last summer by the Government to rescue failing savings and loan institutions, traded on a when-issued basis to yield 8.23 percent, compared with 7.98 percent on comparable Treasury maturities.
Mr. Sullivan and other credit market specialists expect the yield to rise at the auction on Wednesday, because the bonds carry a new ''name'' and thus do have a track record in the market. Also, it is believed that unlike the principal, the interest on the Resolution Funding bonds may not be fully guaranteed. Furthermore, the Government plans to sell $4.5 billion or more of these bonds each quarter for the foreseeable future, Mr. Sullivan noted.
 
Long-Term Bond at 7.98%
 Late in the session, the benchmark Treasury long-term bonds, the 8 1/8 percent issue maturing in 2019, were being offered at 101 20/32, down 8/32, or a quarter-point, on the day. These raised the yield to 7.98 percent, from 7.95 percent Thursday and 7.86 percent a week earlier.
Earlier in the day, the long-term bonds hit an intra-day high of 102 8/32 as some traders covered their short positions in expectation of further large purchases of long-term bonds by Japanese interests. These buyers are said to have bought $1 billion to $2 billion of long-term bonds Thursday.
Elsewhere in the secondary market, the 8 3/8 percent notes of 1991 fell 3/32, to 100 26/32, for a yield of 7.91 percent. The new two-year notes to be auctioned on Tuesday traded at a yield of 7.90 percent on a when-issued basis, up from 7.85 percent Thursday. The 8's of 1996 lost 7/32, at 100 4/32, for a yield of 7.97 percent, while the long-term notes, the 8's of 1999, dropped 8/32, and now yield 7.98 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Quiet Trading In U.S. and Gold Is Stable

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended higher in quiet New York trading yesterday after a mixed performance overseas.
Gold prices were little changed. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $367.30 an ounce, up 20 cents from Thursday. 
Currency traders attributed the dollar's modest rise largely to internal market influences in the absence of any new market-moving news. They said the market was awaiting the release of the September durable goods report on Tuesday and the preliminary report on the third-quarter gross national product on Thursday.
But Earl I. Johnson, a trader with the Harris Trust and Company in Chicago, said prospects for increased demand for dollars by the Japanese were giving some support to the currency.
''There seems to be fairly steady demand from institutions, such as large insurance companies, over there,'' he said.
In late New York trading, the dollar stood at 142.425 yen, up from 142.00 on Thursday. And each pound bought $1.5885, down from $1.5975.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's quotes, included: 1.8578 West German marks, up from 1.8500; 1.6285 Swiss francs, up from 1.6205; 6.3105 French francs, up from 6.2789; 1.17415 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17345, and 1,395.875 Italian lire, up from 1,360.75.
Silver prices held steady. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.089 an ounce, up from $5.080 Thursday.

HEADLINE: Fighting Addiction: 3 Days in Phoenix House -- A special report.;
Struggle and Hope From Ashes of Drugs

BYLINE: By MICHEL MARRIOTT

 BODY:
As though part of an enormous stage set for some brooding morality play, Phoenix House, a drug-treatment center, stands on the edge of a sinister block in the heart of the Morris Heights section of the Bronx. Scrawled across the treatment center's facade in graffiti are the letters C-R-A-C-K.
Just across the narrow, rubbish-strewn street, a fortified apartment building buzzes with the business of selling and consuming crack. Skeletal figures sit on steps and curbs sucking at fuming crack pipes.
The treatment center is sanity and order amid anarchy. Inside the modest, five-story former apartment building run by the Phoenix House Foundation, nearly every aspect of life is highly regimented: when residents eat, sleep, study and awaken is mapped out and posted. The men are required to be clean shaven, creating an almost military sameness among them. No one, including the center's 44 women, is allowed to wear elaborate jewelry. 
 
'Bring Structure Back'
With the permission of the residents, a reporter spent three days living and working in the drug center, participating in the house chores, group encounters, seminars and classes and, along with newcomers, mopping, sweeping and serving meals.
''We have to bring structure back to their lives,'' said Douglas Scott, the center's director who 21 years ago was a heroin addict sleeping in a wheelbarrow in Harlem. ''We want them to get rid of those negative patterns they had out there in society.''
Drug therapy here, which takes a minimum of 18 months, is rooted in a philosophy common to such long-term programs. Addicts are first humbled with menial jobs, then given steadily increasing responsibilities.
At the same time, they undergo counseling to bolster their resolve to resist drugs, said Dr. Mitchell S. Rosenthal, president of the Phoenix House Foundation.
The treatment is drug free. Addicts are required to detoxify before entering the program.
Henry Benjamin said he could feel himself changing for the better. A year into the program, Mr. Benjamin, 30 years old, said his mind was clearing after more than a year and a half of smoking crack in Harlem.
''People who use drugs always feel that they are running after the drug,'' he said. ''You never have time to think about what to do with your life.
''After not using drugs you eventually see this is the right place to be to get yourself together. There's nothing for me in the streets.''
Phoenix House was founded in 1967 in New York City by a small group of young heroin addicts who pooled their welfare checks and began developing a program built on group encounters, hard physical labor and an environment free of drugs.
Today, the Phoenix House Foundation is a private nonprofit organization that operates six treatment centers in New York and four in California. Phoenix House provides 1,000 beds in New York in contracts with the State Division for Substance Abuse Services. It serves addicts as young as 14.
The program also develops drug education curriculums for public and private schools across the United States.
 
Circle of Confrontation
'You Can't Do This Alone'
 Seated in a circle, a dozen residents lock eyes on the flushed face of Cynthia Terry, a street-toughened young woman raised in Harlem. Choking back her tears, she spoke of years of neglecting her three children and of drunkenness and drug abuse. The group's observations and questions were relentless.
''Why don't you talk to anybody?'' shouted a 21-year-old crack addict. ''You're encapsulated.'' ''This is what I've got for you,'' screamed another. ''You can't do this alone.''
In a broken voice, the 30-year-old Mrs. Terry told the group that she had become reclusive after a recurrence of guilt about the death of her mother, who died a decade ago of lupus, while Mrs. Terry was snorting cocaine.
''She was always there for me, and all I could do was go out and get high,'' Mrs. Terry said, sobbing. ''I want to start my life over. I want to be a good mother, and this is so hard. It hurts. it hurts an awful lot.'' The group, including Mrs. Terry, then bore down on several others who they believed had shown recent signs of withholding their feelings - ''stuffing feelings,'' or ''encapsulating,'' in the slang of Phoenix House.
 
Search for Identity
'I Feel Better About Myself'
 The issue of identity looms large inside this former apartment building, where men and women live and work to escape their addictions.
Crack addicts have traded in the trappings of their former identities to look like bank teller trainees.
''That's all image,'' explained Dennis McCabe, 22 years old, dressed in a crisp white shirt, narrow necktie and pressed pants. ''I feel better about myself when I look like this.''
Since July, he has been assigned to kitchen duty, where residents sweat and gripe over steamy stoves and hoist and scour dirty pots. Mr. McCabe, who is addicted to hard liquor and hard drugs, is charged with overseeing the kitchen operation.
Like everyone else in the house, his work is part of his therapy. Mr. McCabe said he used to begin his day by drinking a half pint of Absolut vodka in the shower. He said he drank because he was alone, and he was afraid to extend himself to people or become responsible for them. To challenge Mr. McCabe's fears, the counselors forced him to work supervising the kitchen crew.
When new residents arrive, they are usually put to work on the service crew: cleaning the toilets and mopping, sweeping and dusting. The experience serves in part to humble them, in part to teach them the Phoenix House system from the ground up.
A resident who sweeps the worn marble and wood stairwell that winds from the basement to the fifth floor is careful not to leave a single mop string in his wake - even though more seasoned residents often interrupt him to quiz him on the rules and regulations that govern the life inside the house.
Sexual contact between participants in the program is not permitted, nor is smoking in the bathrooms or entering rooms without invitation. Breaking any of these rules could lead to loss of a high-status job, weekend leaves or even expulsion from the program.
Cheryl Baldwin, 32, lost her temper and cursed a staff member. After three and a half months of working at a Phoenix House induction center, where new residents are screened and prepared for life in a drug-treatment center, she was busted back to the service crew where she said she feels ''suffocated.'' Even though she dislikes her new job, she still offers advice on proper behavior to less experienced residents.
''I didn't understand what I had learned in three and a half months,'' said Ms. Baldwin. ''Now I cry. I want to get back outside and work.''
She realizes that there are consequences to her behavior, she said.
Everyone is responsible for their area in dormitory-style sleeping quarters. Beds are made with crisp hospital corners. Shoes are neatly lined up beneath the bed's edge. Clothes are hung up, with the hangers all facing the same way. There are frequent inspections, too. The entire house could be placed on a weekend ban - meaning no one is permitted to leave - if things get sloppy.
The watchword is consistency, Mr. Scott said. ''They got away from all those normal, real feelings of trust and honesty and now have to begin with building up their self-esteem,'' he said. ''One way to do that is to do well and start feeling good about yourself.''
He customarily invites groups of new residents to his office, where he offers a slice of cake and a chance to discover that he can be their friend as well as a howling, omnipresent task master.
The meeting is a break in a day that is a slave to routine.
 
Life of Regimentation
'You've Hit Rock Bottom'
 Every day begins the same way.
 After a 30-minute breakfast at 7 A.M., there is an hour-long meeting that includes inspirational songs and skits written and performed by the addicts. One humorous skit urged residents to take special care in selecting a babysitter. The performers were two characters wearing mops on their heads and speaking in Caribbean accents. When their fictional ''Rasta Babysitting Service'' is found to be indifferent to the children, the room roared with laughter. Yet the point is made when the skit's mothers reclaim their children.
The rest of the day dissolved into a blur of seminars, classes to prepare for the general equivalency diploma, rap sessions, job assignments and more meals and meetings. There is little free time until 9 P.M. Lights are out at 11 P.M. The 185-word Phoenix House philosophy is recited from memory at least twice a day.
The weekend schedule is slightly more relaxed, with rented videos available and highly supervised trips ''out into New York,'' as the residents refer to the world beyond the walls of Phoenix House.
Most of the residents are between the ages of 20 and 40. They come from a range of socio-economic backgrounds but were ultimately impoverished by their various addictions, usually crack, cocaine, heroin, PCP or liquor; sometimes, all of them. Most are on public assistance, which helps to pay for their treatment, Phoenix House officials said.
Fifteen percent of the residents are remanded by the criminal-justice system for treatment. Many have lengthy criminal records, which often include armed robbery, burglary, prositution and drug sales, residents say.
''You've lost everything when you've got to come here,'' said Yolanda Turner, a 28-year-old crack addict who after 14 months of treatment is taking a word processing course outside the center. ''You've hit rock bottom. This place is no resort at all.''
 
Falling From Grace
 
Eternal Vigilance And Freedom
 In the lower lounge, a rough-hewn basement with chairs and the only television in the house, Lawrence Robinson sat wearing shredded ''bum's clothes'' over his own.
Mr. Robinson sadly studied the faces of his inquisitors - impassioned, impatient. Each screamed for a chance to indict him.
After 15 months of accepting the regimentation of Phoenix House and drug-free living, Mr. Robinson, a 38-year-old former New York Telephone engineer, had ''fallen.'' While in the final stages of the recovery program, crack cravings overwhelmed him and his new discipline dissolved into a hazy inhalation of a palmfull of crack rocks, he said.
Recently he returned to Phoenix House to try to regain his footing. On returning, he said he was ''embarrassed and ashamed'' about what he had done.
But no blind hostility greeted him. Peer counseling, steps to understand, began anew. For more than 30 minutes Mr. Robinson listened as a dozen fellow residents alternately berated and befriended the man now forced to wear a torso-sized sign announcing his lapse in judgment. ''I knew what tools to use,'' he said in a soft-spoken defense. ''I just didn't use them.''
Some residents have been known, although rarely, to sneak out to smoke crack. They are dealt with severely. One was required recently to sit at a table in a hallway and talk for days to fellow residents, one at a time, about why he had forgotten or ignored what Phoenix House had tried to teach him.
''When people leave here and get high, it's a selfish act,'' said Carmen Irizarry, a Phoenix House counselor who two years ago was herself a heroin addict recovering in the same institution.
In her office and in several other rooms including the main lounge, tanks of exotic fish are prominently displayed. No one knows why fish have become so popular at Phoenix House. But they seem appropriate since most residents say they feel as though they live in a fish bowl. Little escapes the collective eyes and ears of the house. Several of the residents, known by the clipboards they carry, keep tabs on the exact locations of all residents at all times. There is no privacy.
''If you know something, everybody else is going to know it,'' said William McDowell, a 40-year-old Vietnam veteran, whose shrapnel injury led to morphine addiction and then to a 25-year heroin habit. ''Once you tell one person, that person is going to tell someone else.''
Very often what residents notice in fellow residents is brought into the group encounters, a centerpiece of Phoenix House's drug-free treatment.
 
Tradition of Help
 
'It Takes A Long Time'
 For more than 20 years, addicts have been turning to this Phoenix House and its tradition of helping addicts help themselves to sobriety.
''We are really optimistic about this,'' said Douglas Chiappetta, director of the Therapeutic Communities of America, a Washington-based trade group for drug and alcohol rehabiliation programs. ''They are not just dealing with the drug addiction, but the reason that drives that person to use drugs.''
Yet long-term residential drug programs like Phoenix House have their critics. Residential treatment is relatively expensive, they note, annually costing about $15,000 a person compared with methadone maintenance programs exclusively used for heroin addiction, which cost about a fifth that amount. Additionally, residential treatment program officials acknowledge that drop-out rates in their programs are high, up to 60 percent.
But supporters of residential treatment claim that their graduates tend to stay drug free.
Since crack exploded on New York City streets five years ago, the number of crack-related drug admissions to rehabiliation programs has more than tripled, according to a recent report by the New York office of the Federal Drug Administration. The center on Phelan Place, like the others in the city, is operating at capacity, its officials said.
Testifying before a Congressional committee this fall, Dr. Rosenthal said a recent recidivism study found that ''only 5 percent of one group and 1 in another'' had returned to drug use after five to seven years after completing treatment.
It is still too early to know how effective drug-free residential treatment has been in dealing with crack addiction, he said, because widespread crack use is relatively new.
There is no substance known to counter crack's powerfully addictive hold, experts say.
''It takes a long time,'' Dr. Rosenthal said. ''In a period of three to 10 months the fog starts to clear.''
 
Demands of the Effort
 
'What We Do: Examine'
 Manny Rivera began his day in high gear. The 50-year-old former heroin addict is one of the center's eight counselors. Intellectual, energetic and demanding, Mr. Rivera is revving up his group.
Paraphrasing Socrates, he tells them that an unexamined life is not worth living. ''And in a therapeutic community, that's what we do: examine.''
Borrowing from Abraham Lincoln, he tells them, ''I don't think much of a man who doesn't know more today than he knew yesterday.''
One resident confessed that she did not want to be in the program. After seven months, she said she had grown tired of the house rules, regulations and procedures.
''If you saw a man lying in the middle of the street with a broken arm and leg after being run over by a car and he didn't want to go to the hospital, what would you say?'' Mr. Rivera asked the group.
''You would say he wants to die,'' he said, answering his own question. ''You need to be here.''
She lowered her head and nodded.
