HEADLINE: For Victims of the Hurricane, Pain and Uncertainty Linger

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AWENDAW, S.C., Oct. 20

 BODY:
Every morning for almost a month, 75-year-old Harper McNeil has climbed into his rusted 1972 station wagon and driven to the debris-strewn site where Hurricane Hugo obliterated his trailer home Sept. 21.
Near the beginning of this month, Mr. McNeil applied for Federal emergency assistance, which he hopes to use to buy a new trailer. But he has not yet received any word about his application, and for now all he can do each day is sit alone in his parked car and wait and hope.
''I feel better being here,'' said Mr. McNeil, a retired stevedore whose wife died in April. He is staying with his son nearby but wants to remain independent. ''My mind feels better when I'm here. It's home.'' 
 
'Nothing Is Like It Was'
The nation's attention has moved on to a new disaster, the California earthquake, but here where the hurricane struck, the pain continues, the needs remain enormous and questions about the future still abound.
''Nothing is like it was,'' said Jimmy Lewis, who is living in a 10-by-10-foot utility building and awaiting a disaster loan to rebuild his home in Alvin, S.C., while his wife and daughter stay with relatives. ''People seem different,'' he said. ''Nothing seems like it was before the storm came up.''
Hurricane Hugo remains the nation's costliest storm, with damage on the United States mainland estimated at more than $5 billion. In South Carolina alone, 24 of the state's 46 counties have been designated Federal disaster areas.
 
Criticism of Federal Effort
The month since the storm hit has brought both enormous deprivation and astonishing generosity throughout the Carolinas. There remains considerable criticism of the pace of the Federal disaster effort, which is coordinated by the Federal Emergency Management Agency.
''Now San Francisco gets to find out what it means when someone says, ''I'm from the Government, and I'm here to help,' '' said Dan O'Rourk, who owns a marina that was severely damaged on Folly Beach near Charleston.
But others say FEMA has become a convenient place for venting frustrations. And part of the lesson of Hurricane Hugo is the reminder that what nature ripped apart man cannot easily stitch back together.
 
A Daily Routine Has Returned
For many residents, the routine of daily life has returned. In Charleston, the historic homes on the Battery and the elegant shops and restaurants on King Street seem almost back to normal except for the neat piles of tree limbs and debris stacked by the curb. For homeowners with insurance, the problem is often finding a contractor, not coming up with the money.
But in the poor neighborhoods farther inland, and throughout the shoreline and countryside of one of the nation's poorest states, the hurricane's toll is still everywhere.
It ranges from the eerie, splintered ruins of what is left of the Francis Marion National Forest to towns like Manning, Sumter and Camden, nowhere near the shore, that are still littered with upended trees and overturned mobile homes.
Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr. of Charleston acknowledged in an interview that the recovery of downtown masks the continuing problems, particularly for the city's poor.
''They live closest to the economic edge,'' he said. ''Their houses are less solid. Their insurance is less extensive. Their jobs are less secure. Their churches have fewer resources. It is always the poor who get hurt the worst.''
 
Aid Remains Elusive
In a state that ranks 42d nationally in per capita income, an enormous number of people are finding how close to the edge they are and how elusive aid remains.
Gherman Guthrie's livelihood depended on the 40-foot shrimp boat he built himself five years ago. A month after the hurricane, it has been patched up and is almost seaworthy, he said. It will eventually need a $7,000 overhaul, but he does not have the money and does not think the Federal emergency effort can help him.
''If you can make $25,000, you probably don't need the loan they can give you,'' he said. ''If you're making $7,000 or $8,000 you can't get one because they say you're not able to pay it back.''
Others said the chaotic pressures of realigning life after the hurricane made it impossible to spend the hours or days needed to wait in line and grapple with the paperwork to apply for Federal assistance.
''I don't understand,'' said Allston Leland, a shrimper in McClellanville, S.C., who saw one of his boats sink and who has propped up the other on land awaiting repairs. ''They give farmers $100,000 not to plant peanuts, and here we're totally wiped out, and they're trying to figure out whether to give us 4 or 8 percent loans. Someone's got their priorities out of whack.''
In some towns, like McClellanville, a seaside community that was one of those hit hardest by the storm, recovery is still a full-time job, whether it is shrimpers trying to get their boats together, homeowners hauling away debris or people arranging food and shelter for children or the elderly.
 
Help From Unexpected Places
Like many other communities, McClellanville could not have come back without a vast volunteer effort from around the country. A crew of 45 striking miners from West Virginia appeared from nowhere, pitched tents for themselves so they could help the town dig out.
There were contractors who donated building materials, and the residents of Ocean County, N.J., who sent 37 truckloads of food and clothes, three fire trucks and a dump truck, and electricians and other workers to help McClellanville.
About 30 miles away in Cordesville, where almost every building suffered damage, a group of volunteers in the Mennonite Disaster Service from several states were repairing buildings today. They expect to work in the town regularly over the next year.
''Without the volunteers, without the one-to-one help, I don't know where we would be,'' said Patti Gross, a McClellanville resident. ''They've been absolutely beautiful.''
Feelings are far more mixed about the Federal relief effort. Officials admit the Government has been slow. Of 23,451 applications for emergency grants of up to $10,000 in South Carolina, only 1,939 have been approved and 1,500 checks totaling $4.2 million have been sent out. Of 16,754 people who have applied for temporary housing assistance, 1,782 have received aid so far.
The Government has more than 2,000 trailers for emergency housing, and 150 of them have been moved to South Carolina. So far, one family has been placed in one.
Inspectors must review damage before approving claims. When the first center opened a week after the storm, there were 25 inspectors for the whole state; now there are 100. Fewer than a third of the 26,000 damaged or destroyed residences whose owners have applied for grants or housing assistance have been inspected.
 
Even FEMA Is Overwhelmed
Even FEMA officials say the task has been overwhelming, especially for an organization that relies on part-time reservist staff members who work only when called up.
''We had St. Croix, the Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico and Charleston, and now San Francisco,'' said Verne McCloskey, center director for the FEMA office in Moncks Corner, S.C., one of 12 now open in the state. ''There was a hurricane in Texas and a flood in Kentucky. We just can't get to everyone that fast.''
There are many people whose needs far exceed what FEMA can provide.
Emily Runey's house on what was the second row of houses - it may soon be the first - off the beach at Folly Beach, S.C., is barely standing. One room is habitable and the rest is a waterlogged pile of boxes and rubble.
She has applied to FEMA for a $10,000 grant for repairs, but city officials say it will cost $50,000 to salvage it.
''I'd rather my throat be cut than move,'' said Mrs. Runey, a 72-year-old retired seamstress. ''And where do I have to go to? I just want things fixed up so I can live decent.''
Charleston has raised $1.1 million in donations that will go toward home repairs and other needs the Government cannot meet.
Officials in Folly Beach are hoping to raise $300,000 to $400,000, but they know it will not be easy. In addition to residents' problems, the city faces severe revenue problems because most of its businesses, including the Atlantic House restaurant, its best-known attraction, were destroyed.
''We lost the restaurant, the marina and 50 percent of the houses rented out to tourists; that's most of what we had,'' said Carol Linville, who is the wife of the town's Mayor, Bob Linville, and who is heading the relief operation. ''We're just hoping other cities around the country will adopt us.''
Jack Glover, a spokesman for FEMA, said much of the criticism of the agency and the relief effort reflected a lack of awareness of the agency's structure and what it can and cannot provide.
''This is not the great engine of social justice,'' he said. ''We're here to provide temporary assistance in an emergency.''
He said that in the long run, communities emerge from disasters as well off or better than they had been, because of the vast construction efforts.
But Mayor Riley of Charleston said the nation's growth, particularly along the coasts, may be outstripping its ability to manage disasters.
 
Patience Is Praised
''The one thing we know for sure is that each natural disaster will involve more people and be more complex to deal with,'' he said.
Mr. McCloskey of FEMA praised the patience of the people of South Carolina. ''People have been wonderful, long-suffering and patient,'' he said.
But after a month of uncertainty, most are hoping to get their lives in order soon.
Mr. Leland, the shrimper from McClellanville, may have summed up the mood when he tried to decide whether an available crane would be big enough to lift his 50-foot shrimp boat, Regulus.
''They say it might take care of it,'' he said. ''We don't want no more mights. We're about mighted out here.''

LENGTH: 1306 words

HEADLINE: A Potential New Soviet Export Product: Cold-War-Surplus Missiles

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
In an effort to turn swords into plowshares, or ''tanks into tractors,'' as Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d put it last week, the Soviet Union is trying to turn its SS-20 missile into a commercial rocket for launching small satellites into space.
The SS-20, an intermediate-range missile that held three nuclear warheads, was eliminated as part of the 1987 treaty banning medium- and shorter-range missiles based on land. The Soviet Union is in the process of destroying its 654 SS-20 missiles.
But now, with the help of a Houston-based company, Moscow wants its SS-20 factory to make a space launcher that could be transported to launching sites around the world. It would be the first Soviet-American joint venture derived from military armaments. 
Officials familiar with the project were unable to say exactly when, or if, it might be realized, because of the the approval needed at various levels of the United States and Soviet Governments. Some Federal officials worry that the conversion project might violate the 1987 treaty or complicate the negotiation of future arms accords. After all, they say, a rocket is able to serve either military or civilian ends.
 
Part of Economic Change
Promoters of the project insist that only peaceful uses are envisioned for the rocket and that this could be easily confirmed by inspectors. They say such conversion projects are crucial to the success of the economic restructuring now sought by Soviet officials.
''They don't want to throw people out of work,'' said Arthur M. Dula, president of Space Commerce Corporation, which has joined the Soviets to develop and market the new rocket. ''We think it's interesting that the Russians want to convert their industry to something other than building weapons.''
So far, Mr. Dula said, seven or eight potential customers have asked for information, and Norway, Canada, Brazil and Australia have shown interest in providing launching sites. In Moscow on Oct. 11, Mr. Dula obtained technical specifications, which he will use to conduct a detailed market survey.
Mr. Dula has worked with Moscow on other commercial space projects, including the sale of satellite launchings on large Soviet rockets and the use of Soviet space hardware for the display of advertising.
 
To Be Priced Competitively
Moscow says its end of the conversion deal is being handled by Technopribor, a Soviet consortium set up to export previously secret technology that has been declassified as some defense industries try to switch to civilian production. Technopribor's deputy director, Yuri S. Solomonov, recently told Tass, the official Soviet news agency, that the rocket's price for lofting commercial payloads would be lower than that of any Western competitor.
In an interview, Mr. Dula said the price could range from $3 million to $5 million. By contrast, launchings by a new small rocket under development in America, the Pegasus, are to cost $6 million to $8 million.
The 1987 Intermediate-Range Forces Treaty calls on the Soviet Union to scrap not only its SS-20's but also 170 SS-4's, 6 SS-5's, 726 SS-12's, 200 SS-23's and 84 SSC-X-4's. For its part, the United States is destroying 247 Pershing 2's, 170 Pershing 1A's and 442 ground-launched cruise missiles. The treaty bans flight testing and production of all these missiles as well as production of their launchers.
The SS-20, known in the West as the ''Saber,'' is a 54-foot-long, two-stage, solid-fuel missile that was moved about on a huge green vehicle that had 12 oversized tires. A Pentagon publication, ''Soviet Military Power,'' said in 1987 that ''the mobility inherent in the SS-20 design has afforded a level of undetectability and survivability unmatched in previous systems.''
 
Can Launch 770-Pound Payload
The Soviets call the new commercial rocket ''Start.'' It is to have three stages instead of two, to give the payload extra kick, and is to be 65 feet long. Mr. Dula said it would be able to lift payloads of up to 770 pounds into orbit. The main use, he added, would be for launching small scientific satellites measuring about three by four feet. He said the rocket, its mobile transporter and associated tracking equipment could be flown virtually anywhere in the new AN-225 ''Mriya,'' the largest transport aircraft in the world.
''The whole idea is to be able to launch from the customer's launch site, or from his driveway, if he wants to,'' Mr. Dula said.
There is a growing worldwide market for the launching of small satellites, which are becoming increasingly powerful as they benefit from the revolution in the miniaturization of electronic circuitry.
The Soviets have said they can build 300 launchers within 10 years after a decision to go ahead. Flight testing of the launcher could begin in early 1991.
 
Steps Before Go-Ahead
A Soviet go-ahead decision depends on the results of the market survey, Mr. Dula said, adding that the decision could come within a few months. Government experts said the Soviet Union would also have to consult in detail with the United States to iron out any potential conflicts with 1987 treaty before pressing ahead with the project. The treaty set up a Special Verification Commission for American and Soviet representatives to ''resolve questions relating to compliance with the obligations assumed'' under the treaty.
The factory that once built SS-20 missiles is at Votkinsk, west of the Urals. More than two dozen American inspectors are stationed there permanently to make sure the Soviets comply with the treaty, which calls not only for the destruction of existing intermediate and shorter-range missiles, but also for an end to the production of new ones.
The ''Start'' rocket, Mr. Dula said, is of a completely new design that will not incorporate the main parts of SS-20 missiles, such as rocket motors, all of which are to be destroyed. The plan, however, calls for using engineering plans and tooling for the SS-20, as well as some existing parts that the treaty allows to be converted for other purposes. For instance, the SS-20's guidance system is to be used to steer satellites into orbit.
Soviet officials have acknowledged that conversion of the factory would require new legal and technical safeguards to insure against possible military use of the commercial rocket. American officials are wary. Possible Conflict With Treaty State Department and Pentagon spokesmen said they could make no comment about the conversion project, and one State Deparment official said ''people are looking at the possibility of conflict'' with the treaty.
An official at the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency said other worries included whether the project might complicate the negotiation of a Start treaty to reduce long-range nuclear missiles, since the new commercial rocket might be counted as a Soviet SS-25 missile under rules being developed. The SS-25 is a three-stage missile that is slightly longer than the SS-20. He also said the project might violate international limits on the export of ballistic missile technologies.
''We don't have enough information on it at this point to make a judgment,'' the official said.
On Monday, Secretary Baker said the United States was prepared to provide Moscow with advice and technical assistance to help restructure the Soviet economy, adding that the transformation of ''tanks into tractors'' that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union had spoken of had yet to materialize.
Mr. Dula said he hoped the rocket conversion plan would find favor with Mr. Baker.
''The Soviets are trying to compete in areas where they're good,'' Mr. Dula said. ''They're not going to succeed with Coke or pizza. Their aerospace industry is the best they've got in the country, and they're trying to convert it to commercial production.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Jews Plan Drive to Protect Auschwitz Site

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Troubled by the decay of buildings and exhibits at the site of the Auschwitz death camp, American Jews are organizing an international campaign to conserve them.
Polish experts have long recognized an urgent need for conservation measures, but given the depressed state of Poland's economy little money has been available.
This month, Kazimierz Smolen, the director of the Oswiecim-Brzezinka Museum, as the camp site is officially known, signed an agreement permitting a team of conservation experts to visit the site in December to assess what kind of preservation work is necessary. The team will be headed by James Frantz, the chief conservator of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, The agreement said the purpose of the inspection, which is scheduled for Dec. 15 to Dec. 17, will be to develop a ''program of preservation of the premises and buildings'' at the camp. Signing the agreement with Mr. Smolen was Kalman Sultanik of New York, vice president of the World Jewish Congress, and Frank Reiss, the vice president of the Ronald S. Lauder Foundation, which is financing the initial study. 
The camp has been the center of a dispute over the presence of a Carmelite convent just outside its walls. Roman Catholic Church leaders only recently bowed to pressure from Jewish groups demanding that it be moved from the site, which they consider the central symbol of the Nazi genocide carried out against European Jewry.
 
'Entirely Unrelated'
Mr. Sultanik stressed the importance of carrying out plans to build an interfaith center near the camp site to which the nuns are to move. But he said the conservation project was ''entirely unrelated'' to the convent dispute.
According to Mr. Sultanik, who also represented the Lauder Foundation, the idea is to begin an international campaign to raise money for refurbishing and preserving the camp remnants.
Many of the buildings at the various sprawling camp sites that make up Auschwitz are in an advanced state of decay. Visitors to Birkenau, the nearby site of enormous gas chambers and crematoriums where the Germans sent millions of Jews to their deaths, are struck by the decrepit condition of the wooden barracks that once housed Jews awaiting their fate. Many were destroyed by fire right after the war and others were dismantled by local people seeking building material.
But there is also serious concern over the state of exhibits in Auschwitz, the main camp site, including huge heaps of personal items, like hairbrushes, spectacles and luggage, as well as mounds of human hair, that testify to the brutality of the camps.
''If nothing is done the place will simply fall apart,'' Mr. Sultanik said in a telephone interview.
But he said the plan was to ''restore and improve'' the camp site ''without disturbing the exhibits, barracks, crematoria and other facilities.''
 
'This Demonic Symbol'
The project appears to bear the potential for concern that changes could be made in the character of the camp site.
Reflecting some of the those concerns, Rabbi A. James Rudin, the national director of interreligious affairs at the American Jewish Committee, cautioned against any refurbishing project that would ''alter the character of Auschwitz, this demonic symbol.''
On a visit to Warsaw to prepare a conference of Jewish and Polish leaders, Rabbi Rudin said, ''Maintenance is one thing, but the second large question is how will the Holocaust be remembered, how will it be taught 50 years from now.''
He said the convent dispute and the re-emergence of the Catholic Church in Eastern Europe after years of repression by Communist Governments prompted concern among Jewish leaders about attitudes toward Jews and the recollection of the Holocaust.
''We are moving into a new generation that will not have survivors around to remind them,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Some Say Plan for Lake Erie Park Could Make Matters Worse

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRESQUE ISLE, Pa.

 BODY:
Despite a decade of evidence that breakwaters ruin shorelines, Pennsylvania recently began building the world's largest breakwater system here to protect one of the nation's most popular parks from the pounding waves of Lake Erie.
Presque Isle State Park is little known outside the Great Lakes region, but it attracts more visitors - six million last year - than any national park except the Great Smoky Mountains in Tennessee. The 3,100-acre peninsula, which forms a natural harbor for the city of Erie, has five and a half miles of sandy beaches and such a diversity of forests and wetlands that botanists say it is one of the rarest and finest ecological preserves in the world.
But almost every winter storms erode its beaches, and geologists say this 600-year-old sand spit will be washed away by lake currents and storms in 300 years if erosion is not controlled. For many years, the state and Federal governments have replenished the beaches with thousands of tons of new sand at a cost of up to $1.5 million a year. 
 
Effort to Cut Annual Costs
Sixteen years ago, in an effort to cut these costs, the Army Corps of Engineers proposed building a breakwater of rocks parallel to shore that would rise six feet above the waterline and act as a buffer, absorbing the energy of crashing waves and protecting the beaches. The corps says the plan, which is estimated to cost $30 million and was approved by Congress last year, offers a permanent solution and would reduce the cost of the annual sand replenishment program to $500,000.
The state endorsed the federally subsidized plan because there was no good alternative, said Mary Ellen Bolish, a spokeswoman for the State Department of Environmental Resources, which oversees state parks. She said that Federal subsidies for the existing sand replenishment program were winding down and that the state could no longer shoulder those costs alone.
But a number of safety and environmental questions have been raised about the breakwater, including fears that it would create the dangerous turbulence of riptides and would trap bacteria that would aggravate a pollution problem that caused temporary beach closings 15 times last year.
A variety of geologists and engineers, including some hired by the state last year, say the project's designers have not shown persuasively that the breakwater will warrant the risk and expense. ''The state could buy sand forever just with the interest payments it would get by putting the breakwater money in a bank,'' said Paul D. Knuth, an associate professor of geography at Edinboro State University in Edinboro, Pa.
Dr. Joseph T. Kelley, a marine geologist with Maine's Geological Survey, said his state outlawed breakwaters a decade ago. He said the problem with breakwaters is so well established that the certification exam for geologists in Maine includes the question: ''If one were to erect a breakwater offshore from a beach, what would be the effect over the next five to 10 years?'' The correct answer, Dr. Kelley said, is that sand would be trapped directly behind the breakwater and severe erosion would occur at both ends of it.
Dr. Orrin Pilkey, a professor of geology at Duke University who is an authority on beach erosion, said breakwaters are outlawed in North Carolina, and in many other states, including South Carolina, Texas and Louisiana, they are meant primarily to protect harbors. ''The Corps of Engineers is very, very far behind in understanding this trend,'' he said.
 
Questioned for Many Years
The Presque Isle project has been questioned in professional circles for many years but has never encountered organized opposition. By now the plan has gathered so much political support in the state that it is almost a taboo to criticize it, said Wasinder S. Mokha, a member of the Presque Isle State Park Advisory Board and director of the Public Works Department in Erie, which adjoins the park.
''It just keeps steamrolling along and nobody wants to stop and think about it anymore,'' Mr. Mokha said. ''But if public hearings were held today, there would be enough technical information to put tremendous doubt about the advisability of building the breakwater, and it would never be built.''
The Pennsylvania delegation to Congress, including Senator John Heinz, a Republican with a strong environmental record, lobbied hard for Federal financing for the breakwater. ''The Senator would share any concern raised by the experts,'' said Leonard S. Glickman, the Senator's legislative specialist on the breakwater. ''But Presque Isle has been studied for years by the Army Corps of Engineers and all the studies the Senator has seen indicate that the breakwater has a chance; if it doesn't work, we go back to where we were.''
Construction cranes, now gathering in Erie harbor, will soon start placing more than half a million tons of desk-and car-sized boulders in 58 separate mounds, one every 350 feet along a line parallel to the shore and 300 feet out.
Opponents say it is difficult to determine where design and politics part company in the project, and they cite two examples of how the corps rewrote its plan to get Federal subsidies. In 1981, for instance, the corps justified the breakwater plan as a way to protect a recreational area. But in 1986, after the Reagan Administration rejected that idea, the corps submitted the same plan but said it would provide no recreational benefits - only protection for Erie Harbor.
 
From 12 Years to 2
In another instance the corps, to win Congressional approval, agreed to build the project in two years after previously insisting that the breakwater had to be constructed over 12 years to permit flexibility in design, reduce costs and maximize benefits. Richard J. Gorecki, project manager for the corps, concedes that the plan has been compromised, but he added, ''I don't have any problem building it in two years.''
State officials say they relied on the corps' expertise in endorsing the project. ''The corps is really the primary sponsor of the project,'' said Terry R. Fabian, director of the State Office of Natural Resources in the Department of Environmental Resources. ''They have looked at all the specifics.''
Still, he said, the state was sufficiently concerned about the project to have the plans reviewed by a coastal-engineering firm, Moffatt & Nichol of Raleigh, N.C. ''They were satisfied with the project,'' Mr. Fabian stated.
But the consultants said in their report that they were unable to reach any conclusion. ''Segmented breakwaters may be the appropriate solution, but there has been insuffient evidence presented that the proposed structures wil perform adequately,'' the consultants said in the June 1988 report.
The study also raised questions about the project's economic justifications, its engineering assumptions and its effect on public safety. John R. Lesnik, an author of the report, said in a recent interview that the corps had disagreed with the findings and had ignored its call for further study.
''There is room for reasonable doubt and disagreement on whether the breakwater will work,'' Mr. Lesnik said.

HEADLINE: Science Agency Cancels Supercomputer Aid

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
The National Science Foundation has canceled the financing for the John von Neumann National Supercomputer Center in Princeton, N.J., one of five supercomputer centers in the nation.
The foundation decided not to renew its financing for the center beyond September 1990, the end of the current five-year grant period. The center,, which is operated by a consortium of 14 universities, including Princeton, Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has received about $44 million from the Federal science agency in the last five years. It had expected grants of about $69 million over the next five years. 
Several computer science experts said last week that the decision, announced by Princeton on Tuesday, was surprising because the supercomputer centers are widely viewed as the foundation of the Bush Administration's plan to link the nation's supercomputers with a high-speed computer network.
 
Equipment Problems
National Science Foundation officials defended the decision, saying it was made because ETA Systems, the company that made the two computers used by the von Neumann Center, went out of business in April.
''It was a difficult situation, but they were faced with hardware and software that was less than adequate,'' said Thomas Weber, director for advanced scientific computing at the foundation. ''It was a risk when the decision to fund the von Neumann Center was made in 1985. It's unfortunate that the risk didn't pay off.''
The financing cutback was not related to budgetary concerns, he said.
''This is more negative fallout from the demise of ETA Systems,'' said Larry Smarr, director of the National Center for Supercomputer Applications at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. ''This is an unfortunate development that shows what can happen when strategic American manufacturers remove themselves from the marketplace.''
When the program to create supercomputer centers began, there were few supercomputers at educational institutions. Now there are 35 to 40 nationwide. The von Neumann Center supports the research of 1,400 scientific researchers nationwide. A Setback for the U.S. The closing of ETA Systems, the Minnesota supercomputer maker that was a subsidiary of the Control Data Corporation, was seen as a setback for United States high-technology industries. American computer makers now hold a lead in supercomputing over Japanese competitors, but the Japanese are making significant progress.
Officials at the von Neumann Center said the foundation's decision undercut national science and industrial policies. ''I was astonished at this decision,'' said Doyle Knight, president of the center. ''It is inconsistent with the recommendations of their own peer review panel.''
He said, for instance, that the foundation's review had endorsed the center's proposal to buy a supercomputer made by Cray Research Inc.
Mr. Knight also said the von Neumann Center had trained more specialists in supercomputing than any other center in the United States.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL AFTERSHOCK;
California Quake Seen as Challenging State's Reluctance to Tax and Spend

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21

 BODY:
The devastating earthquake here is already having a political aftershock: a re-examination of California's reluctance to tax and spend, enshrined in law by a series of voter initiatives over the last decade that now constitutionally handcuff the state's ability to repair its crumbled highways and bridges.
Officials in the Bay Area, in Sacramento and in Washington are to meet to design a Federal relief package, expected to total more than $3.5 billion, and consider new state taxes, probably on gasoline, to pay the huge repair bills.
But before California can spend much of this money, experts say, voters will have to go to the polls and rewrite the constitutional provisions that put California in the forefront of a taxpayer revolt that began in 1978 with a ground-breaking ballot intitiative by Howard Jarvis and Paul Gann and solidified the next year in another Gann measure. 
Experts in state government, taxation and California politics have little doubt that these shackles will be loosened in response to the recent catastrophe, which left a shambles of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge and a half dozen stretches of Bay Area highway, with new damage discovered every day and projected repair times lengthening. Change in Political Landscape? But there are larger questions being asked here about whether the earthquake has changed the political landscape in more lasting ways, about whether the temblor that rolled through seven counties on Tuesday jolted Californians out of the dream of adequate services and extensive public works without new taxes.
Representative Don Edwards, a Democrat and the dean of the California Congressional delegation, compared the potential for a political sea change to events that followed July's Supreme Court ruling limiting access to abortion. That ruling prompted vigorous lobbying by abortion rights groups and modified positions by elected officials who had previously been adamantly opposed to abortion.
''Something like that could happen here,'' Representative Edwards said.
Mr. Edwards and other local leaders, most of them Democrats opposed to the taxing and spending limits, noted that California has been suffering a quiet dimunition of services for a decade, now highlighted by an enormous natural disaster.
''This state has contrived through the initiative process to bind itself in fiscal knots and restrict itself in emergencies,'' said Representative Vic Fazio, a Democrat. ''Now Mother Nature has entered in and brought that reality more clearly to the fore.''
 
Two Constitutional Limits
There are two state constitutional provisions that limit California's ability to tax and spend, the first more famous and the second more far-reaching and disabling in the current crisis.
The first measure, Proposition 13, was approved by the voters here in 1978. It limits real estate taxes, which finance an array of county and city services. Experts estimate that this measure has cost local governments $7 billion a year statewide since its passage.
The second measure, passed the following year and referred to here as the Gann Limit, puts a lid on annual government spending, based on a complicated formula involving population and inflation. While Proposition 13 was forcefully opposed by most of the state's politicians, the second measure was generally supported because elected leaders felt, ''The people had spoken and they are the boss,'' said Representative Nancy Pelosi, a Democrat.
The state is expected to reach its spending limits this year, as it did last year, when tax refunds were made to the people of California. Once the limit is reached, new tax revenue, like the 25-cent-a-gallon gas tax suggested this week by several state legislators to pay for damaged roads and highways, cannot be spent without mortgaging the future.
The Gann measure permits the state to exceed the limit in emergencies declared by the Governor and Legislature, but the money must then be subtracted from the general fund in the next three years, potentially causing drastic reductions in vital state services. ''We have no resilience in an emergency, given these limits,'' said Eugene Lee, a professor of political science at the University of California at Berkeley.
To use new gasoline tax revenue under these circumstances, state voters would have to cast ballots on whether to amend the Constitution. Such a measure, sponsored by State Senator John Garamendi, a Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Revenue and Taxation Committee, is already on the ballot for next June's primary election. Until the earthquake Tuesday, the prospects for passing the ballot measure were ''dismal,'' said Jim Donnelly of the California Taxpayers Association, a lobbying group.
 
Alternatives for State
To receive Federal disaster aid, the state must come up with 25 percent in matching money, either from a rainy day fund that currently has $800 million or by collecting new taxes, which cannot be spent without a vote amending the State Constitution. It is doubtful that Gov. George Deukmejian will empty the contingency fund, which would not count against the Gann limits but would leave the state's cupboard bare.
A special legislative session is expected to be convened here by Governor Deukmejian. He is a staunch opponent of new taxes, but this week he said he ''had not ruled out'' a ''temporary tax increase'' to help pay for rebuilding the area's highways and bridges.
That legislative session could also consider calling a special election to hurry the process of waiving the Gann limits. Bidding and the letting of contracts for highway reconstruction generally take a long time, and thus in real terms there is no hurry to amend the Constitution. But voters are more likely to approve such a measure while the calamity here is fresh in their minds.
''As time goes by, my guess is people are more likely to vote 'no,' '' said Randy Hamilton, a visiting scholar at the Institute for Government Studies at the University of California at Berkeley. ''The public memory is short.''
 
Shift in Sentiment
Bruce Cain, the associate director of the Berkeley institute, said public sentiment here had already been shifting before the quake. Lately, Mr. Cain said, Californians have begun to realize that the Gann limits failed to foresee the conditions of the late 1980's: a mushrooming population that included needy newcomers like the South East Asian refugees, new social problems like AIDS and drug abuse, and growing environmental concerns, all of which cost huge sums of money.
In this climate, both citizens and politicians are quick to ask whether the collapse of highways and bridges was, in part, a result of maintenance delayed by fiscal constraints.
''Up and down the state, repairs have been put off because of lack of money,'' said State Assemblyman Richard Katz, a Democrat who is head of the Assembly Transportation Committee.
Senator Pete Wilson, the Republican candidate for governor here in 1990, hotly challenged that contention, arguing instead that the problems on the Nimitz Freeway, the major scene of destruction here, were a matter of obsolete technology.
''If the premise is that we have been chintzy and set ourselves up for a fall, I don't think the facts bear that out, '' Senator Wilson said. It is probable and proper that there be some kind of inquiry. But I don't think the appropriate question is whether we have been spending enough on infrastructure.''
But television images are more vivid than reports by blue ribbon commissions and could reshape a debate in the nation's most populous state, where the tax revolt of 1978 lay the foundations for the supply-side economics of the Reagan Administration.
''Bureaucrats have been assuring us that things are all right while privately crossing their fingers,'' said State Assemblyman Tom Hayden, a Democrat. ''In the practical world where politicians live, that debate has come crashing down on the Nimitz.''

HEADLINE: DARKENING GLOOM IN A STRICKEN CITY

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Oct. 21

 BODY:
Probably no Northern California city was harder hit economically by the earthquake than this picturesque town on the rocky Pacific Coast. Almost all its downtown business district is in ruins, 250 businesses are shut and 2,000 people are out of work.
The almost festive air that reigned on the sunny day after the quake turned to gloom, anger and frustration today as rains began and the true costs - and the deaths - began to sink in.
The quake, centered a few miles northeast of downtown, devastated the city's commercial center when it turned the Pacific Garden Mall into splinters. The four-block mall, whose historic Victorian buildings housed scores of boutiques, restaurants, bookshops and other stores was the town's main raison d'etre for the millions of tourists who visit annually. 
 
'Not Very Promising'
''The outlook is not very promising,'' said Robert J. Shepherd, the city's director of finance. ''People came to Santa Cruz to stroll the Garden Mall and go to the beach, not to look at wreckage. Everybody in this town has lost something.''
Barred by city building inspectors from visiting their shops, more than 300 angry owners and employees jammed into the City Council chambers to fill out entry permits and discuss their problems with the Downtown Association.
How much of the mall can be rebuilt and how many businesses salvaged is not yet known. But gone for now are small businesses that gave this city its appealing flavor and generated $100 million a year in sales and $1 million in sales taxes for the city.
 
More Pervasive Damage
While the overall damage was greater in San Francisco and Oakland, the impact on this city of 47,000 was disproportionately large and more pervasive.
When President Bush visited the mall on Pacific Avenue Friday, he saw what remained of Santa Cruz's three bookstores, Lulu Carpenter's restaurant, Rainbow Records, Chi Pants, the Acapulco Restaurant, Camouflage, Revelation, Earth Angel and scores of other shops and eateries. These buildings have been ''red tagged'' by the city, meaning they may have to be demolished.
For the shop owners, the chief issue is whether they can remove inventory and business records, to salvage something with which to restart. Not all were certain that Santa Cruz would recover soon enough as a tourist destination to make it worth reopening.
Neal Coonerty has operated the Bookshop Santa Cruz on the mall for nearly 23 years until Tuesday evening. The jolt peeled off the north wall of his store and it collapsed into the Coffee Roasting Company next door, killing two employees there. One book store worker was trapped in the basement for a while.
Now Mr. Coonerty and his staff of 25 are applying for unemployment, some sleeping nearby in their cars. ''At this point, the building is going to have to come down,'' Mr. Coonerty said. ''The big question is whether we can get the inventory out to start over. It's like waiting to hear if you have cancer.''
With the Christmas season near, Mr. Coonerty had $450,000 worth of inventory on hand, at retail, and owes large sums to publishers. ''If we can get the books out, we can pay,'' he said. ''Otherwise I don't know what to do.'' If he can recover, the bookseller plans to reopen in a tent on the parking lot until a new building is ready. In one of the starker quirks last week, Mr. Coonerty left his shop early Tuesday to mail a $1,000 check to help fellow booksellers wiped out by the hurricane in South Carolina. ''A half hour later, our store was down,'' he said.
Meanwhile, frustration mounted among shop owners. ''The President and the Governor can go in, but we can't,'' complained Robert Rader, who has run Rader's Jewelry & Loan Company on the mall for 30 years. His windows were all blown in, leaving ''several hundred thousand'' in goods vulnerable, although he presumed most is protected by his safe.
 
Forced to Evacuate
Alan Johns, the owner of Warehouse Liquors on Front Street, managed to get in the day after but was forced to evacuate by the authorities. He estimated that up to three-quarters of his $60,000 in inventory was destroyed. He has been meeting with the state alcohol control authorities and the Federal Emergency Management Agency in the hopes of relocating temporarily.
''I'd like at least to get in and get my checkbooks and invoices,'' he said, waiting outside City Hall in the drizzle for the business owners meeting to begin. Just who is to pay for all these losses is a big question. Neil Sandow, a broker with the William W. Kelly & Company insurance agency, has been besieged by clients.
City officials estimated that there had been $83 million in damage, including $46 million to public installations like sewers and water lines. They said they expected to lose about $2 million a year in sales taxes, business license and parking fees from the lost tourism, or nearly a tenth of the city's $25 million general fund.
There was some good news. Of the 13,000 homes and apartments in the city, no more than 50 had been red-tagged for possible demolition, although nearly all had some damage. ''The residences fared extremely well, and except for the Pacifc Garden Mall, other businesses fared very well,'' said Anne Marie Mitroff, a spokeswoman for the city. The mall consisted mostly of older unreinforced buildings, but most newer parts of the city suffered relatively minor cosmetic damage, like fallen mirrors and shelves.
This was not the first time Santa Cruz has been hit by nature. About a quarter of a century ago, a flood on the San Lorenzo River rushed through downtown. And there was hope that the latest calamity, if the downtown is rebuilt, would result in stronger buildings and housing above the shops. And there would be much new work for contractors, landscapers and painters.
But for now, few were taking solace in that, given the lost income and tax revenues. ''For a city the size of Santa Cruz,'' said Mr. Shepherd, the finance director, ''this is a major impact.''

HEADLINE: 595 High Earners Avoided Income Tax in '87

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
A handful of the highest-earning Americans are still able to avoid paying Federal income tax despite repeated Congressional efforts to close loopholes.
Of 529,460 couples and individuals who reported total income above $200,000 on returns filed in 1987, 595 paid no tax, the Internal Revenue Service said in a report issued this week. Those 595 had income averaging $600,000, and two out of three had capital gains averaging $490,000. 
An additional 33,805 couples or individuals who earned more than $200,000 paid tax at an effective rate of less than 15 percent, typically less than a middle-income family would pay. Almost 3,000 high-income people paid less than 10 percent.
The estimates were reported without comment by the I.R.S. in the quarterly ''Statistics of Income.'' The agency has been required since 1978 to estimate the number of high earners who legally avoid paying any tax.
High earners were able to avoid taxes by reporting big losses on farm and partnership investments; by accumulating large capital gains, 60 percent of which were excluded from taxation in 1986; by claiming itemized deductions averaging $262,000 and by using the credit for taxes paid abroad. The figures do not include high earners whose incomes are made up largely of tax-exempt interest, like that of most municipal bonds. The I.R.S. report is based on unaudited returns; after an audit, some of the returns could lose their no-tax status.
Returns covered in the latest report, reflecting income earned in 1986, were the last filed before most provisions in the latest Federal tax overhaul took effect. Several changes in that 1986 law were designed to reduce the ability of high earners to avoid taxes.
The report showed that the number of people with annual incomes above $200,000 grew from 370,430 on returns in 1985 to 529,460 in 1986. The chief reason apparently was a big selloff of investments in 1986 to avoid a higher capital gains tax that took effect in 1987.
 
Attempts to Toughen Law
Fifty-three couples or individuals who earned more than $200,000 paid no Federal tax on returns filed in 1977, and the number has generally grown steadily. Exceptions were in 1985, when it dropped to 325 from the previous year's 579, and in 1987, when it fell by 18.
The percentage of tax-free high earners has risen despite repeated toughening of a provision aimed at requiring all high-income people to pay some tax despite the large number of credits and deductions they may legally claim.
Thirty percent of those earning more than $200,000 paid a minimum tax on returns filed in 1987. The Federal revenue from this source was $4.8 billion, an average of $30,263 per return.
 Here are some of the income and deduction items reported by the 595 couples or individuals who paid no tax:
* 457 had wages averaging $232,000.
* 394 had capital gains averaging $490,000.
* 3 received unemployment compensation. Nearly 4,600 of the 524,460 people with incomes over $200,000 reported some unemployment compensation.
* 5 reported net income from farming, averaging $1,400 each. But 58 had farm losses, averaging $275,000 each.
* 118 had state tax refunds averaging $21,000.
* 548 received interest income averaging $133,000.
* 262 reported net partnership income averaging $334,000, but 320 had partnership losses averaging $700,000.
* 33 had taxable Social Security benefits averaging $6,000.
* 9 received alimony averaging $267,000.
* 373 reported dividends averaging $136,000.
* 275 deducted home mortgage interest averaging $68,000.
* 325 reported charitable contributions averaging $49,000.
* 25 had medical deductions averaging $110,000.
* 19 claimed casualty and theft-loss deductions averaging $668,000.
The I.R.S. said 133 of the tax-free high earners claimed itemized deductions - chiefly interest - that exceeded their income.

HEADLINE: Alfred Hayes, 79, Retired Chief Of the Reserve Bank of New York

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Alfred Hayes, who headed the Federal Reserve Bank of New York until 1975 and played a pivotal role in the national and world banking systems for nearly two decades, died yesterday at a nursing home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 79 years old and a longtime resident of New Canaan.
Mr. Hayes was known as a conservative money manager who took a strong stand against inflation. He also had a reputation as a lightning-fast mathematician. 
The bank he led in New York is by far the most significant of the 12 that make up the Federal Reserve system. It dominated the system until William McChesney Martin Jr., then the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board in Washington, did battle with Mr. Hayes's predecessor, Allan Sproul, to wrest control from him.
Mr. Sproul resigned in 1955, and Mr. Hayes, a vice president of the New York Trust Company with 23 years of banking experience, took his place. When, at age 65, he handed the reins to Paul A. Volcker, Mr. Hayes said he was proud to have mended fences and with the board.
 
Aid for Britain
''The great strength of the system,'' he told an interviewer in 1975, ''is the existence of the 12 semi-autonomous reserve banks.''
But Mr. Sproul and Mr. Hayes successfully defended New York's special standing in the important Federal Open Market Committee by keeping their bank's permanent hold on the vice chairmanship. The committee sets general policy on buying and selling Government securities in the open market - the key instrument in monetary policy.
A frequent visitor to central bankers' meetings overseas, Mr. Hayes came to the rescue when crises battered the British pound sterling in the mid-1960's. He was instrumental in persuading other central bankers to buoy the British currency with a multibillion-dollar credit package.
Being a monetary conservative, Mr. Hayes was against involving the central banking system to help fiscally troubled cities. ''As a practical matter,'' he said when New York City faced bankruptcy in the 1970's, ''there are very good reasons for the Federal Reserve to stay clear of this problem.''
 
Rhodes Scholar
After his retirement, he moved to Morgan Stanley International, holding the posts of chairman and advisory director until 1981.
Mr. Hayes's love of reading did not keep him from skiing and tennis, and he was fond of the theater and photography as well.
He was born on Independence Day in 1910, in Ithaca, N.Y., where his father, also named Alfred, taught constitutional law at Cornell. He attended private schools, studied at Harvard and graduated from Yale in 1930.
Then, after a year at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, he spent two years as a Rhodes scholar at New College in Oxford, England, and joined the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, which is now part of Citibank, in 1933 as an investment analyst.
Mr. Hayes moved on to New York Trust's bond department in 1940. He served as a lieutenant in the Navy and then rose to vice president in charge of New York Trust's foreign division, the post he held when called to lead the New York Fed.
Mr. Hayes is survived by his wife of 52 years, the former Vilma Chalmers; a daughter, Anita Gratwick of Philadelphia; a son, Thomas C., of Cambridge, Mass.; a brother, M. V. Hayes of Woodstock, Vt.; a sister, Christine Hayes of Washington, and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Miss Pond Weds R. G. Hubbard 2d

 BODY:
Constance Sue Pond, the president of Charter Service of America, an aircraft charter company in Nashua, N.H., and Robert Glenn Hubbard 2d, a professor of economics and finance at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, were married in Boston yesterday. The Unitarian-Universalist ceremony was performed at the First and Second Church in Boston by the Rev. Dr. Rhys Williams and the Rev. Lawrence X. Peers. 
Mrs. Hubbard, a graduate of Indiana University with a master's degree in occupational therapy from Tufts University, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cecil Elwood Pond of South Bend, Ind. Her father is a retired president and chief executive of Wheel Horse Products, a maker of lawn and garden equipment that he founded with his father, the late Elmer E. Pond, in South Bend.
Mr. Hubbard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. W. Hubbard of Apopka, Fla., graduated from the University of Central Florida and received an M.A. and a Ph.D. in economics from Harvard University. His father and his mother, Myrtle Hubbard, teach English at Apopka High School.

LENGTH: 3547 words

HEADLINE: Now Showing, Survival of the Fittest

BYLINE: By ALJEAN HARMETZ

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD

 BODY:
The buzzword in Hollywood today is ''bulk'' - in studio size and in movies. The strongest studios are committed to making more movies, pictures that are larger in scope and budget, films that can feed a growing worldwide appetite in television, cable and home video.
''For better or worse, the wave of the 90's will be huge, well-financed companies that are involved in four or five forms of entertainment and whose competition is not other American companies but Sony in Japan and Bertelsmann in Germany,'' said Terry Semel, president of Warner Brothers.
For moviegoers, the changes will make a difference in what is on the screen. Almost immediately, increased numbers of bigger and more elaborate movies from the major studios will replace films supplied by defunct independents. As always, however, films produced will be determined by what sells, and long lines this summer for ''Batman'' and ''Parenthood,'' which drew crowds of people in their 30's and early 40's, have pretty much determined the tone of production for the next 18 months. 
The studios that will survive the 90's are jewels in the crown, protected parts of a larger corporate whole. As the strongest of them - Paramount Pictures, Universal, Warner Brothers, the Walt Disney Studios and 20th Century Fox - have increased their bulk and their global reach in production, theatrical distribution, television, home video, foreign sales, cable and pay cable, most of the others have shriveled.
The survivors will thrive because it is the seemingly unduplicable energy, pacing and glamour of American films for which worldwide audiences hunger. As foreign sales become more and more important to the studios, actors' salaries will rise even higher since stars are more necessary to attract foreign audiences. The floor for top male stars is now $5 million a picture. But if Chevy Chase gets $6 million, will Tom Hanks and Steve Martin be satisfied with $5 million for long? Budgets are already rising as studios turn to the kind of action movies that can leap national boundaries. ''Black Rain'' cost $37 million. ''Tango and Cash,'' a prison movie starring Sylvester Stallone and Kurt Russell, cost over $50 million. So did ''The Abyss.''
Five years ago there were nine major studios and more than a dozen independents snapping at their heels. What has happened since duplicates the plot of Agatha Christie's thrice-filmed murder mystery ''And Then There Were None.''
One by one both majors and minors have been eliminated. Figures from Variety, the industry trade journal, are a dramatic illustration. In September 1987, independent distributors released 53 films. Last month they released 26. Slaughtered by their lack of cash, their lack of size or their lack of good movies, Lorimar, Cannon, Tri-Star, New World, Atlantic, De Laurentiis, Vestron, Film Dallas, Island, Alive and half a dozen smaller companies have gone bankrupt or been reorganized or swallowed up by one of the bigger fish in the Hollywood sea.
Weintraub Entertainment Group is teetering. And MGM/UA with its glorious lineage is perceived by its rivals to be on its deathbed.
Three years ago Jeffrey Katzenberg, chairman of the Walt Disney Studios, predicted the downturn in production. ''So, I was only off by two years,'' he said a few days ago. ''But it was extremely clear a year ago that we'd already gone into the slide.''
Disney's response was a plan to double its output of movies by forming a second production wing, Hollywood Pictures. At MCA's Universal Pictures, the chairman, Thomas Pollock, plans to release 25 films in 1990, up from 10 in 1986. ''With its enormous overhead, the biggest sin for any studio is not to make enough movies,'' said Mr. Pollock.
''I was hired to triple production,'' said Joe Roth, who became chairman of Fox Film Corporation, owned by Rupert Murdoch, two months ago. ''The game plan is increasing production and distribution in all media all over the world.''
Not all the game plans are alike. Here is a studio-by-studio profile of the strengths, weaknesses and strategies of each of the competitors during the next 18 months.
 
UNIVERSAL
A Lawyer Swings For the Fences
 Universal Pictures has been the surprise of 1989. Three years after he took over amid whispers that an entertainment lawyer would be hopelessly out of his element making creative decisions, Thomas Pollock has crafted a string of what he calls ''doubles and triples,'' including ''Field of Dreams,'' ''K-9'' and ''Uncle Buck.'' Although none have been $100 million home runs, few of his 1989 movies have struck out. With Steven Spielberg's sequel to ''Back to the Future'' ready for release at Thanksgiving, Universal, now in a tie with Paramount for third place at the box office, may well challenge for first.
Unlike Disney, Universal is not creating a second production unit. ''Big studios are not necessarily the best at making movies, but we're the best at marketing and distribution,'' said Mr. Pollock. ''It probably isn't possible for Universal to make 25 films well each year, but it's certainly possible for Universal to market and distribute 25 films well.''
Universal plans to rely on outside relationships to provide it with a steady stream of product. Imagine, Ron Howard's company, is 20 percent owned by Universal. This year it came up with ''The Burbs,'' ''The Dream Team'' and a major hit, ''Parenthood,'' and there will be four or five films next year. Amblin, Steven Spielberg's company, has its headquarters on the lot and will give the studio three movies in the next three months. ''Our job is to tell them what we can sell,'' said Mr. Pollock of such semiautonomous suppliers.
With movies like ''Parenthood'' and ''Sea of Love,'' Mr. Pollock is taking advantage of the aging of the movie audience. ''In the early 80's, your movies had to appeal to the 12-to-25-year-old audience,'' he said. ''Today, if you can keep your costs down, you don't have to get that audience at all. Unless you make movies with $20 million budgets for narrow audiences, most pictures won't lose you any money.''
One example: ''Field of Dreams,'' a risky fantasy aimed at 30-year-olds, cost $12.5 million. Because of the unusual strange subject matter, Universal sold off foreign theatrical rights, leaving it with only a $5 million cost (before advertising expenses) for a film that has sold $61 million worth of tickets in America and Canada.
But Universal is faulted for giving away up to 50 percent of the ''back end'' or potential profits on its films to such stars and directors as Arnold Schwarzenegger and Ivan Reitman of ''Twins,'' a 1988 blockbuster.
 
WALT DISNEY
Sleeping Beauty Is Now a Giant
 Since Michael Eisner and Jeffrey Katzenberg took over The Walt Disney Studios five years ago, the sleeping beauty has turned into a giant that was in first place at the box office in 1988. Because Disney made movies more cheaply and released fewer of them, the company also led in the average profitability of its films last year.
The indefatigable Mr. Katzenberg describes himself as ''a bottom fisherman.'' Disney's first successes were made with such down-on-their-luck actors as Richard Dreyfuss and Bette Midler. The studio recently made an exclusive deal with Goldie Hawn, whose last movies have been box-office disappointments. Equally important, the studio put writers under contract because stars and directors go where the good material is.
The penalty of being smart and first is that people use you as a blueprint. Universal is taking a leaf out of Disney's book by trying to put writers under exclusive contract. Mr. Roth at Fox says that he is emulating Disney's way of ''getting a lot of product and not wavering when they are convinced that a concept is salable.''
''I think consolidation means good news for those of us who are going to survive,'' said Mr. Katzenberg. ''Although I also think it's a disgrace that we have a national atmosphere in which the trading of assets is valued far beyond the creating of assets.''
In the title character of last year's top box-office film, ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit,'' the studio created a new asset for Disney's theme parks and merchandising division.
Said Mr. Katzenberg: ''No matter what your vision of the future is, no matter what technology will be the gatekeeper for the consumer -the phone company or satellite or some Captain Courageous invention none of us have heard of yet - the four priorities of making things work in the entertainment business are product, product, product and product.''
Of Disney's decision to create the separate Hollywood Pictures to supply extra product, Mr. Katzenberg said: ''We asked, 'How can we have the most control?' By consistently delivering lots of quality product.''
In an effort to become a major television supplier, Disney has recently spent more than $100 million to tie up the writer-producers who created or were instrumental in the success of such series as ''Golden Girls,'' ''Empty Nest,'' ''21 Jump Street,'' ''Roseanne'' and ''My Two Dads.'' These deals are worth from $5 million to $10 million for each of the writing-producing teams.
The majority of Disney movies are initiated by the studio, but Disney does have one steady producing partner in Interscope (''Three Men and a Baby,'' ''Cocktail''). No matter who makes its movies, Disney is known for keeping elbows- and knees- as well as hands-on control. Executives at other studios admiringly call the Disney leaders arrogant.
When Rick Moranis, the star of ''Honey, I Shrunk the Kids,'' asked for $2 million to do the sequel to the $125 million blockbuster, most other studios would have given in. Disney threatened to replace him with Martin Short.
In the eyes of Hollywood, Disney's strength is also its weakness. Its reliance on Mr. Katzenberg may cause a bottleneck when the studio is making 25 movies a year. Disney's two units, Touchstone and Hollywood, have separate staffs, but Mr. Katzenberg's fingers are still on both pulses.
 
PARAMOUNT
Eddie Murphy Plus A Godfather
 The No. 1 studio in 1986 and l987, Paramount has slowed down.
 Frank Mancuso's game plan since he became chairman in 1984 has been to create tent poles: high-visibility and often high-budget movies whose success supports the rest of the schedule. But Paramount's tent poles are breaking. ''Star Trek V'' and ''Friday the 13th Part VIII'' did poorly last summer. Steven Spielberg refuses to make another ''Indiana Jones,'' nor will Paul Hogan make a third '' 'Crocodile' Dundee.'' The studio's other franchise, Eddie Murphy, is only under contract for three more films. Many Hollywood deal makers feel that Tom Cruise has replaced Mr. Murphy as the world's biggest movie star, but Mr. Murphy - who, like Mr. Cruise, gets $8 million a movie - is no worse than second, and he is widely reported to be unhappy at Paramount.
Mr. Mancuso, who is considered a brilliant distributor, said that the studio had just revived ''the ultimate Paramount franchise'': Francis Coppola's ''Godfather III.'' The movie is scheduled to start production Nov. 15.
For its major films Paramount relies on home-grown producers and pays up to $5 million a year apiece to care for them and house their staffs. The most successful have been Don Simpson and Jerry Bruckheimer (''Top Gun''). They have not made a movie since ''Beverly Hills Cop II,'' which was released in May 1987, but they are now developing an auto racing film for Tom Cruise. Other major Paramount producers are Stanley Jaffe and Sherry Lansing (''Fatal Attraction,'' ''Black Rain'') and Art Linson (''The Untouchables'').
Paramount is trying to increase the number of movies it releases but without the missionary fervor of Disney, Universal and Fox.
 
WARNER BROTHERS
After 'Batman,' What's Next?
 The success of ''Batman'' and ''Lethal Weapon II'' - a total of $393 million in ticket sales so far - masks a weakness at the studio. Warners has released 23 movies this year; only those two and ''Lean on Me,'' the story of the tough high-school principal Joe Clark, have made much of a profit at American theaters.
As of Sept. 24, Warners led in the box-office race with 18.4 percent of ticket sales, according to Variety. But Disney, in second place with 15.2 percent, had only released 14 films. And Paramount, with 14.4 percent, had distributed 11 movies, fewer than any of its seven rivals.
''Our appetite in production will continue to be very aggressive,'' said Mr. Semel, Warners' president.
In terms of distribution, Warners is leaping to take advantage of the consolidation in the industry. ''We're making our distribution companies around the world available to other people's films,'' Mr. Semel said. ''We'll grow because there are fewer distributors able to bring product to the marketplace for theaters, cable and television.''
Warners' special relationships are with Clint Eastwood, whose last few films have been box-office disappointments; Joel Silver, the producer of ''Lethal Weapon''; the former Columbia chief David Puttnam, who plans to supply two movies a year; David Geffen (''Beetlejuice''), who steadily produces one movie a year; Mr. Spielberg's Amblin, which will have ''Gremlins II'' ready for next summer, and, most importantly, Peter Guber and Jon Peters, the producers of ''Batman'' and ''Witches of Eastwick.''
Sony has purchased Mr. Guber and Mr. Peter's production company, Guber-Peters Entertainment, and asked them to head Columbia. If Warners allows them to wriggle out of their contract, it will leave a big hole in the studio's schedule.
 
20TH CENTURY FOX
Fresh Air And Tent Poles
 ''How is Hollywood facing the next two years?'' asks Joe Roth. ''Aggressively. I sense that not everyone is going to survive. The stronger you get, the less of a target you are.''
Like Columbia and MGM/UA, Fox has had a revolving door to its executive suite. Much of what Hollywood acts on comes from perception. Fox was dismissed as a studio with hardening of the arteries. The energetic Mr. Roth, who started with a bare cupboard, is perceived to be ''a breath of fresh air.''
''I have 15 movies in the works for the second half of 1990,'' Mr. Roth said.
His first, ''Die Hard II'' with Bruce Willis, is planned for release in June. The bulk of Fox's schedule will come from ''medium-budget-range movies that don't require Eddie Murphy or Tom Cruise,'' he said. ''But three or four times a year I'm venturing into a star-driven tent pole.''
In addition to his other problems, Mr. Roth has handicapped by saying he only wanted to stay in his job for three years. When it can take two years or more to shepherd an idea into a final film, such pronouncements make directors and producers nervous - as David Puttnam discovered at Columbia.
 
COLUMBIA/TRI-STAR
Not Enough In the Pipeline
 Despite and partly because of Sony's purchase of Columbia, the studio is in disarray. Producers, actors and directors will choose a studio with a stable management, so most observers think that Columbia will struggle for the next few years.
Successful executives at other studios are angry that the sale to Sony will mean millions of dollars for Jeff Sagansky, who had little box-office luck during his four years at Tri-Star, and for Dawn Steel, whose fatal flaw at Columbia was an inability to put enough movies into production.
When Ms. Steel replaced David Puttnam two years ago, she chose to make what are called housekeeping deals with movie stars, paying from $300,000 to $3 million a year to house an actor's production company. That strategy was clever shorthand to let Hollywood know that Columbia was back in the mainstream movie business. But such ''first look'' arrangements rarely translate into films because actors can be wooed away to other studios by good scripts.
In a striking example of the difference between Disney and Columbia, Ms. Steel purchased ''Pincushion,'' a $500,000 script about a country suffering a plague after a biological disaster. Other bidders saw ''Pincushion'' as a gritty $10 million action movie, and John Carpenter was willing to direct with Jamie Lee Curtis starring. Because Cher, who has a housekeeping deal at Columbia, expressed some interest, Ms. Steel had the script rewritten several times. The cost, including a retainer for Mr. Carpenter, is now up to $1.5 million, and Cher still has not committed.
In contrast, when Disney was wooing Dustin Hoffman to star in ''Dead Poets Society'' and the actor asked for one more rewrite, the studio said no and hired Robin Williams.
Columbia has one solid relationship, with Rob Reiner's Castle Rock, which produced the surprise hit ''When Harry Met Sally . . . '' Michael Douglas's production company has an exclusive three-year deal to make movies for the studio, which might or might not star Mr. Douglas.
If Warners' Mr. Guber and Mr. Peters end up running Columbia, Hollywood can prepare for more bidding wars. In the past, the two producers have concentrated on buying expensive, highly visible material such as ''The Color Purple'' and ''The Bonfire of the Vanities.'' They recently spent $1 million for the rights to the story of the martyred Brazilian rubber tapper Chico Mendes.
 
ORION
A Little Fellow Fights to Survive
 Orion is Hollywood's object lesson in the problems of being small. The studio was created and is run by a management team that headed United Artists in the 1970's and won Oscars for best picture three years in a row (''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,'' 1975; ''Rocky,'' 1976; ''Annie Hall,'' 1977).
Although Orion is respected for its taste and its willingness to tackle risky material (''Amadeus,'' ''Platoon,'' ''Mississippi Burning''), Hollywood wonders whether it can survive. The majority of top executives at other studios think that Orion will be the next studio to be sold.
Orion's major movie last summer, ''Great Balls of Fire,'' was a box- office disaster. And, when its pictures falter at the cash register, Orion does not have the cushion of a big library to sell in various mediums as its rivals do.
''Summer was not very kind to us,'' said Eric Pleskow, president of Orion. ''Our films did not find audience favor. But we are undaunted. We do not see ourselves at a disadvantage just because other people are trying to make more films. We're all fish in the same pond. Things will always depend on the films you make.'' Orion's major long-term relationship is with Woody Allen. The company recently became a home for the director Jonathan Demme and the actor Kevin Costner, who is directing and starring in a post-Civil War adventure film, ''Dance With Wolves.'' Orion also has nonexclusive but what Mr. Pleskow calls ''special relationships with long-term implications'' with Dennis Hopper, Jessica Lange and Michelle Pfeiffer.
 
MGM/UA
Oldies, Goodies But Nothing New
 In the jargon of the industry, MGM/UA has ''no throw,'' no viable projects in its development pipeline. The deal to sell the company to Qintex, an Australian conglomerate, has apparently failed. The only advantage to buying MGM/UA instead of developing a studio from scratch is the 1,000-film United Artists library and home video rights to the 3,000 MGM films that were sold to Ted Turner. And there may be a bit more box-office mileage from the ''Rocky'' and ''James Bond'' series.
 

 
'THE INDUSTRY ALWAYS SURVIVES'
In addition to being a movie star and the Academy Award-winning director of 'Ordinary People,'' Robert Redford is one of the rare stars who puts time and money into the independent film movement. He is the founder of the Sundance Institute, which supports independent film makers. In January he will produce ''Dark Wind,'' the first of a series of low-budget movies based on the novels of Tony Hillerman. Errol Morris (''The Thin Blue Line'') will direct the detective story about the exploits of a Navajo police officer.
''The film industry always survives,'' Mr. Redford says. ''Through thick and thin, through inflations and recessons, it survives better than most. It's up, down, boom and bust, but it's never out.
''Control of the industry shifts. Twenty years ago, the studios, which had had their own autonomy, were taken over by outside conglomerates - Gulf & Western, Warner Communications, Transamerica. The congclomerates tried to run things strictly as a business. Films are this crazy mix of business and art.
''There are good signs to this new consolidation, but it may mean an even greater eye to the bottom line, which will threaten the independents. Just a few years ago there was a big hurrah coming out of the independent film world, a cry of enthusiasm and glee. The independent film market - the financing and festivals - had started to increase. Now it may be harder to get distribution. Independent film makers will always have a hard time because their films don't make money or bring the audience in as much.
''I'm committed to diversity. If the consolidation leads to a narrowing of production and distribution, in effect the consolidation is a problem.
''As to the artist within the system, musical chairs are never good news for the artist. It makes them feel like they're standing on the California coast along a fault line.''
