HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
The Pendulum Swings Away From Cynicism

BYLINE: By Andy Grundberg

 BODY:
In the 1980's art has seemed to suffer from a fin-de-siecle anxiety. The source of that anxiety has been a fundamental skepticism about the possibility of ''making it new.'' Instead of seeming limitless, culture and the world itself have come to be seen as finite, closed systems that have been depleted by overuse. All that is left for artists is to reflect on their own imprisonment in a universe of existing words, forms and images.
This point of view has come to be known as post-modernist, and it represents a radical departure from the spirit of boundless originality and individuality that characterizes most of the art of this century. To artists and critics of the 1980's, that optimistic spirit, identified with the rarefied and to some eyes elitist esthetic of modernism, was exhausted by the beginning of the decade. But now, at the end of the decade, it is showing signs of staging a comeback.
The cracks in the post-modern empire of skepticism and dismay are as yet minuscule, but they suggest that the precepts of modernist art are not as discredited and exhausted as many have assumed. Modernism's conception of the artist as a seer, its unabashed quest for spiritual experience and its belief in abstraction as a means of achieving this experience have caught the attention of a generation for whom post-modernism's challenges to originality and authorship seem cynical and - even worse - old hat. 
That photography should be at the forefront of this revival is no small paradox. It is, after all, the medium that post-modernism has prized for its role in the manufacture and reproduction of cultural stereotypes. In the post-modernist decade of the 80's, photographs acquired both critical cachet and marketplace success. But in the same way that photography's profligate nature helped post-modernists dismantle the modernist canon, it has made appropriation, fabrication, pastiche, rephotography and other hallmarks of post-modernist art practice seem repetitious at an early age. In this observer's eyes, at least, there already exist enough pictures of artificial environments and of rephotographed magazine advertisements to last several lifetimes. The post-modernist point seems to have been made, in spades. The photographs of quintessential modernists like Alfred Stieglitz, Laszlo Moholy-Nagy and Alexander Rodchenko, on the other hand, were fueled by the artists' passionate beliefs in the power of images to change individual lives and, ultimately, the world. This gives their images - of skyscrapers, machines, city streets - a simplicity that life today cannot match. Life in the 1920's and 1930's probably did not match it either, but the visual evidence of the modernist period between the wars in Europe and the United States has a clarity of purpose we can only envy.
Most sea changes in art are accompanied by timely historical exhibitions that give voice and focus to unspoken discontents. Exhibit No. 1 in the case of modernism redux is ''The New Vision: Photography Between the World Wars,'' a beautiful and invigorating show of 125 photographs from the Ford Motor Company Collection of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. While the exhibition's curator, Maria Morris Hambourg, may not have intended the conjunction, the pictures in ''The New Vision'' display precisely the optimistic, experimental spirit of creativity that many artists are now seeking to restore.
As if to reinforce the point, the New York Public Library is currently presenting a retrospective exhibition of Berenice Abbott's modernist photographs, some of which also appear at the Metropolitan. And a show of Aaron Siskind's postwar abstractionist images, which was recently on view at the Museum of Modern Art, served to recall the visionary qualities of a later modernist era, one in which Abstract Expressionism was the dominant style. Together, these three exhibitions are as powerful a demonstration of the appeal of modernist photography as one could conceive. To an art audience tired of strategically calculated art positioned with one eye on critical theory and one eye on the marketplace, they are a salve to the spirit.
But it is not only in photography that the modernist legacy is being looked at with fresh eyes. Sherrie Levine's recent show at Mary Boone Gallery, for example, consisted of frosted white abstract sculptures that were presented in elegant wood and glass cases. While the work had Miss Levine's customary cutting edge - the three-dimensional shapes were appropriated from the ''bachelors'' in Marcel Duchamp's ''large glass'' - it also evoked the economical beauty of early-20th-century sculpture. The artist's subject may have been Duchamp, but the artworks themselves seemed a homage to Brancusi. Miss Levine is no modernist, of course, but she is remarkably adept at sensing and distilling the exact temper of the art world.
Just what makes modernist art in general, and modernist photography in particular, seem so appealing today? Partly it is a matter of nostalgia. In addition, the practitioners of what was called the ''new photography'' aimed their pictures not at an insular art world but at the culture at large. Moholy, from whom the exhibition borrows its title, conceived of ''the new vision'' as a revolutionary force and the camera as an instrument of truth. Stieglitz committed himself to the metaphoric capabilities of the medium, attempting to capture simultaneously personal and universal feelings in his pictures. The absolute sureness of their faith in art and their uncompromising vanguard cultural spirit shine like beacons in today's climate of dimmed expectations.
It is difficult not to be in awe of the modernists' drive for formal purity in their art. The pictures in ''The New Vision'' seem pared to their essence, without the fractious details and ironic incongruities that are currently fashionable. The prints are utterly gorgeous in terms of technique, and while they are minuscule in comparison with the vast majority of today's art photographs they seem more potent for it. The architect Walter Gropius's image of New York's Flatiron Building, taken at such an angle that it seems to be falling over, is a mere 9 by 7 inches, but it does not need to be an inch larger. Charles Sheeler's 1927 picture of the Ford River Rouge plant, about the same size, is so poster-perfect that it serves not only as a signature image of the Machine Age but also as a not-so-subliminal advertisement for the exhibition's sponsor, the Ford Motor Company. (These and all the other prints in the show were originally in the collection of John C. Waddell, who donated a portion of their value to the museum, with Ford picking up the rest of the tab.) Compared to these pictures, much in contemporary photography can seem flabby and overblown. The backlit color transparencies of Jeff Wall, for example, which were shown at the Marian Goodman Gallery last month, towered overhead and reached lengths of more than 10 feet, but their size seemed designed mostly to evoke the blatant artificiality of billboards. At more than $100,000 a picture they seemed inflated in another way. Such considerations served to obscure the artist's medium-sized ideas about social relations and the environment.
On the other hand, some recent photographs do seem to aim at the kind of unalloyed beauty found in ''The New Vision.'' MacDuff Everton's color panoramas of picturesque itineraries in Britain and South America, at the Janet Borden Gallery (560 Broadway, through Saturday) and Lynn Davis's powerfully stark prints of icebergs, at Lowinsky Gallery (584 Broadway, through Nov. 4) are examples of old-fashioned attitudes about photography - and landscape photography in particular -being dressed up in new, seemingly post-post-modern clothes.
But perhaps the clearest indication of the new-found interest in modernist photography lies in the recent return to abstraction. While rebuking the notion that abstraction is innocent of cultural fetters, the new wave of abstract image-making - by such artists as Cindy Bernard, Adam Fuss, Oliver Wasow, James Welling and, one might argue, the Starn Twins - also reflects an attempt to move beyond the re-use of imagery from mass culture. Siskind, of course, is the living master of modernist abstraction, and his influence can be felt as well as seen in a show at the Zabriskie Gallery called ''Abstraction in Photography'' (724 Fifth Avenue, through Nov. 25). The exhibition includes Fuss, Welling, Andres Serrano and Astrid Klein on its contemporary roster, as well as Stieglitz, Paul Strand, Man Ray and other important modernists who figure in ''The New Vision.''
Abstraction - or at least abstractionist leanings - is an important focus of ''The New Vision,'' although none of the curator's organizing categories address it directly. It can be seen in Paul Strand's close-up of his movie camera, taken in 1922, in Berenice Abbott's distorted self-portrait of about 1930, and in Florence Henri's mirror-image ''Still Life With Lemon and Pear'' circa 1929. None of these images is abstract in the sense that the subject is unrecognizable, but each seeks to separate pictorial experience from everyday reality. Henri's picture, with its Cubist-inspired overlapping planes, puts one in mind of Jan Groover's work of 50 years later. Miss Groover's recent color still lifes, which were shown last season at Robert Miller Gallery, are as convincing revivals of modernist photography as we are likely to see.
Abstraction was attractive to photographers between the wars because it represented a plane of experience in which natural, intuitive vision seemed to override cultural convention. In other words, it was a step outside the bounds of ordinary life and in the direction of the spiritual. Since it was free of cultural coding, it also represented something the artist could claim entirely as his own creation; it was a sign of the artist's independence and visionary status. Abstraction represents much the same notions today, especially among painters in their 20's and early 30's, in whom the urge to resuscitate abstraction seems greatest.
According to the prevailing theories about post-modern life, however, abstraction is no more free of cultural coding than any other form of representation. Indeed, post-modern theorists would argue that abstraction is itself a social representation - one that can be used, for example, to restore the claims of artistic autonomy that post-modernist art disputed. Thus a theoretically grounded artist like James Welling is not merely practicing a form of abstraction, he is critiquing it. A Welling image may look like a Robert Motherwell painting in its form, for example, but it simultaneously reveals itself as a camera image of chunks of Jell-O. Photography, once again, serves as a reminder of culture's domain.
Photography served many of the modernists in much the same way, especially in the practice of photomontage, which was employed by the Dadaists, Surrealists and Constructivists and by political activists like John Heartfield. Photomontage, as a technique, and Dada, Surrealism and Constructivism, as movements, were disruptive and disorienting in an effort to change the way people looked at the world. Rather than aspire to abstraction, the Surrealists and Constructivists tried to find the keys to the new vision hiding in the mudane and overlooked. This helps explain Duchamp's marvelous 1936 photograph of a cigarette shorn of its wrapper, and Rodchenko's worm's-eye view of pine trees in Pushkin Park. In pictures like these - as well as in all the cameraless photograms, solarized prints and multiple exposures the show contains - ''The New Vision'' suggests that modernist photography was as discomfiting to the established culture of its time as post-modernist photography has been to ours.
The difference, of course, is that the Dadaist, Surrealist, Constructivist and Bauhaus artists all had clearly defined (if not always clearly stated) programs. The age of early modernism was also an age of manifestoes and theoretical tracts, and these writings served to position these movements at the leading edge of avant-garde art in the early 20th century. In the late 20th century, modernism no longer is supported by its early theory, and no new theory has emerged that would give it a new vanguard status. Post-modernism's critique of cultural production - in essence, that art can no longer pretend to be innocent of its broad social context - does not leave much room for a modernist response. If the modernist revival is to mean anything more than style - anything more than a fashionable pastiche, fashionably recycled - then it needs to counter post-modernist theory with a theory of its own.
As luck would have it, one post-modernist theorist has already prepared the ground. Jean-Francois Lyotard, in a book called ''The Post-modern Condition: A Report on Knowledge,'' has arrived at the startling conclusion that post-modernism is the precursor of modernism. ''A work can become modern only if it is first post-modern,'' he wrote in 1979. ''Post-modernism thus understood is not modernism at its end but in the nascent state, and this state is constant.'' Lyotard's contrarian point is that modernism has always rebelled against its own momentum: Picasso and Braque broke with Cezanne, Duchamp broke with them, and so on. Every ''post-modern'' rupture is merely another step in modernism's evolution. In this sense, one could say the current modernist revival was inevitable. (''The New Vision: Photography Between the World Wars'' will remain at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 83d Street, through Dec. 31, after which it will travel to the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, the Art Institute of Chicago, the High Museum of Art in Atlanta and the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston. A catalogue of the exhibition, with essays by Maria Morris Hambourg and Christopher Phillips, is being distributed by Harry N. Abrams; a companion volume, ''Photography in the Modern Era: Documents and Critical Writings From Europe, 1913-1940,'' edited by Mr. Phillips, has been published by the museum and Aperture. Every weekend through Nov. 11 the Metropolitan is showing classic modernist films in conjunction with the show.)

HEADLINE: TELEVISION;
The 'Original' 'Show Boat' Comes to TV, Via New Jersey

BYLINE: By KEN MANDELBAUM; Ken Mandelbaum is the author of '' 'A Chorus Line' and the Musicals of Michael Bennett'' (St. Martin's Press).

 BODY:
The only American musical of the 1920's that remains a part of the standard musical theater repertory, the Jerome Kern-Oscar Hammerstein 2d ''Show Boat,'' has been revived frequently on Broadway, in the West End, by opera companies and stock and amateur groups, and in the movies.
But unlike other Hammerstein musicals, such as ''Oklahoma!'' or ''Carousel,'' ''Show Boat'' is never performed in precisely the same version that Ziegfeld Theater audiences witnessed in 1927 when it opened in New York. While Kern's hit tunes (''Make Believe,'' ''Ol' Man River,'' ''Can't Help Lovin' Dat Man,'' ''You Are Love,'' ''Bill'') and the leading characters and the basic plot about prejudice, miscegenation and unhappy marriage have always remained, the 1927 text has been altered in virtually every subsequent incarnation.
So, when the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., and WNET's Great Performances series jointly decided to mount the musical last June, they were faced with an abundance of choices. The result of the course they took can be seen Friday evening at 9 on WNET and other Public Broadcasting Service stations as Great Performances begins its 17th season. 
This new ''Show Boat,'' although initially presented in a theater, was specifically conceived with television in mind. More than 1,200 performers were auditioned, and ''screen tests'' for several of the leading roles were held to find actors who would not only sing and act the parts well but also look right on camera.
Adapted from Edna Ferber's sprawling 1926 best-selling novel about life and love on the Mississippi over a span of 50 years, ''Show Boat'' was a revelation to audiences, offering three-dimensional characters and a depth of emotion unknown to musicals of its period. Kern and Hammerstein pushed ''Show Boat'' further than any musical of its time in terms of the integration of song and dance into the dramatic situation, while creating a score whose richness has rarely been equaled on the musical stage.
When ''Show Boat'' traveled to London in 1928, three of the Broadway numbers were dropped. The 1936 film version omitted five of the stage numbers and added three new ones, while the 1946 Ziegfeld stage revival reorchestrated the score, eliminating tubas and banjos, and cut several of the original songs.
Some of these changes were made to shorten a work that ran more than four hours at its first tryout in the world premiere performance in Washington, while others reflect changing racial attitudes or progress in scenic design. Then, too, some of the original material, written for specific star personalities (Charles Winninger, Helen Morgan, Sammy White and Eva Puck), proved less suited to subsequent performers.
Attempts to restore ''Show Boat'' to its original three-hour form began in the early 1960's, when Miles Kreuger, who wrote a book on the show's history, '' 'Show Boat': The Story of a Classic American Musical,'' and Robert Russell Bennett, the show's original orchestrator, looked into the Rodgers and Hammerstein warehouse on West 52d Street and found boxes containing the original 1927 orchestral parts.
In 1982, the Houston Grand Opera, a company that had already successfully restored Gershwin's ''Porgy and Bess,'' presented ''Show Boat,'' and John McGlinn, then music editor for the company, was asked to reconstruct a full orchestral score from the surviving 1927 parts. This production, also seen on Broadway at the Gershwin Theater in 1983, went back to the original script, restored several musical cuts and employed the original overture and orchestration, both unheard since 1927.
In 1982, the complete original orchestral score, including all material dropped during the show's tryout, was found in the Warner Brothers music storage warehouse in Secaucus, N. J., and this discovery led directly to a landmark recording of the score, issued by EMI a year ago and conducted by Mr. McGlinn. This 3-hour-and-45-minute album contains not only the complete score as heard in 1927 but also music cut on the road, music written for the show but never used, material added for revivals and film versions, and much of the dialogue and underscoring.
The EMI album, while an archival marvel, created a certain amount of controversy over whether the material unearthed for the recording should be used in subsequent stage versions. (EMI has since issued a single-disk version reflecting the score as heard on opening night on Broadway.) William Hammerstein, son of the show's lyricist-librettist, who has frequently directed ''Show Boat'' productions, cautioned, ''We have to remember that when authors and composers who have experience and talent remove numbers from shows they're working on, they do it for good reason.''
The version that television audiences will see, directed for the Paper Mill Playhouse by the company's artistic director, Robert Johanson, takes advantage of 30 years of ''Show Boat'' scholarship. ''We had the good fortune to be able to look back on all of the versions that exist,'' Mr. Johanson said, ''and choose what we felt - based on Edna Ferber's novel and the intentions of Oscar Hammerstein as related to us by his son Bill Hammerstein - was the heart of 'Show Boat.' But we wanted to keep the show under three hours.
''Much of the material on the EMI album doesn't enhance the dramatic action, and I don't think you can do a stage show to satisfy your own personal museum desires. You have to please the audience and not go beyond their endurance level.''
The Paper Mill version departs from the original ''Show Boat'' on several occasions, most notably in its inclusion of a scene from the 1936 film version containing the song ''Ah Still Suits Me.'' That was written to strengthen the role of Joe, the stevedore on the Mississippi steamboat, for Paul Robeson, whose other big song is, of course, ''Ol' Man River.'' Three musical numbers from the original have been eliminated. ''In Dahomey'' was dropped for reasons of time and economics - it requires hiring a large black dance chorus in addition to the regular chorus. ''Till Good Luck Comes My Way'' was cut from productions of the show long ago, as it was part of a scene used to permit a scene change and was eliminated when scenic changes became more fluid. The song ''Ah Still Suits Me,'' which was added to this production, replaces the original's ''Hey, Feller!''
The Paper Mill version softens the starkness of the original opening, substituting the phrase ''colored folk'' for the original's lyric, ''niggers all work on the Mississippi.'' The recording uses the original lyric. The Paper Mill decision was arrived at after much soul searching. William Hammerstein says that he prefers to see the original lyric performed, but adds: ''In every production I've ever staged, I've tried to explain to the black singers that the word was used to show right from the beginning that there are two separate worlds on stage. That opening line is a complaint, made out of deep-seated resentment. While the performers often agree, they just can't say it, and I don't blame them.''
Mr. Johanson offered the black chorus members of his production the chance to decide the issue for themselves, and their decision led to excising the offending term.
The Paper Mill version also contains several major restorations, some not seen since the musical's Broadway premiere. Television audiences will see the scenes of Act II performed in their original order for the first time since 1927, along with the world premiere of the opening chorus of the Trocadero Music Hall scene, eliminated before the show went into rehearsal in 1927.
More significantly, the part of Kim, daughter of Magnolia and Ravenal, has once again been made a significant part of the action of the final scenes. Portrayed by the same actress (Rebecca Baxter) who plays Magnolia, Kim performs the reprise of ''Why Do I Love You?'' - first performed by Irene Dunne on the 1929 national tour of ''Show Boat'' - which is developed in the Paper Mill staging into a full-scale production number.
''Kim has to be brought back,'' says Mr. Johanson, ''just as she was in Ferber's novel, to tie it up and to emphasize the idea that the river and life go on and on. By having the same actress play Kim, we show that people contain something of those that have come before them, and that they carry that forward with them.''
Audiences watching the new version can expect to see a larger company (48) and more dancing than in most recent ''Show Boat'' productions, along with staging that emphasizes the kind of continuous, fluid movement common in contemporary musical productions.
This ''Show Boat'' version comes from New Jersey because WNET, Channel 13, is licensed in Newark, and executives of the channel were interested in presenting an arts program emanating from the Garden State. After visiting Millburn, they decided that they had found a company whose productions of popular American musicals would make ideal fare for home viewing. ''We contacted William Hammerstein and the Ferber estate,'' Mr. Johanson says, ''and it proved miraculously simple to work out. They all wanted it to happen because they wanted a genuine record of the show as a show.''
Paper Mill budgeted $1.2 million for this ''Show Boat,'' about $200,000 more than for most of its musical productions. A grant from the New Jersey State Council on the Arts made up the difference; the council also gave $400,000 to Channel 13 for the telecast.
To translate the production to television, WNET called on Kirk Browning, director of countless television versions of plays, operas and musicals over 40 years. Three performances were shot ''live'' in their entirety, the finished tape reflecting more of the final performance than the others.
According to Ted Chapin, executive director of the Rodgers and Hammerstein office, the Paper Mill/WNET version may become the standard performing version of ''Show Boat'' for years to come. This ever-evolving watershed of musical theater history may finally be taking on definitive form.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (88%);

CITY: LONDON, ENGLAND (57%);

HEADLINE: WHAT'S NEW IN AUTO DEALERSHIPS;
As Profits Slide, a Struggle to Survive

BYLINE: By LISA H. TOWLE; Lisa H. Towle is a New Jersey-based writer.

 BODY:
These are tough times for the nation's $303 billion a year business of selling automobiles.
Over the next two years, the National Automobile Dealers Association, a trade group, estimates that about 10 percent of the nation's 25,000 dealerships will go under. And J.D. Power & Associates, a marketing concern in Agoura Hills, Calif., predicts that by the year 2000 half of the 16,000 dealer owners will sell or go out of business. 
While manufacturers had a banner year in 1988, with total vehicle sales peaking at nearly 16 million units, dealers had their worst year in decades. Their after-tax profits fell to less than 1 percent.
And 1989 will probably be bleaker still. In the first six months, dealers' operating profits plunged by 96 percent from the same 1988 period. After five record years, sales of new autos slumped 7 percent in the first six months. The poor showing prompted the association to revise its 1989 sales forecast to 14.7 million cars and light-duty trucks, down from 15 million.
Yet falling sales are only one reason profits have sagged. Dealers largely blame the rebates and incentives that manufacturers require them to offer buyers to clear their inventories and offset overproduction. Popularized during the recession in the early 80's, these programs, the association says, have outlived their usefulness and only burden dealers with paper work.
''Do manufacturers really think customers don't know that the price they're getting after the rebate is what they should have paid in the first place?'' said Ron Tonkin, president of the association and of Ron Tonkin Dealerships in Portland, Ore. ''Rebates are phony.''
While BMW and Volkswagen plan to drop their rebate programs and offer lower prices, instead, others have not followed suit. In fact, for the first time, some 1990 models will come off the production line with a rebate attached.
To survive, many dealers have taken steps to improve their longstanding public image as smooth operators. Some flaunt cleaner stores and cleaner selling practices.
To gain operating efficiencies, strong dealers are acquiring their weaker, cash-poor brethren for fire-sale prices. They are looking for capital from sources other than banks, some of which have become skittish lenders as dealers' profits have fallen. Several investment bankers including Smith Barney and Oppenheimer are gearing up to help them line up financing.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: THE BUDGET IMPASSE;
Don't Mess With Gramm-Rudman

BYLINE: By ISABLE V. SAWHILL; Isabel V. Sawhill is an economist and senior fellow at the Urban Institute.

 BODY:
Pressure is building to revise Gramm-Rudman, the budget-balancing legislation enacted in 1985 and amended in 1987. Indeed, Congress seems to be on the verge of adopting a pattern of amending the law every two years. This year the argument for revising the targets will have a new and powerful twist: the need to protect people's retirement checks by segregating the Social Security accounts from the rest of the budget for deficit reduction purposes. Although politically appealing, this argument is fundamentally flawed. The right choice is to count Social Security the same way as other outlays and to preserve whatever discipline is left under existing Gramm-Rudman rules.
The concern about Social Security stems from the fact that a 1983 effort to put the system on a fiscally sound path is currently generating an excess of payroll tax receipts over benefit payments. These surpluses are being used to finance a portion of the Government's regular operating expenses. To prevent this, it is argued, we must balance the budget without the use of these funds and set the surpluses aside to pay for the baby-boom generation's retirement. 
But excluding these surpluses from budgetary calculations would balloon the estimated deficit by $54 billion in 1989 and by much higher amounts in subsequent years. Thus, setting them aside would require a much more ambitious set of overall deficit reduction targets and a stretching out of the period over which budget balance is to be achieved if the annual targets are to remain reasonable. In the process, the temptation to modify the 1991 target to put it in the range of what is politically feasible in an election year is likely to be irresistible. The whole package would then be sold to the public as a way of protecting the Social Security system.
Politically, it is a brilliant plan. Liberals will like it because it appears to protect Social Security and conservatives will like because it promises to limit spending. But politics aside, it is a terrible idea.
First, the plan is based on a fundamental misunderstanding of how the Social Security system works. Most people believe that any portion of the surplus not used to pay current Government expenses can be squirreled away for a rainy day. Just as an individual can put aside money in a bank account to spend at a later time, so, it is argued, the trust fund can accumulate surpluses to pay for the baby boom's retirement.
The analogy is a false one. Whatever the Gramm-Rudman rules, the Social Security surplus is invested, by law, in Government securities. The Treasury then spends the money either to finance a portion of the deficit (as it is doing now) or to retire previously accumulated debt by repurchasing bonds from the public (as it would do if there were no deficit). In both cases, the Social Security Trust Fund is left with nothing but paper i.o.u.'s. These do no more to protect the long-term solvency of the system than the moral commitment that already exists to pay these claims. By themselves they do not produce additional real resources to meet the needs of the elderly population.
To be sure, a more ambitious set of deficit reduction targets than are on the books could, if achieved, produce more national savings and more economic growth. For example, if the Treasury were a net lender rather than a net borrower in financial markets this would put downward pressure on interest rates and encourage more investment. But the public shouldn't be led to believe that changing the Gramm-Rudman rules is automatically going to produce more deficit reduction and more growth (the record is not encouraging here). Nor should they think that more growth is going to have more than a minor effect on the long-term solvency of the Social Security system. Higher growth increases payroll tax revenues but it also increases Social Security benefits (because these are tied to wages). The net result is a rather modest improvement in the long-term fiscal position of the system. Indeed, whatever the rules and the rate of economic growth, tax burdens will have to be increased substantially in the 21st century.
A second problem with changing the accounting rules for Social Security is that it would eliminate all fiscal discipline in one of the fastest- growing parts of the budget and set a precedent for doing the same thing in other areas, like Medicare. These two programs have been responsible for all of the growth in Federal outlays relative to gross national product since 1962. Unless this growth is contained, or overall tax burdens are increased substantially, the rest of Government will be starved for funds. Spending for such purposes as education, the war on drugs, preventive health care, infrastructure, research, the environment and other investments in the future will be crowded out by the escalating costs of programs for the elderly. Worse, by artificially segregating Government accounts in this way, chances are that the elderly will come to view this money as rightfully theirs and will demand and receive additional benefits. Outlays would then grow even more rapidly and Social Security would find itself in a still deeper fiscal hole when the baby boom retires.
Finally, using the public's (misplaced) fears about their own or their children's retirement checks as an excuse for changing the Gramm-Rudman rules in 1991 would be the ultimate in budget chicanery. Truth in budgeting requires sticking with the existing targets. If a balanced budget can be achieved by 1993, a more ambitious set of targets, involving surpluses in the Government's overall accounts including Social Security, could then be set. But the purpose would be to encourage economic growth rather than to protect the Social Security system and no segregation of accounts would be necessary.
For all of these reasons the White House and Congress should resist changing the budgetary rules one more time and instead make a concerted effort to meet the current targets. Alternatively, they could scrap the whole Gramm-Rudman process, which has badly distorted budget-making in Washington and contributed little to reducing the deficit. The public, in turn, needs to understand that the Government's ability to meet its obligations to the elderly has nothing to do with how the Government keeps its accounts and everything to do with what we, as citizens, are willing to pay for.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL FINANCE;
Hanging On When the Dow Plunges

BYLINE: By Deborah Rankin

 BODY:
With the stock market on a roller-coaster course again, many people are wondering if they belong in the equity market at all. But most financial experts warn against panic selling should the Dow Jones industrial average experience another precipitous drop, the way it did on Oct. 13, and urge long-term investors to hang on for the ride.
''The only people who should be selling right now are those who have a near-term cash need,'' said George Barbee, executive director of Price Waterhouse's Personal Financial Service in Waltham, Mass. ''If you have college tuition coming up, or plan to retire soon, or hope to buy a house within the next couple of years, you should get out of the equity market if you haven't already.'' 
Mr. Barbee said he expects the market to ''bounce around a lot,'' with daily fluctuations of as much as 100 points. Because of this volatility, people who are going to need to draw on their financial resources soon should put their money into investments ''with little or no risk of capital loss.'' This, he said, means purchasing things like certificates of deposit, Treasury securities and money market funds.
But people who can afford to take a longer-term view, and don't need to touch their money for 5 or 10 years, should be buyers, not sellers, say many financial planners. ''This is not a time to give up and go home,'' said Kathy Muldoon, a vice president with Carter Financial Management in Dallas. ''This is a time when there's money to be made.''
Because she feels that most small investors, ''who buy 100 shares of this and 100 shares of that,'' lack the savvy and experience of big institutions and can be clobbered by short-term trading swings, she suggests buying mutual funds instead. Among the value-oriented funds she thinks will perform well in the future are Weingarten Equity Fund (managed by AIM Distributors in Houston), Royce Fund-Value Series (Quest Distributors in New York), Templeton Growth Fund and Templeton World Fund (Templeton Funds in St. Petersburg, Fla.), and any of the Pioneer equity funds - Pioneer Fund, Pioneer II and Pioneer Three (Pioneer Group in Boston).
Dollar-cost averaging, in which people invest a set sum in mutual funds (or individual stocks) on a regular basis, remains a good technique, but should be speeded up now, she said. ''You ought to be accelerating, by amount and timing. If you had been investing $500 every month, think about doubling that amount and buying every two weeks.''
Does this mean you should be 100 percent in equities? Far from it, although studies by Ibbotson Associates, a Chicago-based research group, show that for almost every 5-year and 10-year period since the crash of 1929, stocks have far outpaced fixed-income investments.
''Most of my clients are only 25 to 30 percent in stocks, which is probably one reason that I didn't get a single client call after Friday the 13th,'' said Alexandra Armstrong, head of a Washington, D.C., financial planning firm bearing her name.
Miss Armstrong believes it is a good time to purchase ''defensive stocks'' - those likely to suffer less in a recession - like Waste Management, Disney and Martin Marietta. For those who prefer mutual funds, she suggests Washington Mutual Investors, a fully invested growth and income fund (American Funds Distributors in Brea, Calif.).
The rest of her clients' portfolios are in a mix of fixed-income investments, like bonds and Treasury bills, and real estate, through such means as partnership arrangements. But determining the exact mix of these different investments, a technique called asset allocation, can be a difficult task in today's unsettled times.
''There's no magic formula,'' said Dennis J. Kelly, a financial planner and vice president in the New York office of Janney Montgomery Scott Inc., a Philadelphia brokerage house. ''In the last 15 years or so, we've had five major tax acts, four recessions, watched interest rates go from 21 percent to 7 percent, and seen inflation go from 15 percent to 1 percent. All these vagaries impact investors, and will continue to exist.''
Mr. Kelly employs several strategies to minimize the impact of such volatility on clients' portfolios. With fixed-income investments, he staggers maturities, so that clients have a range of 1- to 12-year paper. He then reinvests as the shorter-term securities come due, so that clients earn a rolling average of market rates. To maintain diversity outside the fixed-income area, he also suggests investing the semi-annual bond coupons and the discount amounts between the purchase price and the face value of Treasury bills in individual stocks or stock mutual funds.
But he is wary of going out too long in fixed-income securities, and prefers to concentrate in the 5- to 10-year range. ''That's just far enough out so you can get some capital appreciation should rates drop dramatically, but not so far out that you'll get killed if you guess wrong.''
For individual stocks, Mr. Kelly recommends Wal-Mart Stores because it is well positioned to weather an economic slowdown. ''During a recession, people who historically shop at traditional department stores step down a peg or two, and bargain-hunt at discounters,'' he said. ''Wal-Mart's new warehousing concept has given them a jump on their competitors.'' He also likes certain oil stocks, particularly Amoco and Sonat.
For mutual fund investors, he suggests Addison Capital, a low-load proprietary fund of Janney Montgomery available through brokers. Many load funds have a sliding scale of front-end sales charges, which decline as the amount invested increases. Mr. Kelly suggested that people who plan to use dollar-cost averaging to purchase shares can minimize the sales charges with such funds by signing a ''letter of intent'' stating that they plan to buy a certain amount in the fund over 13 months. Even though the purchases may be made monthly, rather than in one lump sum, the buyer can qualify for the lowest sales charge on the total amount invested over that period, he said.
Of course, people can avoid sales charges entirely by finding a no-load fund that they like. Sheldon Jacobs, editor of the No-Load Fund Investor, a monthly newsletter, says that while he's ''long-term bullish'' on the market, he also thinks it's time to cut holdings of speculative growth funds and switch to more conservative funds with low volatility. He recommends a number of ''all-weather'' funds, which tend to outperform their peers in down markets but lag a bit in up markets. His choices: Wellesley Income and Vanguard Star (Vanguard Group in Valley Forge, Pa.), Janus Fund (Janus Capital in Denver), Gabelli Asset (Gabelli Funds in New York), Evergreen Total Return (Saxon Woods Asset Management in Harrison, N.Y.) and Strong Investment (Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management in Milwaukee).

HEADLINE: The Realities of 'Friday the 13th'

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
Thank you, Tokyo.
Had it not been for the Japanese, the recent 190-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average could have gone from a scary market aberration to a disastrous financial freefall. With global exchanges now linked, as trading closed in New York that Friday, all eyes were on how Tokyo would open the following Monday. But because Japan remained calm, disaster was averted. ''If it weren't for Japan holding up, I'd say that internationalization was a disaster,'' said Barton M. Biggs, a managing director at Morgan Stanley & Co.
But the fact that Japan held firm illustrates the benefits - and the risks - of continued market globalization. Financial theory teaches that there are no returns without risk and greater stock market links give investors the opportunity to make more money in more places. With that, however, comes new risks: of a system that is far more vulnerable to sudden jolts and of individual central banks that are increasingly unable to do anything about it.
''The danger of globalization is that if everyone goes crazy at the same time, you've got a bigger problem than before,'' said Hans Stoll, director of financial markets research at the Owen Graduate School of Management at Vanderbilt University. Said Richard Levich, a finance professor at New York Unversity's Stern School of Business: ''You've got more eyes focused and when news comes out you've got more people running through a small door.'' 
And that rush is what almost took place when the Dow plunged 190 points in the last 45 minutes before the New York Stock Exchange closed on Oct. 13. The Federal Reserve Board took advantage of the weekend, when most markets were closed, to try to calm the markets by promising liquidity.
Financial experts say the event adds several points to the debate about the impact of greater market internationalization:
* The appetite for foreign equities will increase despite such terrifying market plunges because these securities help provide diversification that reduces portfolio risk.
* On any single day, except for times of worldwide panic, most stock exchanges generally act independent of one another. In general, they respond to specific economic, cultural and regulatory environments in their countries - differences that keep the various equity markets from marching in lock step. A rise in prices in London doesn't automatically spell a rise that day in Tokyo.
* Over time, globalization will reduce the power governments have over their nation's economy. The increased ease with which money can flow across borders means policy makers can no longer assume that their nation's capital is captive. Because of this, some say financial markets will play a larger role in overriding, or even setting, economic policy.
* When a worldwide market panic sets in, globalization can take a bad situation in one market and create an international crisis. This took place during the stock market plunge in October 1987 when ''hot money'' from investors seeking to liquidate their positions at any price circled the globe.
* Investors have less of a safety net than they once had because there is now no single lender of last resort. In the past, jittery American markets could be calmed by assurances of ample liquidity from the Federal Reserve. While such assurances are still powerful, globalization lessens their impact. This is because central banks all have different national interests and cannot be expected to act as a united front during a crisis.
''It doesn't really matter whether globalization is good or bad,'' said James Rogers, a finance professor at the Columbia University Business School. ''Nothing can be done about it. Electronics and communications are changing the world. There's lots of money sloshing around the world and it's got to go somewhere. Many of the economies are closely linked and that means their markets will be closely linked. Now, everyone has to worry.''
 
Cross-Border Craze
 Certainly, nothing appears to be halting the trend toward greater cross-border equity trading. As American firms set up shop overseas and foreign investment houses settle here, it has become increasingly easy for investors to buy the stocks of other nations.
Since 1980, foreign trading in United States securities has increased by 19 percent annually to reach $384 billion at the end of 1988. American purchases of foreign equities have increased by about 30 percent annually, reaching about $151 billion in 1988, according to the Securities Industry Association.
From an investment perspective, globalization provides investors a safe way to get greater portfolio diversification without reducing their expected returns. The notion is that investing in many countries provides safety since as one country's market goes up, another's may go down.
As a result, overseas investments are becoming a standard part of most institutional portfolios. And, increasingly, mutual funds made up of stocks from a single country or geographic region are being bought by retail investors. Since 1985, global equity funds have grown faster than the mutual fund industry in general. With about $20 billion in assets, they now represent about 10 percent of the total mutual fund market, according to the Investment Company Institute.
Yet their returns can be wiped out in one terrifying moment if investors panic. While long-term investors may be fine, those with short-term focus can be devastated.
''This time we saw the Frankfurt market drop after our market dropped,'' said John J. Phelan, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange. ''But that seemed to be a local condition rather than enormous amounts of hot money running around the world. Hot money makes the markets riskier, more volatile, for short periods of time. What we saw after 1987, is that if you hung on, in most markets in the world you would have been better off than before 1987 occurred.''
Ironically, for all the market linkages, studies show that exchanges generally perform independently of one another. ''The evidence shows that markets are driven by what happened in local economies,'' said Gary P. Brinson, president of Chicago-based Brinson Partners, which manages about $12.5 billion.
Of course, there are global economic trends that can affect many markets similarly. For instance, most world markets have rebounded since the 1987 crash, largely due to sustained global economic growth. The tendency of markets to respond to different cues, while still keeping an eye on one another, was also evident in the Dow's recent 190-point plunge. New York fell on Friday and then recovered on Monday. London and Tokyo remained firm on Monday.
 
Japanese Composure
 ''When the Japanese market didn't overreact, other markets sensed what was happening and came back into synch,'' said Joseph R. Hardiman, president of the National Association of Securities Dealers Inc.
The events also reflect the influence that investor psychology has on the markets. For instance, Mr. Brinson said Japanese investors are generally less sensitive to risk considerations and are more likely to ride out a storm. ''They have been through an ebullient period of their economy,'' he said. ''Their currency and their markets are strong. It's given the Japanese a great deal of self-confidence about their situation.''
Likewise, the unexpectedly steep decline of 13 percent in the Frankfurt exchange reflected unique West German attitudes. ''We were flabbergasted that the German market went down as far as it did,'' Mr. Brinson said. ''German investors are almost hyper risk-averse and if any global event takes place, it is amplified within the minds of the German people.''
In fact, these differing responses to the 190-point drop in New York has turned some notions about the German and Japanese markets on their heads. Theoretically, the underpriced German market should be considered a less risky investment than the Japanese market, where stocks are considered overpriced. But that theory did not hold in the most recent drop.
''German individuals panicked because of what was happening in the United States,'' said Mr. Biggs of Morgan Stanley. ''After what happened last week, the risk premium for Germany should go up, and for Japan it should go down. What all professionals agree is that Japan, the most overpriced market in the world, consistently understands panic better than anyone else.''
Increased market globalization is also bringing about shifts in power between financial markets and their home governments. ''The most significant implication of globalization is that a domestic government cannot really control the economic destiny of a country because the capital will leave,'' said Michael A. Petrino, president of Matrix Capital Management in Greenwich, Conn. ''For instance, if you have a disadvantageous tax policy, the capital will leave, unemployment will go up and you get thrown out of office. This means that markets will determine economic policy to a larger degree than they did when we had highly segmented markets.''
And this means a new role for the central banks. Steven Einhorn, chairman of the investment policy committee at Goldman Sachs, said that increased market links have brought about heightened international economic policy coordination, with the Group of Seven's attempts to stabilize foreign exchange rates one prominent example. After October 1987, virtually all major central banks provided liquidity to their economies. ''They acted like our central bank, and going forward, they would continue to do that,'' Mr. Einhorn said.
But others aren't so sure. ''Averting a crisis requires coordination of central banks; and when there are national interests that diverge, you may not be able to assure that,'' said William L. Silber, a professor of finance at New York University's Stern School of Business. ''A crisis in Japan, for instance, may lead the Japanese central bank to do something that may not be in the best interest of all other countries. You do not have the safety net of a single central bank except to the extent that central banks agree to cooperate. That's a safety net, with holes.''
 
Global Limitations
 Still, for all these links, barriers remain that prevent the worlds' exchanges from becoming more fully integrated. The limitations are real: back-office operations are often cumbersome and time-consuming, settlements in different currencies can be problematic and regulations vary significantly among countries, as do corporate accounting standards.
''The major barrier to greater globalization is regulation,'' said Morris Mendelson, a professor of finance at the Wharton School of Business. ''America doesn't like Americans being taken for a ride on foreign exchanges. And there are significant clearing and settlement problems. Let's say you want to trade Japanese securities in Tokyo. You've got to ship them off to Tokyo and convert your money to yen. That's a lot of delays.'' But Steven H. Reynolds, managing director of the investment group at the Bankers Trust Company, noted that many of these barriers are falling. ''Ten years ago, the limitations were infinite,'' he said. ''Day by day, they are being broken down. The world is changing rapidly toward a more unified system.''
What is more, informal contacts among traders and bankers are solidifying. Mr. Reynolds said that after the October 1987 crash, ''there was little cooperation and coordination among market participants.'' But, this time, ''principals in this country contacted people overseas and exchanged knowledge so that investors didn't act irrationally.''

HEADLINE: WEEK IN BUSINESS;
Hectic Recovery For Stock Prices

BYLINE: By STEVE DODSON

 BODY:
Stocks came back after the Friday the 13th plunge of 190 points. Sell orders poured in when the markets opened on Monday and the Dow Jones industrial average had an early 60- point loss but the market turned around within about an hour and the day ended with the Dow up 88 points. Volume on Monday was 416 million shares, the fourth-busiest day ever. The rest of the week saw an 18-point drop on Tuesday but a gain of nearly 40 points on Thursday. The Dow closed out the week at 2,689.14, up 119.88 points, a record. Before the American markets opened Monday, the European markets showed losses, with Frankfurt losing the most, 13 percent. But the Tokyo market fell only 2 percent, helping prevent a recurrence of the worldwide panic seen in the October 1987 crash. So far, the only serious damage appeared to be to some takeover deals, particularly in the airlines. Since Oct. 12, the Dow Jones transportation index has fallen 17 percent. 
 
*
 The credit markets benefited as the Federal Reserve gave clear indications early in the week that it would feed money to the economy to help alleviate any stock market crisis. Yields on the Treasury's 30-year bonds stayed below 8 percent all week. At week's end, however, some people in the credit markets were saying they detected signs that the Fed had decided it had eased enough and would hold the key short-term rate, the Fed funds rate, at about 8.75 percent . . . The dollar stabilized after plunging during the stock selloff.
 
*
 The problems of ''junk bonds'' worsened. At least four issues of the high-yield securities, totaling more than $1.5 billion, were postponed because of poor market conditions. The junk market has had the jitters since late summer. Companies issuing the bonds must pay rates as much as seven percentage points higher than on comparable Treasury issues.
 
*
 Housing construction was down 5.2 percent in September, with the annual rate dropping to 1.26 million units, its slowest pace in seven years. A large inventory of unsold homes and fears about rising mortgage rates last month were given the blame . . . Consumer prices rose a modest two-tenths of a percent in September, leaving the inflation rate so far in 1989 at the same 4.4 percent posted in 1988 . . . The trade deficit widened sharply in August, reaching $10.8 billion, as imports climbed to a record level and exports posted a small decline . . . Business sales were up a strong 3.1 percent in August, while inventories rose only three-tenths of a percent.
 
*
 Two airline deals were in turmoil. The stock market's plunge was set off by the failure of the UAL bidding group to complete financing for its $6.75 billion offer for the parent of United Airlines. The group said it would try to organize a lower bid, but that effort was dealt a severe blow last week when British Airways said it would no longer take part. In the original offer, British Air was to have taken a 15 percent stake in exchange for providing the bulk of the deal's cash, $750 million. UAL stock was near $170 late Friday; earlier this month it had traded near the $300 a share being offered by the bidding group . . . In the wake of the market selloff, Donald J. Trump withdrew his $120-a-share, $7.5 billion offer for AMR, the parent of American Airlines. He said he might make another offer, at a lower price.
 
*
 Some big names reported profits for the third quarter. I.B.M.'s earnings were down 29.7 percent, at the low end of what had been expected. Digital Equipment was off 32.5 percent. Apple Computer was up 49 percent because of a stock transaction, but operating profit rose only 2 percent . . . Philip Morris, the world's largest consumer goods company, had a 21 percent rise in earnings . . . Merrill Lynch was down 37.5 percent, but Charles Schwab had a 70 percent gain . . . Citicorp had a 9 percent decrease, but Wells Fargo was up 17 percent and NCNB's profit more than doubled. J. P. Morgan and Manufacturers Hanover had the big losses that had been expected after they added to their reserves for third world loans . . . A.T.&T. was up 19 percent; MCI rose 58.7 percent, and GTE was ahead 17.6 percent . . . Drug companies generally reported double-digit percentage gains.
 
*
 Miscellanea. Ford Motor will quit importing its Scorpio luxury sports sedan from West Germany because of poor sales. The base price for the car is $28,400 . . . The cost-of-living adjustment in Social Security benefits will be 4.7 percent next year, the largest increase in seven and a half years . . . Farley Inc. will sell its Cluett-Peabody unit to Bidermann of France for $600 million. Bidermann's designer clothing lines include Ralph Lauren and Yves Saint Laurent. Cluett-Peabody makes Arrow shirts and Gold Toe socks . . . K Mart is paying $322 million for the 41 stores of Pace Membership Warehouse Inc., a Colorado-based operator of no-frills discount stores.

HEADLINE: Prospects;
Free Trade With Mexico

BYLINE: By JOEL KURTZMAN

 BODY:
In comments made before a Senate hearing on the Latin American debt situation, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher predicted that the United States and Mexico would eventually enter into a free-trade agreement similar to the one that went into effect with Canada in January. Four experts comment on the possibility.
 
Rogelio Ramirez de la O
General director, Ecanal, an economic analysis and consulting firm in Mexico City.
 We are heading in the direction of a free-trade agreement. It is only natural to formalize the integration of our two countries, which is happening anyway. A silent agreement is in place and an agreement will only formalize it under a corpus of law. The Mexican Government has given the signals that say it is willing to ensure access to Mexico and to negotiate a formalized agreement. Mexico will go along with a pact if it is not outside the scope of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade rules. Mexico has done a great deal of homework on opening its economy. Conditions for an agreement could proceed out of negotiations on textiles, electronics and autos. 
The Mexican economy stands to benefit most from an agreement because the American markets are so large. To serve that market Mexico would have to build larger plants and get economies of scale. That will bring much greater levels of productivity.
 
Alan J. Stoga
Managing director, Kissinger Associates.
 A free-trade agreement with Mexico is desirable, but it should include Canada. I would say the optimal strategy is for the three countries to get together to define their objectives. They should begin with a free-trade agreement and then think beyond to a common market agreement.
Clearly we need to do what Japan did. Japanese industries have been obtaining products from other countries in Southeast Asia. We need to do the same thing but we need to do it with Mexico. We need to do this not just to take advantage of low wages but also to take advantage of the more pro-export structure of Mexico. We need to create better trade and have a prosperous Mexico.
 
Sidney Weintraub
Dean Rusk Professor, Lyndon Baines Johnson School of Public Affairs, University of Texas, and author of ''Marriage of Convenience: the relationship between Mexico and the United States.''
 If Commerce Secretary Mossbacher says ''Let's do it,'' I think we'll just gulp and stall. In the next 10 years we may see a free-trade agreement with Mexico, but it won't come before then. What we'll see is a process. We'll see a series of agreements on textile quotas, steel, intellectual property and so on. We'll see a series of negotiations that will conclude in a free-trade agreement. The rest of the world is moving toward regional trading blocks and big corporations and industries trading with each other. But I think Canada will be reluctant to share its preferential access to the American market with Mexico.
 
C. Michael Aho
Chief economist, Council on Foreign Relations.
 Mexico has asked for years to have access to the American market. However, I think Mexico's nationalists will be very vociferous against an agreement. American labor unions don't want to compete with low-wage Mexican labor so they're against a pact. I don't see a compreshensive agreement between Mexico and the United States before the next century.
The problem with a bilateral trade pact is that it will tend to undermine the expectations that were engendered by the first one with Canada. If we want to have a special auto pact with Mexico, Canada will be in an uproar.
The one thing that could push an agreement, however, is if the negotiations under way at the GATT fail to produce results. In the mid-1980's, Reagan was frustrated on trade and said he'd negotiate bilateral trade agreements with whatever country he could find. With the Canadian free-trade agreement he demonstrated he could do it. Mexico would be the only other that could be justified.

HEADLINE: Private Carriers vs. the Post Office

BYLINE: By WAYNE CURTIS; Wayne Curtis is a writer on Peaks Island, Me.

 BODY:
Last summer, about 5,000 Atlanta subscribers to Time, Sports Illustrated, People and other Time Warner publications found their magazines in unexpected places: not in their mailboxes, but sealed in waterproof plastic bags under their boxes and on their doorsteps.
It was the work of Publishers Express Inc., a wholly owned Atlanta subsidiary of Time Warner Inc. Within five years, Publishers Express plans to open a much wider crack in the United States Postal Service monopoly by delivering magazines, catalogues and advertising in 38 metropolitan areas nationwide.
Private carriers like Publishers Express hope to thrive as magazine publishers and direct marketers search for alternatives to the post office. At present, private carriers deliver about a million magazines a month, compared with the 866 million magazines and newspapers delivered at second-class rates by the Postal Service each month. But the private services say they are poised to expand rapidly after the next postal rate increase, possibly in early 1991. 
Even a member of the United States Postal Rate Commission, John W. Crutcher, grants that the private carriers are a threat. ''I see no reason they can't make a go of it, especially in doing some cream-skimming,'' he said. The Postal Service could find itself with a dwindling volume of magazines and bulk mail to support higher-cost delivery routes and services, he added. ''If they choose to let all that business go out the door, the cost of mailing a letter would increase more dramatically.''
If Time Warner see private delivery first as a means of cutting its own costs, United Delivery Systems wants to exploit an emerging market. U.D.S., based in Grand Rapids, Mich., dominates the industry, delivering 800,000 magazines a month. Phillip D. Miller, the company's founder, sees his business taking off. ''There's no question that the last postal rate increase created the environment for alternate delivery to thrive,'' he said.
Private carriers are taking advantage of exceptions to the Postal Service's legal monopoly on mail. Just as the United Parcel Service and the Federal Express Corporation can deliver packages and overnight letters, Publishers Express and U.D.S. depend on provisions allowing private delivery of catalogues and magazines.
The private carriers face more obstacles than rain, hail, sleet and snow. Previous private efforts to deliver magazines have failed. The Postal Service says its own rates might stabilize in the 1990's. When rates held steady in the mid-1980's, U.D.S. deliveries dropped 70 percent.
But large mailers are increasingly open to private carriers. Though alternate delivery costs are comparable to the Postal Service's now, mailers fear the next second-class rate increase will be at least 25 percent. In April 1988 the Postal Service raised rates by 18 percent. ''There's more interest in alternate delivery now than I've seen in years,'' said Marilyn Luers, distribution supervisor at the Meredith Corporation.
Meredith, one of the first publishers to pursue alternatives to the post office, uses U.D.S. to deliver 345,000 copies a month, including 200,000 of Better Homes and Gardens. The Hearst Corporation delivers 187,000 magazines a month through private carriers. Times Mirror Magazines Inc. distributes 40,000 copies a month of three titles - Golf, Popular Science, and Home Mechanix - through U.D.S. in Michigan. ''Almost everything one hears about postal rates is negative, and my level of interest rises as we get closer to the next rate increase,'' said Diane Potter, Times Mirror Magazines' vice president of circulation.
Time Warner's service delivers just 21,000 magazines a month now, but it has the potential for huge expansion. Time Warner is the nation's largest second-class mailer, with $175 million in magazine postal charges last year. Since 1971 Time magazine's delivery costs have soared sevenfold. ''There's no question that postal costs have far outstripped the other costs of publishing,'' said Deane D. Raley Jr., the company's director of paper purchasing, distribution and postal affairs.
Publishers Express is only Time Warner's latest, and largest, delivery venture. ''We've dabbled in it from the beginning,'' Mr. Raley said. ''We delivered in milk trucks when they had milk trucks.''
The new service was begun in June in the Atlanta suburb of Marietta. Just 13 part-time carriers drive their routes weekdays between 3:30 A.M. and 6:30 A.M. Mr. Raley contends that Publishers Express can deliver magazines earlier and in better condition than the Postal Service. ''Getting it there before dawn is sort of like getting it there a day early for people who work,'' he said.
Time Warner recently signed up Meredith and Rupert Murdoch's News America Publishing Inc. as partners in Publishers Express. In five years, the venture plans to employ 2,200 carriers.
Publishers Express plans to wrap catalogues and direct-mail advertising with the magazines. Fees from these ''ride-alongs'' can give private carriers a major advantage, allowing them to lower their rates for magazines. The Postal Service delivers advertisements and catalogues as third-class mail, prohibiting publishers from sending these with their magazines at lower second-class rates.
U.D.S. already has close ties with direct marketers. Mr. Miller, U.D.S.'s 38-year-old president, founded the company in 1973 to deliver supermarket and department store circulars. With a typical U.D.S.-delivered magazine, two or three catalogues or advertising inserts ride along. The company also delivers advertising packets separately from magazines.
Within five years, U.D.S. aspires to be in the top 95 metropolitan areas, reaching 40 percent of all mailboxes in the United States, with potential annual revenues of $400 million, up from $5 million currently. But so far, U.D.S. is ''a national umbrella organization'' by Mr. Miller's description only, delivering to just 14 Middle Western markets and Buffalo. Publishers have not given Mr. Miller the long-term commitments he needs to build a nationwide system. Mr. Miller said he is negotiating five-year contracts with Hearst and Meredith, but most of his current contracts have 60- or 90-day termination clauses.
The odds have been against any private magazine carrier circumventing the post office for long. In the 1970's, many carriers failed when they tried to match the Government's rates. Poor service doomed another wave of small carriers that vanished in the early 1980's. Publishers were ''awash with complaints'' about damaged or undelivered magazines, said Larry Flynn, director of customer service at Hearst Publications.
Some private carriers say that publishers flirted with alternate delivery just to frighten the Postal Service into moderating its rate increases in the mid-1980's. ''Alternate delivery has been like the second girlfriend,'' said Leonard Merewitz, a Postal Rate Commission economist. ''Mailers visit them to make their first girlfriend jealous, but they eventually come back.''
Ken Hunter, an associate postmaster general, is confident that his agency will prevail. ''If we get our costs back at or below the Consumer Price Index, which we have every intention of doing, then I think alternate delivery will subside again,'' he said.
But Mr. Miller's optimism remains boundless. ''We believe that some day we'll be looked back on as another Federal Express or MCI,'' Mr. Miller said. ''There was no such thing as an overnight package 15 years ago. There was no such thing as a newspaper insert 20 years ago. I'm very confident that we've got the trend right.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: FORECASTING INFLATION;
'P-Star' Can Spot Inflationary Trends

BYLINE: By L. DOUGLAS LEE; L. Douglas Lee is vice president and chief economist of County NatWest/Washington Analysis Corporation, part of the NatWest Banking Group.

 BODY:
Recent work at the Federal Reserve board, christened P-Star analysis, has stimulated a renewed debate about the relationship between the money supply and inflation. This new work is based on the earlier work of Irving Fisher, which he conducted evidence, and concluded that the P-Star concept is helpful in understanding inflation.
Members of the Federal Reserve and its staff have been very careful in describing the usefulness of the P-Star concept. This is not a short-term forecasting tool that will predict next month's consumer price index. Nor will it provide simple answers to the policy choices central bankers must make. 
What P-Star will do is provide a reasonably useful guide to whether inflation should be expected to speed up or slow down over the next 6 to 12 months. It can serve as an indicator of inflation over this period of time, provided there are no shocks to the system, like a major oil price change, and provided the current trends continue with respect to growth and the velocity of money - the number of times each unit of money is used to purchase the nation's output of goods and services each year.
After reviewing the Federal Reserve's analysis and agreeing that it provides a useful approach to understanding the relationship between the money supply and inflation, one is left wondering how well P-Star will travel. Can it be applied to other countries?
If a concept is really helpful in understanding the workings of a capitalist economy, then it should be helpful when applied to any particular capitalist economy. To ascertain whether P-Star is equally useful outside of the United states, my colleagues and I examined the concept as a predictive tool in a number of different countries. We applied P-Star analysis to the United States, Britain, Japan and Australia. For each country, we found that the P-Star concept is useful in understanding the relationship between the money supply and inflation.
Applying empirical tests to any economic theory is always a tricky proposition, but this is even more true when the theory is tested for different countries.
Capitalism is the common denominator, but each economy has its own characteristics. Definitions of commonly used terms, like money supply, vary. Measurements are made differently and data are aggregated differently. In some cases, financial instruments in one country do not have an exact counterpart in another.
With this standard in mind, we have reached conclusions about the outlook for inflation in each of the countries we examined. What makes these conclusions so interesting is that in each case P-Star analysis confirms the results of our inflation analysis based on traditional methods using real growth, wage trends, capital costs, resource costs, and so on.
In the case of Japan, our economists have concluded that the P-Star analysis is useful, provided transitory shocks like the oil crisis and the recently imposed 3 percent consumption tax are excluded. This work suggests that inflation in Japan has probably peaked as these special factors boosting inflation work through the system.
For Britain, there appears to be an unusually long time lag between changes in the actual rate of inflation and changes in the expected rate of inflation. Our analysis suggests that the current policy that has resulted in 14 percent interest rates and a sharp slowdown in the growth of the money supply is not excessive. However, it will have to be maintained for some time before the inflation outlook improves.
In Australia, the leveling out in the growth of the money supply since the end of 1988 points to the likelihood that there will be a lower inflation rate for 1990 and 1991.
No matter which country is used for the P-Star analysis, however, a healthy dose of caution is appropriate. It is quite possible that the stock of money outstanding in the world is large enough to maintain inflation's current momentum. In other words, there is still a substantial amount of liquidity in the global economy that was accumulated during 1987 and 1988 and that could cause inflation problems. Central bankers must continue to be alert to this possibility as they develop their policies.
It is our conclusion that P-Star is not foolproof. But neither is any other tool of economic analysis. Its results are sensitive to assumptions about economic growth, money velocity, and money growth, and it is most useful in judging the long-run forces influencing inflation. Having said that it is not perfect, however, it is also worth saying that the P-Star analysis is a useful addition to the tools that help us better understand the workings of the economy. In short, P-Star travels well.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: FORECASTING INFLATION;
The Fed's New Tool Just Doesn't Work

BYLINE: By LACY H. HUNT; Lacy H. Hunt is chief economist at Carroll, McEntee & McGinley Inc. Stephanie Murphy assisted with this article.

 BODY:
The research staff of the board of Governors of the Federal Reserve has developed what is described as a new method for forecasting inflation. The announcement of this new construct brought a great deal of publicity. The equation, which is called P-Star, is a throwback to strict monetarism in its most primitive form. However, my analysis of P-Star's results over the last three years shows it to have been a faulty predictor of inflation. A number of sound fundamental reasons suggest this approach is too limited to be used as a tool for successful monetary policy decisions.
P-Star is a derivative of an equation developed by Irving Fisher, the great American economist of the early 20th century. Professor Fisher's original equation stated that the money supply, called M, when multiplied by the velocity of money, called V, equals the current dollar value of the nation's gross national product. By velocity, Professor Fisher meant the number of times a dollar passes through the economy as it buys the nation's output. In this equation the term ''P'' is what economists call the current price level or the rate of inflation in the economy. 
To arrive at P-Star, the Federal Reserve's staff uses as a starting point the same equation Professor Fisher used. But the researchers at the Federal Reserve have introduced assumptions that transform this simple economic truism into a forecasting device. Rather than use the current value of velocity, the Federal Reserve's equation fixes it at its 30-year historical average, not at its current rates. And, instead of using the actual real growth rate in the economy in the equation, the Federal Reserve substitutes a figure - 2.5 percent - which it deems to be the long-term annual potential growth rate of the economy. According to the Federal Reserve, this formula is a guide to identifying the nation's future inflationary tendencies.
There are a number of limitations to the Federal Reserve's approach. First, since the Federal Reserve's equation uses a fixed value for the velocity of money and the potential growth rate of G.N.P., then the inflation rate - in the Federal Reserve's equation - can only be determined by changes in the money supply. But, in reality, the inflation rate is determined by the demand from all sectors of the economy and the growth of the money supply is only one aspect of that demand. Fiscal policy, family income, corporate income and international income all contribute to inflation. So do the costs of production, which are influenced by changes in wage rates, swings in productivity, availability of plant capacity, movements in the price of oil, argricultural and other commodities prices, as well as the cost of imported goods.
In addition, the assumption of a stable rate of velocity for money is highly questionable. In late 1986 and early 1987, velocity averaged about 1.55, which means that each dollar changed hands 1.55 times during each of those years. In the second quarter of this year, however, velocity jumped to almost 1.69 - a significant increase. Velocity can also be ascertained only after the fact. Swings in interest rates and the changing attitudes of investors about current and prospective economic conditions, as well as other factors, all influence changes in velocity.
The Federal Reserve's researchers also ignore the fact that the economy does not grow at a constant rate of 2.5 percent from quarter to quarter as this forecasting tool assumes. The actual growth rate may rise above, and then fall below, the assumed potential rate of growth for several years. Problems also arise in measuring the potential rate of growth in the economy. While the Federal Reserve's figure may have been valid in the 1960's and 1970's, such a number is probably too optimistic in the current environment of diminishing labor-force growth and considerably weaker gains in productivity.
In view of these limitations, one might expect that P-Star is doing a poor job forecasting actual inflation. The surprise is how bad it really is. According to my analysis, in seven of the last nine quarters, P-Star underestimated the inflation rate. Only once was P-Star on target. P-Star's cumulative error of 5 percent was greater than the inflation rate for all of 1988. This shows the problem with inserting fixed values into Professor Fisher's old equation.
There is no reason to believe that the P-Star equation will provide any useful information about future inflationary trends unless velocity were stable, the economy grew at a fairly constant rate, and the prices of labor, oil, and all other inputs to production remained fixed. By relying on P-Star, the Federal Reserve could misread the economy's future inflation rate, thereby making misguided policy moves. The Federal Reserve may be lulled into the view that inflation is under control when that is not the case.
