HEADLINE: FAULT LINES;
California Struggles With The Other Side Of Its Dream

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
FROM the beginning, California has been the American symbol of opportunity, freedom, renewal, sunny paradise and human dominion over a land that was as beautiful as it was terrible. Dams and aqueducts brought water into the desert, where vast cities and farms blossomed. Dramatic bridges and mammoth freeways turned small towns into powerful cities. Roads were terraced into steep hillsides and houses were cantilevered along canyon walls.
In just 15 seconds on Tuesday evening, nature sought to restore a bit of its equilibrium. A powerful earthquake knocked down a freeway in Oakland, ravaged San Francisco's Marina district and tore the commercial heart out of the lovely tourist town of Santa Cruz near the quake's epicenter south of the bay. Scores of people died, a painful reminder that California, for all its beauty and wealth, is particularly vulnerable to some of nature's harsher realities. 
The quake came at a time when the Golden State was already grappling with a profound shift in its once-shimmering self image as problems mounted with growth. The image of Los Angeles has changed from that of a utopia of wide beaches and myriad possibilities to that of a vacuous sprawl of clogged traffic and brutal crack gangs under a dirty halo of smog. Pretty San Francisco evokes grim thoughts of AIDS.
''We are in a watershed time even without this quake,'' said the historian Kevin Starr in San Francisco. ''This is not the end of the California dream, but an element of correction has become an essential part of the California formula. The idea of coming to California to escape reality was a bad thing for the state, for its literature and culture.''
It was sobering to know that Tuesday's frightening jolt was perhaps only one-thirtieth as powerful as the ''Big One'' that the experts say is all but inevitable. The United States Geological Survey said the quake, which measured 6.9 on the Richter scale, did nothing to alter its ominous warning that there is a 60 percent chance of a quake with a Richter magnitude of 7.5 to 8.0 along the San Andreas Fault near Los Angeles and a 50 percent chance of one in the Bay Area in the next 30 years.
Almost from the Gold Rush, California has straddled a psychological fault as deep as the geological ones, caught between psychic plates of optimism and doom. The earthquake has for now underscored the latter, what Bill Bradley, a Sacramento writer who is completing a book called ''The United States of California,'' refers to as the ''last frontier'' notion: the idea that Americans have pushed to the very end of the continent in pursuit of the American dream, and ruined it. Such themes have long pervaded California literature in the works of Nathaniel West, John Steinbeck and Joan Didion.
The quake has spawned arguments that technology has gone too far in trying to tame California's unforgiving terrain. The day after the disaster, Marc Reisner, the author of ''Cadillac Desert,'' a history of water in the West, wrote in an essay in the Los Angeles Times that he would not be ''staring at unseen corpses'' in the darkness from his San Francisco home if bridges, elevated highways and other ''gargantuan wizardry'' had not been built to ''snub nature.''
But once the dust settled, a more defiant view emerged. J.S. Holliday, the historian, chronicler of the Gold Rush, said in an interview that it was ''a mistake to emphasize the feeling that collectively or individually California is suffering any kind of psychic damage.'' People ''bore up'' under the much more powerful 1906 quake, he said, adding that the state needed more ''steel in the spine,'' to look to its ''glorious rambunctious hormonal'' past for succor. The quake was almost a favor, he went on, ''a test run at almost no price'' for the future.
Indeed, some San Franciscans emerged from the experience with a new sense of urban community. After he got over the initial terror, Herb Gold, a novelist who wrote ''Dreaming,'' about California real estate promoters who had to allay people's fears over quakes, found that a tremendous, unaccustomed sense of caring enveloped his Russian Hill neighborhood. And there was pride and astonishment on both sides of the bay that few took advantage of the chaos to loot and pillage.
Although few seemed to fully share the feelings of John Muir, the 19th century naturalist, who reported the joy of experiencing a quake in Yosemite Valley, many here saw value in being traumatized, shocked out of trivial concerns.
''For cultures to be mature there has to be some internalization of a tragic metaphor,'' said Mr. Starr, the historian. ''This gives a certain depth to a culture in San Francisco that was in terminal pursuit of the trivial. It was acting as if spending $100 million for a new baseball stadium was the greatest issue in history, as if the next restaurant opening was akin to a new Shakespeare play at the Globe theater. San Francisco has always had a temptation for frivolity. That's part of its charm, but this experience will give depth to the city again.''
Psychiatrists and sociologists said the trauma would fade quickly except for those who suffered profound personal losses. Californians expected some residents would move to other states or to less quake-prone parts of the state, and migration from other states might slow, for a while at least.
In Los Angeles, the country's second largest city, residents had good reason to ponder their good life and Mr. Reisner's words from San Francisco: ''Remember, you were supposed to have been hit before us. How many people are you going to squeeze into your deadly little arid basin? What are you going to do when your aqueducts are destroyed? When your freeways come tumbling down? When the mobility you have so assiduously pursued bites you back, paralyzing you?''
Whatever the local response, though, the national reaction of sympathy and awe for what happened served to validate the fact that California is not easily dismissed anymore as the land of fruits and nuts. It is the largest state, the world's seventh largest economy, seat of Silicon Valley and the aerospace industry. It is also home for 28 million people, one of every nine Americans, who live under the constant threat of imminent and random anhilation at the hands of the magnificent natural forces that are both the curse and the magnet of the West Coast.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Why the Deficit Is Paralyzing Congress

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
RARELY in peacetime has a single issue dominated politics here the way the budget deficit is doing now.
The most important legislative measures of the year -tax cuts, expansion of child-care benefits, changes in Medicare and Medicaid and many others - are paralyzed. President Bush was compelled last week to order across-the-board reductions in spending for the military and most domestic programs, at least temporarily, because he and Congress could not agree on a deficit-reduction bill. Essential legislation to raise the Government's statutory borrowing limit, a bill that logically ought to be routine, will probably tie the lawmakers in knots over the next week or two. 
The dispute over the deficit is not really about how much more the Government is spending than it is taking in. Rather, it is about which party and philosophy should lead the country and, as an economic issue, it is a cover for other issues that are more difficult to grasp. Hardly anyone - not the politicians, not economists and certainly not the public - believes anymore that the deficit is the most critical problem facing the nation.
''If someone came down from Mars and looked at our economic problems, they'd be amazed at how much attention we pay to the deficit,'' said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat from Brooklyn who is one of the most serious students of economics in Congress.
In their new book, ''The Debt and the Deficit,'' the economists Robert Heilbroner and Peter Bernstein list what they consider more urgent economic goals than cutting the deficit. They include, in descending order of gravity: making the American economy more competitive internationally, controlling inflation, checking the decay of urban life, restoring the environment, reforming the financial markets and restraining ''corporate civil war,'' and improving education.
As for the public, the New York Times/CBS News poll found last month that only 3 percent of American adults consider the deficit ''the most important problem'' in the country, while 54 percent said it was drug abuse. As recently as January, 17 percent said the deficit was the nation's worst problem, and a few years ago it was seen as a truly major threat.
This is not to say that the deficit does not matter. According to the Congressional Budget Office, the deficit for the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30 was about $160 billion, four times what it was a decade ago. As a proportion of Gross National Product, the current deficit is 3.1 percent, about half what it was in 1983 but still much higher than it has been historically in years when the economy was prospering.
Charles L. Schultze, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Carter Administration and now director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution, describes three schools of thought among economists about the significance of the deficit. He calls them the wolf at the door, the domesticated pussycat and the termites in the basement.
The wolves say that because of the deficit, this country faces an imminent crisis in which foreigners lose confidence in the United States economy, the value of the dollar plummets, prices at home rise sharply, interest rates soar and a market crash and severe recession follow. This view was once prevalent on Wall Street and in international financial circles, but it is heard less and less.
The pussycats, some left of center and some on the far right, hold that the deficit is trivial. The pick of the litter is Prof. Robert Eisner of Northwestern University, a former president of the American Economic Association. He argues that when adjustments are made for inflation, for capital projects like highways and sewers that actually add to the nation's productive wealth and for the budget surpluses of state and local governments, the deficit turns out to be inconsequential.
But in Mr. Schultze's taxonomy, most economists are termites. The deficit, they believe, may not be the nation's most urgent problem, but by draining away productive investment by Americans, it is eroding the quality of life of the next generation. Benjamin M. Friedman, professor of political economy at Harvard, puts it graphically: ''America has thrown itself a party and billed the tab to the future. The costs, which are only beginning to come due, will include a lower standard of living for individual Americans and reduced American influence and importance in world affairs.''
But if the consensus is that the deficit is not a dire situation, why does it so dominate the political debate? The main answer is that it gives politicians a backdrop for deep-seated views. Democrats can argue that, despite years of prosperity under Republican Presidents, times are not so good as they seem. In outlining a Democratic vision of the economy, including a lower deficit, the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, said last week that ''for the first time, the American people now fear that their children will be worse off than they were.'' From the Republicans' perspective, the deficit gives President Bush and his allies an excuse for opposing Government social programs without appearing to be callous. The economist Milton Friedman maintains that the deficit is a blessing in disguise because it has restrained the Democratic Congress from voting for more spending and thus more Government intrusion into the marketplace and people's lives.
Another reason for the emphasis on the deficit is that the solution is so easily understood. Neither politicians nor economists know how to end poverty, control inflation without inducing a recession, persuade Americans to save more, improve American goods or attack many other economic problems they may perceive as more critical. But no one doubts how to end the deficit: raise taxes, cut spending or both.
''Of course, the deficit matters,'' said Representative Schumer. ''But what it is really is a security blanket. When things go wrong, you can always blame it on the deficit. Other problems are more serious, but the deficit is easier to talk about.''

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Noriega Might Stay, But the Canal Will Go On

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
UNDER the Panama Canal treaties, a Panamanian is supposed to take over as administrator of the waterway on Jan. 1. But in the last few weeks, the Bush Administration has made clear that that will not happen if Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega is still ruling Panama. Nevertheless, the canal will continue operating regardless of whether General Noriega retains or surrenders power, American officials say. These officials assert too that the treaties will remain in force, even though there may be problems carrying out some of the provisions.
Both Panama and the United States are eager to see the canal operate without interruption. The waterway is vital to Panama's economy, and while it has lost some of the importance it once had in American eyes, it still remains significant for the United States' strategic and economic interests. 
Panamanian and American employees of the canal report being harassed by the Noriega regime, and the political turmoil in Panama has increased the costs of operating the canal. But the United States and Panama share a strong interest in seeing continued use of the canal by ships carrying wheat, corn, soybeans, oil, coal, automobiles, chemicals, lumber, iron, steel and other cargo. For these reasons, the war of nerves over the continuation of General Noriega in power has not been allowed to do any serious harm to operations of the 75-year-old canal.
Nevertheless, the next step in that war of nerves appears likely to involve the canal and the schedule for implementing the treaties, under which Panama is supposed to assume complete responsibility for managing operating and maintaining the canal at noon on Dec. 31, 1999.
Until that date, the canal is to be operated by the commission, an agency in the executive branch of the United States Government. The administrator of the canal, now an American, is appointed by the President and is subject to confirmation by the Senate. On Jan. 1, Dennis P. McAuliffe, the administrator, is stepping down, and a Panamanian recommended by the Panamanian Government is supposed to become the administrator, subject to Senate confirmation. An American is to replace the Panamanian whose term as deputy administrator expires on the same day.
 
Prospect of a Standoff
In the last few weeks, as American attention focused on the coup attempt in Panama, many senators said they would not approve a candidate proposed by the Noriega regime. The Bush Administration has said it would not accept recommendations from the regime, which it regards as illegitimate. The standoff does not necessarily imply any interruption in canal operations, however. One temporary solution being considered by the White House is simply to appoint an American as deputy administrator, leaving a vacancy in the office of administrator.
There is much debate about the military and commercial importance of the canal, which was built when warships were the major strategic weapon. Planes and missiles have superseded ships in that role, some analysts say, and not many military ships now pass through the canal. But a study by the conservative Heritage Foundation says the waterway ''remains a strategic choke point.''
Under the treaties, American rights to station forces and maintain bases in Panama end in December 1999 unless there is an agreement to extend such rights. Considering the vicissitudes of Panamanian politics, some members of Congress say the only way for the United States to be sure that the canal will stay open after 1999 is to keep forces there, and the United States may seek a base rights agreement with a post-Noriega government.
Canal officials estimate that 14 percent of the United States' seaborne trade moves through the waterway. However, the canal faces growing competition from pipelines, air freight carriers and sea-rail transport. The number of ships passing through the 50-mile waterway dropped by about 15 percent in 1983, after the opening of a pipeline to carry Alaskan oil across the isthmus of Panama. Since then, the number of ships and the cargo tonnage have been climbing gradually. Michael Rhode Jr., the secretary of the Panama Canal Commission, which operates the canal, said that with a projected increase in world trade, ''We expect cargo tonnage to grow by 1.5 percent to 2 percent a year'' in the 1990's.
While demanding the departure of General Noriega, the United States insists that it is still committed to the Panama Canal treaties. Sol M. Linowitz, one of the treaty negotiators, has said that abrogation of the treaties would inflame nationalist sentiment in Panama and could undermine the legal basis for American troops to remain there.
So White House officials take pains to avoid casting their reluctance to approve General Noriega's candidate for administrator now as a breach of the treaty arrangements. They say they still cling to the hope that somehow General Noriega will have relinquished power by Jan. 1 so they do not have to worry about the problem.

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Who Has to Do What As New York Prepares To Pick a New Mayor

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
THE nomination of David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani for mayor of New York City last month also produced two political truisms: that Mr. Giuliani could not win without first deflating Mr. Dinkins, and that this would be Mr. Dinkins's election to lose.
After coasting in a post-primary euphoria while Mr. Giuliani appeared to be self-destructing, Mr. Dinkins spent last week dousing political brushfires, or worse. For the first time, he appeared vulnerable to what would be the city's only successful mayoral campaign by a Republican in a generation.
Now, with just over two weeks before the general election, the candidates have reversed strategies. Mr. Dinkins, after issuing an ultimatum to Mr. Giuliani to abandon ''gutter politics,'' has gone on the offensive with a television commercial portraying Mr. Giuliani's flipflops. Mr. Giuliani, while still sprinkling salt in Mr. Dinkins's largely self-inflicted wounds, has substituted a positive television advertisement for a negative one. 
In interviews, independent political consultants and some advisers to the candidates say the shifts are overdue. The consultants make some additional suggestions to the candidates for the closing weeks.
It is not enough, they argue, for Mr. Dinkins to offer himself as just another nice guy - everybody knows where they finish. He must paint Mr. Giuliani as a Reagan Republican whose philosophy goes against the grain of a city in which enrolled Democrats seem unusually united and outnumber Republicans 5 to 1. Dramatize the contrast by visiting the day care centers that would have been shuttered because of budget cuts by a Republican administration but were maintained by a Democratic mayor.
The consultants say Mr. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President, still needs to reassure many voters that he has the heft to deal with urban crises. They applaud his recruitment of Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, to an economic advisory council and his appointment - premature, perhaps - of a transition team led by Nathan Leventhal, a former deputy mayor. But they bemoan his ducking of debates, as Mr. Giuliani did in the Republican primary, as seemingly arrogant.
Meanwhile, the Dinkins campaign must contain the hemorrhaging from its political wounds, the latest being the payment of $9,500 to a group headed by a self-described black nationalist, Robert (Sonny) Carson, ostensibly for a get-out-the-vote drive on Primary Day, and accounts of apparent discrepencies between the $1 million value Mr. Dinkins placed on his stock in a communications company and his sale of the stock to his son two years later in 1985 for $58,000. If he had undervalued the stock, he might be liable for state gift taxes.
Those controversies may represent Mr. Dinkins's greatest vulnerabilities. New Yorkers need no reminder that he would be the city's first black mayor, and while he won 3 in 10 votes among whites in the Democratic primary, the pool of whites is larger in the general election. Last week, Arthur J. Katzman, a Queens Democrat and senior member of the City Council, said he would not vote for Mr. Dinkins because ''he has got baggage around him that I can't tolerate,'' which he identified as Mr. Carson and the Rev. Jesse Jackson, among others. Moreover, the stock controversy revived memories of Mr. Dinkins's failure to file income tax returns for four years ending in the early 1970's. He later paid in full and blamed the lapse on negligence, but that may reflect on his ability to manage a $27 billion city budget.
The Giuliani forces, with the candidate himself a former Federal prosecutor and his campaign manager a tax lawyer, were trying to make the most of it. ''You have a pattern,'' said Peter Powers, the Giuliani campaign manager. ''He's not in control.''
After initial fumbling with the complicated accounting, Mr. Dinkins demonstrated coolness under fire during a news conference on Friday reminiscent of Geraldine Ferraro's interrogation over family finances after her nomination for Vice President in 1984. But what will register with voters: Mr. Dinkins's responses or the questions?
''I don't think this is fatal, but it makes it a very close race,'' said Meyer S. Frucher, a Dinkins adviser. ''Dinkins has been hurt, no question. But they haven't made Giuliani a viable alternative.''
Strapped for cash, Mr. Giuliani may not be able to keep his positive commercial on television. Can he afford not to? With scars still visible from his own self-inflicted wounds - among them, racial remarks by the comedian Jackie Mason, Mr. Giuliani's onetime ambassador to the Jewish community - he must broaden his appeal. Corruption might have been a better issue had Mayor Edward I. Koch been his opponent.
So Mr. Giuliani, the consultants argue, has to dramatize his municipal agenda and position himself as a renegade Republican. Rather than making President Bush's appearance at a Giuliani fundraiser last week the climactic moment of his campaign, he should instead call upon the President to sign legislation to provide Federal funds for abortions for victims of rape or incest. Is It Too Late? Is it too late for Mr. Giuliani to catch up? Raymond B. Harding, the Liberal Party leader and Giuliani adviser, likened the dynamics of the evolving campaign against Mr. Dinkins to Saturn's rings: ''The first is me and 40 others; then, the people who read three newspapers a day; the third ring is my mother, who reads The New York Post and watches the 10 O'Clock News. The question is, has the impact of the charges gone from the first to the third? I suspect, based on the polls, that it has not penetrated.''
That was last week, though, and, as Governor Mario M. Cuomo said, ''there's time for a few more swings in this race.''
Of the stock controversy, a sanguine Norman Adler, political consultant to the Teamsters union, which is supporting Mr. Dinkins, said, ''I just don't think this is a knockout punch.'' But, he added, ''Now, the question is, what else is there?''
Variables do emerge, some beyond a candidate's control. In the primary campaign, the murder of a black teen-ager by a gang of whites in Brooklyn was said to have solidified support for Mr. Dinkins. In 1969, when the city last elected a Republican, John V. Lindsay's victory was attributed to five M's: his weak opponents, Mario (Procaccino) and (John) Marchi; a visit by (Golda) Meir, the former Israeli prime minister, and the euphoria of the Moon landing and the Mets victory in the World Series. Mr. Giuliani's hopes seemed tied to the letter C: crime, crack, corruption, compassion, competence, character, color, Carson, cronyism, credibility and, most recently, cash.
Yet David Garth, a strategist for Mr. Lindsay and Mr. Koch, suggests that the winner may again be determined by an M-word.
''It's going to be the one who makes the fewest mistakes,'' Mr. Garth said.

HEADLINE: A Return to The Past in Austria's Alps

BYLINE: By HANS FANTEL; HANS FANTEL writes on sound and video for The New York Times.

 BODY:
NOT many visitors to Salzburg realize that just a short drive south of the city, in Austria's Hohe Tauern national park, a unique project is underway. The Austrian Government has set aside a section of the park - dubbed Tauriska, after the region's ancient Celtic name - for an experiment in small-scale economic development.
Unlike national parks in Unlike national parks in the United States, Tauriska is not conceived of merely as a nature preserve. Although it lies in a spectacular and largely unspoiled region of the Alps, protecting the wilderness is not its only aim. Rather, the project fosters the folkways of the region and even promotes a distinctive local economy in balance with the natural environment.
''This is an inhabited park,'' explained Alfred Winter, commissioner of cultural affairs for Salzburg Province. ''The villages are as much part of it as the mountains and forests. After all, this place has been settled for more than a thousand years.'' 
Austria's national park consists of adjacent Alpine tracts administered separately by the provincial governments of Salzburg, Tyrol and Carithia. Tauriska is a special sector within the park, chiefly government-financed and concerned with cultural preservation. The Tauriska project, now in its sixth year, came just in time to save 10 colorful mountain settlements in a region roughly the size of the Berkshires region of Massachusetts. It can be traversed in about two hours and is home to a total population of about 35,000.
In recent decades, these ancient hamlets, many dating back more than 500 years, had declined in population as their younger people drifted to cities and factory jobs in search the kind of life they observed on television. Mountain farms, which once enlivened the echoing valleys with the gentle clanking of cowbells, all but disappeared.
But now this trend has slowed, and even reversed in some cases. Word has got around that the cities in the plain and their factories are not as inviting as they look on television, and quite a few younger villagers are staying or coming back now that Tauriska provides congenial forms of economic opportunity.
''In this town, we now again have families with several generations living side by side,'' said Otto Kaiserer, the mayor of Rauris, one of the main villages of the region. ''This provides a different atmosphere. We can feel the change. Everything holds together again.''
Economic opportunity has been created partly by the organized revival of traditional crafts, notably lace-making and embroidery, cabinetry and the making of painted peasant furniture, as well as fine hand-crafted ironwork. Some home distilleries have been restored to prepare their special kind of (perfectly legal) moonshine from local fruits and berries. One town, Hollersbach, has started growing medicinal herbs on a relatively grand scale, and the fragrant and colorful herb fields cover acres of valley bottom near the town's center.
These products are sold, mostly to tourists, at the local Heimatwerk shops, which are cooperative outlets for these small family enterprises. One of the best of these outlets is in Neukirchen, a village not far from Hollersbach, and there is a Heimatwerk even in Salzburg, right under the carillon in the Residenzplatz. In addition, the provincial government at Salzburg is making efforts to develop markets for these hand-crafted products through major department stores in several large cities. The trade supports apprenticeships for younger members of producing families that will assure the continuity of once-endangered crafts and skills.
The historic restoration of the villages provides local employment as well as an impetus to the revival of old trades. Many of the finest houses in towns like Rauris, Hollersbach and Neukirchen were built in the early 1500's, when they flourished as centers of Alpine gold mining. Having fallen into disrepair during the decades after World War II, they are now being authentically renovated. This calls for the skills of stonemasons, woodcarvers, ironsmiths, shinglemakers and restorers of frescoes, whose workshops are open to visitors. Even the asphalt of streets and sidewalks has been torn up and replaced with the traditional cobblestones. ''It all builds local pride,'' said Mayor Kaiserer of Rauris. ''And that's an absolute requirement if a town is to live.''
We approached Rauris by a serpentine road winding upward through a broad valley flanked by peaks as high as 12,000 feet. From a parking place at the a short walk took us to a small central square dominated by a Gothic church whose 13th-century murals have kept remarkably well in the clean mountain air - an unexpected art treasure in these rustic surroundings. Across from the church, a massive but surprisingly graceful stone house dates from about 1500. Its gabled roof is weighted with huge stones and the curiously angled bay windows blaze with geraniums. Recently restored, the building now serves as the town library and community center. Next to it, an inn of similar vintage, the Gasthof Grimming, serves meals under its ancient vaulting.
OPEN meadows surround the town, and marked hiking paths extend for many miles, offering splendid vistas and well-kept benches from which to enjoy them. Even strangers meeting on these paths exchange a cordial ''Gruss Gott,'' Austria's traditional salutation.
Despite the emphasis on tradition, visitors will find no trace of a museum atmosphere, no self-conscious imitation of the past. Rather, Tauriska is an attempt to create a vivid present within a preserved natural and cultural framework.
Nor is Tauriska planned purely as a tourist attraction. Naturally, everyone wants visitors to come, but not in the proverbial droves. Nobody wants these valleys turned into parking lots, or people bumping into each other on the hiking trails. And nobody wants big hotels crowding out the country inns - many of them old farmhouses with their original furniture - that now abound throughout the area.
The planners are talking of ''controlled tourism,'' with access sufficiently limited to assure tranquillity in town and even a feeling of solitude up in the mountains. One proposal, still under consideration, is a ban on motor vehicles in the narrow side valleys. Cars would be parked near the main road outside the narrow valleys, and from there visitors would be transported to the higher regions on horse-drawn farm wagons.
It is in the upper reaches of these valleys that nature conservancy takes over as the chief goal. Here, at the glaciers' edge, beneath the the mountains' icy peaks, the natural ecology remains undisturbed. Thanks to the Tauriska plan's rigorously enforced conservation measures Indigenous animals, from ibex to eagles, once rare, have now returned in encouraging numbers. The expanse of mosses in the highest ice-free regions, the flowering meadows reaching just above the tree line, and then the tall pines - all these are to remain pristine. Nearer the villages, barns and stables must adhere to traditional forms and materials. It has been suggested that during certain hours no sounds of machinery should disturb the stillness of the valley.
''At first the local farmers were all against it,'' said Mr. Winter, an athletic man in his mid 30's whose is the moving force behind the Tauriska project. ''They didn't want any constraints on the use of their property. But when they saw all the positive changes in the townships that had adopted the program, they changed their minds. They now realize that land values have risen as a result. No land is ever expropriated to create the park. All that is needed is acceptance of the idea and observance of the rules.'' And, after a thoughtful moment, he added ruefully: ''That's a tough notion to get across to independent mountain folk.''
The Tauriska program, is not just economic and ecological, Mr. Winter stressed. It includes the revival of folk music and festivals involving regional costumes and dances, along with the sometimes grotesque masks meant to frighten off evil spirits - a device similar in function to the hex-marks of the Pennsylvania Dutch.
At the same time, cultural contact with the larger world outside the valley is encouraged by concert series and theater performances, bringing in artists to perform in local churches and in splendid old buildings restored to serve as community centers. ''We don't want to isolate the population from the modern world,'' said Mr. Winter. ''We want them to take part in it, but on their own terms.''
He doesn't claim credit for the idea. The basic notion of reviving the economy and ecology of small towns comes from Leopold Kohr, a former professor at Rutgers University in New Jersey. Professor Kohr, a native of Salzburg who emigrated to the United States and now lives in London, believes that many of the social and ecological crises in the modern world are basically problems of scale and can be solved by a return to smaller, self-contained settings for human activity.
Tauriska is the first tryout anywhere for Professor Kohr's ideas. Visitors who are not too distracted by the splendor of the scenery or the charm of the towns can also observe what may prove to be an important social experiment.
 
VENTURING INTO ALPINE VALLEYS
 
Getting There
Tauriska comprises several separate valleys clustered in the part of Salzburg province called the Pinzgau. At its center lies the resort of Zell-am-See, which can be reached from the city of Salzburg in little more than an hour by going part of the way on the A 10 Autobahn to the south. Those who don't mind a more leisurely two-hour drive through the ragged limestone formations of the Salzburger Kalksteingebirge might opt for the older parallel road leading through the ancient town of Hallein. Zell-am-See itself looks like the setting for an operetta, with a rococo square, an early Gothic church, and a charming lakeside promenade. From there, Tauriska towns like Rauris and Hollersbach are within easy reach by car or bus.
 
Lodging
Rates are for double rooms. Travelers preferring to stay at a world-class hotel where English is spoken as a matter of course might check in at the elegant Grand Hotel (phone: 23880) whose spectacular location on a promonitory in the lake justifies room rates of about $150 for a room with bath and balcony. The simple, pleasant Hotel Kaiserhof (6216) run by Otto Kaiserer, mayor of Rauris, is a good example of local country inns. A room with breakfast goes for about $14 a person.
Accommodations in an old chalet full of rustic antiques can be found in Hollersbach at the Gasthof Kaltenhauser (81170) where a room with a balcony costs about $25 per person and offers a view of the church steeple against deep-green hemlock forests and white mountain peaks.
 
Dining
A meal at a local inn might consist of Bauernschmaus, the indigenous version of what is called choucroute garni in Alsace. It is a combination of mild, wine-cured sauerkraut, roast pork and sausage, usually served with dumplings. For lighter fare, there is always tender veal (Kalbsbraten) from the dairy farms or trout (Forelle) fresh from the local streams. For desert try Kaiser schmarrn (a fluffy pancake with plums) or a copious souffle known as Salzburger Nockerl, and finish the meal with a Kaiserbirn pear brandy or a Marillen-Likor - a fragrant distillate of apricots. Meals will run from about $12 to $30; the latter price should include wine and service.
 
Information
Additional information, including lists of hotels, inns and bed-and-breakfast places, is available from the Austrian National Tourist Office (500 Fifth Avenue, Suite 2009, New York, N.Y. 10110; 212-944-6880) or in Salzburg at the Landesverkehrsamt (Regional Tourist Office) at 96 Alpenstrasse; 205060). - H. F.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY

Braniff Cutback: What to Do With Tickets
When Braniff Airways filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code on Sept. 28, it left a lot of customers wondering what to do with the tickets for their canceled flights. ''Technically the tickets are still valid until Sept. 27, 1990, but that doesn't help our passengers who have tickets to cities we no longer serve,'' said a Braniff spokeswoman. The airline, which had been serving 40 airports with 256 flights a day, now has only 46 flights to 11 airports.
Some other airlines, including Trans World Airlines and Continental, are accepting Braniff tickets when there are seats available on their own flights, but the conditions vary from airline to airline.
For people who want refunds, truth-in-lending laws offer some protection to those who paid by credit card. But those who paid by cash or check are now creditors of the airline and will have to file a claim with the bankruptcy court. 
According to information supplied to Braniff by the Department of Transportation, a person filing a claim should get a ''Proof of Claim'' form from a United States courthouse or a stationery store that sells legal forms. Keep one copy and send the original to the United States Bankruptcy Court, Middle District of Florida, First Bankers Building, 135 West Central Boulevard, Suite 950, Orlando, Fla. 32801; reference case number 89-3325. If possible, a photocopy of the ticket should be enclosed.
There is no guarantee that payment will be made or, if it is, that it will be for the full amount. The process will take several months ''at least,'' the spokeswoman stressed. More information: 800-282-5586.
 
Artful Design On the Thames
Visitors to London this fall will find at least one new museum, the Design Museum, which aims to reunite the world of art and work by explaining the development of design in such items as typewriters, radios, cars, trains, bicycles and newspapers. The museum, sponsored by the Conran Foundation, which was established by Sir Terence Conran, the owner of furnishings stores, occupies a converted warehouse at Butler's Wharf on the south bank of the Thames across from the Tower of London.
The foundation says the museum's role is ''to promote an understanding of the contribution of commercial and industrial design to everyday life.'' Roller skates, computers on which visitors can design such products as toothbrushes, and exhibits tracing the design of goods from Wedgwood china to experimental video gadgets from Japan are among the exhibits.
The Design Museum (at Maguire Street and Shad Thames; telephone 403 6933) has a riverside cafe, library and lecture theater. It is open daily, except Monday, from 11:30 A.M. to 6:30 P.M., and admission is about $3.20. The building can be reached by walking across Tower Bridge from Tower Hill Underground station on the north side of the river or by ferry from Tower Pier to Butler's Wharf. It is also close to London Bridge Underground station.
 
U.S. Warns Of Cuzco Peril
Visitors to the temples and other archeological sites at Cuzco, Peru, are warned in a State Department advisory not to wander far from well-traveled roads because of the possibility of violent crime. Tourists, the advisory said, have been robbed in Cuzco and on trains between there and the pre-Incan city of Machu Picchu.
In the last three years there have been several instances of sabotage against trains on the Cuzco-Machu Picchu line, including two that ''resulted in the injury and death of United States citizens,'' the advisory said. Thousands of tourists travel safely each year, the message added, but ''no security is provided along the route.'' It advised hikers to avoid the Inca Trail and said that those who did use it should travel in large groups with guides. Robberies, it said, were frequent and some victims have been seriously injured.
The State Department said that aside from anti-Government activity by two terrorist groups, a difficult economic situation has lead to increased crime in tourist areas. In general, road travel is not recommended.
The advisory listed several areas that should be avoided and pointed out that while other areas were considered relatively safe, conditions could change at any time. For this reason, American visitors should seek the latest travel information on arrival in Peru and register with the consular section of the United States Embassy in Lima.
 
Tall Ships In New Zealand
Sailors, from novice to experienced, can sign on to assist the professional crews aboard tall ships in New Zealand this winter. Voyages are of 3 to 16 days and nine itineraries between New Zealand ports. There will be 13 departures from Dec. 27 to Feb. 22. The program will coincide with New Zealand's 150th anniversary celebrations next year.
The oldest of the five ships in the package is Trade Wind, which was built in 1911 and has space for 10 guest sailors as well as the regular crew of 8. Spirit of New Zealand, built three years ago, is the newest ship. She has a crew of 11 and accommodates 42 passengers. Annette Wells of the Adventure Center in California, which is offering the program, said there were no private cabins or bathrooms. The guest sailors would share cabins and sleep in bunks, she said.
Participants can extend their stays to attend some of the anniversary events. One is the Commonwealth Games (for athletes from British Commonwealth countries) being held at various sites in New Zealand from Jan. 24 to Feb. 7. The expeditions range from $386 for three days afloat to $1,300 for 16 days. (Adventure Center, 1311 63d Street, Suite 200, Emeryville, Calif. 94608; 800-227-8747 outside California and 415-654-1879.)
 
U.S. Football In Dublin
A large contingent of football fans from Pennsylvania and New Jersey is expected to lead many more Americans to Dublin when the Rutgers University Scarlet Knights and the University of Pittsburgh Panthers kick off the second Emerald Isle Classic at Lansdowne Road Stadium on Dec. 2. A Massachusetts tour operator that is the official packager for the event is offering three programs that include game tickets.
A parade and a charity ball are among festivities being planned for the event, which is the last scheduled game of the season for both schools. The organizers of the Classic say 10,000 Americans went to Dublin for last year's game, which ended with a victory for Boston College over West Point. The event reflects the growing interest in Britain and Ireland of American football.
The three packages offered by Brian Moore International Tours (116 Main Street, Medway, Mass. 02053; 800-982-2299 or, within the state, 508-533-6683) include round-trip air fare from New York or Pittsburgh and game tickets.
Prices per person in double occupancy begin at $699 for three nights in guesthouses; $799 for a six-night self-drive plan with rental car and rooms in hotels or farmhouses, and $1,099 for a six-night bus tour, accommodations and some meals.
 
MALLETS SWING IN FLORIDA
At Wimbledon the grass courts are deserted, but in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., the ''Wimbledon of croquet'' begins tomorrow and continues through the finals next weekend. The national open singles and doubles championships will be played on the home courts of the United States Croquet Association at the PGA Sheraton Resort.
Ninety top players who have spent the summer qualifying in five regional championships will compete for the singles crown and a share of the $5,000 purse.
Johnny Osborn of the New York Croquet Club will try to regain the singles championship he held for seven years before losing it to Reid Fleming, a player based in Vancouver, in last year's final. Forty doubles teams will vie for the doubles title. Matches will be played Monday through Sunday, 8:30 A.M. to 6 P.M., on the five courts at the resort's Croquet Club. Admission is free.
A courtside luncheon with unlimited champagne will be held next Sunday in connection with the tournament to benefit the Croquet Foundation of America. Tickets are $25 a person.
The PGA Sheraton Resort (407-627-2000) describes its croquet complex as the largest in the Western Hemisphere.
The resort also has 5 golf courses, 19 clay tennis courts and a five-lane lap pool.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 22, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Page 38, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4738 words

HEADLINE: WHAT IS FUKUYAMA SAYING? AND TO WHOM IS HE SAYING IT?

BYLINE: By James Atlas; James Atlas is an editor of this magazine.

 BODY:
THE YEAR 2000 FAST APPROACHES, and millennial doom is in the air. Global warming, nuclear proliferation, chaos in Eastern Europe. Even the notion of post is over. Post-modernism, post-history, post-culture (to borrow the critic George Steiner's term) - we're beyond that now. ''The sun is about to set on the post-industrial era,'' declares the economist Lester C. Thurow in The New York Times.
What follows post? Samuel P. Huntington, Eaton Professor of the Science of Government at Harvard, has a name for the latest eschatological craze: ''endism.'' The critic Arthur C. Danto theorizes on ''the end of art.'' Bill McKibben, a former staff writer for The New Yorker, issues a dire report on ''The End of Nature.'' Clearly, it's late in the day.
On the face of it, the lead article in the summer issue of The National Interest, a neoconservative journal published in Washington, seemed like more bad news. ''The End of History?'' it asked. The author, Francis Fukuyama, a State Department official, was unknown to the public, but his article was accompanied by ''responses'' from Irving Kristol, Allan Bloom, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and others notable for their gloomy prognostications. 
The magazine's readers were in for a surprise. What was Fukuyama saying? That the end of history is good news. What is happening in the world, claimed his eloquent essay, is nothing less than ''the triumph of the West.'' How else to explain the free elections in Poland and Hungary? The reform movement in China? The East German exodus?
In Fukuyama's interpretation, borrowed (and heavily adapted) from the German philosopher G.W.F. Hegel, history is a protracted struggle to realize the idea of freedom latent in human consciousness. In the 20th century, the forces of totalitarianism have been decisively conquered by the United States and its allies, which represent the final embodiment of this idea - ''that is, the end point of mankind's ideological evolution and the universalization of Western liberal democracy.'' In other words, we win.
Within weeks, ''The End of History?'' had become the hottest topic around, this year's answer to Paul Kennedy's phenomenal best seller, ''The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers.'' George F. Will was among the first to weigh in, with a Newsweek column in August; two weeks later, Fukuyama's photograph appeared in Time. The French quarterly Commentaire announced that it was devoting a special issue to ''The End of History?'' The BBC sent a television crew. Translations of the piece were scheduled to appear in Dutch, Japanese, Italian and Icelandic. Ten Downing Street requested a copy. In Washington, a newsdealer on Connecticut Avenue reported, the summer issue of The National Interest was ''outselling everything, even the pornography.''
''Controversial'' didn't begin to cover the case. Unlike that other recent philosophical cause celebre, Allan Bloom's ''The Closing of the American Mind,'' Fukuyama's essay was the work of a representative from what is often referred to in academic circles as the real world. This was no professor, according to the contributor's note that ran in the magazine, but the ''deputy director of the State Department's policy planning staff.''
It wasn't just the message, then; it was the source. Maybe there was an agenda here. . . . By mid-September, Peter Tarnoff, president of the Council on Foreign Relations, could speculate on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times that ''The End of History?'' was ''laying the foundation for a Bush doctrine.'' Not bad for a 16-page article in a foreign-policy journal with a circulation of 6,000.
YOU HAVE TO PASS THROUGH A METAL detector to get to Francis Fukuyama's office in the State Department, and the silver plaques beside the doors - INTERNATIONAL NARCOTICS MATTERS, NUCLEAR RISK REDUCTION CENTER - confirm that this isn't a philosophy department. But the elegant private dining room on the 8th floor, overlooking the Potomac, could easily be mistaken for an Ivy League faculty club. Plush carpets, chandeliers, a sideboard out of Sturbridge Village, oil portraits of 19th-century dignitaries on the walls - an environment conducive to shoptalk about Hegel.
It's mid-September, and the arrival of Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze for meetings with Fukuyama's boss, James A. Baker 3d, is less than a week away. ''It's a busy time,'' says Fukuyama, apologetically. Apart from assisting in the preparation of ''talking points'' for the Secretary of State, he's been besieged with telephone calls from book editors and agents eager to cash in on his famous article.
How does he account for the commotion? ''I don't understand it myself,'' Fukuyama says quietly, sipping a Coke. ''I didn't write the article with any relevance to policy. It was just something I'd been thinking about.''
He does seem an unlikely celebrity. (But so was Paul Kennedy. So was Allan Bloom.) His khaki suit has an off-the-rack look about it, and he speaks in a tentative, measured voice, more intent on making himself clear than on making an impression. A youthful 36, he emanates a professorial air - an assistant professorial air.
Fukuyama doesn't quite fit the neo-conservative stereotype. Whatever ideological direction he has gone in lately, he's still a child of the 60's. He belongs to the Sierra Club; he's nostalgic for California, where he worked for the Rand Corporation; he worries about pesticides in the backyard of the small red-brick bungalow in the Virginia suburbs where he lives with his wife and infant daughter.
''The last thing I want to be interpreted as saying is that our society is a utopia, or that there are no more problems,'' he stresses. ''I simply don't see any competitors to modern democracy.'' In short, he's a liberal neo-conservative.
Fukuyama grew up in Manhattan's Stuyvesant Town, a middle-class housing development on the Lower East Side. His father was a Congregational minister who later became a professor of religion, and Fukuyama's own direction in the beginning was toward an academic career. As a freshman at Cornell in 1970, he was a resident of Telluride House, a sort of commune for philosophy students; Allan Bloom was the resident Socrates. They shared meals and talked philosophy until all hours, living the good life Bloom would later evoke in ''The Closing of the American Mind,'' the professor and his disciples sitting around the cafeteria discussing the Great Books.
Fukuyama majored in classics, then did graduate work in comparative literature at Yale, where he studied with the deconstructionist Paul de Man (who would achieve posthumous notoriety when it was discovered that he'd published pro-Nazi articles in the Belgian press at the height of World War II). ''It was kind of an intellectual side journey,'' Fukuyama says.
After Yale, he spent six months in Paris, sitting in on classes with Roland Barthes and Jacques Derrida, whose abstruse and fashionable discours would become required reading for a generation of American graduate students. Fukuyama was less than impressed. ''I was turned off by their nihilistic idea of what literature was all about,'' he recalls. ''It had nothing to do with the world. I developed such an aversion to that whole over-intellectual approach that I turned to nuclear weapons instead.'' He enrolled in Harvard's government department, where he studied Middle Eastern and Soviet politics. Three years later he got a Ph.D. in political science, writing his thesis on Soviet foreign policy in the Middle East.
Fukuyama's first job out of the academic world was at the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica. Then, in 1981, Paul D. Wolfowitz, director of policy planning in the Reagan Administration (and also a former student of Bloom's), invited him to join his staff. Fukuyama worked in Washington for two years, then returned to Rand.
For the next six years, he wrote papers for Rand on Soviet foreign policy, speculating on such weighty matters as ''Pakistan Since the Soviet Invasion of Afghanistan'' and ''Soviet Civil-Military Relations and the Power Projection Mission.'' In ''Gorbachev and the Third World'' (published in the spring 1986 issue of Foreign Affairs), Fukuyama claimed that Soviet foreign policy was still expansionist, and that despite efforts to economize at home and act conciliatory abroad, Gorbachev was quietly ''trying to stake out a more combative position'' in client nations like Angola and Afghanistan, Libya and Nicaragua. The message of these heavily footnoted articles was clear: The cold war is still on.
Last February, shortly before he returned to Washington to become deputy to Dennis Ross, the new director of policy planning, Fukuyama gave a lecture at the University of Chicago in which he surveyed the international political scene. It was sponsored by his former professor, Allan Bloom. ''My whole life has been spent in organizations that prize technical expertise,'' says Fukuyama. ''I was anxious to deal with larger and more important issues'' - what Bloom calls ''the big questions.''
As it happened, Owen Harries, co-editor of The National Interest, was looking around for a think piece on the current situation - a piece, as Harries explains it, that would ''link history with the great traditions of political thought.'' Harries got hold of Fukuyama's lecture and instantly recognized that it was ''a provocative, stimulating essay, just what the times needed.''
HARRIES, A DONNISH, PIPE-SMOKING Welshman whose desk is piled high with books - he was educated at Oxford and was for many years a professor of politics - belongs to a type that exists only in Washington. Leon Wieseltier, literary editor of The New Republic, calls them ''policy intellectuals.'' In New York, people talk about the latest issue of Vanity Fair; in Washington, they talk about the latest issue of Foreign Policy.
Some of these policy intellectuals are in government; Carnes Lord, the author of a highly regarded translation of Aristotle's ''Politics,'' is national security adviser to Vice President Quayle. Others are ''fellows'' or ''scholars'' at the Heritage Foundation or the Brookings Institution. Often, they have grand titles; Michael Novak, for instance, is the George Frederick Jewett Scholar in Religion and Public Policy at the American Enterprise Institute. Many are fugitives from academic life. ''A lot of people around the office came up to me after the article appeared,'' Fukuyama says. ''Hegelians who hadn't gotten tenure.''
The political orientation is well to the right. ''We hold to a traditional view of foreign policy,'' says Owen Harries. And what does he mean by ''traditional''? ''The belief that power politics is still in business. A belief in the efficacy of force.''
The National Interest is clearly a well-heeled outfit. It's funded by the Lynde and Harry Bradley Foundation, a prominent neo-conservative organization; the John M. Olin Foundation, established by a wealthy manufacturer who made his fortune largely in munitions, and the Smith Richardson Foundation -which, says Harries, ''supports a number of good causes around the place.''
The magazine's quarters, in a modern office building on 16th Street in Washington, are a far cry from the grubby cubicles one associates with political journals on the left (if there still are any). The floors are carpeted and the phones ring with a muted chirp. The elevator has piped-in Mozart instead of Muzak. Directly across the street, behind a high wrought-iron fence, is the Russian Embassy.
The National Interest, now four years old, is the creation of Irving Kristol - listed on the masthead as its publisher. His desk at the magazine is sort of in the lobby area; but then, he occupies many desks. Apart from his two magazines (he's also publisher of The Public Interest), Kristol is a distinguished fellow at the American Enterprise Institute. Last year, he gave up his professorship at New York University and moved to Washington. New York was no longer the nation's intellectual center, he wrote in The New Republic a few months later, explaining his decision. The intellectuals had disappeared into the universities. The culture of Washington was just as ''nasty and brutish,'' in Kristol's Hobbesian view, as anywhere else. ''But there is one area in which Washington is an intellectual center, and that is public policy: economic policy, social policy, foreign policy, today even educational policy.''
Living in Washington doesn't make Kristol any less a New Yorker. The cigarette, the rumpled seersucker jacket, the shrewdly self-deprecating wit are more congenial to a seminar room at the City University of New York's graduate center on 42d Street than to a Washington think tank. Why did ''The End of History?'' make news? ''I'd like to think it's because my coming to Washington from New York has raised the level of discussion,'' Kristol says with a laugh. And Fukuyama's thesis? ''I don't believe a word of it.''
Neither did a lot of other prominent opinion-makers around town. ''At last, self-congratulation raised to the status of philosophy!'' sneered Christopher Hitchens, a Washington-based Englishman who writes a column for The Nation. ''The Bush years have found their Burke, or their Pangloss.'' For Strobe Talbott, editor at large for Time magazine, ''The End of History?'' was ''The Beginning of Nonsense.''
If it wasn't nonsense, Fukuyama's basic thesis wasn't exactly news, either. For months, conservatives had been gloating over the demise of Communism. ''The perennial question that has preoccupied every political philosopher since Plato -what is the best form of governance? - has been answered,'' wrote Charles Krauthammer in The Washington Post last March, before anyone had ever heard of Francis Fukuyama. ''After a few millennia of trying every form of political system, we close this millennium with the sure knowledge that in liberal, pluralist, capitalist democracy we have found what we have been looking for.'' Essentially, that was Fukuyama's message, but it didn't draw swarms of reporters to Krauthammer's door.
So how did ''The End of History?'' become such a big event? It was the Hegel spin that did it. Not only is America winning, Fukuyama claimed, but the flourishing of democracy around the world is the fulfillment of a grand historical scheme. The end of the cold war and the disarray of the Soviet Union reflected a larger process -the realization of the Idea. History, Hegel believed (or Fukuyama says he believed), ''culminated in an absolute moment - a moment in which a final, rational form of society and state became victorious.'' And that moment, it just so happens, is now.
A weird thesis, utterly speculative and impossible to prove. But ''The End of History?'' was a stylish performance, erudite and written with a rhetorical flair rare in the somber prose of Washington policy journals; it possessed intellectual authority.
Fukuyama's respondents greeted the piece with open arms. ''I am delighted to welcome G.W.F. Hegel to Washington,'' declared Kristol. Senator Moynihan, himself a Harvard government professor before he discovered politics, confessed that his grasp of Hegel was shaky; but he dusted off his European history, tossing in a few references to Marx and Rousseau. ''It is not often that one has the opportunity to argue about Hegel in The National Interest (or anywhere else, for that matter),'' noted the historian Gertrude Himmelfarb, who is the wife of Irving Kristol. Soon after the article appeared, there was a conference held to discuss it at something called the United States Institute of Peace. Kristol, Himmelfarb and Krauthammer were in attendance, along with the Sovietologist Richard Pipes. The rest is . . . history?
IT'S NOT HARD TO SEE why Fukuyama's essay won favor among this community. It's not only the high-flown references to Kant and Hegel, not only the message that Western democracy beat out the competition. ''The End of History?'' has a polemical edge familiar to readers of ''The Closing of the American Mind.''
Like Bloom, Fukuyama doesn't have much patience for non-Western cultures. (''For our purposes,'' he writes, ''it matters very little what strange thoughts occur to people in Albania or Burkina Faso.'') And like Bloom, Fukuyama's no booster. The West isn't so hot either. At the heart of his critique is a veiled contempt for the very culture whose triumphs in the political sphere it purports to celebrate.
What distinguishes Fukuyama from the crowd of conservative pundits elated by Gorbachev's troubles is his curled-lip attitude toward the victorious party. Say the West has won, that fascism and Communism are dead, that no significant ideological challenges are on the horizon - then what? There's an ''emptiness at the core of liberalism,'' Fukuyama maintains. What does America have to offer? ''Liberal democracy in the political sphere combined with easy access to VCRs and stereos in the economic.'' The society Hegel envisioned at the end of history, a universal state in which the arts flourish and virtue reigns, is nowhere to be found. Instead we're stuck with a ''consumerist culture'' purveying rock music and boutiques around the world.
So the end of history may not be such a good thing after all. In fact, Fukuyama concludes, it will be ''a very sad time.'' Why? Because the meaning of life lies in the causes that we fight for, and in the future there won't be any. ''The struggle for recognition, the willingness to risk one's life for a purely abstract goal, the worldwide ideological struggle that called forth daring, courage, imagination and idealism, will be replaced by economic calculation, the endless solving of technical problems, environmental concerns and the satisfaction of sophisticated consumer demands.'' Put plainly, we're heading for a time of ''boredom.''
As a Washington cab driver said when I tried to explain why I was in town, ''Give me a break!'' Does Fukuyama really believe all this? ''I guess I prefer not to answer that,'' he said one afternoon, talking in his State Department office. ''Leave it ambiguous. All I can say is, if people can't take a joke. . . .''
That he meant to be provocative is obvious; but it's clear from his rational, erudite prose that he wasn't fooling around. As a political theorist, Fukuyama is more in the tradition of Bentham or Locke than of pop futurists like Alvin Toffler. ''All I meant by that last paragraph,'' he says, ''was that there's a tension in liberalism that won't go away. There are all kinds of reasons for being a liberal: the security and the material wealth it provides, the opportunity for spiritual and intellectual development. But it fails to address some fundamental questions. You know, what are the higher ends of man? Should we just be content with having secured the conditions for a good life, or should we be thinking about what the content of that good life is?''
IF LIBERALISM STILL has a few kinks to work out, Communism is finished, although ''there may be some isolated true believers left in places like Managua, Pyongyang or Cambridge, Massachusetts,'' writes Fukuyama with characteristic acerbity.
In Cambridge, the contempt is mutual. Even in that citadel of 1960's subversion, there aren't too many Communists left, but there is an inordinately dense concentration of people around Harvard Square who know their Hegel, and the summer issue of The National Interest sold out there virtually overnight. By and large, the Cambridge intelligentsia is dubious about ''The End of History?'' The distinguished Harvard government professor Judith N. Shklar didn't even have to read Fukuyama's piece in order to dismiss it as ''publicity.'' Her colleague Daniel Bell, who did, pronounced it ''Hegel at third remove . . . and wrong.'' (Bell's classic book, ''The End of Ideology,'' anticipated Fukuyama 30 years ago.) The historian Simon Schama, author of ''Citizens: A Chronicle of the French Revolution,'' is more tolerant. Himself an idiosyncratic practitioner of the genre, he found the piece ''spirited and lively,'' but wonders how Fukuyama could have failed to address the revival of religious fundamentalism or the conflicts that could arise out of nationalism. ''It's more of a theological document, don't you think, a work of prophecy,'' he says. ''I mean, nobody really believes in the end of history.''
It's not too hard to think of scenarios that would spoil Fukuyama's end of history. Who's to say what would happen in the Soviet Union if glasnost and perestroika collapse? What new dangers might a reunified Germany pose? Or a newly industrialized China? And what about the nuclear threat? That would put an end to things, the political scientist Pierre Hassner observed, ''in a more radical sense than he envisages.''
Gertrude Himmelfarb's response in The National Interest was perhaps the most damaging refutation of all. To begin with, Hegel never said that history would end in a literal sense; it's a continuous process in which ''the synthesis of the preceding stage is the thesis of the present, thus setting in motion an endless dialectical cycle - and thus preserving the drama of history.'' And what about black poverty, the poverty of the underclass? asked Himmelfarb. In southeast Washington, where young blacks are dying nightly in the front lines of the drug war, history doesn't seem over; it seems to be just beginning. As Irving Kristol tartly put it, ''We may have won the cold war, which is nice - it's more than nice, it's wonderful. But this means that now the enemy is us, not them.''
Liberals complained that Fukuyama ignored the third world. Conservatives weren't too enthusiastic about his dour assessment of the winning team. Where is it written that government should provide for the spiritual needs of its citizens? Michael Novak wondered in Commentary. Democracy promises freedom from tyranny; it doesn't promise to make us happy. ''The construction of a social order that achieves these is not designed to fill the soul, or to teach a philosophy, or to give instruction in how to live,'' Novak wrote. Democracy isn't a required course; it's an elective.
ANUMBER OF COMMENTATORS have compared ''The End of History?'' to the famous article published by George F. Kennan in Foreign Affairs in July 1947 and signed with an anonymous ''X.'' Kennan's essay warned of Moscow's expansionist tendencies and called for a policy of ''firm and vigilant containment,'' thus supplying the term that would come to characterize America's foreign policy in the postwar era.
In an article in Policy Review last summer, ''Waiting for Mr. X,'' Burton Yale Pines, the magazine's associate publisher, called for an update. The cold war was over, Pines agreed; only what was the United States doing about it? How to deal with the turmoil Gorbachev's reforms have provoked? What should be our policy toward Eastern Europe? ''Needed, in essence, is another 'X' article,'' wrote Pines - an article that would encourage the United States to seize the initiative. Given this hunger for a sequel, it's not surprising that Fukuyama is being touted as our ''X.''
But is he? It's tempting to dismiss the whole thing as a media phenomenon. ''Each year needs a new sensation,'' says Daniel Bell. ''It encapsulates a mood that people feel and gives it a vocabulary.''
The practical consequences have been more difficult to measure. In the wake of Shevardnadze's visit, interpreters of foreign policy were busy scrutinizing speeches for evidence of endism. Did Fukuyama's article reflect President Bush's thinking? Was it a high-level policy paper in disguise? Senator Moynihan, for one, is skeptical. ''The minute you announce that the cold war has ended and history is over,'' he notes, ''a lot of people are going to say, 'Hey, wait a minute, we're out of a job.' '' If only for bureaucratic purposes, then, history is still a going concern. As for the article's actual influence, ''there's no connection between this piece and what the Government does,'' Kristol says flatly. ''No one in the Administration has read it.''
Everyone else has. Whether or not we've reached the end of history, we haven't reached the end of ''The End of History?'' The fall issue of The National Interest featured more ''responses,'' and you still can't pick up a magazine or a newspaper without stumbling across some reference to Fukuyama. ''I don't see much of a future for liberal democracy here in Peru's Shining Path country, but people would be pretty excited about VCRs if they only had electricity,'' the journalist Tina Rosenberg reported with laconic irony in The New Republic, writing from Baja Collana, Peru. ''But that's just one of those technological problems Francis Fukuyama says we'll have to spend our time grappling with now that there are no more ideological conflicts to keep us busy.''
In a way, though, the question mark in Fukuyama's title has pre-empted criticism. History, after all, is only a way of making sense of things. Human beings depend on narrative to create an illusion of order, the literary critic Frank Kermode has argued in his profound book, ''The Sense of an Ending.'' ''To make sense of their span they need fictive concords with origins and ends, such as give meaning to lives and to poems.''
''The End of History?'' is a poem. (No wonder no one in the Administration has read it.) Even if we have come to the end of history, that may not be the end of it. As the historian Jerry Z. Muller observed, writing in Commentary last December, ''After late capitalism comes more capitalism.'' And after the end of history comes more history.
 
THOUGHTS FROM 'THE END'
The passing of Marxism-Leninism, first from China and then from the Soviet Union, will mean its death as a living ideology of world historical significance. For while there may be some isolated true believers left in places like Managua, Pyongyang, or Cambridge, Massachusetts, the fact that there is not a single large state in which it is a going concern undermines completely its pretensions to being in the vanguard of human history. And the death of this ideology means the growing ''Common Marketization'' of international relations, and the diminution of the likelihood of large-scale conflict between states.
This does not by any means imply the end of international conflict per se. For the world at that point would be divided between a part that was historical and a part that was post-historical. Conflict between states still in history, and between those states and those at the end of history, would still be possible. There would still be a high and perhaps rising level of ethnic and nationalist violence, since those are impulses incompletely played out, even in parts of the post-historical world. Palestinians and Kurds, Sikhs and Tamils, Irish Catholics and Walloons, Armenians and Azeris, will continue to have their unresolved grievances. This implies that terrorism and wars of national liberation will continue to be an important item on the international agenda. But large-scale conflict must involve large states still caught in the grip of history, and they are what appear to be passing from the scene.
The end of history will be a very sad time. The struggle for recognition, the willingness to risk one's life for a purely abstract goal, the worldwide ideological struggle that called forth daring, courage, imagination and idealism, will be replaced by economic calculation, the endless solving of technical problems, environmental concerns and the satisfaction of sophisticated consumer demands. In the post-historical period there will be neither art nor philosophy, just the perpetual caretaking of the museum of human history. I can feel in myself, and see in others around me, a powerful nostalgia for the time when history existed. Such nostalgia, in fact, will continue to fuel competition and conflict even in the post-historical world for some time to come. Even though I recognize its inevitability, I have the most ambivalent feelings for the civilization that has been created in Europe since 1945, with its North Atlantic and Asian offshoots. Perhaps this very prospect of centuries of boredom at the end of history will serve to get history started once again.
 
(From ''The End of History?'' By Francis Fukuyama, The National Interest, No. 16, Summer 1989.)
