The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 22, 1989

SECTION: Section 6; Page 31, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4258 words

HEADLINE: Hong Kong on Borrowed Time

BYLINE: By Margaret Scott; Margaret Scott is cultural editor of the Far Eastern Economic Review. She lives in Hong Kong.

 BODY:
EARLIER THIS MONTH, WHILE CHINA'S LEADERS WERE staging a grandiose celebration of their revolution's 40th birthday, thousands of somber Hong Kong residents gathered for a dreary commemoration of their own. Far from the fireworks display in Beijing, Hong Kongers huddled in a rainstorm near the bronze statue of Queen Victoria, singing patriotic songs and listening to mournful poems dedicated to those who died in Tiananmen Square.
Since the Beijing massacres on June 4, Hong Kong has become a city frightened of its future and obsessed with one date - July 1, 1997, when Britain is to return its colony to China. (Box, page 32.) The city of almost six million is increasingly torn between those who already have a foreign passport or can obtain one, and the 60 percent or so who cannot afford to leave or are unwanted elsewhere.
Hong Kongers are pursuing the possibility of flight with the same diligence they show in making money. Banks and financial institutions are concocting ways to snare passports for their senior staff. Smooth-talking representatives from Singapore, Fiji, Thailand, Canada come offering foreign travel documents - for a price. A glitzy shopping mall recently became the scene of a near-riot when some 30,000 people scrambled to get application forms for permanent residence in Singapore. Even American Congressmen such as Stephen Solarz have joined in, visiting the colony with proposals to admit more Hong Kongers to the United States. 
To Hong Kong's business moguls no survival scenario seems too farfetched: Some suggest moving Hong Kong to a spot near Darwin, Australia; others propose the west coast of Scotland; still others argue the United Nations should lease Hong Kong from China and turn it into ''the Switzerland of Asia.''
The mood of grim desperation is a far cry from the euphoria that engulfed Hong Kong before June 4, when crowds of close to a million jammed the streets in support of China's democracy movement. In late May, Hong Kongers held a jubilant fund-raiser for the students at the Royal Hong Kong Jockey Club's Happy Valley racecourse. Wealthy entrepreneurs in Rolls-Royces, bankers, Queen's Counsels, students, secretaries and factory workers - all poured in by the hundreds of thousands to the ''Concert for Democracy in China.'' When the legend ''Chinese of the world unite'' flashed across the racecourse's vast video screen the cheers were deafening. After 12 hours, the scattered bins were full of red and green bank notes - about $1.5 million raised for the Chinese students. The mood was one of joyous hope: China would be reborn in Hong Kong's own image, and with time to spare before 1997.
But there was no rebirth in China, only tanks and gunfire and death. In Hong Kong that Sunday, mournful defiance reigned, and by day's end, hundreds of thousands of people had poured into the streets in protest. It wasn't long, however, before protest gave way to panic and, for many, a frantic search for a way out.
Now, more than four months later, Hong Kongers feel trapped between a looming Chinese motherland they cannot change and a departing imperial motherland - Britain -that is betraying them by pulling back the welcome mat from all but a select few. More than 45,000 emigrated from the colony last year and that number is expected to soar. But thousands of others, less wanted or less affluent, are searching for passports. They are British subjects, but London has made it clear that holding a Hong Kong British passport is not good enough for entry to Britain.
For Hong Kong's economy the situation spells danger. If Hong Kongers know they can gain asylum in Britain upon request, many, if not most, will stay in the colony and keep it prosperous. But if London keeps the gate closed to most, many will work full time seeking asylum elsewhere and the colony's economy will nosedive.
During the months since the Tiananmen massacre, the choices for Hong Kongers, especially the young, have begun to seem increasingly stark: Beg Britain for protection, or join the fight to change China. This choice gives expression to a fundamental clash of identities that is becoming ever more apparent in the city - a clash between British and Chinese Hong Kong.
HONG KONG THRIVED ON THE GREED of 19th-century opium traders and the dreams of Chinese fleeing the mainland.
Like San Francisco, Hong Kong was a place of hope and opportunity; it was built by Chinese immigrants who had found their golden mountain, and it grew under a colonial tradition of authoritarian rule.
It has been a winning combination, as anyone gazing down on the city from Victoria Peak can see. Once squat and concrete, Hong Kong is now a city of soaring, glass-sheathed skyscrapers. Looking over Victoria Harbor, the eye is inescapably drawn to a new addition reigning over the skyline: the Bank of China, a 70-story rocket of a building of silver glass designed by I.M. Pei. It is a testament to China's growing dominance in Hong Kong's economy.
A 1959 Life magazine cover story on the city quoted a British civil servant: ''Healthy neglect, that's what did it . . . . Leave the Chinese alone, I always say, and they'll muddle through. . . .''
What was healthily neglected was democratic institutions. The colony was ruled with the trappings of democracy but none of the substance. A Legislative Council meets inside a stately building wth a dome and Ionic columns, but only since 1985 has anyone run for office. And these elected members -24 of the 57-member body - are indirectly voted in by functional constituencies (one represents lawyers, another doctors and so on) with only about 60,000 voters out of Hong Kong's six million people.
It is the Executive Council, chosen by the British-appointed Governor (currently Sir David Wilson) and serving as his cabinet, that holds the real power. Sitting on this council as its most senior member is the standard-bearer of British Hong Kong: Dame Lydia Dunn. If, as the author Jan Morris has said, Hong Kong is the epilogue of empire, then Dame Lydia, the daughter of Cantonese emigrants, could be its heroine - though lately she has been playing the damsel in distress in her plea for the right of abode for Hong Kong's British subjects.
I met Dame Lydia in her elegant downtown office at John Swire & Sons - one of the British ''hongs,'' those huge shipping and trading companies born of empire and once the wellspring of the city's power. Thin, petite, immaculately tailored in a red suit, Dame Lydia is an executive director at Swire's - not quite a taipan, but close. With her taste for Chanel suits and her degree from Berkeley, she is the epitome of the Westernized Chinese. Her fair complexion and almond-shaped wide-set eyes are classic Cantonese. She switches easily from Cantonese (the mother tongue of 98 percent of Hong Kong's population) to English. Handpicked by the colonial administration as a rising political star, she was appointed to the Executive Council in 1982.
After the Beijing massacre, Dame Lydia remarked that at least Hong Kong could be consoled by its newfound sense of identity - a sense of unity forged, she said in her most soothing tones, by a recognition of just how separate, how different, Hong Kong is. Hong Kong's future thus depends on protecting that separateness, on insuring that the Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping's promise of ''one country, two systems'' actually comes to pass.
We met in a room paneled in blond wood and lined with portraits of past taipans. Shortly before, Dame Lydia had traveled to London to plead for British passports. (By 1981, Hong Kong residents had been stripped of their right to live in Britain, and their passports are now merely travel documents.) British newspapers, impressed with her determination, dubbed her ''The Iron Lady of the East,'' an Asian Margaret Thatcher. But when she appeared before Parliament's select committee on foreign affairs looking into the colony's future, the Iron Lady broke down and cried.
''I felt so humiliated,'' she told me. ''I was born under British rule and I grew up as a Hong Kong Chinese - Chinese but different. We want to stay that way, that is what this whole thing is about. But I keep conjuring up this image of proud Hong Kongers shuffling around the globe, searching for a place that will take them in. I feel so humiliated.''
Dame Lydia's British Hong Kong crowd has spawned the ''Honor Hong Kong'' campaigners, an assortment of taipans and Hong Kong Chinese business tycoons who have hired advertising agencies, including Saatchi & Saatchi, to convince Britain's powerbrokers to grant Hong Kongers right of abode. One full-page ad shows a young Chinese businessman in an impeccable pin-striped suit. ''There's no point in being almost British,'' the copy reads. All he wants is insurance for the future in the form of right of abode. ''Otherwise, being almost British is like being homeless.''
So far, the ''Honor Hong Kong'' campaigners have been dismally unsuccessful. The Britain they identify with worries that a huge influx of Hong Kong Chinese would upset Britain's fragile racial balance. In late September, British Foreign Secretary John Major told the United Nations General Assembly that only those ''essential to Hong Kong's future stability and prosperity'' could be resettled.
Just who that includes the Foreign Secretary did not make clear. The current gossip in Hong Kong has it that Britain has postponed revealing this crucial bit of information in order to shield the Prince and Princess of Wales from any embarrassment when they visit the colony next month. When it comes, most expect the news will be bad -current estimates of the total number to be admitted hover around 200,000, probably limited to those with ''special skills,'' with independent wealth or with British spouses. When these terms are spelled out, the reaction in Hong Kong will likely be bitter.
For those who advocate an autonomous Hong Kong, it is a shame that the Crown Colony is separated from mainland China only by a filthy creek called the Shenzhen River. They would prefer an ocean - so that Hong Kong could be, like Singapore or Taiwan, a Chinese place that is not China. Because China is so close, autonomy will require a deft balancing act: encouraging economic interdependence, which is growing by the day, while discouraging political meddling.
''China will let Hong Kong survive not because it is just or right but because of our economic value,'' says Dame Lydia. Under the Britsh, she continues, ''We have been told to stay out of politics and if we did we could make money. We did.'' Up to Tiananmen Square, China's commissars had expected to inherit the same deal.
There once was reassuring talk within the colonial bureaucracy of political reform of a more democratic Hong Kong; but when China voiced displeasure, the talk became muted, the timetable vague. Indeed, it was those who inhabit Dame Lydia's Hong Kong, espousing allegiance to British values, who since 1984 have been the most chary of democracy.
After 1984, the British and Chinese governments cleverly invoked patriotism to sell the Joint Declaration and blunt any talk of democracy. Deng's ''opening'' was going so well, Hong Kong's people were told, and your return to the Chinese motherland will only help his reforms. But it is a delicate affair - don't rock the boat. Democracy is not what China wants; don't displease China.
But then the students took over Tiananmen Square and laid a new claim on Chinese patriotism. Now, Dame Lydia and others have begun to wonder whether the pace of reform should not pick up again. After all, Dame Lydia says, democracy is a useful ingredient in restoring confidence.
''Democracy is now the most important safeguard we can give to the majority who cannot leave,'' she says. ''They need to feel that they have leaders who represent their interests.'' In July, the legislature agreed in principle to a proposal that would create, for the first time, some directly elected legislative seats in time for 1991.
Dame Lydia's separate Hong Kong is the product of empire, but there are others who evoke a different future, the one encapsulated on the videoscreen that day in May: ''Chinese of the world unite!'' It is the call of those who believe that Hong Kong, as the capital of overseas China, must fight to free the motherland.
IT WAS ONE OF THOSE humid August evenings, and the 34-year-old Francis Lau was settling in for another night at Hong Kong's mock Tiananmen Square. With his blue jeans, daypack and wire-rimmed glasses, Lau, a high school teacher, looks the part of the former student activist he is. Crowded around him in a tiny encampment outside the turnstiles of the Star Ferry that crosses Victoria Harbor were banners, wall posters caricaturing Chinese leaders (Premier Li Peng as a bulldog with a spike collar, Deng Xiaoping withdrawn under his turtle shell), tables strewn with pamphlets, and a tape recorder endlessly playing the Internationale. Overhead a banner proclaimed: ''Chinese in Hong Kong and China should come together to fight for democracy to the end.''
Lau and his friends were exchanging tidbits on the latest victims of China's purge. No one talked about passports here. ''The right of abode will only help the elite,'' Lau told me, rearranging a stack of placards. ''Why beg from a colonial government? Our future is with the Chinese students. We both need democracy. Hong Kong's only future is a democratic China.''
Like Dame Lydia, Lau and his colleagues invoke unity -but the unity of patriots fighting against China's current rulers. Li Yi, editor of the journal The Nineties, offers this comparison: Just as the overseas Chinese bankrolled Sun Yat-sen's revolution against the Manchus, earning the sobriquet ''mother of the revolution,'' today's overseas Chinese must be the ''mother of counterrevolution,'' rescuing Wuer Kaixi and other leaders of the student movement and supporting them in building a democratic movement outside China.
This call plays on the deeply ambivalent patriotism of overseas Chinese, most of whom are refugees from communism. For them, Deng's reforms had held only a fragile appeal - one demolished along with the goddess of democracy. But though they have broken ranks with Deng Xiaoping, the Hong Kong patriots remain loyal to Chinese civilization by holding aloft the students, their values and their goals, as ''the real China.''
One who heeded this call was Jimmy Lai, who stole across the border from Canton when he was 11 and now, at 40, owns Giordano, a clothing conglomerate. ''I was Chinese but could never relate to China,'' he told me, sitting in his stylish, high-tech office in Kowloon. ''I lived with that typical contradiction of overseas Chinese. But the students in Tiananmen changed all that.''
Lai didn't join the sit-in at the Star Ferry but he was part of the euphoric crowd at the racecourse and took part in the series of huge marches through Hong Kong's streets. ''I cried everyday,'' he said. ''I'm lost in it. Us Chinese, we are like the Jews. We are waiting for a messiah. The students are our messiah.'' Once he made money for the sake of making money, but ''now I make money with an ideal.''
His company printed 23,000 T-shirts for rally organizers and then began making shirts emblazoned with the faces of student leaders such as Wuer Kaixi, Chai Ling, Wang Dan. He also donated more than $60,000 of his own money.
LATE IN AUGUST, Lau and his friends abandoned their miniature Tiananmen. They had stayed long enough, Lau told me, to show Beijing they were not afraid. It was now time to move into an office and continue the crusade for democracy in China.
Not far from Jimmy Lai's chic office, in a room borrowed from the Professional Teachers Union on the ninth floor of the Good Hope building, members of the executive committee of the Hong Kong Alliance for the Support of the Patriotic Democratic Movements in China conduct long, arduous meetings, discussing what to do next. Martin Lee, a Legislative Council member, a barrister and a Queen's Counsel, along with another local legislator, Szeto Wah, formed the alliance in those heady days of late May, joining together 200 local groups. But now it is dissolving into factions.
One of the most tangible disagreements debated around the square conference table is what should be done with the alliance's $2.5 million treasure chest -money collected for the students but never dispensed. But on this question hinges much broader ones: Can Wuer Kaixi and his small band of exiles bring on a revolution? Can Hong Kong really change China? And, even if Hong Kong could be the mother of counterrevolution, is it worth the risk? Isn't it inviting China to snuff the colony out?
In July, Wuer Kaixi and others, including the exiled former journalist Liu Binyan, founded the Democratic China Front in Paris. Their largest benefactor was the alliance, which paid for Wuer Kaixi's plane ticket and put up the money to furnish the Maison Chinoise de la Democratie, the Paris office donated by the designer Yves Saint Laurent. So far, the alliance has helped more than 60 dissidents flee China. If these dissidents wind up as the heirs of Sun Yat-sen, Hong Kong is well on its way to being their sponsor.
Beijing bristles at this prospect, branding the alliance a bunch of subversive counterrevolutionary plotters. On July 21, an article in the People's Daily, China's official newspaper, attacked the alliance for ''declaring that they would make Hong Kong the front line for supporting subversive activities and help supply weapons and ammunition to counterrevolutionary rebels!''
In public, Lee and the alliance insist they will not be intimidated, that they will continue to support the democratic movement; besides, they say, guns were never part of their intended largesse. But behind closed doors at the Good Hope building, matters are not so clear.
Democracy Tides, for instance, was the alliance's newspaper, until it printed this: ''We must become the bridgehead of the democratic movement. . . . As for the idea of one country, two systems and 50 years of autonomy, that idea has been destroyed. . . . '' Some alliance members thought this was too provocative; Democracy Tides is now an independent publication.
The more aggressive alliance members, which includes those who tended the tiny Tiananmen, believe it is a waste of time to worry about Beijing's reaction. For them, the Joint Declaration has been rendered worthless; they are convinced that no paper treaty will stop the People's Liberation Army. And they view the right-of abode campaign as the great escape. Instead, they say, they will stand by Hong Kong's ''real'' people, those who cannot afford to flee or have nowhere to go. Yes, Hong Kong needs democracy, they say; but, more important, China needs democracy.
The more moderate alliance people, including Martin Lee, concentrate on what needs to be done in Hong Kong, now. They demand that the Basic Law - Hong Kong's miniconstitution, now being drafted by a special committee chosen by Beijing - insure that the territory's judiciary will remain independent; that Hong Kong's political reforms be accelerated so that by 1997 the entire legislature is directly elected, and finally, that Hong Kong's future chief executive be directly elected come 1997, rather than appointed by Beijing. Most important perhaps, they demand that the Joint Declaration be renegotiated to bar the People's Liberation Army from Hong Kong - a demand that Beijing has already denied.
Is reforming Hong Kong more important than reforming China? Or is it the other way around? In the Good Hope conference room, the debate continues, week after week. Lee, whose father was a general in the vanquished Kuomintang army of Chiang Kai-shek, argues that fighting for democracy does not preclude fighting Britain for right of abode; as he sees it, Hong Kong citizens need all the protection they can get from the current Chinese state. Francis Lau and others consider it somehow dishonest to fight for British passports; how, they ask, can you claim to be fighting a revolution against Beijing and then ask for an escape clause in case things get rough?
THERE ARE PLENTY of people, Dame Lydia among them, who consider the alliance a dangerous outfit that is undermining Hong Kong by confronting China. If Hong Kong doesn't want interference from China, then Hong Kong can't interfere in China either. She has a point; but what constitutes interference?
For instance, is the effort to record and preserve the history of the student movement interference? Right after the massacre, people in Hong Kong began compiling videotape collections of news footage to be smuggled into China. (One woman I know bought a kung fu movie, replaced the movie with a news video and carried it over the border.) Hong Kong students gathered outside the train station to offer China-bound passengers neatly prepared sets of news clippings, asking them to tuck them in their bags and distribute them at their journey's end.
In Hong Kong, photography exhibits, a huge audio-visual show called ''The Awakening,'' a new dance performance entitled ''Hellscreen'' -all commemorated the student movement and the crackdown. Professors and lecturers at Hong Kong University have painstakingly compiled a record of what happened the night of June 3-4 as well as a list of intellectuals and students who have been arrested. Another group of writers and film makers have created the Democracy in China Publication Fund to finance scholarly books on the student movement.
Are such efforts interference in China's internal affairs? Beijing says they are.
There are pessimists who say that, in any case, the chances are slim that any of this will survive. Lynn Pan, a writer who lives in Hong Kong, refers to the city's new breed as ''Treaty-Port Chinese,'' pointing out the similarities between the modernized, comfortable Hong Kong Chinese and the educated, professional types who lived in Shanghai before the 1949 revolution. They only lasted one generation, she says, and then they were wiped out or emigrated. She thinks the same thing will happen in Hong Kong.
DOWN THE BLOCK from where Martin Lee and the alliance debate tactics, in Mong Kok, one of the most densely packed urban pockets on the globe, Samuel Poon and some neighbors gather at a tea shop after work. Another immigrant from across the border, Poon, a burly man of 45, has worked in a textile factory for 20 years; he has watched his two children grow up and Mong Kok evolve from a maze of squatter's huts to tenements to high-rises. Before June 4 he never thought about emigrating; now he calls it his impossible dream.
''I feel trapped and afraid,'' he says. ''I came to Hong Kong to get away from the communists. And now they are coming. Before, I thought they had changed, but now I see they haven't.'' He repeated this to his friends in Chinese. Everyone nodded.
He and his friends know of the activities of the alliance from Hong Kong's newspapers and from television. I asked him if he thought the alliance represented his interests. As a Chinese, he said, he approves of what they are doing, but as a Hong Konger, he is afraid of China's reaction.
''I support the students. I support democracy,'' said Samuel Poon. ''But what can we do? Hong Kong is powerless.''
 
1997, AND AFTER
On July 1, 1997, Britain will return Hong Kong to China, which will govern the former colony as a ''Special Administrative Region.'' Under this arrangement, Hong Kong is to enjoy ''autonomy'' that will be maintained for at least 50 years. The Joint Declaration on the Question of Hong Kong, signed by Britain and China in 1984, sketches out the terms of that autonomy.
 
Defense
Beijing may send troops into Hong Kong ''for the purpose of defense,'' but these forces, according to the Joint Declaration, ''shall not interfere in the internal affairs'' of the city.
 
Economic System
The Joint Declaration states that Hong Kong's ''previous capitalist system and life style shall remain unchanged for 50 years.'' It stipulates that ''the socialist system and socialist policies shall not be practiced'' in Hong Kong, that private property shall remain legally protected and that Hong Kong's government shall retain the power to set its own economic policies and to enter into trade agreements as ''Hong Kong, China.''
 
Political Structure
Hong Kong's government will be composed of Hong Kong residents and headed by a chief executive ''to be selected by election or through consultations held locally'' and to be ''appointed by the Central People's government.'' Other top officials ''shall be nominated by the chief executive'' and ''appointed by the Central People's government.''
 
Law & The Judiciary
The ''laws previously in force in Hong Kong . . . shall be maintained, save for any that contravene the Basic Law,'' the latter being Hong Kong's miniconstitution, which a committee selected by Beijing is drafting. Hong Kong's legislature will be able to enact laws but must report them to the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress in China. There will be a new court of last appeal; its judges will be appointed by the chief executive.
 
Taxes
Hong Kong's government will raise its own taxes, devise its own budgets and spend its own public funds independently of China. China will not be allowed to levy taxes in Hong Kong. - MARGARET SCOTT

HEADLINE: NOTED WITH PLEASURE

 BODY:

The Dazzle of Evil
 Nothing is more fascinating than the failings of great artists. This summation of Louis-Ferdinand Celine is from ''Danube'' by Claudio Magris (Farrar, Straus & Giroux).
 Celine let himself be dazzled by the revelation of evil. He listened to the voice of degradation, said Bernanos, like a confessor in a slum quarter; but he did not have the ability, unlike some of the old father-confessors, to take a nap between one penitent and the next, weary of the reiteration of predictable sins: he failed to see the stereotyped banality of evil. Like other French writers of his generation, who thought that they could echo Gide in saying ''J'ai vecu,'' he sought for ''life'' without suspecting the megalomania of such a pretension. By bawling at the top of his voice, as he himself wrote, he thought he was defending a virginal, unsophisticated innocence of the ego. He prided himself contemptuously on not being a clerk, as if that ought to guarantee him some sort of special authenticity, and as if all Hemingway's brawling ought, a priori, to be more poetic than Kafka's office routine. 
 
Is Art an Honorable Discharge?
 Evelyn Waugh was such an embarrassing soldier that the British Army gave him a special leave, even though there was a war on, to go home and write a novel. This is from ''Wartime: Understanding and Behavior in the Second World War'' by Paul Fussell (Oxford University).
 Pronounced ''unemployable'' soon after Crete, Waugh was granted a prolonged leave to write Brideshead Revisited, an absurd anomaly, to be sure, but under the circumstances the handiest way of removing him, with his satirist's sharp tongue, from contact with troops. Finally, he accompanied Randolph Churchill on an error-studded mission to Yugoslavia, which began with an airplane crash, from which Waugh miraculously escaped little damaged, and ended with comic misapprehensions on both sides as Waugh tried earnestly to explain to the Pope the dangers to the Church posed by Yugoslavian Communists but got in return His Holiness's ''English parrot-talk of how many children had I'' and the usual handful of blessed rosaries to take home.
 
On the Peninsula of Regret
 It sometimes happens that angry old women are full of a furious, wrinkled poetry. Here's one who has transplanted her quarrel with life to Florida, where she feels nothing but impatience for the other expatriates. This is from ''Rosa,'' a novella in ''The Shawl'' by Cynthia Ozick (Knopf).
 She had nothing in common with them. Old ghosts, old socialists: idealists. The Human Race was all they cared for. Retired workers, they went to lectures, they frequented the damp and shadowy little branch library. She saw them walking with Tolstoy under their arms, with Dostoyevsky. . . . They were from the Bronx, from Brooklyn, lost neighborhoods, burned out. A few were from West End Avenue. Once she met an ex-vegetable-store owner from Columbus Avenue; his store was on Columbus Avenue, his residence not far, on West Seventieth Street, off Central Park. Even in the perpetual garden of Florida, he reminisced about his flowery green heads of romaine lettuce, his glowing strawberries, his sleek avocados.
It seemed to Rosa Lublin that the whole peninsula of Florida was weighted down with regret. Everyone had left behind a real life. Here they had nothing. They were all scarecrows, blown about under the murdering sunball with empty rib cages.
 
The Overflow of Poetry
 Robert Frost's talk was almost as famous as his poetry. In ''Robert Frost Himself'' (Braziller), Stanley Burnshaw tells us what it was like.
 And now he had started again, the one-way speaker nobody wanted to stop: taking us off into talk of people, books, events, speculations, tragedy, fortune, marking each with a word, a quip, a comment brief or long, with an obbligato of tone and gesture none might forget. His listeners were part of this presence in a bond of voice, tone, bodily motion, easeful-to-taut gaze of the eyes, between the poet who spoke and the one or the few who were there. Tape recordings could hardly give a sense of the humor or earnestness, of the shifting rhythms, the mimicking phrases . . . with their unmistakable messages. Now I was borne on a wave of friendliness flowing steadily - the low-pitched voice: soft, beguiling, bluff, mocking, brusque, as the thought required.
 
The Upside-Down Cake of Culture
 Some travelers come home with fond souvenirs and others bring back mostly ironies. This is from ''Harp'' by John Gregory Dunne (Simon & Schuster).
 East and west, I wonder how the local intelligentsia feel about being trotted out to meet the visiting firemen from America. The conversations are generally impenetrable. ''I in Los Angeles once,'' my host said in Jogjakarta. ''You in Los Angeles once?'' I replied, falling into a kind of makeshift pidgin. I was eating pineapple upside-down cake, the dessert I was given every time I had dinner with Indonesians; it seemed the local idea of an Occidental delicacy. ''Where you in Los Angeles?'' ''Manhattan Beach in Los Angeles.'' ''Really?'' ''You know Manhattan Beach?'' ''My cousin lives in Manhattan Beach.'' I felt like a tennis player trying to keep the rally going. ''First cousin?'' ''Second cousin.'' ''Ah, second cousin.'' Then wild whooping laughter. ''Second cousin,'' he repeated.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES: Churches as Builders;
A Struggle Over Sites in the South Bronx

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
IN the waning days of the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, it is still uncertain whether a housing production program that could bring Nehemiah-style one-family houses to vacant, city-owned land in the South Bronx will ever get started.
The city has offered sites for about half the 1,500 houses that South Bronx Churches would like to build. But the plan, with a formal memorandum of understanding waiting to be signed, has been sitting with the group since August with no sign of a decision. Speculation is widespread that the organization is holding back in hopes of getting a better reception for its program in the next administration.
But that seems doubtful because the principal leaders of nonprofit assisted-housing development in the South Bronx over the last decade feel that the Nehemiah approach uses too much land to accommodate too few people of a single, and low, income level. Their preference is for mixed-income, higher-density development. 
Nevertheless, major sites have been offered, including a cleared urban renewal tract at Prospect Avenue and East 163d Street about the same size as Site 404, the 4.35-acre cleared urban renewal plot near the Hub, the central business district at East 149th Street and Third Avenue, where South Bronx Churches had hoped to start its program.
These efforts come on top of many additional difficulties in transferring the production concepts of the Nehemiah program to the South Bronx. Site preparation costs are much higher than they are in the flat open land of the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, where the Nehemiah plan made its name with I. D. Robbins as builder and the Levittown approach as model. The public investment per housing unit is much higher in the Bronx, which argues for more intensive re-use of the land.
Another problem lies in the nature of South Bronx Churches itself as a nonprofit housing producer. It is led by clergymen without a housing background and community organizers with a major voice in policy decisions. For housing expertise, it places full reliance on the outspoken Mr. Robbins. After he publicly called Abraham Biderman, the Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, ''a liar,'' Mr. Biderman refused to deal with him directly. That has not hastened the arrival of a Nehemiah program in the South Bronx.
The positions and tactics of South Bronx Churches are influenced also by James Drake, a 52-year-old Industrial Areas Foundation staff member whose career as an organizer includes eight years as administrative assistant to Cesar Chavez, the farm labor organizer in California.
According to Mr. Drake, if South Bronx Churches had an ''ironclad'' agreement from the city that the offered sites indeed would be available in accordance with the schedule the city specifies, ''I think we could start building.'' He also objects to language in the proposed memorandum of understanding that would oblige South Bronx Churches, if it signs, to support to development of Site 404 under the New York City Housing Partnership program.
Mr. Robbins, for his part, says he is not confident he can assure the organization that he can deliver houses at the prices he promises if he must depend on the availability of dispersed sites not already under the city's control. The goal is to sell houses for $42,500 to buyers, building them for $57,500 with a $15,000-a-home city subsidy.
But the basic problem is density and housing mix. Extended too broadly, the densities that the Nehemiah plan espouses are too low to satisfy local leaders' interest in gradually rebuilding, at least partly, the area's decimated population. The South Bronx may never become the crowded metropolis it was in 1950, but neither is it going to shrink away to a suburb of one-family homes.
THUS the sites must be chosen with care, saving for higher-density use, and also middle-income use, those locations where they are appropriate and the market will support them.
In some ways the problem is exactly the opposite of the one William Levitt faced when he built Levittown. The essential fact after World War II, when veterans and their families were thirsting for new low-cost homes, was that a huge middle-income demand for housing already existed in his suburban market. In the South Bronx, that market must be nurtured back to existence.
It is the siting issue that has attracted most attention. Some of the supporters of the Nehemiah effort in the South Bronx feel that the Koch administration reneged on a promise to provide Site 404. Last April more than 5,000 people turned out to a rally to hear the administration castigated for its decision to award the land to a private builder to produce three- and four-story town houses under the New York City Partnership program.
CITY officials say that Site 404 never was promised, formally or informally, to South Bronx Churches. The Rev. John L. Heinemeyer, pastor of St. John's Lutheran Church and former chairman of the South Bronx Churches housing committee, said that ''we proposed it and it was not countermanded or denied, but it would be unfair to say it was formally offered to us and taken back.'' The Rev. Bertram Bennett, current chairman of the committee, also said that ''no city official ever said that Site 404 would go for Nehemiah housing on a sole-source basis.''
What does seem plausible is that the city administration was goaded by the Nehemiah initiative and the powerful church support it engendered to push into construction land that it might have preferred to hold in inventory for future midrise development. More recently, it had been discussed by planning officials as a possible ''showcase'' site for Melrose Commons, an effort to develop a wide area of underdeveloped land west of Third Avenue extending to the middle-income Concord Village development.
This is a long-term project, involving heavy site acquition and preparation costs, needing environmental and public land-use review. Site 404 was never shown on maps of Melrose Commons, however. It can be redeveloped without the planning and environmental reviews needed for the Melrose Commons project.
The written offer of alternative sites and the proposed memorandum of understanding was sent by Mr. Biderman, the housing commisioner, to Mr. Heinemeyer in August. The commissioner said that sites sufficient to start 159 homes by December would be granted, that sites for 450 more houses would be available for construction by December 1990, and that action would start promptly on the urban-renewal acquisition process to acquire still more sites.
For Site 404, the Koch administration, backed by Borough President Fernando Ferrer, has chosen a typical Housing Partnership density of 57 units to the acre. There are to be 251 housing units, mostly in three-story masonry buildings, with two-bedroom apartments on the first floor and three-bedrooms on the second and third. The mix is 72 two-bedrooms, 155 three-bedrooms and 24 one-bedrooms. Onsite parking is be provided for 50 percent of the units.
The builder, the Briarwood Organization, is an experienced company based in Bayside, Queens. Vincent Riso, the president, said that two-bedroom units would sell for $68,000 and three-bedrooms for $76,000. The one-bedrooms will sell for for $45,000. Construction is to start in the spring.
The units are targeted for buyers with incomes between $22,000 and $32,000 a year, Mr. Riso said, which is close to the average incomes of Nehemiah buyers. As a rule, buyers' ability to meet the down payment and cover all the closing costs are the crucial factors in eligibility, and the housing is targeted to meet the conditions of the market where it is built. According to the city, the average income of current Nehemiah buyers in Brooklyn, based on mortgage documents, is $31,000.
Housing built under the Partnership's program typically has densities of 30 to 60 units an acre. Ironically, even these densities 15 years ago would have been derided by community officials as exemplary of the ''planned shrinkage'' doctrine that housing officials once put forward as the policy that should guide new development planning.
The most extreme example of low-density Bronx development was the original Charlotte Street project of Edward J. Logue, with six houses to the acre, spacious lawns and yards and white picket fences. The Nehemiah density is higher than that at about 20 units to the acre, but well below the existing Bronx zoning.
Since last year the over-all planning issues have been explored by a housing and neighborhood task force of the New Directions for the Bronx project formed by Borough President Ferrer and Community Board 3. Its report is being written by William B. Shore, senior vice president of the Regional Plan Association.
The 45-member task force is chaired by Genevieve S. Brooks, executive director of MBD Community Housing Corporation, a major nonprofit housing sponsor. The task force advocates densities of 60 to 100 units to the acre for Melrose Commons.
One-family houses built at large scale at low densities are too wasteful of land, said Ms. Brooks. ''We would be foolish if we did that,'' she said. Moreover, the same moderate-income level of buyer that is reached under the Nehemiah plan can be reached in other higher-density home-building programs, she said.
''The task force is quite clear that they want to bring middle-income people into the Bronx and keep them there,'' Mr. Shore said, ''and there should be much more mixed-income development. There should also be a higher density than is now being built on vacant land.''

HEADLINE: A Skyscraper-High Office Space Surplus

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
WITH office construction running at high levels at a time when New York City and its suburbs are struggling through an economic downturn, experts say the region is confronting the largest office space surplus in more than a decade.
The surplus, reflected in vacancy rates nearly twice as high as during the early 80's, seems certain to grow before it starts to be absorbed; studies show that the same industries that had been the region's fastest-growing office tenants earlier in the decade have been thinning their employment ranks.
Manhattan brokerage houses, banks, advertising agencies and insurance companies are cutting costs deeply, reorganizing and laying off workers. In the suburbs, where a wave of corporate relocations had been supporting a real estate boom, hostile takeovers, leveraged buyouts and management purges have left huge blocks of office space vacant.
Analysts expect demand to weaken further in some parts of the region's service-oriented economy. The Oct. 13 stock market plunge served as a reminder of the volatility of trading and employment on Wall Street. But beyond that, the experts say, many small and middle-sized companies in the city and its suburbs are planning to leave. 
''The key growth industries of the 1980's are now growing at a snail's pace, if at all,'' said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, New York Regional Commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. One result, he said, was a ''churning real estate market'' in which many businesses are looking for lower-cost or more technologically advanced offices, but adding little to the overall demand for space.
The impact of job losses on demand for office space is shown by the kind of arithmetic being done these days by real estate brokers. With each office employee estimated to need 250 square feet of space, the loss of 23,000 jobs recorded by Mr. Ehrenhalt's bureau at New York City banks and brokerage houses between October 1987 and August this year translates into a demand loss of 5,750,000 square feet of office space. That is the equivalent of five of the large buildings now going up in midtown Manhattan.
Even without the economic slowdown, analysts say, the torrid pace of commercial construction in Manhattan would have led to a temporary surplus. The Manhattan boom was prompted by by zoning incentives - allowing larger buildings than are normally approved in West Midtown - that expired in May 1988. The zoning incentive deadline prompted the construction of 16 high-rise buildings with more than 9 million square feet of rentable space, according to Cushman & Wakefield, a real estate concern. It said ten of the buildings are complete but 38 percent vacant and six are scheduled for completion by the spring.
OVERALL, vacancies in modern, well-located buildings are running at 13 percent in Manhattan, and from 18 percent to just under 28 percent in the region's suburban corporate centers, according to several studies by real estate companies.
''For most New Yorkers this is just fine,'' said John Dowling, Cushman & Wakefield's executive vice president. For companies planning to expand in the region, he added, conditions in the commercial real estate market ''are like motherhood.''
The high inventory of vacant commercial space is good and bad news for the regional economy. On the one hand, with developers and landlords struggling to rent out space, banks, pension funds and other large lenders are worried that some builders will be forced into bankruptcy. On the other hand, with rental rates flat or declining, many companies are looking at large blocks of space and the region may be regaining some of the corporate cachet lost since the stock market collapse of 1987.
Competition for large corporate tenants is intense. One developer, William Zeckendorf Jr., attracted three major tenants - Ogilvy & Mather and NW Ayer, the advertising agencies, and Cravath, Swaine & Moore, the law firm - by making them limited partners in Worldwide Plaza, his huge complex of offices, condominiums and retail space that takes up a full bock bounded by Eighth and Ninth Avenues and 49th and 50th Streets.
Cushman & Wakefield said the average rent in midtown Manhattan is $40.20 a square foot, up 75 cents from a year ago, and downtown rents average $34.77, down 93 cents from a year ago. And many owners have been offering tenants as much as a year's free rent and extensive interior renovation to meet their needs.
''There are very good real estate deals to be had in New York,'' said Gene Croisant, executive vice president of RJR Nabisco, the diversified tobacco and food company, which announced in September that it was moving its headquarters and 100 top executives from Atlanta to a high-rise on Avenue of the Americas at 52d Street. Its move bucks a trend of the last 20 years in which dozens of large, diversified corporations have moved their headquarters away from Manhattan. RJR Nabisco will occupy three floors of a building vacated last year by J. C. Penney, which moved its headquarters to Plano, Tex.
Analysts say they do not expect many moves like that of RJR Nabisco, but the real estate industry is rife with expectations that several large leases will be signed over the next six months, principally by New York City companies planning to consolidate now separate operations in new, state-of-the art offices.
News America Corporation, the publishing company; Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm; Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette and Kidder Peabody, the securities firms, and Chemical Bank are reported to be looking for new headquarters in Manhattan. Indeed, executives say that if commitments are made by all the large shoppers currently in the market, more than 20 million square feet of offices - more than the entire inventory of most large cities - would be filled by new tenants.
''We are playing a game of musical chairs, waiting for the music to stop and a few big chairs to be filled,'' said Bruce Eichner, a Manhattan developer who is seeking tenants for a high-rise office building he is completing on Times Square. ''At this point we are all looking for lead tenants, but just watch what happens after the first two or three big deals are announced. You will see an awful lot of activity.''
One area of robust demand for space has been among foreign corporations, many of which have had small offices in the New York region for decades but are now consolidating and expanding.
''New York is the place where markets operate and the place one has to be,'' said Melissa Wall of Midland Montagu, the third largest bank in Britain, which this year moved its American headquarters and 500 workers to three floors of City Spire, a new tower on 56th Street west of Avenue of the Americas. The company had been running its national operations, which are involved in currency trading, commodities and other financial markets, from three smaller Manhattan offices and one in San Francisco.
Although Manhattan's vacancy rates are far higher than in the early 80's, they are not as high as during the fiscal crisis of the 70's, when dozens of large employers fled and nearly 20 percent of the city's newest and most conveniently located offices were empty.
NOR is the surplus throughout the New York region as severe as in some parts of the Sun Belt, where a wave of construction in suburban corporate areas in the mid-80's led to a glut. Cushman & Wakefield said several areas had vacancy rates above 25 percent, including the suburbs around Houston, Austin and San Antonio, Tex., Newport Beach, Calif., and Boca Raton, Fla.
Demand for New York City offices, like the city economy itself, began surging in 1978 and cooled in some industries by 1985. As Manhattan vacancy rates shrank below 5 percent from 1978 to 1982, landlords were able to raise their rents fourfold, from an average of $10 a square foot to $40, a rate that has changed little since 1982.
Some experts maintain that higher vacancy rates are a healthy development because of the changing character of the city's and the region's economy. There is a greater dependence on fast-changing, technologically advanced industries like securities trading, consulting and professional services - industries that go through wide cycles of profitability and employment - and some vacancies are necessary as a cushion. When these industries enter periods of rapid expansion, the experts say, it will be necessary to have vacant offices complete and available for rent.
''It used to be that vacancy rates normally ran at 5 or 6 percent, and at 11 or 12 percent people got very upset,'' said William Wheaton, a real estate economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. ''Now it's a different market. Owners are a bit worried, but nobody expects things to cave in.''
Nonetheless, Mr. Wheaton said the vacancy rate in New York City is too high for a period of sluggish economic activity. He added that it would grow higher - perhaps as high as 15 percent - before it begins to reverse.
David G. Shulman, director of real estate research at Salomon Brothers, said that 6.3 million feet of new office space would be completed in midtown Manhattan over the next two years and that this was twice as much new space as could be absorbed. A result, he said, is that vacancy rates will swell throughout the city as tenants are drawn away from established buildings in lower Manhattan by landlords aggressively marketing their new midtown space.
''Underlying demand is just too weak'' for all of the new construction, he said.
Executives say many companies are certain to reduce their employment levels. In a survey of 600 executives who control ''middle market'' companies in the region - those with annual sales of $10 million to $250 million - Bank Leumi Trust Company found that most were pessimistic about economic prospects. The bank, which released its survey results in September, said 23 percent of the respondents planned to move their companies out of the region over the next five years. The price and availability of office space was not cited as a major factor, but drug abuse, crime, high taxes and high housing costs were among their biggest problems pointed to by the executives, the bank said.
One problem peculiar to some of the region's business centers is that their corporate real estate - much of it built for companies that left Manhattan in the 70's and early 80's - was designed to meet needs of individual companies looking for something different from a routine, big-city office environment. When those companies left or reduced their employment, as many have, it has sometimes been difficult to find others to fit the same space.
''There are a bunch of Taj Mahals out there,'' said Mr. Shulman.
HARDEST hit has been Fairfield County, which in the 1960's and 70's became a magnet for large corporations, including more than a dozen of the nation's 500 largest companies. Now, huge blocks of the same corporate space are for rent.
One example is in a lush residential section of Greenwich, Conn., where the headquarters built in the early 70's for the American Can Corporation has been nearly vacant for more than three years. American Can sold off its manufacturing businesses, became a much smaller company specializing in financial services, changed its name to Primerica Corporation, and vacated most of the headquarters by 1986. Greenwich officials have denied repeated requests to set aside their zoning rules that allow only one corporate tenant in the building.
In Stamford, Conn., the Singer Corporation, dismantled after a hostile 1988 takeover, has left a gleaming corporate headquarters building vacant. And in Danbury, Conn., where the Union Carbide Corporation became a corporate pace setter in the early 70's by erecting a circular, glass-enclosed headquarters - somewhat resembling a space station dropped in the woods - brokers have been scrambling to find corporate tenants. Union Carbide has vacated large blocks of space in its headquarters since its 1984 disaster in Bhopal, India, and a corporate restructuring.
Many other suburban corporate installations have been vacated, leaving the office vacancy rate in Fairfield County at 27.6 percent as of last June, according to Rostenberg-Doern, a real estate brokerage based in Stamford, Conn., and White Plains that publishes a semi-annual real estate report. The surplus is the largest in the New York region and one of the largest in the country.
In New York City, where most of the current surge of office construction is in midtown Manhattan, intense competition for tenants has prompted a northerly migration from Wall Street and other parts of lower Manhattan. A result is a growing surplus of downtown space, particularly blocks suitable for law firms, small brokerage houses, consulting organizations and other medium-sized Manhattan companies.
''Downtown has lost its middle market,'' said Maurice D. Solomon, executive vice president of Julien J. Studley, a brokerage based in Manhattan. An analysis by Cushman & Wakefield found that in midtown the vacancy was 13 percent, the same as at the end of 1988, but that in downtown it was 13.6 percent, as opposed to 11.9 percent at the end of 1988.
Much of this is attributable to the retrenchment throughout New York City of industries that had been leasing vast blocks of office space during the region's economic boom earlier in the decade. One such industry is banking, which entered a period of consolidation and layoffs even before the stock market collapse of October 1987. The Bureau of Labor Statistics, in an analysis of New York City, said bank employment, which had been as high as 172,600 in August 1986, has been declining steadily. Banks in the area employed 162,400 this August, it said.
Wall Street employment has shrunk sharply since the 1987 market debacle. The analysis found 147,500 employed in August in securities and commodities brokerages, down from 162,400 in August 1987.
One industry that continues to expand is legal services, with law firms in the city growing, merging and expanding their business with clients around the world. The Bureau of Labor Statistics said 75,400 people were practicing lawyers or employed by law firms in August after a steady expansion throughout the decade. The industry now employs almost 30,000 more people than in 1980, according to the analysis.
But the advertising industry, another of the city's engines of economic growth in the early 1980's, has been buffeted by mergers and layoffs in the last four years. Advertising agencies employed 39,500 in August, down from a peak of 41,500 in August 1985, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said.

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Gazing Into the Economic Crystal Ball

BYLINE: By Jon F. Weinstein; Jon F. Weinstein is a Hauppauge executive and was a delegate to the 1986 White House Conference on Small Business.

 BODY:
THE bad news: The Long Island economy faces trouble. The good news? We should start thinking about making some changes in our regional economy. While the Island has long-term strengths, the time to deal with a future of stress is before a storm.
This newspaper and daily life recount the grim realities: accumulating garbage, exploding taxes, paralyzing traffic, fragile defense jobs, lack of affordable housing, massive electrical costs and a worker shortage. Long-term solutions of these and other major problems will help to solve remaining ones. However, if we do not re-examine how we do business and conduct our local economic lives, solutions will not be enduring; they will be Band-Aids. 
Big business and bigness itself are not completely negative phenomena. Many functions can best be performed on large scales; big business breeds major technological developments as well as the ability to do great things that smaller organizations cannot easily accomplish. But bigness can become a mind set. ''Long Island will grow if we get more big companies here,'' boosters say, or, ''Long Island is big - big business, big projects, big bucks -and that's how it will stay big.'' These are short-sighted beliefs. Before those who represent big interests feel that this is a rank condemnation of growth and large size, don't.
There is need and room for both large operations and dispersed, innovative, smaller ones. We should plan to down-size in order to up-size our quality of economic and environmental life. We need service, specialization, innovation, and a gradual diminution of what Paul Hawken in ''The Next Economy'' calls the intermediation of economic life.
Great size and distance from human efficiency often go hand in hand. Depersonalization and inefficiency based on lower-incentive environments are often bred by massive institutions. Likewise, innovation flourishes in a small field. A National Science Foundation study showed that small companies produce 24 times as many industrial innovations as larger firms do. Research and development is big on Long Island: our efforts must uplift and promote small R & D shops.
Between 1972 and 1982, over two-thirds of the new jobs in the United States were created in companies with 20 or fewer employees. Since Long Islanders are both critical and service-conscious, small can be better. Smaller companies can better respond to a changing economy. It is fun to crystal-ball-gaze. When I do, I see the following economic shifts in Long Island's future:
Medical research: We already have both a technologically and intellectually rich base. The future demands new medical hardware, and ''peopleware'' as well. Long Island should take the lead in developing a broad range of mechanical as well as human service medical support that we require for the next century.
Aerospace: New fighters and more old ones are important. However, the future challenge in aerospace will come in the form of rehabilitating older aircraft and developing ''smart'' systems for use by a group of military and civilian workers needing sharper training tools.
Waste management: Some call it ''garbagecare.'' Smaller organizations can aid localities in dealing with a new generation of waste disposal needs.
EducationaL development: Despite the high test scores we run up, schooling is in trouble on Long Island, as it is all over. Home-based, freelance and innovative educational tutoring and curriculum development can be a vital industry.
Housing rehabilitation: Barring miracles, no major expansion of affordable housing is foreseen. Therefore, revamping and rehabilitating existing structures to address new living needs will likely be a big business on Long Island.
Alternative energy technology: From cutting electrical use to alternative sources, energy will be a linchpin issue on Long Island. The most innovative and entrepreneurial among us will develop responses to our inadequate energy supply that will likely be our burden for the next half century.
From home-based mental health services to innovative defense contracting and a huge host of roles in between, companies and organizations that will produce and distribute in newer, more streamlined and individualized ways will cause truly constructive growth on Long Island.
The Regional Plan Association recently estimated that the Nassau-Suffolk population would jump by about 224,000 between 1987 and 2005. Vehicular registrations are projected to jump even more. A shift to smaller organizations will allow localities to tame is traffic. By doing this, we alter traffic patterns and garner more breathing space.
E. F. Schumacher wrote in ''Small Is Beautiful'' that ''wealth, education, research . . . are needed . . . for civilization . . . what is most needed today is a revision of the ends which these means are meant to serve.''
In the next century, development of smaller, more responsive and innovative businesses that respond to specialized community needs can help us cope with the future.

SECTION: Section 12LI; Page 24, Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 832 words

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND OPINION; TRIMMING SCHOOL COSTS: READERS RESPOND;
Statistics in Support Of the Indefensible

 BODY:
The adage ''Statistics don't lie, statisticians do'' came to mind when I read That Irving Gerber feels comfortable living in ignorance of economic realities is his prerogative. However, selling his ignorance to others is, in his own words, indefensible.
Let's give Mr. Gerber the benefit of every doubt (including the assumption that his statistics are accurate). His citations fail to substantiate his point that better education can be had for a fraction of its current cost. For instance, he criticizes the Oceanside district for having three assistant superintendents for 5,000 students where it ''used to have 10,000 children and one superintendent.'' 
When did that district have 10,000 children and one superintendent? 1929? 1945? 1962? How many buildings did the district maintain to house 10,000 students and how many now? How many of the current students require special services not formerly performed but now mandated by the state, which cost money and require coordination and supervision? Finally, no mention is made of whether the students of Oceanside are performing better, worse or the same as they did in the good old days, whenever they were.
Mr. Gerber also states that Bayport lost 1,400 pupils in 10 years, yet doubled its budget. Mr. Gerber, does it cost you the same to live as it did 10 years ago? Has your electric, gas or water bill increased? How about your food bill or the cost of getting to and from school? It is beyond dispute that the cost of these necessities have skyrocketed. Schools, like other entities, are not immune to economic fluctuations. Given his admirable desire to improve our schools, how would Mr. Gerber propose to maintain quality, if not to at least maintain the former status quo he thinks so highly of?
Would Mr. Gerber be willing to kick in 10 percent of his pension to help keep our schools afloat instead of burdening the ''poor taxpayers'' who don't even have the benefit of any pension plan to look forward to in retirement, but who have children in school now?
Mr. Gerber says, ''we are paying for a pig in a poke...to satisfy the power lust and prestige needs of school superintendents and school boards.'' Being a retired principal of the illustrious New York City school system (and who could ever question the efficiency and economy of that system, of which Mr. Gerber himself is a product), could he cite any functionary of our educational system who has chosen his lot for its ''glamour appeal'' instead of for the intrinsic value of having a say in the care and nurturing of our children? Would he ever have tolerated denying students the necessities, regardless of cost increases? I should think not.
Finally, while Mr. Gerber magnanimously recognizes that teachers are ''professionals'' deserving of the salary increases they have fought for and won, he has arbitrarily designated a $40,000 or $50,000 ceiling, and no more than cost-of-living increases, on what those professionals should be allowed to earn.
In support of this argument, he asserts the inanity that teaching has long been equated with poverty in our history and our ''pedagogues can hardly cry poverty'' now. However, Mr. Gerber neglects to mention that teachers' starting salaries remain well below that of other professionals, and that the ceiling he espouses may generally be reached only after teaching 20-odd years in the same district and/or earning the equivalent of a Ph.D. in education.
In fact, teachers are now required to acquire a master's degree within five years of graduating from college merely to continue to pursue their career. Does a mere 4 or 5 percent increase on a starting salary in the low $20,000 range realistically reflect not only the cost of living, but the cost of financing the undeniably high cost of becoming a teacher? Does 8 percent? Isn't a 25-year veteran entitled to earn more than a pittance?
The statistics Mr. Gerber ignores are infinitely more telling than the ''facts'' he cites as to why costs have increased. While excess spending may exist in some school programs, and overactive egos may affect an occasional superintendent or board member, Mr. Gerber's accusations beg the very issue of running schools.
Where does Mr. Gerber sugest that schools begin? Reduce the already deficient supply of teachers by returning them to subsistence wages? Stop providing heat or nutritious lunches or bus services, while making children travel twice as far to sit in overcrowded classrooms? Cut back on textbooks and supplies?
The cost of keeping a school on par with its own performance of 10 years ago has become very expensive. We cannot wish away today's high costs by clicking our ruby slippers together three times and repeating, ''There's nothing like the old days.''
There is no Yellow Brick Road leading to an educational Emerald City. If you want quality, you have to pay for it, and I can think of no better place to splurge than on the future.
 
CHERYL P. VOLLWEILER
 West Hempstead

LENGTH: 982 words

HEADLINE: Many Issues Neglected In Race for Governor

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
AS it enters its final weeks, the campaign for governor is attracting notice as much for what the candidates are not talking about as for what they are.
In addition, the campaign's negative tone is raising concerns that voters who are not registered Democrats or Republicans may be turned off and stay home on Election Day.
''Some people are beginning to feel this could be one of the lowest turnouts in history,'' said Richard Roper, the executive director of the Council on New Jersey Affairs at Princeton University. ''The candidates are not presenting themselves in a way that will entice voters to come out.'' 
Besides electing a governor when they go to the polls on Nov. 7, voters will pass on the merits of five referendums, involving $590 million in bond issues, and will decide which party will control the 80-member State Assembly for the next two years. The Assembly races take on added significance in light of the 1990 census because of the Assembly's role in Congressional redistricting that will follow the census.
In their television commercials and in their two televised debates, Representative Jim Courter, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, and Representative James J. Florio, his Democratic rival, have attacked each other in personal terms.
Mr. Florio has accused Mr. Courter of lying, of prejudice against homosexuals and of failing to quickly clean up toxic waste on property he owns. Mr. Courter has accused Mr. Florio of accepting contributions from a labor union once controlled by the mob, of interceding on behalf of people in trouble with the law and of countenancing questionable financial deals made by some former associates in Camden County.
Taking a page from Gov. Thomas H. Kean's 1981 campaign book but perhaps failing to read the final chapter, Mr. Courter has signed a pledge not to increase the income tax or sales tax in his first term. Mr. Kean promised not to increase the two taxes and pledged to try to reduce the sales tax. But within a year he signed increases in both taxes to close a budget deficit of several hundred million dollars.
The two candidates take different positions on auto insurance and on abortion. Mr. Courter supports deregulation of the insurance industry, and Mr. Florio favors tighter controls. Mr. Florio supports a woman's right to choose an abortion, and Mr. Courter opposes abortion, except in cases of rape or incest or when the mother's life is in danger.
But aside from discussing those issues and a few others like the environment, the candidates have not provided the public with much information on pressing state concerns like AIDS, affordable housing, urban revitalization, welfare reform, job training and health care.
Mr. Roper said some of those items have become grist for the debates in the form of anecdotes - Would you leave your child in a classroom with a child who had AIDS? - but were not discussed in a more substantative way, for example, What do you plan to do to meet the growing problem of acquired immune deficiency syndrome in a state with one of the highest rates of AIDS-related health problems among children in the country and the fourth highest incidence of the disease?
''I've seen some position papers by the candidates in forums before special-interest groups,'' Mr. Roper said, ''but the general public does not participate in the policy arena, and the people expected to vote are being left out.''
 
Role in Redistricting
The approach of the 1990 census gives the Assembly races additional significance. New Congressional districts based on population changes will be drawn by the Legislature and approved by the Governor. When one party controls both houses and the governorship, the new map invariably includes districts fashioned to give the controlling party maximum advantage in subsequent Congressional races.
The last two maps, after the 1970 and 1980 censuses, were challenged in court, and the final redistricting plans were dictated by a Federal court.
Republicans have a narrow majority, 41 to 39, in the Assembly and must retain control to have a hand in designing the map that will go to the Governor. Democrats control the Senate and will do so when the redistricting bill is drafted. Mr. Florio has been pictured as the front-runner in the gubernatorial race for most of the campaign, which has heightened the importance of the Assembly races for the Republican Party.
The executive director of the State Republican Committee, Peter Verniero, has said that the party could lose two Congressional seats if both houses and the Governor are Democratic and if the new map they draw up survives a court test. The current Congressional delegation comprises eight Democrats and six Republicans.
 
Approval Sought for Bonds
In the public questions on the ballot, voters are asked to approve the issuance of $590 million in bonds to finance a variety of land acquisition, construction and grant programs. The first question calls for $300 million to acquire land for conservation and recreation and to preserve farmland.
The second question seeks permission for the state to spend $125 million to improve state and community-based centers for the developmentally disabled and the mentally ill, and to build additional corrections centers.
The third referendum would provide $50 million for low-interest loans and grants to local governments to upgrade storm-water systems and to prevent local sewers from overflowing into state waterways.
The fourth question asks authorization to spend $115 million to repair state, county and municipal bridges and to acquire railroad rights of way.
The last question does not call for new spending but asks permission to expand the purposes of the 1981 and 1986 hazardous waste discharge bond acts, to allow money already allocated to be used for projects to protect underground drinking water supplies.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY OPINION;
To Challenge Top Students, Academies Are Needed

BYLINE: By Robert F. Guarasci; Robert F. Guarasci lives in Fort Lee.

 BODY:
AT a time when other states are moving aggressively to provide challenging opportunities for their best and brightest high school students, New Jersey is lagging behind.
Since the beginning of this decade, at least 17 states have established specialized academies for students who excel in science and math. At these schools, students are taught by scientists and other highly trained instructors and are offered courses like astrophysics, genetics and biotechnology. They are able to work with sophisticated equipment, including state-of-the-art computers, and in many cases are linked with mentors at companies who provide them with expert and practical guidance. 
New Jersey, however, has refused to build specialized academies for our top students. The State Department of Education has instead preferred to focus its efforts on encouraging each local school district, of which there are more than 500, to devise and implement its own advanced curriculums, based on a district's unique circumstances and needs. It's a policy that, while good in some ways, doesn't go far enough in addressing the needs of the state's most outstanding students.
It's easy to agree with the basic thrust of the department's policy. It probably is best, as they maintain, for each individual school district to create whatever programs it feels are needed for its students. And if every district had the talent and the resources to establish its own truly advanced curriculums, there would be no problem. But this is not the case.
While some school districts, like Paramus and Tenafly in Bergen County, do offer their top students advanced science courses, not all do. Similarly, some schools like Fort Lee High School, my own alma mater, have programs that link gifted students with mentors to allow in-depth study in a particular area of interest. But again, not all districts offer programs like this.
Bergen County is also the site of the state's most comprehensive and encouraging attempt to provide gifted students with superior instruction. Planners from a number of the county's school districts have developed a groundbreaking concept to share resources among all of the county's schools.
Part of this effort will be a new facility in Hackensack called the Academy for Advanced Science and Arts, and its objective will be to offer challenging coursework to qualified Bergen County students. It's a real plus for those who live in Bergen, but students in the state's other 20 counties are not as fortunate.
The problem, of course, is that unless a student happens to live in a place that offers the appropriate coursework, that student's needs are not being met. Though there is a chance that a student in this predicament might be able to attend classes at a local college or perhaps special summer programs like the Governor's School in Math and Science, these opportunities are limited and not available to everyone. And so the fairness gap exists. The remedy, I believe, is simple. The state should act quickly to build a centrally located campus of specialized academies for our best and brightest high school students. Most of the other states have limited their efforts to math and science academies, but New Jersey should go even further. Our campus should contain several academies that would address the needs not only of students skillful in math and science, but also of students who are interested in careers in government, the arts and other fields.
Critics are certain to point out drawbacks. Some might cite the cost of such an undertaking. It doesn't have to be prohibitive. Let's interest the leading corporations in this state, as well as civic- minded benefactors, in sharing in the cost. Additionally, school districts that send students to this academy might help to defray costs by paying tuition for each student they send. And perhaps bonds could be issued to help cover land acquisition and construction costs.
Local school district officials might fear that their best students would be taken from them. That might be true, but our real concern ought to be for our students' potential and not for a particular district's scores or statistics.
If the academy is of the boarding variety, as it is in nine other states, some educators and parents might worry about a teen-ager growing up away from home. But there's no reason why students couldn't return home often enough, especially if the academy is located centrally, to maintain close contact with family and friends. And perhaps the programs could be designed to accept students for one or two years, rather than for the entire four years of high school.
In truth, the establishment of a campus of specialized academies for our most gifted high school students would not supersede or undermine current policy, only complement it. Let each district continue to do all it can to reach the greatest number of its top students, but let's also have a campus of specialized academies that would bring together our most outstanding students, who, with their parents, would choose to enroll in them.
It's ironic that a state that's been leading the way in its introduction of progressive educational initiatives should fall behind other states on a matter as important as this. The consequences of inaction for our students and our economy are too great. We simply cannot in good conscience deprive generations of future students of the chance to develop their talents to the fullest. And if we do, every one of us will eventually pay the price.
