SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 26, Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 631 words

HEADLINE: Opposing a Raise For Federal Judges

 BODY:
I was intrigued by Federal Judge Harold A. Ackerman's responses to questions concerning the pay increase issue for Federal judges, in a recent New Jersey Q & A. Judge Ackerman's reasons for supporting a raise for the judiciary were at least more substantive than those provided by President Bush and Chief Justice Rehnquist.
As much as I respect Judge Ackerman for his 34 years on the bench, the last 10 as a Federal district judge, and for his obvious dedication and love for his work, I feel compelled to take exception to some of the arguments he uses to justify a raise for Federal judges.
His main argument for the judiciary is that inflation has eroded the base pay of the justices. Is inflation any less eroding of the income of the 98.6 percent of the American people who earn less than the current $89,500 received by Federal judges and members of Congress? 
The same holds true for educating one's children. With college tuition rates increasing at twice the inflation rate, everyone is having difficulty paying for children's education.
As for Federal judges leaving the bench in droves, the average vacancy rate for the Federal bench is 35 to 40 seats a year. That translates to a 5 percent turnover rate, as opposed to a 15 to 20 percent turnover in the private sector.
There are over 700,000 lawyers in the United States, of whom about 750 are Federal district or appeals court judges. With such a huge pool of legal talent to choose from, it is difficult to imagine there would be any problem in finding qualified replacements. Chief Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes said the Constitution is what the judges say it is. But it's the Federal judges, not the Supreme Court, who have the greatest influence on how the Constitution is interpreted. The Supreme Court hears only about 150 cases a year, while the inferior courts pass judgment on thousands of cases a year.
This is all the more reason why we have to change the method of selecting Federal judges from that of a patronage political plum system to one that seeks the most qualified and indiscriminate in terms of political affiliation, ideology, race and gender. Only then would I be willing to listen to arguments about qualifications and the dispensing of equal justice for all.
There are those who seek election to Congress and appointment to the Federal bench as springboards to the lures of the lucrative salaries offered by the private sector. Would Federal judges have the same value to the private sector had they not first obtained Federal judgeships? I wonder how justice is served when a Federal judge presides over a case that may involve a future law partner? I would build a moat around the legislative and judicial branches of government in the form of a conflict-of-interest barrier about five years wide.
Judge Ackerman did not mention that a retiring Federal judge receives as a pension the salary he had on the last day of his employment. Nor did he make reference to the Federal judges who have achieved senior status, permitting them to choose their caseloads, and that 20 percent of them handle no caseloads, being content to hang on to take advantage of any raises that come along.
The fact that we are now a debtor nation and supporting our current standard of living on borrowed money makes President Bush's proposal to raise the salaries of Federal judges by 25 percent and raise executive branch salaries substantially - and by extension, the salaries of members of Congress - reprehensible to the voters. The people want the legislative, executive and judicial branches of government anchored to the Constitution and want to place a tether on these branches so that they cannot economically distance themselves too far from the American people.
 
ED MURPHY
 Lakewood

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: letter

HEADLINE: Lack of Mass Transit Affects Employment

 BODY:
Senator Frank Lautenberg's fine article (''Reducing the Labor Shortage,'' Opinion Page, Sept. 3) on the labor shortage in this state, with emphasis on high unemployment in urban areas, did not address a major reason for this state of affairs: lack of available mass transit.
N. J. Transit should vigorously develop reverse-peak service from urban areas to suburban and even rural job sites, so that the urban poor, most of whom cannot afford a reliable car, can get to these job sites where employers are crying for help. 
 DOUG MARKS JR.
 Dumont

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: AUGUSTA, ME.;
Competing For the Malls

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH plans for regional shopping malls in both Augusta and Waterville have been announced, it is generally acknowledged that only one is likely to be built.
In Augusta, Melvin Simon and Associates of Indianapolis, the shopping-mall developer, has commitments from three department stores for a 500,000-square-foot mall it wants to build on 50 acres. And in Waterville, the owners of 330 acres are set to select a developer for a 550,000-square-foot mall there. 
''There's not room for both,'' said Greg Boulos, a commercial real estate broker in Portland who is not involved in either project. ''Either one will go.'' Both projects are near an exit of Interstate 95, separated by about 20 miles. ''In some ways we're competing with each other, but both are putting on blinders and trying to get the permits we need,'' said Gary Craig, whose family owns or has options to buy the Waterville tract. He said his site has better access from I-95 and will not need extensive preconstruction work because of wetlands.
But Michael Murphy, a spokesman for Simon and Associates, said the company is already working with the Army Corps of Engineers to solve problems posed by five acres of wetlands and is preparing a traffic study to see what road work will need to be done. He said his company examined several sites, including the Craig property, but deemed Augusta ''far and away the best.'' It is the state capital, with low unemployment as a result largely of state jobs, is centrally located and, has 22,000 people, as opposed to Waterville's nearly 18,000.
Maine has only three regional enclosed malls, the largest being Maine Mall in South Portland, a 1.1-million-square-foot center built in 1971. Bangor Mall, built in 1978 and serving much of the northern part of the state and Canada, has 550,000 square feet. Auburn Mall, about 30 miles southwest of Augusta, has 300,000 square feet and was completed in 1979.
Retail space is considered by analysts to be the healthiest segment of Maine's real estate market, especially in the three cities where there are malls. Strip shopping centers, covering 500,000 square feet, near the Maine Mall, for example, have few vacancies.
In addition, a 200,000-square-foot center to be built nearby next year by New Market Development Company of Atlanta has anchor stores already committed. The same company plans to build a 260,000-square-foot shopping center near the Auburn Mall.

HEADLINE: Focus: Framingham, Mass.;
Keeping U.S.-Aided Housing Affordable

BYLINE: By SUSAN DIESENHOUSE

 BODY:
IN an experiment that could have national significance, a section of a 20-year-old housing complex here was sold last month by a private developer to a nonprofit corporation specifically designed to own and operate the project.
As a result, 286 units of the 548-unit development called The Beavers - a complex of 62 two-story garden apartment houses on a 32-acre site developed with the help of a Federal mortgage interest rate subsidy - will remain affordable for low- or moderate-income tenants.
The John M. Corcoran & Company of Milton, Mass., bought the complex six years ago. Its sale of the 286 units to the nonprofit Pelham Corporation was financed in two ways - with $13.6 million in tax-exempt bonds issued by the Massachusetts Housing Finance Agency, a state agency and the $3.65 million from the leasing of 58 of those units to the town's public housing authority for 99 years. The state's Executive Office of Communities and Development provided the funds for those units. 
As its contribution to affordability, the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development awarded up to 95 section 8 housing vouchers to the Framingham Housing Authority to assist tenants whose income is less than 50 percent of the area median, which is $45,000 for a family of four.
In the 60's and 70's, the Federal Government helped financeabout 650,000 new low-cost rental units around the country through its mortgage interest rate subsidy, according to Michael Nail, director of community development for the National Association of Housing and Redevelopment Officials, an organization of government and private nonprofit community development agencies.
The quid pro quo was that the developer maintain the low rents over the mortgage term, in some cases up to 40 years. It was agreed that the Federal use restrictions could expire in 20 years if the property owner wished to prepay the mortgage.
In the past few years, as projects approached prepayment eligibility, Federal, state and local officials and housing advocates have sought measures to protect existing lower income tenants from rent increases that would exceed their ability to pay.
''These expiring-use projects are time bombs ticking away that are due to detonate now,'' Mr. Nail said. Landlords often want to prepay mortgages to convert them into condominiums and others may no longer find it attractive to own such properties after the 1986 changes in the tax law, he explained.
Early in 1988, the Federal Government imposed a moratorium on prepayments until next February. But as the number of low-income families grows and the supply of low-cost housing shrinks, said Mr. Nail, the specter of more homeless people has led many communities and states to try to acquire some of these properties to maintain their long term affordability. ''Massachusetts has been one of the leaders,'' he said.
In this state, where about 170 rental projects were built under the Federal mortgage interest-rate subsidy program, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis last year called upon developers to negotiate new agreements to preserve the low-cost housing stock here.
''If developers did not cooperate in negotiating reasonable deals, it was feared that the state legislature would pass laws to limit their ability to prepay mortgages or convert to condominiums,'' said Joseph L. Flatley, who is in charge of preserving and building low-cost housing for the state's Executive Office of Communities and Development.
HE also noted that developers with ''expiring use'' properties, such as Corcoran, work with the state and Federal governments in the construction and management of other housing projects.
''We have an ongoing relationship with H.U.D. and E.O.C.D.,'' said Richard J. High, director of development for Corcoran, which owns and manages about 8,000 rental units, including some public housing, in the Northeast and Southeast.
With the 1986 tax changes, he said, losses on low-cost rentals ''were no longer permitted to shelter income from other property.''
''We were sitting with property that was not providing any economic return,'' Mr. High said. ''It forced our hand.'' He added that Corcoran was now seeking a similar deal to sell off the remaining apartments.
''Given the pressure from the Federal and state government not to do what we thought we had a right to do when we bought the property,'' he continued, ''the deal is pretty good, but it's not a fair-market deal.'' He said that Corcoran received about $60,000 per unit plus a contract to manage the apartments and a $3 million contract to renovate them.
The Beavers sale and its unusual refinancing is the state's first, according to Mr. Flatley, the state housing official, but he expects that within six months, four to six more projects will negotiate transfers of ownership that will maintain low rents.
Housing advocates here applaud the sale of the Beavers apartments, since it seems to minimize tenant displacement. They also endorse the sale of ''expiring use'' properties to nonprofit groups.
But they question the amount of tenant involvement in the Pelham Corporation. Its eight-member board includes two state appointees, a Corcoran staff person and local advocates for lower-income tenants, including the Southern Middlesex County Tenants Council. But there are no Beavers tenants on the board.
''We believe these properties should be sold to tenant controlled non-profits or limited-equity cooperatives,'' said Lizbeth Heyer, legislative coordinator of the Massachusetts Tenants Organization. Moreover, she added, ''the Beaver deal is very expensive and the state should not hold it up as a model that can be reproduced, especially given its current fiscal problems.''
But, said Mr. Nail, the national housing organization official, ''if the state had not intervened, the landlord would probably have made much more profit and the units would have been lost from the affordable housing stock.''
THE project was orignally built for about $3.3 million with a federally subsidized mortgage for which the developer paid about 3 percent interest rather than the prevailing 5.5. percent, Mr. High said.
To qualify for a unit just prior to the sale last month, the income of a family of four could not exceed $38,500. Rents range from $242 to $319 a month for the small two- and three-bedroom units.
About 26 percent of the tenants earn more than 80 percent of the median income in the area, 34 percent earn 50 to 80 percent and 41 percent earn less than 50 percent. Under terms of the sale, the tenant income distribution will remain similar. But rents will now be 30 percent of the tenants' income. Rent increases will be phased in over three years after a one-year renovation plan, which started last month, is completed, Mr. High said.
Corcoran bought the project in this town about 45 minutes west of Boston, in the fastest growing sector of the state, intending to convert it to condominums that would sell for about $110,000, he said.
In this town of about 60,000 residents, condominiums sell from $110,000 to about $300,000; the median home price is $175,000 and sales have gone up to $1.3 million; rents meanwhile range from $650 to $1,000 a month for two- or three-bedroom apartments, said Randall J. Kincaid, the chairman of the Board of Assessors.

GRAPHIC: photo of garden apartments at The Beavers, Framingham, Mass. (NYT/Jim Bourg)

HEADLINE: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Augusta, Me.;
Competing For the Malls

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH plans for regional shopping malls in both Augusta and Waterville have been announced, it is generally acknowledged that only one is likely to be built.

LENGTH: 1629 words

HEADLINE: Old Shows With New Twists

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
THE show is George and Ira Gershwin's ''Oh, Kay!'' The year is 1926, the setting is a swanky estate in Southampton and the characters include a titled bootlegger (The Duke) and an English heiress (Lady Kay).
But not at the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, where the musical comedy about Prohibition has been transported to a Harlem speakeasy: the mythical Paradise Club.
Meanwhile, at the Yale Repertory in New Haven, ''Miss Julie,'' August Strindberg's classic tragedy, circa 1888, about the fatal attraction between a countess and a valet, is not being played out in a chilly Swedish castle, as prescribed, but on a coffee plantation in Brazil, and the antagonists are named Dona Julia and Joao (for Jean). 
By coming up with new interpretations of old works, the two theaters are expanding the possibilities for nontraditional casting, one of the most discussed topics in theater today. For both Goodspeed and Yale, these productions mark the first time a play or musical has been rediscovered by a director, reinterpreted and recast entirely for minority actors. But the Yale Repertory has made a tradition of nontraditional casting ''in the 'colorblind' or integrated sense, even before it became a fashionable issue,'' said Robert Wildman, a theater spokesman. ''Our audiences take it for granted; we just do it.'' In the most recent instance, in this season's opening production of the 1953 comedy ''The Solid Gold Cadillac,'' Tommy Hollis, a black actor, was cast as a business tycoon and politician in a role that had customarily been given to whites.
Other Connecticut theaters - the Long Wharf in New Haven and Hartford Stage - practice colorblind casting ''in context,'' said Arvin Brown, the artistic director at Long Wharf. ''We cast from show to show,'' he said. ''It has to do with the fabric of the play. If it is not falsified, as long as you're not playing mix and match, an actor of any race can play any role and should.'' He mentioned the casting of black actors in Long Wharf productions of such plays as ''The Skin of Our Teeth'' and ''Camille.''
 
A Multicultural Family
As for Hartford Stage, in its production of ''Pericles,'' the actors playing the title character, his wife, her father and their daughter were white, black, Hispanic and Asian, respectively.
But giving a play a new setting with an all-minority cast could signal a trend, if not a breakthrough. ''It can make terrific sense if you're creating a world that has its own unity,'' Mr. Brown said. ''We haven't done that yet, but I'm not averse to it if it works.
The Yale Repertory's ''Miss Julie,'' which opened Friday and runs through Nov. 11, is ''singular and a first,'' said Lloyd Richards, the artistic director.
''We seized the opportunity of moving the play without changing it - and the play permitted us that opportunity,'' Mr. Richards said. ''We won't restructure a playwright's work by bending it from its original intent. Here, we can go deeper into what the playwright provided. It's an organic thing to do.''
Transplanting ''Miss Julie'' from Sweden to Brazil without modernizing it was the idea of the Jamaican-born director Dennis Scott, who last season staged ''Playboy of the West Indies,'' a retelling by a playwright, Mustapha Matura, of Synge's Irish classic, ''Playboy of the Western World.''
 
Conflicts in New Terms
''I thought we could take Strindberg's original conflict between class and gender one step further and ask: Is there a similar set of relationships between color and economic exploitation?'' Mr. Scott said.
''Shifting the setting thus allows the combatants a historically determined position, and the audience can see the relationships between class and power in new terms. A socio-economic and cultural conflict is created by adding just a few years - the action takes place in the early 1890's - right after the emancipation of slaves in Brazil.''
Mr. Hollis, who appeared in the Yale Repertory production of ''The Piano Lesson'' by August Wilson, which will open on Broadway in April, said nontraditional casting opens up employment opportunities for minority actors and can reinvigorate plays.
''If you put these plays on as they were written in the first place, no black would be cast in them,'' Mr. Hollis said. ''Rethinking can wake up audiences - and wake up old plays. No one will come in saying, 'Oh, we've seen it a hundred times before.' All of a sudden, it's brand new. I don't know whether the rest of the country knows what to do with this yet. We'll have to see successful attempts at it.''
Commenting on the director-created concept of nontraditional casting, the veteran producer William Ross, whose touring productions have played at the Westport County Playhouse, said: ''Any effort we make in terms of casting nontraditionally is important. It's only getting lip service in the commercial theater. We've had novelties like an all-black 'Guys and Dolls' and 'Hello Dolly' on Broadway, and they just become statistics.''
''But this is a new way to move forward,'' he added. ''It's healthy, and I applaud it.'' Earlier this month, Mr. Ross received a Paul Robeson Award, given by the Actors Equity Association for his efforts to create equitable casting opportunities in the theater.
 
The Romantic Lead
At the Goodspeed, Dan Siretta, the associate artistic director and resident choreographer, was responsible for reconceiving ''Oh, Kay!'' which runs through Dec. 23 with Ron Richardson as the romantic lead, Jimmy Winters, a playboy.
''When I looked at 'Oh, Kay!,' it had a complacent script by Guy Bolton and P. G. Wodehouse, and I didn't even know what to do with the opening scene,'' Mr. Siretta said. ''The plots were thrown together.''
''Then I came upon the number 'Clap a Yo' Hands,' and it all started with that,'' he explained. ''It had an introductory line about a 'red hot mammy' so that a white character could sing it. I started to play with the idea of giving it a rush of new energy - and a real identity to the characters. Kay was rich and had a yacht, and they all lived off their money. Now she survives by working in an upscale club. It's still 1926, and we're in the middle of Prohibition, but by making it black and moving it to 138th Street, the story has an edge, and it's totally believable.
''This is a rediscovery, not a re-creation. It can never be done as it once was. How can it? And the opportunity existed to open up an old American musical to a black cast - with a real book, not a revue like 'Black and Blue' or 'Ain't Misbehavin' .' So this is a first for us.''
 
'A Strong Point of View'
Since Mr. Siretta, Martin Connor, the musical's director, and James Racheff, who adapted the book, are white, Sheldon Epps, who conceived and directed the musical revue ''Blues in the Night,'' was engaged as the production's artistic consultant ''to provide a strong point of view as a black American,'' Mr. Epps explained.
''The spirit of the original lines was kept but something had to be done about the language, which suddenly had a false English tone,'' Mr. Epps said. The play now has names that have the resonance of musical royalty and become harbingers of the Harlem Renaissance, like the title Duke and the switch from Lady Kay to Lady Katie. ''Lady was an esteemed title given to a black artist, like Lady Day,'' Mr. Epps said.
On the song ''Clap a Yo' Hands,'' Mr. Epps commented: ''That was a racist setup, and we've thrown it out. Now it has a real life and there's a new truth to the score because Gershwin was influenced by the Jazz Age and black music. The music is now coming from a natural place, and the material has a new point of view. That's not happening anywhere.''
''We didn't just take a show and dip it in chocolate,'' Mr. Epps explained. ''We gave it an environment that supports the material and makes casting it this way realistic and exciting. If this was just another gimmick, no one would be served by it. Now here's a chance to open up new doors for black actors, and that's exciting for the theater in general. Why don't we just call it open-minded casting?''
 
'Another Revival'
Mr. Connor, an English director, said: ''When I was asked to do 'Oh, Kay!,' I thought, What's the point of another revival? But Dan's idea made me stay. Looking at the original script, it's clear that the topicality of it made it a success. It was risque and naughty to deal with something blatantly illegal.
''But once Prohibition was lifted, the immediacy and danger and recognizability faded away, and this became a quaint little American musical. Now it's in the center of clubland - and the Gershwin estate was convinced of our integrity so they gave us permission to do it this way.''
Mr. Richardson, who won a 1985 Tony Award for his performance as the runaway slave Jim in the musical ''Big River,'' learned Japanese and recreated the role in Japan with an all-Japanese cast two years ago. ''If it weren't for white companies doing musicals, I would never get a chance to be in them,'' he said.
In Pennsylvania, Mr. Mr. Richardson has played supporting roles in ''Camelot'' and ''Man of La Mancha'' and the lead in ''West Side Story.''
''I wouldn't get to be a traditional leading man like Jimmy Winters,'' he added. ''That doesn't happen to black actors - unless the show is 'Dreamgirls.' '' ''There are no blacks in 'Les Mis' or in 'Phantom.'
''In 'Oh, Kay!,' the parallels between the original character and the one I'm playing are consistent. It's my hope that producers and directors will open their eyes to the possibilities created by a completely reconceived production like this. And this may be the first time a black company has played the Goodspeed Opera House since the minstrel shows in 1877.''

GRAPHIC: Photo of Ron Richardson at the Goodspeed Opera House; scene from ''Oh, Kay!'' (pg. 30) (NYT/Peter Kramer)

HEADLINE: Dinkins Pledges to Cut Spending By 1% to Reduce the City's Deficit

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

 BODY:
Acknowledging that New York City faces ''difficult times'' financially, David N. Dinkins, the Democratic mayoral candidate, said yesterday that he would be prepared to cut city spending - except for the Police Department - by 1 percent to reduce a looming budget deficit.
Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate who has criticized Mr. Dinkins for his ''free-spending'' policies, ridiculed the proposal, saying it was nothing more than a formula created by Mr. Dinkins to avoid making difficult choices.
Mr. Dinkins said yesterday on ''News Forum,'' a morning interview program on WNBC-TV, that spending cuts would be one way he would deal with the fiscal austerity that most experts agree awaits the new mayor.
 
The Giuliani Plan
''I am prepared to institute a 1 percent cut across the board,'' Mr. Dinkins said. ''If that is not enough, we'll see what else we have to cut.'' 
Mr. Giuliani attacked the plan as irresponsible, saying that he would instead take a number of steps, including the refinancing of city bonds and the reinvestment of pension funds.
''David Dinkins's whole reaction to the budget crisis is to run away from it and say things that are deeply disturbing,'' Mr. Giuliani said at a news conference in midtown Manhattan. ''And now he comes up with a 1 percent decrease, which is in essence trying to substitute a formula for a tough assessment.''
Until now, Mr. Dinkins has refused to answer questions about the budget deficit, saying he would await recommendations from task forces. He said in one interview that he would rather be ''hazy and fuzzy'' than ''upset some apple carts prematurely.''
His nod yesterday in the direction of spending cuts - instead of taxes, layoffs or other ways to close the gap -came a day after Mr. Giuliani said fear of Mr. Dinkins's election had caused a decline in New York City bond prices on Friday. Mr. Giuliani's assertion was disputed by the City Comptroller's office.
Mr. Giuliani repeated yesterday that bond traders were ''very afraid'' of a Dinkins election, although a recent report in Barron's said market analysts had expressed wariness about both candidates, since neither has ruled out a tax increase as a solution to the city's fiscal problems.
Mr. Giuliani will be endorsed today by Crain's New York Business, a weekly newspaper, which said, ''Mr. Dinkins's style of governing will lead to years of inaction and paralysis.''
The Crain's editorial praised Mr. Giuliani's ''intelligence and commitment,'' which, it said, ''suggest that he will, in a resonable amount of time, learn the job.''
 
Hiring Freeze Recommended
At the news conference yesterday outside the Women's National Republican Club, Mr. Giuliani said that in addition to refinancing city bonds and reinvesting pension funds, he would seek a hiring freeze to reduce the deficit.
''We are taking a responsibile approach,'' Mr. Giuliani said, adding that spending cuts should be specific and not spread across the board.
On Tuesday, Mayor Edward I. Koch is expected to outline his plan to reduce the deficit in this year's budget. City officials now estimate that the gap will exceed $500 million.
Paul Dickstein, the city's budget director, would not say disclose yesterday how the city expects to close the budget gap, but he said spending cuts would be ''considerably more'' than the $75 million originally predicted.
 
Bigger Deficit Next Year
Mr. Koch, who entered office in 1978 on the heels of the city's fiscal crisis, has repeatedly pledged to leave office with a balanced budget. But even if this year's budget is balanced, fiscal experts are predicting a larger deficit next year, based on a decline in revenue and an increase in costs, tied in large part to pending settlements with municipal unions.
Mr. Dinkins stressed that the Police Department would not be affected by any budget cuts in his administration. ''What we don't cut is cops,'' he told Gabe Pressman of WNBC, ''because if we cannot be safe and secure in our persons, in our homes, in our parks, in nighttime as well as the daytime, the rest of this will matter little.''
Later, however, he said budget constraints could delay the hiring of police officers from the Police Academy's next two graduating classes, in January and next June. During the Democratic primary campaign, Mr. Dinkins criticized Mr. Koch for similar delays, saying the postponements had created the illusion of an expanded, or ''phantom,'' police force.
Such delays in hiring are ''to be avoided, if at all possible,'' Mr. Dinkins said yesterday.
 
'From His Own Experience'
Because state and Federal law determines much of the city's budget and sets the level of more than half the work force, not all city services would be affected by an across-the-board squeeze, Mr. Dinkins noted yesterday. And the amount saved by a 1 percent cut would depend on where it fell in the budget cycle, one of his advisers said.
The campaign aide, Barbara Turk, said the idea of a 1 percent across-the-board cut had come up in recent staff meetings but had not been recommended by the campaign's Council of Economic Advisers, which is led by Felix G. Rohatyn, the financier and head of the Municipal Assistance Corporation.
Mr. Dinkins ''got this from his own experience as Borough President,'' Ms. Turk said.
Mr. Dickstein said yesterday that the Koch administration has never made an across-the-board budget cut, although it has asked agencies to determine what effect a percentage cut would have on their programs. This was done last year as the budget was modified to match revenues, he said, but the final cuts were made on an agency-by-agency basis.
 
Makes Report Public
Mr. Dinkins, who was emerging from a week of intense scrutiny of his taxes and personal finances, yesterday released a report that the City Department of Investigation had done on him. The report was made after Mr. Dinkins, who was to become a deputy mayor, had withdrawn his name after revealing that he had failed to file city, state and Federal income taxes for four years.
The report, which Mr. Dinkins until now had refused to make public, was signed in September 1975 by Nicholas Scoppetta, the commissioner. Mr. Scoppetta said in a letter to Mayor Abraham D. Beame, ''This investigation has uncovered no evidence of a derogatory nature which would disqualify'' Mr. Dinkins from a city appointment.
Campaigning in Brooklyn yesterday, Mr. Dinkins called on Mr. Giuliani to reciprocate by releasing Federal background investigations of him, as well as his income-tax forms for the last 19 years. Asked if he suspected his opponent, a former United States Attorney in Manhattan, of financial wrongdoing, Mr. Dinkins said, ''I am far more careful with the reputations of people than some I know.''
On the campaign trail yesterday, the issue of Mr. Dinkins's transfer of 588 shares of stock in the Inner City Broadcasting Corporation to his son in 1986 seemed to be fading. Mr. Giuliani stopped hammering at the differences between the stock's $58,000 sale price and the $1 million value Mr. Dinkins put on it in 1983. Asked about the matter on WNBC yesterday, Mr. Dinkins said that in 1983 he was listing its ''market value,'' whereas on other city disclosure forms, he was asked to give ''the estimated cost at time of receipt.''

HEADLINE: War on Cocaine in Peru Is Sputtering

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Oct. 22

 BODY:
In this country where 65 percent of the world's coca crop is grown, the United States and the Government are waging a tiny anti-drug campaign with a handful of men and helicopters.
Each day, unless it rains, 20 to 40 Peruvian policemen and three or four agents from the United States Drug Enforcement Administration fly into the jungle in American-piloted helicopters in search of simple field laboratories and dirt airstrips.
Of the scores of laboratories and dozens of airfields believed to be scattered across the heart of the coca-producing region, the Americans and Peruvians have destroyed 19 laboratories and 12 airfields since beginning operations in early September, a few days after President Bush announced his campaign to fight illegal narcotics trafficking.
 
Little Effect on Big Industry
American and Peruvian officials acknowledge that their efforts so far have had little effect on an industry that yields up to $1.5 billion a year and directly supports up to 300,000 farmers and their families. 
''It's small,'' said a senior United States official. ''But it's coming along. I'm very optimistic of a lot of additional resources.''
President Bush said in September that $261 million would go for anti-narcotics programs in Peru, Colombia and Bolivia. None of the $73 million that has been designated as Peru's share has yet arrived. Last year, Peru received $10.5 million to fight drugs.
 
Fighting Growers and Guerrillas
For eight months before September, the United States and Peru had suspended anti-narcotics police operations and the forced eradication of coca crops because of violent resistance from the coca growers and leftist guerrillas. The eradication effort, which had been limited, has not been resumed. A senior American official estimated that Peru's crop of coca, from which cocaine is extracted, may expand by 20 percent this year, compared with 10 percent in previous years.
Peru's cocaine industry has been dealt at least a temporary blow, American and Peruvian officials say, by American-backed actions in Colombia in which the police and military have seized more than 350 drug smuggling planes and have been trying to capture the major international drug chiefs.
Shipments from Peru of semi-refined cocaine for final processing in Colombia have dropped by half, American and Peruvian officials estimate, and tons of semi-refined cocaine are piling up in jungle redoubts. As demand from Colombia has fallen, the officials say, the price for a kilogram of semi-refined cocaine, or base, as it is called, has plunged from $1,400 last August to about $600.
 
Prices in U.S. Remain Steady
''There's been a lot of disruption in Peru's cocaine production as a result of the pressure in Colombia,'' said a senior American official. ''The planes aren't flying and the decision makers are dispersed and moving around, making it harder to orchestrate these loads.''
United States officials in Washington and Miami say, however, that neither cocaine supplies nor prices in the United States have changed significantly since the Colombian President, Virgilio Barco Vargas, declared war on drug traffickers on Aug. 18; this is partly because of huge stockpiles in Latin America, the Caribbean and the United States.
When cocaine prices drop, American and Peruvian officials say, other crops like coffee and cacao become more attractive to farmers. But Peruvians and Americans who have been in the Upper Huallaga Valley, Peru's main cocaine-growing area, in the last few days say that farmers there seem to regard the current price decline as a temporary phenomenon and give no indication they plan to abandon their illicit crops.
 
Waning Support for Drug War
Both American and Peruvian officials worry that waning public support in Colombia may curtail anti-drug efforts there. Furthermore, law enforcement officials say they have evidence that new smuggling routes on roads, rivers and in the air are being established and they speculate that Colombia's traffickers may move their laboratories into northern Peru and parts of Brazil.
Colombia has been the main battlefield of the drug war as narcotics squads have retaliated for Government raids with bombings and assassinations. But no drug lords have been captured in Colombia and the Government has had few dramatic anti-drug operations in recent weeks, prompting a growing perception among Colombians that the battle is being lost and that negotiations should be considered.
American officials say that traffickers in Bolivia, which grows perhaps 25 percent of the world's coca, have their own refineries and shipping networks and have been little affected by the actions in Colombia.
 
Strapped for Money
Some American officials say it is unrealistic to expect more from Peru, where the economy declined by 20 percent last year and where cocaine production yields are estimated at equal to as much as half the country's annual legal exports of $3 billion.
''This country is in the middle of an economic crisis,'' an American official said. ''It doesn't have the resources.''

HEADLINE: Cleveland Mayoral Race Marked by a Bitter Feud

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, Oct. 20

 BODY:
A bitter feud between the old guard and a new generation of politicians is under way as Cleveland's most powerful black official campaigns for the Mayor's office against a onetime protege.
George L. Forbes, 58 years old, the longtime president of the Cleveland City Council, appears to be badly trailing Michael White, a 38-year-old state senator, in a campaign filled with name-calling and allegations of impropriety on both sides.
The Forbes camp has charged that Mr. White beat a former wife and is a ''slum landlord'' whose inner-city property violates housing codes. Mr. White has denied charges of wife abuse and has vowed to repair the violations at his property. At the same time he has accused Mr. Forbes of using his office for personal gain and of using his wife, Mary, as a ''front person'' for improper investments. Mr. Forbes has denied the charges. 
''It's a nasty race with plenty of publicity,'' said Robert Hughes, chairman of the Cuyahoga County Republican Party. ''It's been bang-crash-boom since the primary.''
 
Top Vote-Getters in Primary
The two men, the only two blacks in a field of five contenders in the primary, were the top vote-getters in the nonpartisan primary last month. Their victory assured that Cleveland would have its first black Mayor since Carl Stokes, the first black Mayor of any major American city, left office in 1971.
A poll by The Cleveland Plain Dealer of 802 registered voters showed Mr. White leading Mr. Forbes 46 percent to 27 percent with 28 percent undecided. Mr. White had support among a cross-section of voters, while Mr. Forbes, an often combative and blunt politician who has alienated many white voters in his 27 years on the council, showed little support beyond black voters.
Mr. White garnered 66 percent of the white vote in the poll as against 9 percent for Mr. Forbes. Among blacks, the two men were almost tied with Mr. Forbes getting 26 percent and Mr. White 25 percent. The poll was taken Oct. 16-19 and had a margin of error of 3.5 percentage points.
The campaign is being seen as a referendum on Mr. Forbes's 17 years as president of the Council, a time during which the city has gone from bankruptcy while Dennis Kucinich was Mayor in the 1970's to economic revival under Mayor George V. Voinovich, a longtime friend and frequent ally of Mr. Forbes.
In some ways, the economic successes of the Voinovich years appear to be working against Mr. Forbes, whom Mr. White and other critics are seeking to portray as an elitist who has been quick to give tax breaks to developers while ignoring the neighborhoods. The Forbes campaign has the backing of several major developers who are hosting a $3,000-a-table fund-raising event for him on Monday.
 
Alliances With the Wealthy
The topic of Mr. Forbes's alliances with the wealthy came up repeatedly during a debate this week between the two men, in which Mr. Forbes was berated by citizens for sitting in the owner's box instead of in the stands at a recent Cleveland Indians game. He was also assailed for statements attributed to him in local newspapers in which he reportedly told developers, ''There's no advantage to being around poor people.''
Mr. Forbes denied the allegations. ''I never said that ridiculous statement. It's insane and ridiculous,'' he said. The Forbes campaign received a blow late this week when Mayor Voinovich said he would not endorse a candidate for Mayor. Mr. Forbes, who has opposed fellow Democrats in the past to support the Republican Mr. Voinovich, had hoped that an endorsement from Mr. Voinovich would improve his standing among white voters.
Many whites have felt antagonized by Mr. Forbes over the years with his bluntness and frequent use of racial epithets. Television broadcasts must regularly censor expletives from his interviews. Not all of the ire is aimed at whites.
Mr. Forbes's displays once provoked former Mayor Stokes to call him a ''foul-mouthed, uncouth, unregenerated politician of the most despicable sort.'' Two years ago, Mr. Forbes threw a chair at a black City Council member and called him a ''mulatto punk.'' That same year, during a Council committee hearing, he asked a pregnant woman who was testifying there, ''Are you knocked up again?''
Mr. Forbes made no apologies for the chair incident and has said the latter incident was taken out of context.
The Forbes camp has tried to downplay the episodes and create uncertainty about his opponent. ''We all know too well about the outbursts,'' said Tuan Bustamante, Mr. Forbes's campaign manager. ''But his opponent is an unknown quantity. He has not faced the scrutiny that George has been under. People see George mad for five seconds of television and don't know he's been there for four hours. They see it totally out of context.'' He dismisses this behavior as a way of getting his point across. ''It's like when Mike Tyson or Muhammad Ali go into the ring,'' he told The Plain Dealer. ''It's all show-biz. The purpose is to get the job done and make sure the city comes out ahead. Most of the things I do I think out. I'm not as crazy as people think.''
In recent days, he has been running advertisements with his young grandson to show another side of his personality, but some analysts say it may be too late. ''I don't think you can soften a 17-year image in two weeks,'' Mr. Hughes said.
Meanwhile, Mr. White, capitalizing on white hostility toward Mr. Forbes, has been portraying himself as a unifier of the city's disparate communities, comparing himself to Mayor Curt Schmoke of Baltimore and other black mayors who have had wide crossover appeal. He has spoken out in favor of a key concern of white voters, the ending of forced busing in Cleveland, and has promised a city ''free of division, free of hatred, free of bickering, one Cleveland for blacks, whites and Hispanics.''
White voters are being seen as pivotal in the race in a city where there are nearly as many black voters as white and where the black vote is almost evenly split between the two men.
''This race will be decided by the white voters,'' Mr. Stokes said. ''Mike White has to walk that line of appealing to white voters while keeping blacks on his side. And George has to walk that line to keep that nominally irate white citizen from purposely going to the polls to vote against him.''

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Crowe v. Abrams: A Private Feud Over Handling Panama Becomes Public

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22

 BODY:
The feud pits a true believer against a four-star admiral; a six-shooter against a 16-inch gun on a battleship.
Neither Elliott Abrams, the onetime Assistant Secretary of State who shaped the Reagan Administration's Panama policy, nor Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., the Chairman of the Joints Chiefs of Staff, who fought to keep American troops from fighting in Panama, still holds his Government post.
But both have an abundance of ill will left over from the days when they vied for control of American policy. Now their animosities have been played out in public, complete with name-calling and jousting in the Op-Ed pages of The New York Times and The Washington Post. 
It is a display that tells a lot about the two men, but perhaps it tells even more about the state of the art of feuding in Washington in the ideological 80's.
 
Gauntlet Thrown and Picked Up
''I was aware for a long time that Abrams was bad-mouthing me under the table all over town, saying, 'Isn't it sort of weird that the J.C.S. are wimps,' and things like that,'' Admiral Crowe said in an interview in a small office he keeps at the Pentagon in retirement. ''I was getting a little bit tired of Elliott. Now that I'm free to talk, I felt I should throw down the gauntlet.''
Mr. Abrams was only too willing to take it up. ''The chairman's position consists of distortions, name-calling and leaks,'' he said in a telephone interview from Sao Paolo, Brazil, where he was representing a client as a private lawyer. ''Basically the position of the J.C.S. was: 'Count us out. Maybe the State Department, the C.I.A. or the Treasury can do something, but don't look at us. Period.' ''
Bare-knuckled battles of words are rare in a town where Government officials generally curse their political foes in closed-door meetings or off-the-record remarks to think tank audiences. Public discussions of who-said-what in policy meetings would violate convention and secrecy rules and probably get the offenders thrown out of their jobs.
 
Doubts on a Reagan Policy
But this month's failed coup in Panama brought more than stinging recriminations about President Bush's handling of the crisis. It also cast doubt on the wisdom of the Reagan policy that pushed Washington into a diplomatic cul-de-sac in Panama, raising questions about the use of military intervention to force change in another country's leadership.
The heart of the debate centers around whether, as Mr. Abrams argues, the admiral's refusal to use force in Panama was responsible for keeping Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in power, or, as Admiral Crowe believes, that policy goal was never worth risking the loss of American lives and the alienation of Latin governments.
In his Op-Ed articles in The Times and The Post this month, Mr. Abrams accused the admiral of delay, obfuscation, gross exaggeration of the military threat from Panama's Defense Forces, leaks of sensitive White House meetings and contempt for the civilians who disagreed with him.
In a verbal declaration of war published as a letter to the editor of The New York Times last week, the usually tranquil Admiral Crowe, who retired from the military three days before the Panama coup attempt, fought back. He called Mr. Abrams' proposals ''naiive in their formulation and reckless in their casual commitment of our military men and women.''
 
Battling Out of Character
Such recklessness, he continued, ''is not unknown among young appointees who have never served in uniform,'' adding, ''However, Mr. Abrams raised it to an art form.''
Analysts in and out of government were stunned that two high-profile people who held such influential postswould comment on such sensitive matters so personally.
''It's not in the nature of either of these guys to make personal attacks, but here they were, two players just out of the Government, and they grabbed the opportunity to make their points,'' said Abraham D. Sofaer, the State Department legal adviser for both the Reagan and Bush Administrations. ''And,'' he said as an afterthought, ''this is a town that, if you play dirty, you'll get it back.''
 
Fighters With Different Styles
Both Mr. Abrams and Admiral Crowe are fierce intellectuals who relish a good fight, but that's where the comparison stops.
Admiral Crowe is 64 years old, 6 feet tall, weighing nearly 200 pounds and is rumpled even in his formal uniform with the 33 medals and decorations. A Princeton Ph.D. in politics, he has never commanded a ship larger than a diesel submarine in 47 years of military service, though he has served in Vietnam, the Middle East, Western Europe and the Pacific.
His detractors say he is too political, too accommodating to the civilian leadership and reluctant to use force unless he can win. His pet peeve is lawyers.
 
A Master of the Diatribe
Mr. Abrams, 41, is well-spoken and well-tailored, a Harvard-educated conservative lawyer from New York who has never served in the military. A master of well-argued staccato diatribes, he was the most forceful defender of the Reagan doctine in Central America, calling himself a ''gladiator'' for the cause and advocating an American military invasion of Nicaragua following the assault on Grenada in 1983.
If Admiral Crowe lopes, Mr. Abrams swaggers.
But when Admiral Crowe read Mr. Abrams' article, he took off both his stars and his gloves. His first thought, he said in his Oklahoma twang, was, ''This snake's hard to kill.''
''I never took on Elliott publicly before,'' he said. ''I didn't think it was proper as Chairman, and I was never being hurt that much. But in the wake of recent events I felt we needed a little more sanity in the public dialogue.''
 
Spectrum of Possibilities
Admiral Crowe likes to tell stories of how, during war games, civilians are much quicker than military people to advocate the use of force. He said that when it came to Panama, he argued repeatedly at White House meetings that he didn't want to put American boys at risk unless Panamanians did the same.
He recalled attending a dinner party in Panama in which political opposition leaders told him, '' 'I'm not going to put my sons in the streets' -that didn't exactly grab me,'' he said.
In his defense, Mr. Abrams says, ''Nobody was proposing D-Day in Panama, but there was a broad spectrum of overt and covert possibilities that would have complied with all applicable laws, executive orders and regulations.''
The salvos offer a rare inside glimpse not only at the policymaking process but also of the Reagan Administration's dissonance on Panama policy, which echoes on today.
Admiral Crowe tried to delay imposing financial and economic sanctions in Panama, Mr. Abrams charged. Admiral Crowe replied that he never opposed sanctions; he only questioned whether they would achieve General Noriega's overthrow in a matter of weeks, as he said the State Department claimed.
 
When the Course Is Set
The State Department never claimed that economic sanctions would be enough to oust General Noriega, said Mr. Abrams, but Admiral Crowe remembers it differently. ''When people are arguing for their positions in the United States Government, it is quite common to make exaggerated statements,'' he said. ''Once your course is adopted, it doesn't matter whether you were right or wrong.''
In his most serious charge, Mr. Abrams said that Admiral Crowe's operation deliberately leaked and distorted sensitive proposals involving military action. Admiral Crowe acknowledged that ''military people do leak,'' but added: ''We consider an accusation coming from anywhere in State about leaking as sort of ridiculous. And Elliott was world class.''
Admiral Crowe does acknowledge that Mr. Abrams is not all wrong. The decision to conduct extensive military maneuvers and move troops as allowed by the Panama Canal treaties has politically embarrassed General Noriega and has not affected American servicemen. ''Elliott is correct that we didn't assert our treaty rights as vigorously as we are today, a move that has probably paid off,'' he said.
 
But the Bosses Decided It
Both men argue, accurately, that it was their bosses, not they, who made the ultimate decisions.
''Elliott gives me too much credit for making policy,'' said the admiral, a savvy political player who cut his teeth on Washington politics as an aide to President Dwight D. Eisenhower in the early 1950's. ''I sat at the table, but I felt a little bit like the back bencher. I wasn't the Secretary of Defense and I wasn't the President.''
Mr. Abrams said: ''It's really disingenuous to say, 'Well, shucks, the President decided.' The President decided after being poorly served by his Joint Chiefs, after a behavior pattern by them that narrowed his choices unfairly.''
In his own defense, Mr. Abrams said that it was Secretary of State George P. Shultz, not he, who made all the recommendations. Admiral Crowe agreed that it was Mr. Shultz who pushed the use-of-force policy line, but added, ''Everyone knew that Elliott was the architect of the policy.''
Both men say that their motive in going public with their differences was to set the record straight and to set the tone of the future policy debate on Panama. But it is doubtful the two men will have much to say to each other again.
''After Panama I don't wish to have a personal relationship with Admiral Crowe because he and his staff went beyond the bounds of the acceptable,'' Mr. Abrams said . The admiral, who often says he can get along with anybody, gets less personal. He says: ''I don't want to start a running gun battle with Elliott. This was sort of fun. People shouldn't make too much out of it.''

HEADLINE: Dangerous for Japan to Leave U.S. Security Fold;
The Real Struggle

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Rights and Wrongs of Blaming Japan'' (editorial, Oct. 16) is an improvement over earlier commentaries on the increasing strife between the United States and Japan. It properly points out that we have adequate laws to screen investments that endanger American economic leadership and control of our national economic destiny.
However, you do not mention that our trade laws are not vigorously enforced. The machinery in the Federal Government to deal with proposed sales of companies involved in strategic fields is not utilized. As a result, we continue to suffer from an erosion of our technological leadership. The gradual deterioration of our industries is fully recorded in your business section day by day. 
Your editorial is lacking in a long-range view of the U.S.-Japanese economic struggle and in a failure to note the distinctive qualities of the Japanese people and nation. Russell Braddon, the noted Australian historian, correctly points out in ''Japan Against the World, 1941-2041: The One Hundred Year War for Supremacy'' that ''ever since 1894 when they attacked Korea, occupied Seoul and sank China's navy, [the Japanese] have suffered an apparently insatiable thirst for inter national pre-eminence.''
This, I submit, is the real nature of the trade and investment struggle in which the United States is involved. Americans continue to think of Japan as a trade competitor rather than as a trade adversary with the objective of national pre-eminence, precisely as Japan did in the 1930's. Indeed, Mr. Braddon points out that Japanese officers and officials of more than a generation ago made it clear they were engaged in a war that would last 100 years.
Our problems can't be solved by trying to sell a little rice to the Japanese or by forcing them to modify their internal market. The United States must take unilateral steps to safeguard America's industries and technologies or it will become a second-class power in the world and Japan will truly gain the international pre-eminence it has sought throughout the century.
 
ANTHONY HARRIGAN
President, United States
Business and Industrial Council
 Washington, Oct. 17, 1989

LENGTH: 326 words

HEADLINE: Dangerous for Japan to Leave U.S. Security Fold

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Reassessing the United States- Japan relationship is a worthwhile, and increasingly necessary, undertaking given the enormous economic growth Japan has enjoyed since the end of World War II. However, the suggestions of Ronald A. Morse and Alan Tonelson (''Let Japan Be Japan,'' Op-Ed, Oct. 4) could be dangerously destabilizing for both Asia and the world.
The suggestion that a nuclear-armed Japan would act as a ''balance to Soviet power'' might be accurate in a strictly bilateral sense, but it is doubtful the People's Republic of China, the Republic of Korea or the countries of Southeast Asia would see it that way. Even without an aggressive military regime in Tokyo, any serious increase in Japanese defense capabilities that took place outside of a U.S.-Japan cooperative security effort would be a dangerously destabilizing development and would in all likelihood trigger a regional arms race. 
Also, Mr. Morse and Mr. Tonelson apparently overlook the fact that many influential voices in Japan do not wish to see their country cutting its economic and security moorings to the United States. They know all too well that such a ''divorce'' could place Japan in a most untenable strategic position.
Rather than freeing ourselves of this ''entangling alliance,'' we should work to further our cooperative efforts in scientific, industrial and military fields on an increasingly equal basis. An economically strong Japan does not require a severing of our mutual security commitments; indeed, it presents us with an even stronger rationale to reaffirm current cooperation and interdependence. Both countries would be far better off working to avoid choosing ''a more dangerous course'' than to be ''better positioned'' for its eventuality.
 
ROGER A. BROOKS
THOMAS J. TIMMONS
Washington, Oct. 5, 1989
 The writers are, respectively, director and research associate at the Heritage Foundation's Asian Studies Center.

HEADLINE: The Voices of Namibia

BYLINE: By Anthony Lake; Anthony Lake is professor of international relations at Mount Holyoke College.

DATELINE: SOUTH HADLEY, Mass.

 BODY:
In the black township of Katatura, over supper, I listen to a former organizer and current supporter of the South West African People's Organization, which led the fight against South African occupation of Namibia and is now, by all accounts, its largest political party. He tells of his detention and torture by the South Africans 11 years ago.
He still bears physical scars. I ask him for his feelings about his enemies. And I ask whether after the elections in early November to form a Constituent Assembly, it can produce a constitution for an independent Namibia? Will the necessary spirit of reconciliation be possible? 
''Yes,'' he says to my questions. ''It must be so, for the good of the nation. So many have died. We must get on with living.'' He knows where his torturers now are, but swears he does not hate them. When he encountered policemen who had arrested him, he offered his hand.
How can this be, I ask the guests. Can other Namibians put aside hatreds? ''I think so,'' a friend of his says. ''It is strange. I wonder what kind of people we are. Maybe it is because under the South Africans we had to learn to hold things in.'' Then she reconsiders: ''But maybe our people will let them out again. I don't know. Maybe there will be civil war.''
Her ambivalence about the future is represented by people encountered during a tour of the central and volatile northern regions by an independent American commission monitoring the election process. These Namibians, black and white, provide a mixture of bitterness and hope.
A group of former Swapo members, who had been held in camps in Angola on dubious charges of spying, tell us of life in underground cells and tortures they have endured.
A member of the U.N. Transition Assistance Group recounts the inspiring enthusiasm of the Namibians who registered to vote, and almost all of those eligible did so. The 104-year-old woman who made it through the line. The man who was so proud, he joined every line he saw, registering four times before the computer could catch up with him.
A church worker describes his voter education work in the villages: ''For most of the people, this will be the first time they have held pen in hand. The 'X' they make on the paper will not only be the right they have suffered for. It will be the first letter they will make, the beginning of learning to write.''
In Ovamboland, where Swapo and South African forces fought most bitterly, a U.N. official describes two weeks of violence. The official suggests that it may have been a mistake to demobilize the infamous Koevoet counterinsurgency force (recruited and trained by the South Africans), rather than strictly confining it to base. The ex-fighters have gone on an angry rampage in Oshakati against Swapo supporters, using hand grenades, rifles and mortars.
An organizer for the Democratic Turnhalle Alliance, the party favored by South Africa and Swapo's main national rival, admits he has hired demobilized Koevoet members as party workers. But he knows their violence is hurting his party. And he doesn't seem sure of how to control it.
A Swapo organizer explains why, according to most observers, Swapo has been responsible for much less violence than its chief opponent: ''We have been instructed to be patient. They want to make us fight, so the South Africans will say we are not ready for independence.'' But if the attacks continue, he says, ''It will be hard for Swapo leaders to control the people.''
A U.N. police monitor is frustrated because he must stand by and merely observe while his counterparts in the South West African Police do little to prevent violence. Nor can he do much to correct the bias against Swapo that the police seem to show. He is worried by the large numbers of guns and grenades held by people of all political stripes.
A white police chief in the north expresses his fears in ominous terms: ''We know that if Swapo doesn't win, they will fight again. We have our plans for it.''
In Windhoek, a white civil rights lawyer continues to receive phoned death threats that refer to the assassination of his friend Anton Lubowski, a white member of Swapo.
At our hotel in Windhoek, we are accosted by a local German-speaking businessman, full of beer and anger. He accuses the U.N. and Americans of ruining the country. ''But we've got the guns,'' he says. His pugnacity becomes surrealistic: ''And Germany did not lose the war.'' We are grateful he does not physically resemble some of the hard types we observed on the plane into Windhoek: men who could have cleared the bar room in ''Star Wars'' with a single glance.
We hope that more typical than these and the white police officers we met was a white Democratic Turnhalle Alliance organizer in a quiet area of the country. ''I am hopeful about the future,'' he says. ''Reconciliation is very possible. But we will need help from the outside, economic help, to be truly independent. Please do not forget us.''
It is no wonder that the promise of democracy is threatened by violence and fear. People who have been shooting at each other for 23 years must learn to compete within the limits of a democratic process. In such circumstances, politics is war carried on by other means. In the process, the habits of peace must be crated. This is not easy.
Almost certainly, the election will be held and then certified as free and fair by the U.N. But the current violence works against future reconciliation and increases the chance of postelection hostilities.
The stakes are large, not only for the possibility of peace in Angola but for South Africa. A white South African temporarily working in Namibia, a supporter of the South African Government, is carefully watching what majority rule will bring. ''If it works in Namibia,'' he says, ''it will work very well in South Africa.''
An American working in Ovamboland hopes Washington understands the danger in the violence: ''The South Africans must get their Administrator General in Namibia to make the police act fairly and put an end to the violence. I hope our own Government is doing all it can to get the South Africans to act.''
Such action would serve the interests of South Africa, Angola, the U.S. and others. And, maybe more important, it would help my supper companions in Katatura find the peace and security they deserve.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 783 words

HEADLINE: Campaign Matters;
Crisis After Crisis Lying in Wait For Next Mayor

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
Two weeks from tomorrow, either David N. Dinkins or Rudolph W. Giuliani will be mayor-elect of New York City after spending about $10 million and about 10 months campaigning. It's a wonder that anyone would want the job. The city's 106th mayor will lead New York into the final decade of the millenium, an era which Mayor Edward I. Koch's Commission on the Year 2000 said last year would be characterized by ''New York Ascending.''
''I think we are still right to have a basically optimistic outlook,'' said Robert F. Wagner Jr., the commission chairman, ''but, probably our tone was more positive than it should have been.'' 
Consider just a few of the problems the next mayor will face, but which neither of the major party candidates seems to have adequately addressed:
* ''The biggest decision is going to be associated with how to close whatever budget gap there is,'' said Stanley Brezenoff, the First Deputy Mayor.
''We can only get these things started.
The next mayor will have to decide for himself.'' He faces a problematic economy and high expectations, a budget gap this year of upwards of $550 million and $900 million next year with little likelihood of much help from Albany, and labor negotiations that Mr. Brezenoff said could be more intense than at any time since the city's mid-1970's fiscal crisis.
* The city may be heading for another record year for violent crime - topping the 162,916 reports of murder, rape, robbery, and aggravated assault in 1988. Felony drug arrests in the first six months of this year were nearly 30 percent ahead of the comparable period last year. Jails are already filled beyond their legal capacity; the budget gap may jeopardize plans to hire all 2,000 police officers who were to be recruited this year to increase the force to 28,000.
* Estimates vary widely, but the number of heroin and cocaine abusers in the city may be in the hundreds of thousands and many who want treatment are said to be turned away. A municipal program to expand drug treatment is budgeted at only $32 million this year. But it would cost the city $171 million to treat 77,000 addicts by 1994.
* By the Board of Education's estimate, the dropout rate among public school students is 30 percent or more. The ascent of a new schools chancellor and a new mayor, said Mr. Wagner, the Board of Education president, represents an ideal time to lobby for legislative changes to make the system more effective. ''It's important not to squander the honeymoon,'' he said.
* The health-care system is under seige. It is plagued by an aging population, by patients with acquired immune deficiency syndrome, by overcrowded emergency rooms, and by inadequate centers outside hospitals for medical and psychiatric treatment. It is estimated that 200,000 New Yorkers are infected with the AIDS virus. Of the 22,000 who were diagnosed as having AIDS, about half have died, making this one of the deadliest epidemics in city history. Twice as many New Yorkers are now dying of AIDS each year than are murdered.
* One in four New Yorkers are classified as poor and the poorest sink deeper into poverty, the Human Resources Administration says. About a third of the 100,000 welfare cases represent the all but permanently poor. The average welfare recipient stays on relief for eight years. About 1,600 homeless families still live in 22 hotels; 9,500 individuals are in city shelters. About 450 babies a month are abandoned to hospitals, many the offspring of addicts, and 28,000 of their older brothers and sisters are likely to be in foster care this year. Meanwhile, a deadline looms to draft legislation to conform with new Federal welfare rules.
The next mayor will also have to help carry out a new City Charter and master its land-use processes, and decide how to develop the waterfront, dispose of garbage and control traffic.
But Stephen Berger, executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, warns that the city's ''generative cycle can be disrupted or reversed if we hesitate to attend to those issues now causing so much anxiety as New York's fast-paced decade draws to an exhausted close.
''If the city's institutions fail to shuck their encrusted shell,'' he said, ''if people continue to buy out of the social contract, if priority is not given to the fundamentally middle-class values of working New Yorkers of every economic standing, then the transnational corporations housed here will pull up stakes and head for more civil precincts. And countless New Yorkers who now fill their offices will relocate as well.''
New York may yet ascend, but the problems awaiting the next mayor promise that the battle will be uphill.

PUB-DATE: October 23, 1989

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1142 words

HEADLINE: New Jersey Rivals Differ On Growth and Ecology

SERIES: Courter and Florio On the Issues - First of three articles

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
Pursuing prosperity and protecting the state from its excesses are common goals of both candidates for governor, but their ideas of how to make New Jersey both economically strong and environmentally clean differ, sometimes substantially.
Representative Jim Courter of Hackettstown, the Republican candidate, believes that New Jersey has to look outside its boundaries for help in disposing of toxic wastes. But when it comes to attracting businesses, he says he would not worry about offending other states in his efforts to lure a corporation.
''I wouldn't be so concerned about alienating New York,'' Mr. Courter said. ''I'm going to advocate for this state, not New York.'' 
 
Poorly Thought Out
Representative James J. Florio, the Democrat, believes that New Jersey's efforts at environmental protection were poorly thought out, and he would put some plans, including those for solid waste incinerators, on hold. He said he would act aggressively to keep business growing, but not at the expense of the environment.
''We're not going to have a healthy pharmaceutical industry or a healthy chemical industry if we don't have clean water,'' Mr. Florio said.
The candidates presented their views in separate interviews with New York Times reporters last week.
Their positions on economic development and the environment have often been overshadowed by auto insurance, abortion and their personal attacks against each other. More often than not they have stressed what their opponent has done in the past, rather than what they, if elected, would do in the future.
Important issues like the new state development plan and the state's pressing need for more affordable housing, which Governor Thomas H. Kean said in 1987 was ''one of the great challenges New Jersey faces,'' have scarcely been mentioned.
The candidates have paid more attention to the environment but new initiatives have been few. Both place a high priority on cleaning the state's air and water.
Mr. Florio proposes creating the new position of environmental prosecutor, charged with pursuing polluters and enforcing existing regulations.
Mr. Courter's primary environmental goal is to split the current Department of Environmental Protection into two separate agencies, one to concentrate on pollution, the other to conserve the state's natural resources.
Mr. Courter said that saving farmland and open space is essential because if not, ''there will no longer be a New Jersey as we know it.''
Cleaning up past mistakes also is an urgent need, he said, but while it is possible for some clean-up efforts to be put off, fields and pastures that are sold and developed are lost forever.
 
Both Dislike Solid Waste Policy
Mr. Courter said he was uncomfortable making such statements because people might incorrectly assume that he was not concerned about pollution. ''Both are important,'' he said. Mr. Courter and Mr. Florio criticized the state's handling of the solid waste crisis. The 21 counties were handed most of the responsibility for taking care of their own garbage once landfills were closed.
Now most counties truck their garbage to other states, leading to substantially higher property tax bills. In addition, most plan to build their own incinerator to burn the garbage. So far one has been built, three are under construction and six others are being reviewed.
''It makes absolutely no sense,'' said Mr. Florio, referring to the possibility that 21 incinerators could be built. He said that if elected he would put an immediate halt to the issuance of incinerator construction permits, taking six months to study ways to increase recycling and regional cooperation.
 
Pay-As-You-Throw Plan
Mr. Courter said he too would try to get counties to share incinerators and reduce the supply of garbage through increased recycling and having households pay fees based on how much garbage they produce, rather than the current flat rate.
One of Governor Kean's thorniest environmental problems was what to do with 5,000 barrels of radon-contaminated soil dug from under houses in Montclair. Community after community in New Jersey rejected the barrels, and they sat piled around the abandoned houses for nearly two years before being shipped to Tennessee.
Mr. Florio said it was foolish to have dug up the dirt without having a place for it. ''The alternative of last resort is taking up the problem from somebody and giving it to somebody else,'' Mr. Florio said. He said he would encourage research into technologies for neutralizing toxic wastes.
Mr. Courter said that because New Jersey is so densely developed, it must rely on federally approved disposal sites in other states for disposing of hazardous materials.
 
Luring Out-of-State Companies
Mr. Courter also said he would not hesitate to look outside the state for corporate tenants to fill new office buildings. Mr. Florio said he would focus economic development efforts on improving the concerns that businesses consider before relocating: housing, traffic congestion and the overall quality of life.
These issues are being addressed by the State Planning Commission as it draws up New Jersey's first development master plan. Both candidates have said little about the plan except to support the general goal of regional coordination.
But farmers and real-estate investors fear the plan may drive down the value of their land. And some fear that because the plan tries to nudge development away from open countryside, urban residents may be pushed out.
Since 1983, when the Supreme Court of New Jersey reiterated the obligation of all communities to provide their fair share of low-cost housing, the issue of putting housing in the suburbs for people of modest means has persisted. And in 1987 state officials estimated that New Jersey needed to build some 145,000 affordable dwellings, most in suburban areas where jobs are located.
Since then about 9,000 have been built or are now under construction.
 
Housing Rarely Mentioned
Despite that shortage, housing has rarely been mentioned during the campaign. Mr. Courter and Mr. Florio both want to simplify regulations. They said that because of high suburban land values and political resistance the state probably cannot meet the Supreme Court's housing objectives, and therefore they both support agreements in which suburbs pay cities to have low-cost housing built there.
Some, including John M. Payne, associate dean of Rutgers Law School and president of the Alliance for Affordable Housing, a nonprofit organization, disagree with that stand.
''I don't know whose nose is growing now,'' said Mr. Payne, referring to television commercials in which both candidates are portrayed as Pinocchio. ''I don't know of any basis for anyone to conclude that a suburban affordable housing strategy does not work.''
