HEADLINE: Outdoors: A Reel of Diplomacy

BYLINE: By RICHARD LYONS

DATELINE: ANDORRA LA VELLA, ANDORRA

 BODY:
I WAS sitting in what passes for the Oval Office in this tiny principality high in the Pyrenees talking about fishing with several of Andorra's government officials when Prime Minister Josip Pintat walked into the office.
''Don't you dare say anything about fishing to the Prime Minister,'' demanded Roser Jordana de Madero, in her best Oxford-accented English.
I had come to this tiny mountain nation tucked between France and Spain to go fishing, having been here last year and seeing some of the trout. But I had to leave before I could try out a rod and reel. 
Now, a year later, I was back only to discover that the fishing season had closed for the year two weeks before my arrival. I kicked myself for not checking the dates more closely, but decided to confront the authorities.
So I appealed to Senora Jordana, who not only acts as Andorra's spokeswoman to the world as she is fluent in English, French, Spanish, Italian, German and her native Catalan, but also issues the fishing licenses.
I wanted special permission to fish, a permit she was reluctant to grant since one had never been issued before, ever. She realized I was going to appeal to the Prime Minister in the course of an interview about local economics, and considered it a waste of his valuable time; she quickly offered a deal.
''I'll speak to the Minister of Agriculture and if he approves I'll grant you a license to fish for one day that will permit you to catch one fish, only one,'' she said.
I agreed. The Minister agreed. So after the interview we both went to Senora Jordana's office so she could write the license.
''What is your nationality,'' she asked. ''I'm American; you know that,'' I said.
''Yes, but you have to be French, Spanish, English or German,'' she said. ''The application says so. For the day let's just say you're a Frenchman, you don't really have to speak French to the French.''
I agreed to be a Frenchman for a day.
''What is your marital status?'' she asked.
''Why is that needed for a special fishing license?'' I retorted. ''In Andorra, a Catholic country, I would be considered married but in the United States I am considered to be divorced. Besides, I want a fishing license, not a marriage license.''
The diminutive Senora Jordana shot me a piercing look and said: ''O.K., for the record let's say you're single. License approved. We'll skip the requirements for triplicate photographs and wave the license fee of 2,000 pesetas in the interest of Andorran-American friendship.''
She handed me two official looking documents containing sealed stamps and pointed me on the road to Llac, whose real name is Engolaster, a favorite among the 60 lakes in Andorra that are stocked with fish.
The view of the mountains and valleys was almost enough to take my breath away, and at an altitude of 5,360 feet, it almost did.
I drove several miles up a mountain until the road ended, then made it on foot for half an hour to a woodcutter's bunkhouse maintained by the local hydroelectric power authority.
I immediately flashed my special pass to the chief woodcutter, Senor Francisco, who regarded it with some suspicion until phone calls were made to the authorities.
I then ingratiated myself with Senora Francisco by giving vivid descriptions of my love for ''Los Trutas,'' views she said she shared, and proved her point by launching into a long fishing story spoken in Catalan while I nodded enthusiastically.
Eventually, sensing that I was simpatico about fishing, she loaned me an old rod with a Mitchell reel, some spinning lures and a plastic bucket for the fish. Then I headed for the lake, a 20-minute walk through the woods.
Half a dozen casts and I had the hang of it. I thought.
''Parlez vous Francais?'' a voice said behind me. Answering yes, the speaker who appeared to be out for a walk, said the tip of my rod was too high, and left, shaking his head.
''Habla usted el espanol?'' a voice said behind me. Again answering yes to yet another nature hiker, he said the tip of my rod was too low, and left, muttering.
A few minutes later, Jordi Bartumeu, the engineer in charge of the hydroelectric project, stopped by. His second job is game warden. He demonstrated a few tricks with the rod, pointed out the spots where the fish usually were thickest and mercifully left. I was a duffer and he knew it.
But suddenly, five minutes later, I got a bite, a proper bite, a fish that jumped and thrashed and leaped and fought. I pulled and tugged and reeled and prayed that the 2-pound test line would hold, and with a mighty heave threw the fish over my head onto the bank.
''Do you speak English?'' said a voice behind me. I was too euphoric to speak, so he continued, ''Rainbow trout, a beauty, used to catch them all the time in Kenya.''
I flopped on the bank alongside my fish and Major John King, East African Rifles Retired, or something like that, started telling me fishing stories from the bush, from India, from Western Australia. The sun never sets on fishing in the Empire, that sort of stuff.
I begged leave as gracefully as I could, returned the gear to Senora Francisco, gave her 200 pesetas over her violent protests, walked back to my car, returned to Andorra la Vella, and invited the disbelieving Senora Jordana to lunch at the best restaurant in the city.
Chef Claude Marty was ecstatic. ''Beautiful fish, at least a kilo; I'll cook it with a little butter and lemon,'' he said.
Chef Claude's estimate of the weight was a bit overdone, but not his preparation of the trout, and other diners around us at lunch eyed the platter greedily when it was set before me, wondering where I had gotten it. Trout had not been on the menu here in two weeks and they are a favorite dish in Andorra.
Senora Jordana gave me the ''don't you dare say one word'' sort of look, squelching my would-be braggadocio over the fish, and thus also saving herself endless explanations of why a foreigner could fish out of season when an Andorran couldn't.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
 
Military contractors are turning abroad for parts to build weapons systems, as the Pentagon puts pressure on companies to reduce costs and as foreign suppliers become more adept. The trend is raising fears on dependence, jobs and profits. [Page A1.] 
 
A plan to phase out many American farm programs if other countries agree to similar cutbacks will be put forward this week by the Bush Administration. But there is much skepticism about the prospects for the plan. [D9.]
 
El Salvador's Government has begun an audacious program intended to rebuild a battered economy and alleviate the social injustice, unemployment and stagnation from which leftist insurgents have historically drawn their strength. [D14.]
 
Chile is creating an autonomous central bank that the Government says will help preserve the nation's hard-won economic stability, growth and modernization. [D14.]
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Steel shipments are falling, reflecting a slowdown in the automobile and construction industries. Several analysts predict that total shipments in the second half of the year will be as much as 15 percent below 1988 levels. [D1.]
 
Saving the world from global warming may require sharp reductions in burning fuel, but there was no consensus at a two-day meeting of 40 nuclear industry executives, government officials, energy experts and environmentalists on whether new nuclear reactors are needed. [D1.]
 
COMPANIES
 
I.B.M.'s control of the mainframe market is being threatened by far-reaching changes in the industry. Digital Equipment and Tandem are both planning to challenge I.B.M. in its most successful computer market. [D1.]
 
UAL's board is to meet today to consider its options, under pressure to respond to the plunge in the company's stock. [D1.]
 
R. H. Macy has agreed to make all of its private-label merchandise available to Kintetsu Department Stores of Japan. The one-year contract gives Macy an additional outlet for its large production capacity in East Asia. [D2.]
 
Campeau is again facing cutbacks in merchandise shipments as some suppliers to its Federated and Allied department stores have found their trade credit curtailed or canceled. [D2.]
 
THE MEDIA BUSINESS
 
McGraw-Hill is willing to customize college textbooks to suit the needs of individual professors, or even individual students, and it says it can make the changes in 48 hours. [D1.]
 
Eveready has turned to a marauding rabbit in an advertising campaign intended to startle viewers into paying attention. [D11.]
 
China Books and Periodicals has closed its bookstores in New York and San Francisco and will close its Chicago store on Dec. 1, but it is expanding its other book businesses. [D11.]
 
Magazine publishers are turning away from premiums as part of their campaigns to build circulation. Magazines. [D11.]
 
Holly Farms has dropped Dinah Shore as a spokeswoman and turned to a fast-paced television campaign that puts the focus on health concerns. Advertising. [D12.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
 
Maryland has an innovative plan to try to resolve the thousands of asbestos cases that have swamped court dockets in the state. Stephen Labaton: Business and the Law. [D2.]
 
What did not happen in the stock market last week may be more important than what did. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D8.]
 
Credit market participants are expected to return to their study of economic data and put the stock market's plunge behind them. Credit Markets. [D9.]

HEADLINE: Shipments Of Steel Declining

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Reflecting a slowdown in the automobile and construction industries, steel shipments are below their year-ago level. Several analysts predict that total shipments in the second half of the year will be down as much as 15 percent from the comparable period of 1988.
As a result, total steel industry earnings, which have increased steadily over the last three years, will begin to fall this year, analysts say. They also predict intensifying competition among steel producers and possibly some price cutting. 
 
Drop in Shipments Expected
Several analysts estimate that industry shipments, which were about 84 million tons last year, will fall to about 81 million tons this year and to 75 million tons in 1990. The predictions take into account a drop in business from automobile makers, as well as makers of appliances, machinery and construction materials.
''Things won't get much better in the coming months, either,'' said John Jacobson, an economist with the AUS Group in Philadelphia. ''Profits and shipments are likely to be at their their lowest point in the last few years.''
Already, steel prices have fallen to their lowest point in more than two years, and operating rates for the nation's steel mills have tumbled to an average of 80 percent in the third quarter, from nearly 90 percent a year earlier.
Still, analysts say the effect on steel companies, which will report earnings later this month, will be less severe than in previous periods of declining shipments. For one thing, they say, steel companies are leaner and have lowered their break-even levels.
''Steel companies should still be profitable next year,'' said Christopher Plummer, an analyst with the WEFA Group, an economic forecasting firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. ''With the improvements that have come in efficiency over the last few years, operating profits should still be fairly good.''
Mr. Plummer further explained that the decline in steel shipments and orders was ''a natural part of the industry's cycle,'' adding that ''after a 24-month boom period, you can expect market conditions to alter somewhat.''
Steel industry executives said the decline in shipments was generally in line with their expectations of market conditions this year. Many said they had altered their production and employment levels in anticipation of those conditions.
''We've been in a cost-cutting mode for a number of years,'' said Gary Millenbruch, senior vice president and chief financial officer of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's third-largest steel producer. ''We have already been under the strategy of divesting our underperforming assets and modernizing our facilities.''
Steel shipments were down to about 19 million tons in the third quarter from 20.3 million tons in the quarter last year, Mr. Plummer said. That compares with an average of 22 million tons in the preceding two quarters, which were down slightly from the 1988 period.
Some steel industry executives discount the premise that price competition will result from the downturn in industry shipments and prices. They contend that they learned their lesson after the wrenching industrywide recession of the early 1980's, which left steel companies discounting prices in a desperate attempt to cling to market share.
''No one wants a return to those days,'' said a marketing executive at a large steel company who asked to remain anonymous. ''I think that the major steel companies have seen what can happen when you begin to have intensified price competition. No one wants that to happen again.'' As evidence of the industry's resolve to avoid such a scenario, executives point to the period after the six-month labor dispute at the USX Corporation that began in the summer of 1986. When the shutdown ended, steel prices, defying analysts' predictions, remained firm.
Nonetheless some operators of steel service centers - the industry intermediaries who cut and shape steel to customers' specifications -say that they have begun to see evidence of price competition.
While most steel companies will report their earnings within the next two weeks, Inland Steel Industries, which operates the nation's fourth-largest steel company, last week said that its third-quarter earnings plunged 70 percent from the year-earlier period.
''The short-term business outlook is clouded by uncertainties in the economy and financial markets,'' said Inland's chairman, Frank Luerssen. ''The modest downturn of economic growth that began in the third quarter is reflected in some continued softness in our steel and service center markets.''

HEADLINE: Market Place;
When the Panic Failed to Happen

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
THE stock market news of last week, as in a famous Sherlock Holmes story where the key clue was that a dog failed to bark, may be more in what did not happen than in what did.
What did not happen was a panic, either by institutional investors who had leaped to get out late in the day the previous Friday or by anxious individual investors, a breed often spoken of on Wall Street as if they were far too naive and innocent to be exposed to the fact that, as J. P. Morgan once said, prices will fluctuate.
''As frightened as everybody appeared to be, you would have thought the scare would keep them away from the market,'' said Robert Farrell, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch. Instead, retail customers of that firm were net buyers every day last week, and United States and foreign institutions joined in the buying. Mutual funds reported cash came in for equity funds. 
Early in the week, it was a blue-chip rally only. But by Thursday the party had spread throughout the market. On that day 1,235 issues went up in price on the New York Stock Exchange, the most for any day since June 8, 1988.
In short, investors showed a willingness to believe that the 6.9 percent plunge of Friday the 13th was no more real than the 22.6 percent drop of Oct. 19, 1987, when the Dow Jones industrial average went down an unprecedented 508 points.
The 1987 crash did not presage a recession, let alone a Great Depression, and anyone who worked up the nerve to buy that day profited handsomely. That is a lesson that seems to have been well learned by both individual and instituional investors. As such, what may be happening is that investors are gradually accepting that even sharp market setbacks are nothing but buying opportunities and always will be.
That attitude is not unprecedented. The late 1920's were filled with sharp and quick setbacks for the market, but the fear factor gradually subsided. The culmination of that attitude came in the first week of December 1928, when the Dow dived 11.5 percent in a single week. It was the worst week for the average in 13 years, and was front-page news. In an era when stocks could be bought for 10 percent down, with the rest on a margin loan, such a fall was distressing indeed.
But judging from statistics on margin loans, public investors were not sent into panic selling. Instead, they came up with money to meet their margin calls, confident that a runway bull market would soon be back on track. And they were right. All the week's loss, and more, was made up within the next three weeks, and by the end of that month, the Dow was soon comfortably back setting new records.
In 1929, there were several sharp breaks, each a false warning. Then came the big one, in October, and those who assumed that it would be like all the rest were very wrong.
A quick market recovery certainly does not mean this is 1929 again. But it is interesting, and perhaps a sign of overconfidence, that traders were so quickly willing to believe that the quick 190-point fall said nothing about the economy and everything about the market itself. Those seeking reasons for the plunge focused first on an investor group's inability to finance a leveraged buyout of the UAL Corporation, and on what that said about the ability of future takeovers to be completed. But after that, the talk turned to imperfections in market structure that allow a market to fall 190 points on one day, and then regain almost 120 points over the following week, all without much in the way of fundamental economic news.
Had the decline continued, the program traders would no doubt have been blamed. They were largely forgotten as the market rose, but it is clear that much trading on Monday and Tuesday, in particular, was futures related. And one reason given for the rise on Thursday was forecasts that the expiration of October stock index options and futures on Friday would create a surge of buying. It did, but the increase Friday was a narrow one. The international economic situation got little attention in all the market talk, and it was virtually overlooked that important foreign markets had been sliding for a couple of weeks as central banks pushed up interest rates and brought on recession fears. There was no mention of the fact that fewer United States companies raised dividends in September than in any month in the past three years.
In the Holmes story ''Silver Blaze'' the lack of barking showed the dog thought all was normal when it was not. Last week's market action shows that investors now think plunges are normal and view them as opportunities for profit, not warnings of significant problems in the economy.
In the end, stock prices must be related to the state of the economy and to the outlook for the businesses the shareholders own. Index futures, program trading, circuit breakers and all the other paraphernalia of the 1980's may create volatility and opportunities, but they cannot change that fact. If it is forgotten by the time this bull market ends, it may make the eventual fall that much more surprising, and painful.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Offer Plan to Curb Farm Support

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22

 BODY:
The United States will put forward in Geneva this week a plan to phase out many American farm programs if other countries agree to similar cutbacks. The offer is part of negotiations to end trade distortion in agriculture by the next century.
The strength of farm lobbies here and in Europe has created some skepticism about the plan, which will be introduced this week by Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter and the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills.
Officials from the European Community, which has 8 percent of its population on farms, compared with 3 percent in the United States, say it is unrealistic to expect governments to end support for farmers. 
 
'We Should Do It Also'
And the chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, E. (Kika) de la Garza, Democrat of Texas, commented, ''I'm not going to be too terribly upset about what they're talking about now, because I just don't think it's going to get done.''
Mr. de la Garza said there was still ''basic agreement that we should try to ease out of major trade-distorting activities,'' adding, ''If other countries do it, then we should do it also.''
Among the American programs most affected would be those for dairy products and sugar, where price supports are set well above market levels, leading to overproduction, Administration officials said.
The plan, a high-priority undertaking several years in formulation under both the Bush and Reagan Administrations, calls on governments to stop making payments to farmers eventually, except in cases where the money would not distort either production or trade.
 
Uneasy About Proposals
Other American lawmakers were uneasy about the proposals. Senator Max S. Baucus, Democrat of Montana and chairman of a Senate trade subcommittee, said the ideas ''seem to be as much aimed at eliminating portions of the U.S. farm program that they oppose as at opening foreign markets. ''
For this round of trade talks, Washington has changed strategy. Most obstacles take the shape of quotas, variable levies and government licensing systems. These would be converted into tariffs, which are generally considered the barrier that least distorts trade. The tariffs would then be negotiated down in stages.
The proposals, which are being made at the start of a new phase of the three-year-old global trade talks known as the Uruguay Round, also call for eliminating market access barriers in farm products over 10 years and dismantling export subsidies over 5 years.
Administration officials briefed Congressional staff members and farm associations on the plan last week and expect to present it formally on Wednesday at a Geneva meeting of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, the 97-nation trade agency that is sponsoring the international negotiations.
 
European Criticism Seen
Although many nations have already agreed that the Uruguay Round should achieve ''substantial and progressive'' reduction of trade-distorting agricultural programs, the Administration's plan is likely to run into criticism in Europe, which seeks a slower pace of change.
Washington has been sharply critical of the community's agriculture policies, which use variable levies that curb imports and high price supports that stimulate production. Export subsidies then unload the excess production on world markets, depressing world prices.
But the United States, chiefly in dairy products and sugar, and Japan, chiefly in rice, also maintain tough barriers to market access.
A community official declined to comment on the American proposals ''until they could be studied'' but added that the 12-nation bloc was preparing its own ''comprehensive approach'' on the farm talks to be offered in about a month. Japanese officials also declined to comment.
 
U.S. Efficiency Seen
The Administration contends that the United States is the world's most efficient producer and that if trade-distorting policies are eliminated, American farmers will win back huge shares of the global market.
Elimination of the European Community's Common Agricultural Policy would result, for example, in a $7 billion improvement in the American trade balance, the office of the United States trade representative calculated in a report this year.
Another rationale is the need for budget savings. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development placed the cost of agricultural support in the United States in 1988 at $73.8 billion, compared with $119.4 billion in the European Community.
 
Tariff Safeguards
Although the proposals envisage phasing out domestic farm programs that distort trade, they also call for safeguards that would allow reimposing tariff protection in case surges in imports injure local producers.
To prevent health and safety rules from being used as trade barriers, the United States calls for every country to adopt parallel standards.
To get serious talks under way, the American paper calls on trading partners to identify policies that most distort trade and then suggests how they should be phased out.
''There's room for negotiation,'' an Administration official stressed. ''We're not going to do this unilaterally. We'll only go as far as anyone else does and no further.''
 
Quotas for Australia
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (Reuters) - Australia has accepted new steel quotas on shipments to the United States and will back a new American farm trade proposal, its trade negotiations minister said on Friday.
The new quotas will allow big increases in exports during the next two and a half years and will follow an accord that recently ended, said the minister, Michael Duffy, after meeting with the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, and Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter.
New quotas were reached earlier with the European Community and some smaller producers, United States trade officials said.
Mr. Duffy also said he backed the farm trade proposal that Mrs. Hills will present next week.
He said the proposal called for curbs on commodity export subsidies and domestic farm supports and an end to limits on agricultural imports.

HEADLINE: Treasury Selling $10 Billion in 2-Year Bills

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of issues this week is active, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and continuing with an auction of $10 billion in two-year bills tomorrow.
On Wednesday $4.5 billion in 30-year bonds will be offered by the Resolution Funding Corporation, established by Congress last summer to finance the rescue of some of the nation's failing savings and loan institutions. The sale is expected to become a quarterly event until the corporation's $50 billion borrowing limit is reached. 
Late Friday, the outstanding three-month bill was bid at 7.57 percent, while the six-month bill was bid at 7.56 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 7.90 percent, while Resolution Funding bonds were yielding 8.23 percent.
Government agency offerings this week include a $2.45 billion financing by the Farm Credit System Banks. Interest rates for the three-part consolidated systemwide bond issue will be announced on Wednesday.
The following new fixed-income issues are scheduled this week:
 
TAXABLE
 
THURSDAY
 
Appalachian Power Co., Roanoke, Va., $50 million in first-mortgage bonds, due in 2019, A-/A-2/A-. Competitive.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Chile Plans to Create Strong Central Bank

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 22

 BODY:
As it prepares to turn over power to elected civilians, the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet is creating an autonomous central bank that it says will help preserve Chile's hard-won economic stability, growth and modernization.
Under a law to take effect Dec. 11, three days before presidential elections, a five-member independent council will be created to run the bank. It will direct monetary and exchange-rate policies and regulate the financial system.
The move is opposed by economic advisers to Patricio Aylwin, the Christian Democratic Party leader who is favored to win the presidency. They say the new central bank will be too powerful, going beyond the United States Federal Reserve and the West German Bundesbank. 
''It's one of various indications that this Government, while planning to hand over the Government, is trying to hand over as little power as possible,'' said Jose Pablo Arellano, executive director of Cieplan, an economic research organization that is expected to dominate economic policy in an Aylwin government.
 
Underlying Motives
But Alfonso Serrano, vice president of the current central bank, said critics of the plan do not really want an autonomous bank but want to be free to use monetary and fiscal policy in political ways.
''Everybody - the opposition and the Government - agrees on the need to maintain our macroeconomic equilibria,'' Mr. Serrano said. ''But something in the political process in Latin America has always made that difficult to do. Having an institution on the margin of the political situation would help guarantee stability.''
By creating an autonomous central bank, Chile is treading on new ground for a Latin American country. In neighboring Argentina, the new Government of President Carlos Saul Menem has committed itself to creating an independent central bank.
Mr. Serrano, one of a four-member panel that drafted the Chilean law, said the regulations studied as models were mainly those of the Federal Reserve and the Bundesbank.
 
Sense of Well-Being
''I don't think there is anyone in Chile who doesn't remember the sense of well-being in 1971, the first year of the government of Salvador Allende, with the relatively low inflation and high incomes,'' he said. ''But an autonomous central bank would have seen that the expansion of spending would bring problems.''
By the time Mr. Allende was overthrown by the armed forces in 1973, the fiscal deficit was running 25 percent of gross national product, Mr. Serrano said. Inflation was running at an annual rate of about 1,000 percent.
The Pinochet Government reversed the nationalization and property confiscations and set out to build a free-market economy. Foreign banks laden with petrodollars poured loans into Chile until the foreign debt crisis, which hit the country in 1982-83 simultaneously with the collapse in copper prices.
After a painful depression like that of the 1930's in the United States, Chile began to rebuild its economy around diversified exports, especially fruit, forestry and sea products, and a low exchange rate for the peso relative to hard currencies. The result has been five years of strong economic performance, topped by growth that ran 10 percent on an annual basis for the first half of this year.
 
Inheriting a Surplus
The new Government is expected to inherit a fiscal surplus, healthy reserves, and a well-managed foreign-debt situation. Hernan Buchi, who was finance minister until he resigned in March and began a campaign to try to overtake Mr. Aylwin in the presidential race, is given much of the credit for the success.
Mr. Arellano said he and others on the Aylwin team agree with the departing Government on the need to maintain economic balance and intend to do so, if Mr. Aylwin is elected. But he argued that creation of an independent central bank was not necessary as a means of preventing deficit financing because the Constitution, adopted in 1980, already states that the central bank may not print new money to cover a fiscal shortfall, the common Latin American method when foreign loans are not available.
He said the best example of what he considered excessive autonomy for the new Chilean bank was its right to determine and regulate foreign-exchange policy, which he said would set it apart from the Federal Reserve. He said that would effectively remove from presidential influence such significant matters as the access of foreign investors to foreign exchange for the remittance of profits.
The other significant criticism from the Aylwin team is that President Pinochet will be able to name the first five members of the central bank's governing council. Although the terms are eventually to be 10 years, this first group will have terms of 2 to 10 years to create staggered terms for the future.

HEADLINE: U.S. MOVES TO LIMIT RACKETEERING LAW IN BUSINESS CASES

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
In moves that could significantly limit the use of criminal racketeering charges against white-collar defendants, the Justice Department has revised rules governing the use of the racketeering law by Federal prosecutors.
The revisions limit both the types of crimes that can be used as the basis of a racketeering indictment and the amount of money that the Government can seize before trial. In addition, they require prosecutors to prove that innocent third parties will not be harmed by the forfeiture requirements of the racketeering law.
The law, the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, or RICO, was originally aimed at organized crime and drug traffickers when it was passed in 1970. But lawyers and legal scholars have debated its use against white-collar defendants in securities fraud cases since the first such indictment was brought in 1988. 
 
Forerunner of Other Cases
That indictment, which charged five principals of Princeton/Newport Partners L.P. and a former trader with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. with engaging in a racketeering conspiracy, broke the ground for a number of other RICO cases. These included the indictment of Michael R. Milken, the former head of Drexel's high-yield ''junk bond'' unit and racketeering indictments against scores of commodity traders in Chicago who were charged with cheating customers.
Under the law, a defendant who engages in a pattern of crimes through a so-called criminal enterprise can be charged with racketeering and forced to forfeit all proceeds gained through the enterprise, if convicted. In addition, before a trial begins, the Government can seek to freeze a defendant's assets to preserve what it thinks is forfeitable.
Many of the cases in the securities area were brought under the supervision of Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former United States Attorney in Manhattan who is now running for Mayor of New York. It is unclear if Mr. Giuliani's departure from the office had any impact on the Justice Department's view.
Some in legal circles contend that use of the law in white-collar cases has resulted in unintended consequences, such as damaging people unrelated to the crime. Those results, these experts said, may have prompted the Justice Department to act before Congress or the courts did.
''What you're seeing is the Justice Department responding to the risk of a legislative backlash,'' said Michael Goldsmith, a law professor at Brigham Young University and a vice chairman of the RICO cases committee of the American Bar Association. ''With RICO, there are situations where innocent parties are left unprotected.''
Legal experts also said that the new rules were a response to problems that had been observed in the law's recent use in nondrug cases. ''They represent a codification of common sense,'' said G. Robert Blakey, a law professor at the Notre Dame Law School who helped draft the racketeering law. ''What we are doing is learning that as RICO is applied outside of drug areas, it has to be applied differently.''
The revisions and clarifications of the Justice Department's position on the law were described in two internal memorandums to United States Attorneys across the country. The memorandums, which have been seen by a number of lawyers in New York legal circles, add new rules regarding forfeiture proceedings and clarify the rules regarding the use of charges of tax violations in prosecutions under the law.
 
Press Criticism Cited
In the forfeiture memorandum, Edward S. G. Dennis Jr., the Assistant Attorney General for the criminal division, wrote that the purpose of the new policy was ''to insure that the rights of all interested parties are protected.'' He added that the revisions were being made in response to ''considerable criticism in the press'' of the racketeering law's use.
Under the new forfeiture rules, prosecutors are required to provide details on the impact of an asset freeze on third parties not named in the indictment. That impact would have to be balanced against the need to preserve assets for forfeiture. The rules also require that prosecutors announce shortly after the indictment that the Government will work to protect the rights of innocent third parties.
In the Princeton/Newport case, defense lawyers argued that the efforts to freeze the partnership's assets led to its collapse. It is unclear whether the partnership would have dissolved had the indictment only charged securities fraud or tax fraud, and not racketeering.
However, people who have spoken with Justice Department officials said the collapse of Princeton/Newport, which led to the unemployment of scores of people, had left the department more sensitive to the possible impact of RICO charges on innocent parties in white-collar cases.
 
Proportional Amount Backed
The new forfeiture rules also require the Government to seek an amount proportional to the crime charged, rather than the fullest amount it can recover under the law. In all the RICO cases involving securities and commodity law violations, the Government has been criticized for seeking to punish defendants to a degree disproportionate to the crime committed.
In the Princeton/Newport case, which ended in convictions, the Government sought $21.5 million from the six defendants. The jury agreed to award only $3.8 million, with $3 million coming from a single defendant.
In addition, the new forfeiture provisions require that a prosecutor demonstrate to Justice Department officials that a remedy that is ''less intrusive'' than an asset freeze will not preserve the assets for the Government in the event of a conviction.
 
Tax Rules Clarified
In a separate memorandum from Shirley D. Peterson, the head of the department's tax division, the rules regarding the use of tax violations as the basis for a racketeering indictment were also clarified. Those rules, first reported in Newsday, would restrict the use of tax violations to bring RICO charges ''Tax offenses are not predicate to RICO offenses,'' Ms. Peterson wrote, noting that such a ruling was expressly stated by Congress. ''Charging a tax offense as a mail fraud charge could be viewed as circumventing Congressional intent unless unique circumstances justifying the use of mail fraud charges exist,'' like using the mails to lure people into fraudulent tax shelter schemes.
Such a rule would have made the bulk of the initial charges in the Princeton/Newport case more difficult to bring, legal experts said. At the time of the Princeton/Newport indictment, Mr. Giuliani said that using the mail fraud laws in tax cases was permitted under RICO.
''Criticism of the Princeton/Newport case lies behind this,'' said Gerard Lynch, a professor at the Columbia University School of Law. ''And it does so in a way that would impose a greater burden of justification on a United States Attorney in bringing that indictment.''
 
Doubts on Application
Justice Department officials did not return calls yesterday seeking comment on the memorandums.

HEADLINE: Farmer and Rights Lawyer Among Victims of Jet Crash

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23

 BODY:
A Wisconsin farmer returning from a volunteer mission to Nicaragua and a lawyer working for a human rights group were among the 12 Americans killed when a Boeing 727 jet crashed in Honduras on Saturday.
Of the 146 people on board, 131 died when the Honduran jet crashed near Tegucigalpa. Three Americans were among the 15 survivors.
The farmer, Daniel Yurista, 37 years old, was returning home after spending five weeks in Nicaragua. Another American, Anthony Friedrich, 28, was a lawyer with the Internationl Human Rights Law Group, its executive director said in Washington.
The State Department identified the other Americans known to have been killed as: Eduardo Apodaca, 49, of San Luis Obispo, Calif.; Maria Esther Apodaca, 50, of San Luis Obispo, Calif.; Robert Hebb, 42, an employee of the Agency for International Development; Connie Montealegre, 68; Charles Kendall Morrow, of Grandview, Mo.; Michael O'Shea, of Costa Rica, and Mary Weaver, whose hometown was not given.

LENGTH: 502 words

HEADLINE: Let the Dollar Drift

 BODY:
One reason the financial markets are jittery is the increasing tension between the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve over the value of the dollar. The Treasury wants to push the dollar down and thus push exports up. The Federal Reserve resists. 
On balance, the Fed position is safer. In the wake of the recent stock market shock, there's good reason for the Treasury to give ground and give financial markets a clear, consistent signal about U.S. policy.
Aside from the market plunge, the dollar keeps rising, despite a stubbornly high trade imbalance. Exactly why is unclear. Perhaps the rise is an irrational ''bubble'' inflated by speculative whim. Or perhaps the U.S. continues to serve as a safe haven for foreign investors scared by political turmoil. Whatever the reason, experts agree that the higher dollar will greatly widen the trade deficit.
The dollar's volatility is undesirable. First it falls, making U.S. exports less expensive. The nation's export industries expand. Then the dollar rises. After considerable delay, export industries shrink and workers are wrenched back and forth painfully. The economy would be better off if these ups and down were eliminated.
But attempts to control the dollar can do serious economic harm. Merely buying and selling foreign currencies - a decision the Treasury dictates - does little to offset strong market forces, as recent events resoundingly prove. To lower the value of the dollar effectively, the Fed must pump up the money supply in order to lower domestic interest rates. That way, investors will turn away from dollars to other currencies.
What is the risk? Higher inflation. The Fed says no to this distortion of its monetary policy because its primary task is to stifle inflation.
One way to choose between two policies is to ask what happens when worse comes to worst. If the Fed's hands-off policy prevails, the dollar will likely rise and the deficit worsen. Eventually, these trends may reverse themselves with short-term dislocations to export and import industries. But while these dislocations may fan protectionist fires, the economic costs might not be large. The nation's trade deficit has recently fallen by more than 40 percent without noticeable misfortune.
If the Treasury policy prevails, however, the nation could be subjected to an inflationary surge. The public knows the costs of that. The Fed would eventually have to clamp down, forcing a recession with a prolonged rise in unemployment and drop in output. The 1982-83 recession offered a harsh demonstration of just how damaging the Fed's anti-inflationary policies can be.
The Fed might decide, as a reaction to another stock market plunge or for other reasons unrelated to the dollar, that a sluggish domestic economy needs a charge in the form of lower interest rates. But until that judgment is made, the Fed would be wise to stick to its current monetary policy. Let the dollar drift. There's much less danger in no action than in overreaction.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
How to Embarrass Americans

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
The plain truth is that it is getting a little embarrassing for an American to talk to foreigners.
That is something new, at least for me. You know how it is - usually when you travel abroad or talk to people at the United Nations, say, you have a tendency to jump in and defend the United States Government against criticism.
There is so much criticism and so much is so ignorant or self-righteous that you get sick of it. Sometimes we find ourselves in prickly defense of people and policies that we are not all that wild about. When I lived in India many years ago, to listen to me you would think I thought John Foster Dulles was God's gift to diplomacy when actually I thought that sometimes he was bonkers. 
But now they ask you questions, about the President of the United States and his vision of morality, that you do not want to answer, anyway not among people who are not members of the family.
They ask you if the President of the United States really means it when he says a poor girl raped by her father should not be helped to get an abortion, or if he really believes that the United States should not contribute a few dollars to help deal with the population explosion that is suffocating countries around the world, or if he really thinks it is all right to sell semiautomatic assault weapons across the counter, just as long as they are American-made.
When Ronald Reagan said things like that you could say all right, I don't agree but that is what Ronald Reagan really believes. That was why he was so often so effective -what you saw was what he was and everybody knew it.
What makes the questions so embarrassing to answer for me is that I find it impossible to believe that George Bush means what he says about abortion for rape and incest, about boycotting birth control, and about allowing the sale of the weapons of the drug-gang killers.
After all, it was only eight years ago that Mr. Bush let it be known that although he was against Federal funds for abortion he would not fight Federal aid in the case of rape or incest. I cannot think of a single thing that would have made him change his mind except political opportunism.
If opportunism were a crime we would all wear jail clothes one time or another. But it does not sit right in the stomach for a President to change his mind about that issue, to say that now he believes that Federal aid can go to everybody from ballet dancers to hog raisers, but not to a young woman without money carrying her father's baby.
Next to food and water, what dozens of countries in this world need most is birth control. To withhold it, to insist that their thin gruel be divided into more and more bowls, no end in sight, is cruelty. It is also racial and economic discrimination of a particularly evil sort.
Most Western countries can afford to give their people the basic education about their bodies essential to a birth control system. If they do not, that is their choice - and their people's loss.
But many nations in Asia, Latin America and Africa need help in population control. It is ugly for this country, where birth control is accepted and practiced by most of the people, to deny it to others because they are both non-American and poor.
A man as traveled and sophisticated as George Bush knows the importance of population control. So do his friends and relatives.
But he announces that he will veto any Congressional effort to restore the paltry United States contribution to the United Nations population fund, because of some cockamamie excuse that some of the money may help abortion in China - which it will not.
Guns: The Bush stand on semiautomatic weapons would have the makings of a comedy routine if it came from a less intelligent man. Ban semis made abroad but for Heaven's sake, not those made in the good old U.S. of A. Die American!
Does he honestly believe this makes sense? When he is alone with his wife, or with himself? It cannot be. So, it is sad to feel that the President is saying things he cannot believe.
But the country is way ahead of him on abortion for rape, population control and the stupidity of selling weapons designed to spray murder in the streets.
Since he is part of the country, maybe one day Mr. Bush will catch up and allow his heart and mouth to be in harmony. Then we can all travel without embarrassment, and be just as prickly about America as usual.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: OP-ED

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (97%); INDIA (79%); CHINA (79%);

HEADLINE: Solidarity Struggles - With Democracy

BYLINE: By David K. Shipler; David K. Shipler is senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington.

DATELINE: WARSAW

 BODY:
It's a thrill to watch former political prisoners and underground Solidarity activists sitting in the august chamber of Poland's new Parliament, debating budget bills and tax legislation. This is the Communist world's most dramatic revolution so far. It is also sobering to see how difficult the construction of a democratic system of government is proving to be, mechanically and psychologically.
More than four decades with a rubber-stamp Parliament left Poland without an effective legislative branch. Many new legislators, immersed for years in the moral certitudes of the dissident opposition, have found themselves unprepared for the compromises of democratic politics. 
''The underground is a bad school for learning democracy,'' said Henryk Wujec, a Solidarity member of Parliament who spent time in prison. ''In the underground, you can't vote on anything. I decide, that's it. Now our movement is not so tolerant as in '80-'81,'' before it was driven underground by martial law.
As a result, some Solidarity leaders are demanding unwavering support from their legislators, he said, and many legislators are overreacting by resisting any party discipline at all.
''They think that in a democratic system you have to debate and vote on everything,'' Mr. Wujec lamented. ''If all the time you have many debates and voting, it is a caricature of a democratic system.'' This and the risk that Poland will fail to recover economically could discredit democracy, he fears. ''People will think it's not a good system and will want a demagogic system.''
Party discipline is an essential goal for Bronislaw Geremek, a former political prisoner who is Solidarity's floor leader in the Sejm, the lower house, where his party holds only 35 percent of the seats. ''In our parliamentary group,'' he said, ''we have no discipline. Everyone votes as he wants to. When we introduced the idea of discipline, everybody said no, that's the old Communist system.''
So strong is the association of bloc voting with Bolshevik authoritarianism that some Solidarity legislators were shocked to learn in a recent seminar that such discipline is often a feature of Western democracies.
Parliament also faces logistical difficulties. Most members have no offices, desks and telephones. They crowd several to an office, rotating from one desk to another. ''We are trying to organize to give one room for three or four senators,'' said Andrzej Wielowieyski, Solidarity leader in the Senate, the newly created upper house. ''I do not even have one room for every committee.''
The legislators have no staff to speak of, nothing like the full-time aides on whom Congressmen in Washington depend to help write and analyze legislation and keep in touch with constituents' concerns.
Since there is no budget yet for staff, the 260 members from Solidarity and other coalition parties who have organized into a caucus called the Citizens Parliamentary Club are tithing, in effect, by contributing one-tenth of their $10 a month salaries to pay for secretaries.
Many secretaries worked with Solidarity in its underground days, then moved to Parliament, at first as unpaid volunteers. This has given the club's small suite of offices the same unpretentious, frenetic atmosphere as a strike headquarters. It has also drawn high-caliber people such as Teresa Ogrodzinska, who has given up her profession as a drama critic to be a secretary, explaining: ''It is fascinating work.''
This is not such an odd place for a drama critic. Many new legislators feel a bit miscast. ''We are amateurs,'' said Andrzej Stelmachowski, a Solidarity lawyer who has become speaker of the Senate. ''This is something new for me. It seems like a dream. I feel I am playing a strange role in a theater.''
Others seem to wear power as uncomfortably as Jacek Kuron wears his ill-fitting suit. Mr. Kuron, the gravelly voiced Solidarity theorist who has become Labor Minister, took the rostrum recently to respond to demands from the lower house that he apologize for long delays in pension payments to some workers. This was not his doing, since he inherited his ministry in mid-September, when the new Government was formed.
He did not look happy as he faced fellow legislators. He wriggled. He shifted from foot to foot. He bellowed, ''It's a great idea to find whoever is responsible for this'' - he started to say ''bordello'' and got half the word out when he remembered where he was. The chamber exploded in laughter and applause. ''We can apologize,'' he continued, ''but that is not enough. If I start to apologize by mail, that would be the end of our postal system!''
Democracy is proving to be tough work. Mr. Kuron and his colleagues understand that pretty soon they are going to be held accountable.

HEADLINE: The Welfare War Between the States

BYLINE: By Joe Strohl; Joe Strohl, a Democrat, is majority leader of the Wisconsin state senate.

DATELINE: MADISON, Wis.

 BODY:
Much has been written about the wars waged between states to attract new jobs. A similar war is being waged in welfare reform. Some states keep welfare benefits low so that some of their residents will move to more socially responsible states. 
This is the case between Wisconsin and Illinois. Wisconsin pays a family of three $517 monthly in Aid for Families with Dependent Children welfare benefits; Illinois pays $342.
Studies have shown that since 1986 nearly one-third of new welfare cases in Wisconsin recently moved here from other states. Of the total number of new welfare recipients who moved to Wisconsin in the past three years, almost 30 percent were from neighboring Illinois. Most settle in the southeast part of the state, in five counties near the Illinois border.
Higher benefits are not the only reason people move to Wisconsin, but it is a major factor. And we are suffering the consequences.
As more new residents go on welfare, our work and training programs are increasingly strained. Wisconsin is also experiencing a growing strain on its schools and juvenile correction facilities, an increase in gang-related crime and housing shortages. There also is an increased demand for already overextended social service programs such as out-patient treatment for alcohol and drug abuse.
But who's really to blame for Wisconsin's predicament? The United States Congress.
When Congress passed the Family Support Act of 1987, many viewed it as the first major overhaul of the nation's welfare system in 25 years, one that would result in welfare recipients leaving the welfare roles for meaningful employment. Congress, however, ignored one of the major problems with the Aid for Families with Dependent Children program -it does nothing to correct the disparities in state benefit levels.
In an effort to resolve this situation, I have proposed state legislation to set Aid for Familes with Dependent Children benefits for new residents at the level granted in their home state for their first six months in Wisconsin. Wisconsin benefit levels would apply after the person had resided in Wisconsin for six months.
Opponents of this two-tier system argue that Wisconsin is not a welfare magnet and further suggest that such a system will hurt the poor. I disagree on both charges.
First, it is unrealistic and insulting to Aid for Familes with Dependent Children recipients to suggest that they do not weigh the economic advantages of relocating their families. This is a basic consideration for anybody making a move.
Second, my proposal is not designed to hurt anyone. We will treat people as their home state did.
Those who oppose my proposal to set welfare payments for new residents at the level they received in their home state should focus their efforts on increasing benefits in states like Mississippi and Alabama. There, Aid for Families with Dependent Children benefits are so low - $120 and $118 respectively - that a family cannot even afford basic necessities.
In addition, they should apply pressure at the Federal level to establish uniform benefit levels for each state. Low benefit states must accept responsibility, as Wisconsin has, for building social programs to enable people to rise out of poverty.

HEADLINE: Courter and Florio Contrast Most Over Social Issues

SERIES: Courter and Florio On the Issues - Second of three articles.

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 23

 BODY:
The two candidates running for governor of New Jersey appear in starkest contrast when they speak about social questions facing the state, like how to fight crime, drugs and AIDS, and whether government should place new restrictions on abortions.
Both the Democrat, Representative James J. Florio, and the Republican, Representative Jim Courter, agree on a commonplace of politics today: the level of street crime is intolerable and has to be fought with increased arrests and tougher laws. Both candidates say behind the rise in crime and AIDS stands a drug epidemic, a problem that the state has to attack as a priority.
Mr. Florio differs from Mr. Courter by seeing a solution in more active and effective government. Among his priorities, Mr. Florio says, are a ban on assault rifles to limit drug dealers' armories and programs to create jobs, housing and hope in cities. 
''There are certain settings out of which crime breeds,'' Mr. Florio said. ''Some of us get accused of being sort of syrupy or we're not macho enough, because you start talking about the environment, that causes crime.''
Mr. Courter, by contrast, sees the triple-headed scourge of crime, drugs and AIDS as growing out of an era of flawed values in which people were no longer held ere accountable for their actions. In Mr. Courter's view, it was an era in which criminals were able to tempt almost everyone with drugs at prices that anyone could afford.
In the long run, Mr. Courter said, Americans will overcome the drug plague with the strength and good judgment they have demonstrated in past crises. In the meantime, he added, government can help, within the limits of its budgets, by providing added law enforcement, drug treatment and education, and by helping AIDS patients receive expensive new drugs to battle the disease.
''You know,'' Mr. Courter said, ''we in American society have suffered through and gone through extraordinary tests -war. We have suffered through depressions, and we've gone through civil wars. We've gone through world wars, and we're going through a drug war. This society is resilient. It recognizes the potential risks.'' The candidates presented their views on those and other issues last week in separate inteviews with reporters of The New York Times.
On abortion, the candidates said they believed the state should not impose any more restrictions than now exist. But how they reached their positions and the reasons are strikingly different.
Mr. Florio said he had supported restrictions on abortions until the mid-70's, when he read Roe v. Wade, the United States Supreme Court decision that overturned anti-abortion laws in 1972. Mr. Florio said the heart of the issue was the right to privacy.
''I was just so struck by the obvious wisdom of a constitutionally protected right to privacy,'' he said. ''I'm very much concerned, and in a whole lot of other areas, as well, about governmental intrusion, governmental growth, domination of people's private lives.''
Mr. Courter voted in favor of numerous bills to cut off Federal financing for abortion in his 10 years in Congress. He said he still opposed abortion, except in cases of rape, incest or where the life of the mother was endangered. But, he said, he respects protections of the right to abortion in the State Constitution and would not support an effort to change it.
 
Importance of Approaches
''There is no consensus in the State of New Jersey to change that Constitution whatsoever,'' Mr. Courter said. ''It's a dead issue. I'm not going to impose my views on the people of the state.''
With polls finding that crime and drugs are top concerns among voters here and with New Jersey cities having the highest rates of AIDS infection in the nation, voters and political experts said the candidates' approaches to those problems will play a vital role in the outcome of the election and the future of the state.
The positions on specific issues often differ greatly. But the responses on social issues appear to represent dramatically divergent views of human nature, of social problems and of what government can do to address them.
At one point, the candidates were asked why drug abuse is so rampant.
''You're talking about people being alienated,'' Mr. Florio said. The pace of life, the diminished roles of the church and family had deprived people of sources of support, he said. Government can begin to provide a solution in the schools, not only by educating against drug use, but also by teaching values.
Fighting drugs, Mr. Florio said, also involves creating employment for young people in poor neighborhoods, to provide them with an alternative to the drug trade. To Mr. Courter, the blame lays with criminals who market drugs and with a society that grew permissive.
''It's a sophisticated international cartel that does have the supply, that's No. 1,'' Mr. Courter said. ''No. 2, it's caused to a degree by a change in society, in the attitude that people can do things without personal consequences whatever and that whatever they do it's someone else's fault.''
 
Movies and Penalties
To fight drugs, Mr. Courter said, he favored showing films in schools that dramatically demonstrate the physical damage of drug use and imposing stiffer penalties on users. Both approaches, he said, would make users more aware of the consequences of their actions.
As governor, Mr. Florio and Mr. Courter said they would press for increased arrests and expansions of jails, prisons, education and and treatment. Neither candidate provided specific goals for the programs or said what they might cost.
Mr. Florio said he would try to pay for expanding publicly financed treatment programs by requiring health insurers to cover drug treatment, as well as alcohol treatment. Although many addicts in public treatment are unemployed and have no insurance, Mr. Florio said, he believed enough did have insurance to provide the state with significant new money.
 
To List Makes of Weapons
Mr. Courter said he hoped to employ additional doctors in private practice in drug treatment, possibly using Medicaid for the poor to offset the cost. But the expansion of treatment, he said, would depend on state revenues.
On crime, Mr. Florio listed as his first priority the banning of all assault rifles. He said he would sign a measure now in the Legislature, the Graves bill, that would ban the public sale of assualt rifles.
Mr. Courter said he supported the ban in principle, but opposed the bill as ''poorly crafted.'' He said he would prefer a ban that would specifically list the makes of weapons. He said a priority for his administration would be overturning rules that prevent prosecutors from presenting evidence in criminal cases that the police had illegally seized. ''I think people are just walking out scot free on a technicality, which I loathe,'' Mr. Courter said.
On AIDS, Mr. Florio said his administration would try to coordinate programs dispersed among many agencies. ''We don't have a battle plan dealing with AIDS, as other states do,'' Mr. Florio said. ''New Jersey is dealing with it piece by piece.''
Mr. Courter said he would stress educating the public on how AIDS is transmitted and would encourage people to be tested for the HIV virus by insuring the confidentiality of the results. Within the limitations of budgets, he said, he would like to assist giving expensive treatments to patients.
 
Comparing Their Answers
In separate interviews this month, The New York Times asked the two candidates for governor of New Jersey to discuss the problems facing the state and how to deal with them. This is the second of three articles comparing their responses. These are excerpts from the interviews.

HEADLINE: Medical Schools Open Doors to Minority Teen-Agers

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
In the life of Melanie Rodriguez, there are few cheers for being a 16-year-old mother, a high school student and an aspiring physician.
Instead, when she strolls the streets of the Bronx in her hospital uniform, young people sometimes jeer her, because a starched uniform is simply not ''cool,'' she says, ''After I had my baby, some of my friends avoided me,'' she said. ''They told me my chances were limited. My mother, she keeps pushing me. I'm going to be the first doctor in my family.'' 
Ms. Rodriguez, who wants to work in forensic medicine, is one of 34 students from Herbert H. Lehman and De Witt Clinton High Schools in the Bronx who spend two days a week in medical school. The Clinton 11th grader is enrolled at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine at Yeshiva University in a program for poor and minority students interested in careers in medicine.
 
Studies and Job Experience
The program teaches study skills and offers courses in science, mathematics, the language arts and cultural awareness, in addition to practical experience in Einstein laboratories and local hospitals. Ms. Rodriguez, for example, has worked with elderly patients at the Montefiore Medical Center as a nurse's helper.
The Einstein program is one of a number of efforts to offset the slow pace at which minorities nationwide are entering medical schools. The number of such students has remained virtually stagnant in the last decade, says Dr. Herbert Nickens of the Association of American Medical Colleges in Washington.
Dr. Nickens said that from 1978 to 1988, the percentage of black, American Indian, Mexican and Puerto Rican first-year medical students went from 8.7 percent of overall enrollment to 10.1 percent. Yet blacks alone represent 15 percent of the age group that usually enrolls in college, he said.
Of the 126 medical schools in the nation, one-third have programs to encourage minority and economically disadvantaged students. In New York City, the Mount Sinai School of Medicine, the New York University School of Medicine and the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons are among schools with programs similar to Einstein's.
At Einstein most students are poor black and Hispanic people from the Bronx. All are interested in careers in medicine. They are picked by counselors at Lehman and Clinton High Schools. The students, mostly junior and seniors, are tutored by minority medical students at Einstein, who also provide a window on the rigors of medical schools.
Perhaps beyond anything else, students learn that they can be successful even if no one else in their family or community is. ''I have learned a lot, especially about myself,'' said Talib Saafir, a 16-year-old junior at Clinton who is interested in becoming a brain surgeon. ''Everybody helps everybody else. I was thinking about starting a hospital in a minority neighborhood when I get up there.''
Mr. Saafir said his dream was to enter Harvard Medical School, but he has been told by some of his peers that blacks who enter top medical schools like that somehow turn their backs on their people. Others, like Ashley Singh, a junior at Lehman, said she always felt that she could not make it.
 
'Helped Me Reach the Top'
''This program helped me reach the top,'' said Ms. Singh. She is 16 years old and wants to be a nurse who works with children. ''I never thought I could do anything. I was going through a rough time in my life. I did a lot of things I wasn't supposed to do.''
The Einstein program is in the final year of a three-year pilot program sponsored by the Associated Medical Schools of New York. Thirteen of the 14 medical schools in the state belong to Associated Medical Schools and they offer programs similar to the one at Einstein. Funds for the effort come from the State Department of Education and the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation.
''Our premise is they wouldn't have the exposure if it wasn't for us,'' said Henryne Green, program officer for the Science and Technology Entry Program at Associated Medical Schools. ''This year we are doing a formal evaluation of the program. This is our last year of funding from the state.''
 
Most Continue Studies
Ms. Green said 85 percent of 154 youngsters in New York State who had graduated from the program had pursued higher education. Of those, 85 percent are pre-medical or science majors.
The Einstein program is not for the lethargic. Students must show up on time and ready to work two days a week from 3:30 to 5:30 P.M. They receive homework from their classes and must keep a journal of their personal observations and academic progress.
Louis Shing, the coordinator of the program, said many students are the first in their families to pursue a medical degree or even go to college. He said families sometimes resisted the idea of their children entering the medical profession, often to shield them from what they fear will be certain failure in mainstream society.
And, as in the case of Melanie Rodriguez, peers sometimes tease the Einstein high school students for being too bookish. Those attitudes are as difficult to overcome as any academic deficiencies or lack of funds for medical school, Mr. Shing said.
''Once we get the students here, we show how it is possible,'' he said. ''They meet medical students who look like them. They go into the laboratories and participate in experiments. They learn they can do more than they ever dreamed possible.''

HEADLINE: The California Quake;
A Crippling Blow for Oakland's Poor

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 23

 BODY:
When Jeanette Blackmon moved into her single room at the Oaks Hotel on 15th Street five weeks ago, she thought she had finally arrived.
Months on the mean streets of Oakland and in shelters sometimes less safe than the streets had worn her down. The newly renovated Oaks, with its new buzzer security system and its green false marble facade, was a jewel in Oakland's brave but faltering effort to redevelop its downtown section.
The hotel, built in 1913 and renovated in 1986, was the East Bay's first nonprofit residential hotel for the poor. There were community kitchens, tenants' meetings and a social worker to help people who lived there look for work and keep their lives in order. 
But the earthquake that struck the San Francisco Bay Area on Tuesday ravaged 15th Street, crippling not only the Oaks but also its ugly duckling neighbor, the Danziel Apartments, and even Oakland's ornate City Hall.
 
Damage Put at $1.5 Billion
Mayor Lionel Wilson and his City Hall staff had to evacuate. And about 300 residents of 15th Street, including Mrs. Blackmon, who is 52 years old, were out on the street.
Mayor Wilson said today that earthquake damage to businesses and buildings in Oakland might approach $1.5 billion. Damage assessors for the Red Cross said that property of 3,721 families in Oakland had sustained damage and that 13 apartment buildings and 57 private homes were destroyed.
The Red Cross said Sunday that 681 people were being housed in five Oakland shelters.
Today's heavy rain exacerbated ground shifts caused by the quake. Red Cross officials were scrambling to find shelter for the more than 100 people left homeless in the last 24 hours.
 
'Qualified for Disaster Relief'
The number of people the quake left homeless in Oakland is not high compared with that in San Francisco or the communities near Santa Cruz. But, unlike the well-to-do residents of San Franciso's hardest hit neighborhood, the Marina district, most of Oakland's quake victims lived in decrepit, crime-ridden housing projects, and they lack friends to take them in. insurance brokers and rental agents.
Like many of his neighbors in the Oaks Hotel and the Danziel Apartments, Roy Martinez, 52, took refuge at the Red Cross shelter at the Martin Luther King Jr. Elementary School on 10th Street in west Oakland.
Wearing a donated ''Saratoga Nautical'' T-shirt and chinos, Mr. Martinez, who was unemployed before the quake, spent much of his time last week mopping and sweeping the shelter. ''Us here, we should have qualified for disaster relief before the quake,'' he said, only partly joking.
At the 10th Street shelter there are free clothes, medical care and what seems like round-the-clock hot meals. But it is hard to sleep at night because of the crowding, and there are occasional squabbles over an especially coveted item of donated clothing.
 
A Cat Lands on Its Feet
Dorothy Williams, 59, who lived on 15th Steet before the quake, does not mind the shelter now that she knows that Ezee, her black and white cat with the beauty mark on its face, is safe.
The cat, which fled Mrs. Williams's apartment when the building started to shake early Tuesday evening, was found by a neighbor two days later burrowed in a pile of clothes in a closet. Mrs. Williams said she used her last $10 to take Ezee to the Alameda pet hospital, where the cat is now living comfortably. ''At least one of us is living in the lap of luxury,'' she added.
Benjamin Tiger, a marine machinist at the Port of Oakland, lived in a quake-damaged building on 15th Street that was condemned after being ransacked by looters who even tried to chip away the fake marble panels in the lobby.
Mr. Tiger and his wife, Carol, worry that they will never be able to get together the first and last month's rent, security and a utility deposit to get another apartment. And the Tigers fear that only people on welfare will get grants for new housing.
 
Some Practical Problems
Those ''on the Government,'' like Jeannette Blackmon, Dorothy Williams and Roy Martinez, fear it will take months for aid to come through.
And there were practical problems: Where would the checks be sent to those who are homeless? How would they apply for disaster relief?
On Sunday the former residents of the Oaks Hotel got some good news: city building inspectors determined that there was no structural damage to the Oaks and that renovation would start soon.
But later in the day the authorities decided to move the 10th Street shelter to the nearby Lowell Middle School on 14th Street.
Mrs. Blackmon knows only that she is sick of moving. ''I just want a little cottage, get me a dog, a little garden and watch soap operas,'' she said, ''and forget any of this happened.''

COMPANY: BAY AREA INSURANCE SERVICES (69%);

HEADLINE: The California Quake;
House Panel Votes $2.85 Billion in Quake Relief

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23

 BODY:
The House Appropriations Committee approved a $2.85 billion aid package today to help earthquake recovery efforts in the San Francisco Bay Area. The legislation would provide low-interest loans and grants to rebuild homes, businesses and highways in the devastated area.
The spending plan, approved in a voice vote, contains less money than the $3.84 billion sought by members of Congress from California. But the plan provides more than the $2 billion to $2.5 billion suggested today by the Bush Administration, an amount that Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said was ''manageable and can be accommodated'' within the budget. 
The aid package, which is attached to a spending measure moving swiftly through Congress, now goes to the House floor, where passage is considered likely. If approved, the Senate is expected to act quickly and send the measure to President Bush for his signature before the end of the week.
''We're not attempting to put in here all the money it's going to take,'' said Representative Jamie L. Whitten, a Mississippi Democrat who is chairman of the committee. ''My whole pitch is to do something now, straighten it out later and don't waste any money in the meantime.''
 
Breakdown of Relief Package
Under the proposal approved today, $1.1 billion would be provided to the Federal Emergency Management Agency for direct relief efforts in of grants for housing assistance and other emergency needs. Another $1 billion would be provided to the Federal Highway Administration Emergency Fund for immediate highway repairs.
In addition, the plan provides $500 million to the Small Business Administration for low-interest disaster loans and $250 million to the Presidential discretionary fund for repairs of Federal buildings, veterans hospitals and airport property.
In Sacramento, Gov. George Deukmejian said today that he would convene a special session of the Legislature within two weeks to come up with an earthquake relief package. He said the amount of aid would be at least as much as the $90 million provided after the Whittier earthquake in Southern California in 1987.
Members of California's Congressional delegation expressed disappointment today that they were unable to obtain a bigger aid package, but they said the additional money would help.
''The amount approved does not, of course, meet all our needs, but it's a significant step in the right directions,'' said Representative Vic Fazio, a California Democrat who led efforts to obtain more funds.
 
Optimism Over Quick Approval
While the Administration and some lawmakers disagreed over specific aid proposals, spokesmen for both side said their differences were not as great as it appeared and expressed optimism that a compromise relief package could be approved quickly.
Richard G. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, appeared upbeat after a meeting on disaster relief this afternoon with Mr. Whitten and Republican leaders on the House Appropriations Commmittee.
''Everybody appreciates that it is a national disaster that we've got to address,'' Mr. Darman said. ''We're trying to do it as best we can on the merits on a bipartisan basis. I would hope very much that we wouldn't end up in the kind of situation where we have a bidding war and then a veto threat.''
The Administration plan proposed spending $1 billion from existing programs, including funds authorized to assist the victims of Hurricane Hugo, Mr. Fitzwater said. In addition, the Administration proposed seeking an additional $1.5 bilion in an emergency spending request from Congress that would not require new taxes.
