HEADLINE: Problems Loom in Effort to Control Use of Chemicals for Illicit Drugs

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
FRUSTRATED by the failure to stop the flood of drugs into the country, leaders of America's battle against drugs are seeking to restrict supplies of key ingredients and processing chemicals required to make illegal substances. But many experts believe the effort is doomed to failure by the seemingly endless alternative methods of synthesizing drugs that technically skilled criminals have devised.
Chemists point out that all drugs, including those usually derived from plants, can be synthesized in a laboratory. Economic considerations dictate which drugs are most profitable to make, and chemists say that if coca leaves should ever be in short supply, cocaine could be made entirely synthetically. In any case, illicit laboratories continue to develop new and ever more powerful drugs.
Since March the Federal Drug Enforcement Agency has been phasing in new regulations governing the sale, distribution and exportation of chemicals that can be used to make illegal drugs. Last year the United States also signed, with 79 other nations, an international treaty containing rules about chemicals used in the processing or making of drugs. 
Under the new D.E.A. rules, which will be fully in place by the end of this month, transactions involving these chemicals must be recorded by sellers. Records must be open to Government inspection, and if a seller suspects the intentions of a buyer, he must report his suspicions to the Drug Enforcement Agency. Government officials have suggested to sellers that they should be suspicious when they are asked to deliver chemicals in unusual ways. The law does not restrict the sale of any chemicals but, by requiring that all transactions be recorded, it is intended to deter criminals from acquiring chemicals and to make it easier to pursue them after a purchase.
Government administrators say the new regulations imposed by the Anti-drug Abuse Act of 1988 will significantly hamper criminals who manufacture drugs in warehouses, private homes, vans and other temporary locations. But many chemists and pharmacologists believe that the raw materials and processes that can be used for making drugs are practically limitless and that when one illicit process is disrupted, others spring up to replace it.
''Take alcohol, for example,'' said a chemist who asked not to be named. ''You might decide to curb the sale of corn, which can be fermented to make moonshine. But the bootlegger would merely switch to barley or prunes or any of the thousands of natural substances containing carbohydrates. Curbing the precursors of many drugs involves similar problems.''
The chemicals needed to manufacture drugs are so common, moreover, that controlling them poses almost insurmountable difficulties. Cocaine, currently the chief target of Federal drug agents, typifies the problem.
Besides the coca leaves themselves, the criminal needs only a modest variety of cheap chemicals to make pure cocaine. All of these chemicals are used in large amounts for legitimate purposes and are widely available. According to Government and private technical publications that describe the clandestine manufacture of cocaine, the required chemicals are kerosene; ammonia, commonly used to make cleaning agents, fertilizers and synthetic fibers; lime, used to make bricks and mortar; sodium carbonate, used in glass, soap and cleansers; sulfuric acid, used in automobile batteries; potassium permanganate, used in tanning leather and purifying water, ethyl ether, a common solvent, and hydrochloric acid, used for cleaning metal and preparing food products.
The new law provides for regulation of 12 complex substances, or ''precursor chemicals,'' that can be built up into drugs or modified to produce drugs. The law also regulates eight substances, or ''essential chemicals,'' most of them solvents - liquid chemicals in which reactions can take place or from which dissolved substances can be crystallized in pure form.
 
Law Covers Common Solvents
The law now regulates transactions involving several common solvents used for making cocaine, heroin and dozens of other street drugs. The new regulations apply to ethyl ether; acetone, the chemical in nail-polish remover; methyl ethyl ketone, found in rubber cement, and toluene, used in paint thinners.
The law does not apply to domestic sales of less than 50 gallons a month and foreign sales of less than 500 gallons, unless they seem suspicious to the dealer.
But critics say the solvents are manufactured and sold in such immense quantities that it would be practically impossible to detect all small transactions by drug makers.
''In this country alone, 6 billion pounds of toluene and 2 billion pounds of acetone are sold each year,'' said R. Garrity Baker, director of international affairs for the Chemical Manufacturers Association in Washington. ''Our 170 members, which produce more than 90 percent of the basic chemicals made in the United States, will keep the sales and distribution records required under the new law. But it will be up to the D.E.A. to make use of those records in tracking down illicit drugs, and it will be no easy task.''
 
Chemists Are Critical>
Most chemists avoid making public statements critical of the new regulations. ''Not to go along with the patriotic anti-drug bandwagon can place a chemist under suspicion of being soft on drug dealers,'' one said. ''The truth is, nearly all of us are against drugs, but a lot of us feel the current regulatory efforts are as self-defeating as Prohibition was in the 20's.''
Even if heroin and cocaine were successfully suppressed, new drugs that have entered the street market could become the drugs of choice, some experts say. Some of these substances, which require no natural base like coca leaves in cocaine, are far more dangerous than either cocaine or heroin.
Dr. Gary L. Henderson, a chemist whose expert testimony is frequently sought by prosecutors who also use his expertise in tracking down illicit drug operations, believes that in some cases, anti-drug enforcement may drive illicit producers into switching to exceptionally dangerous substances. Dr. Henderson, an associate professor of pharmacology at the University of California at Davis, coined the phrase ''designer drugs'' to describe potent new psychoactive substances created by criminal chemists to skirt existing laws.
''Dangers increase drastically whenever people start concentrating drugs or consuming them in new ways, to increase their potency and value,'' he said. ''Alcohol in the form of beer or wine probably did relatively little harm before we learned how to distill it. People in the Andean region of South America have chewed coca leaves for thousands of years without major ill effects, but now that the drug is being refined as pure cocaine or converted into crack, it causes great harm.''
One such drug, 3-methylfentanyl is a depressant that is roughly 1,000 times more potent than heroin, for which it was mistaken when the first overdose cases showed up in hospital emergency rooms. Dr. Henderson testified at one trial that the defendant, an industrial chemist, had made enough fentanyl in a single, relatively simple laboratory synthesis for up to 10 million doses. The synthesis had required only a few pounds of starting materials, the most essential of which was purchased in a retail store.
Another fentanyl case in which Dr. Henderson testified involved a chemist, Dr. Michael C. Hovey, who had been employed in Delaware by the E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Company. He pleaded guilty in 1986 to Federal drug charges, but after he had spent a year in prison, the charges were dropped because fentanyl was not illegal when he was arrested. After his release Delaware brought its own charges against the chemist, and last month, a state trooper shot Dr. Hovey dead as he was trying to flee from arrest, the state police said.
An official of the D.E.A., who declined to speak for attribution by name, acknowledged that powerful synthetic drugs made in clandestine laboratories may eventually create large social and public health problems. ''If supplies of cocaine and heroin ever dry up,'' he said, ''some of the new synthetic substances might replace them. Even if the drug lords decide to stay with cocaine and heroin, these substances can be chemically synthesized from scratch, and the day may come when the drug merchants can get along without the natural raw materials, coca and opium. But for the time being, the economics are against it. Coca and opium are still cheap and much too widely available to bother with synthesis.''
 
Drugs Easy to Produce
Meanwhile, illicit laboratories pour new drugs into the pipeline, and most of these drugs are easy to synthesize, chemists say.
One that has been described in recent regulatory bulletins and in High Times, a monthly magazine read by many drug users, is ketamine, a legal anesthetic with effects are similar to those of heroin. Experts describe ketamine, which is also called ''Vitamin K,'' as a cult drug consumed mainly in the Western states. Since it is not classed as among the most closely monitored drugs that have no approved medical use, it is easier to obtain than heroin.
Another new drug, ''Eu4ia'' (pronounced euphoria), is an amphetamine-like stimulant made from materials found in some legal pharmaceuticals, notably diet aids. Eu4ia might gain a foothold as a cocaine substitute if cocaine should ever become scarce, Dr. Henderson said.
A new drug that has caused particular concern in Hawaii and a few Western states is a form of methamphetamine produced as large crystals that can be smoked. The new drug, dubbed ''ice,'' produces violent symptoms that are sometimes indistinguishable from those of acute paranoid schizophrenia.
Chemists say that all the methamphetamine drugs can be synthesized using the common drug ephedrine, an ingredient in many over-the-counter cold remedies.
 
Criticism of New Law
The new Federal law makes ephedrine a regulated chemical, bulk sales of which must be recorded. But some public officials believe the law will have little practical effect.
Representative Vic Fazio, Democrat of California, recently complained about the ephedrine situation to William K. Bennett, director of the White House Office of National Drug Control Policy. ''Unfortunately it appears the new Federal law will have little impact in California, which has far more stringent restrictions already in place,'' Mr. Fazio wrote. Despite these restrictions, he said, there has been a proliferation of clandestine methamphetamine laboratories in Sacramento. Since neighboring states exercise no control over ephedrine sales, he said, criminals in California merely buy what they need over the state line.
In many countries abroad, drug makers use over-the-counter remedies as starting materials for potent drugs. In New Zealand, for example, criminals have devised a chemical technique for extracting the codeine from a popular brand of cold tablets and converting it into a crude form of heroin.
Chemical experts agree that the laboratory synthesis of potent drugs requires relatively little technical education.
''If you have to devise a synthesis method from scratch, you have to go into the chemical literature available from libraries and know what you're doing,'' a chemist said. ''But you don't need to know much if you're just following a recipe. You can buy recipes for almost anything you want to make, just as you can buy precursor chemicals on the black market.''
Phencyclidine, or ''angel dust,'' is made by mixing ingredients in three buckets, he said, and the mixing process, which produces fumes, has to continue for several hours. The procedure is often carried out in the back of a rented van that is kept moving to disperse the fumes and to avoid notice. Because practitioners must constantly pour chemicals from one bucket to another, they have become known as ''bucket chemists.''
Difficult as it is for the United States to curb drug manufacture at home, it is still harder to affect drug production abroad. A treaty aimed at restraining international drug traffic, including chemical used in producing drugs, was signed in 1988 by 80 nations, but it has yet to be ratified by most of them.
Robert T. Angarola, a Washington lawyer and former White House counsel on drug abuse, said he believed most nations would finally ratify at least parts of the treaty. But he acknowledged that some nations with large international chemical industries, notably Switzerland, may remain aloof from the effort. Increased regulation increases the manufacturing costs and reduces competitive advantage. The giant Swiss companies are reluctant to accept such burdens. ''The real problem drug enforcers face is one of economics,'' a chemist said. ''As long as it is possible to become rich by carrying out a simple laboratory operation - perhaps just doing it once or twice in a lifetime - there will be temptation. Very few chemists betray their profession. But I'm afraid the drug dealers will always be able to hire enough professional talent to keep business booming.''

HEADLINE: British TV on Eve of Competitive Era

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 23

 BODY:
On the eve of legislation to change the face of British television by 1992, viewers, critics and broadcasters are debating whether more commercial competition will lead to lower standards on the air.
An outrage against the BBC? The people who made ''Brideshead Revisited,'' ''The Jewel in the Crown,'' ''Upstairs, Downstairs''? No - the BBC did not produce any of these memorable series; British commercial television did.
 
Many Co-productions
''The Jewel in the Crown,'' the series about the end of the British raj, came from Granada Television, which also was a co-producer of ''Brideshead Revisited'' with WNET, the public television station for New York City, and a West German network. ''Upstairs, Downstairs'' came from London Weekend Television. Granada, WGBH in Boston and Dune Television of France co-produced ''A Tale of Two Cities,'' to be broadcast on PBS on ''Masterpiece Theater'' beginning Nov. 19. 
The BBC has commissioned its share of memorable programs: ''A Perfect Spy,'' the series made from the John le Carre novel; ''All Creatures Great and Small,'' the James Herriot tales of a rural English veterinarian, and many more.
But superb programs are not the monopoly of noncommercial television in Britain; they have as often been produced by the 16 commercial companies that make up the tightly regulated independent ITV network.
Many critics here say that high-quality programs are just as conspicuous amid the routine fare on both British commercial and noncommercial networks as they are on ABC, NBC and CBS in the United States, but mercifully without the frequent interruptions for advertisements.
 
American Style Is Debated
Comparison with American television is the first weapon that both advocates and detractors of the British system reach for, since it is commonly assumed that what Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government wants is American-style television: lots of channels, commercials and cheap entertainment.
Not so, the Government says: more competition will produce more choice, not less. Anyway, the Government's argument goes, as the entire European television market expands and becomes more competitive, British television will have to change with it. With cable television and satellite broadcasting like Rupert Murdoch's Sky Channel already competing for advertising and viewer attention, the days of the BBC's and ITV's ''comfortable duopoly,'' as the blue-ribbon Peacock Committee called it in 1986, are clearly numbered.
Last November, the Government revealed its prescription for change: at least one and possibly two more commercially financed broadcast channels, stiffer competition among bidders for ITV franchises, and a move away from the system of mandatory viewer-license fees that pay for BBC-1 and BBC-2.
Since 1946, BBC television has been financed by mandatory annual license fees levied on set owners. A license for a color television set now costs 66 ($105), and the BBC runs no commercials. The ITV companies share broadcasting time on Channel 3, which has commercials. So does Channel 4, which is owned by the public authority that controls ITV and financed by advertising revenue from ITV's regional companies.
Eventually, the Government said, the BBC should be offered as cable television is, to subscribers who pay for it. More immediately, it proposed changing the way the Independent Broadcasting Authority awards commercial franchises for ITV, saying they should go to the highest bidders.
In June, bowing to criticism about the possible effect on quality, the Government agreed to draft legislation to ensure that no winner would be allowed to broadcast substandard programming or skimp on public-interest programs.
How good is British television? ''It isn't all 'Brideshead'; far from it,'' said Alasdair Milne, the BBC's former programming director. ''But on the general level, because we and ITV were competing for the attention of the audience instead of for advertising dollars, we produced peaks that are unmatched in the rest of the world.''
Paul Johnson, a leading critic, disagreed recently, writing in the conservative magazine The Spectator: ''Most of what the duopoly produces is of revoltingly inferior confection -endless quiz-shows and sport, cheap imports (often, nowadays, pap from Australia), lackluster situation comedies and old B-movies without end. There is often virtually no choice. By contrast, U.S. (including cable) is rich in both quality and variety.''
Auberon Waugh, in the same magazine, dismissed American television as ''appalling, like American beer.''
Daphne Lockyer, in Mr. Murdoch's tabloid Today, recently wrote: ''You can knock American TV as much as you like, and you can sound off endlessly about 'quality' British television. But the truth is that the four best series on British TV at the moment are all American imports - 'L.A. Law,' 'Thirtysomething,' 'Cheers' and 'Roseanne.' ''
In fact, recent ratings showed ''M*A*S*H'' among the top-drawing shows on BBC-2; on Channel 4, ''Golden Girls,'' ''Lost in Space,'' ''The Waltons,'' ''St. Elsewhere'' and ''Oprah Winfrey'' were in the top 20.
At the very top on BBC-1 and ITV are soap operas: ''Eastenders,'' a Cockney saga, and ''Neighbors'' on BBC-1, and ''Coronation Street,'' the British antithesis of ''Dallas,'' on ITV. No one would argue that British soap operas are on the same level as ''Brideshead,'' which, Mr. Johnson wrote, ''is the only kind of British program ever seen by American East Coast intellectuals, who assume they are typical, and so endorse the 'best television in the world' nonsense.''
Cheryl Markosky, a journalist, said: ''The reason why there are so few quality programs is money; it's hard to get the money for ambitious, expensive productions, and the BBC is being particularly squeezed.''
 
Licenses Tied to Inflation
To force the BBC to keep costs down, the Government is tying license increases to the inflation rate, now slightly below 8 percent a year.
Last year, BBC television earned $1.26 billion, mostly from the license fees, while ITV made $2.28 billion from advertising, the BBC said.
Producing an hour of drama for television costs about $800,000, Mr. Milne said; light entertainment costs $640,000 an hour, and documentaries $400,000. ''The problem remains that the BBC, having committed itself to 20 major films a year, can't really afford to make them,'' a critic wrote recently in the newspaper The Guardian, arguing that independent television nowadays could not either.
Mr. Milne and others say that the uncertainty created by the Government's plans to auction off ITV franchises after 1991 has frightened the leading companies, like Granada, out of undertaking anything as ambitious as ''The Jewel in the Crown'' until their fate is clear. The BBC's present charter expires in 1996.
 
Blanket Coverage Is Rare
British television's approach to the news also differs from that of American television. Only elections or the annual political conventions get special blanket coverage. Most other major news events are covered, for the most part, during the regular news times on the four networks, at 6, 7, 9 and 10 P.M. on weekdays. When Mikhail S. Gorbachev visited Britain in April, neither the BBC nor ITV interrupted its regular coverage for more than short news bulletins.
The BBC, from its inception as a radio service under Lord Reith in 1927, has always striven for a high standard that some might find elitist. ''He who prides himself on giving what he thinks the people want is creating a fictitious demand for lower standards which he will then satisfy,'' Lord Reith said. Mr. Murdoch, by contrast, said in a speech in Edinburgh last summer, ''Anybody who, within the law of the land, provides a service which the public wants at a price it can afford is providing a public service.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

 
 
The Economy
The Justice Department has revised the rules governing Federal prosecutors' use of the racketeering law known as RICO. The changes could significantly limit the use of criminal racketeering charges against white-collar defendants. [Page A1.] 
The trust set up by Manville to compensate victims of asbestos has almost run out of money. As a result, tens of thousands of people with asbestosis, lung cancer and other often-fatal diseases who ask the trust for money this year will have to wait 25 years before being compensated, the trust estimates. [A18.]
The savings industry lost billions of dollars in deposits in August, as the capital requirements set by the savings and loan bailout forced executives to shrink the size of their institutions. [D1.]
Magazine publishers and editors are celebrating the industry's renewed prosperity at the Annual Magazine Conference. [D20.]
 
 
 
Companies
UAL's board said it would try to keep the company independent while examining its alternatives. The board imposed stringent and possibly insurmountable requirements for future buyout bids from United's pilots, said a Wall Street executive who was briefed on the meeting. The board's announcement came after the stock market had closed. UAL shares rose $9.875, to $178.375, but in after-hours trading the stock changed hands for as little as $151. [D1.] Arbitragers may have paper losses of as much as $1 billion on their holdings of UAL stock, and some of the biggest losses may be at conservative firms that generally do not buy into a takeover target until an agreement is reached with its board. [D8.]
Six oil companies reported mixed third-quarter earnings. Exxon and Phillips Petroleum slipped, while Occidental, ARCO and Amerada Hess reported gains. Ashland Oil reported a loss. [D1.]
Kenneth Roman resigned as Ogilvy's chairman and chief executive, five months after the company lost its fight to fend off a takeover by WPP. He will join American Express as an executive vice president. [D1.]
Capital Cities/ABC's profits rose 29 percent in the third quarter, largely because of significantly stronger revenues for its broadcasting division, led by the ABC television network. [D1.]
Qintex Australia announced a reorganization plan, two weeks after its bid for MGM/UA had to be withdrawn. [D4.]
Wartsila Marine Industries will file for bankruptcy. The Finnish shipbuilder once built 30 percent of the world's cruise ships and more than half of all icebreakers. [D5.]
 
Paribas made an uninvited offer for two-thirds of Navigation Mixte, a French holding company with interests in insurance and banking. [D4.]
Ramada slashed the cash distribution to be received by shareholders after it failed to raise $230 million in ''junk bonds.'' [D4.]
 
 
 
Markets
Stocks dropped broadly, as investors focused on a faltering economy, weakening corporate profits and a stagnant dollar. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 26.23 points, or about 1 percent, to 2,662.91. [D10.] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose, as the stock market weakened. [D18.]
Copper speculators continued their flight from the weakening market, sending futures prices to their lowest levels in more than two months. [D19.] The dollar drifted lower in lackluster trading as the markets awaited the release of U.S. economic data. [D19.]

Health maintenance organizations did well this year, recovering from two years of heavy losses. Business and Health. [D2.]

Multinational companies need to develop a more global strategy, says Hamish Maxwell of Philip Morris. Advertising. [D21.]

HEADLINE: Savings Outflow In August

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23

 BODY:
The savings industry lost billions of dollars in deposits in August as the tough new capital requirements set by the savings and loan rescue forced executives to shrink the size of their institutions, the Office of Thrift Supervision said today.
The agency, known as the Federal Home Loan Bank Board before the bailout legislation, reported that deposits at the nation's savings and loan associations fell by $5.1 billion in August, a dramatic reversal from July, when deposits actually rose by $54 million. That increase, however, was the only one this year and reflected the drop in interest rates that made deposits at savings institutions competitive with rates paid by money market funds.
''Institutions know they have to meet higher capital requirements, and the easiest way to do that is to shrink,'' said James Barth, chief economist for the thrift office, adding that the shrinkage process ''is not going to go away for a while.'' 
 
Confidence Not Big Factor
Mr. Barth added that he saw little indication that the loss of deposits was the result of a lack of confidence by customers.
Indeed, while the loss of $5.1 billion is large, it is only half the losses posted by the industry in January, when depositors fled savings and loan institutions, fearing a possible tax on their deposits as a way to finance an industry bailout, in favor of higher rates paid by money market funds.
But even though the erosion of customer confidence appears to have been stanched, the industry has still lost almost $62 billion of deposits in the last year.
The industry is coping with requirements under the bailout bill that force executives to retain much higher levels of cash and cash-type holdings as capital, or a cushion against losses. The bailout, passed by Congress in August, will provide $159 billion to close down almost 700 sick savings institutions over the next 10 years.
 
Requirements Doubled
While the industry for years was permitted to operate at capital levels between 1 and 3 percent of assets, the bailout bill has more than doubled those requirements. Some analysts predict the industry could be forced to raise more than $30 billion in new capital through stock offerings and cash infusions from mergers with outside investors.
But a much easier way to increase capital levels is by shrinking the size of the overall institution, while keeping the amount of capital constant. This, according to Mr. Barth and other industry experts, was what the industry began to do in August.
Moreover, Mr. Barth added, almost half of the shrinkage was concentrated at five very large California institutions that needed to raise their capital levels.
The thrift office added that the numbers included the outflow of deposits from 264 sick institutions under the control of the Government.
''The surest way to meet higher capital requirements is by letting your deposits run off and selling assets so that you have a smaller base,'' said James W. Christian, chief economist for the United States League of Savings Institutions.
 
Interest Rates Are Lowered
Mr. Christian noted that in August, while interest rates essentially held steady, many California savings institutions were lowering the rates they paid on deposits, which is the easiest way to pare deposits and ''a clear signal that it was deliberate.''
''What is interesting is that we are seeing a very quick and dramatic impact'' of the bailout legislation, said Bert Ely, a financial consultant based in Alexandria, Va.
But Mr. Barth said that some of the loss of deposits was not intentional. August tends to be a heavy spending month for families. ''Getting ready for back to school, parents shell out money for tuition, clothing and suppliers,'' he said.
Accompanying the loss of deposits, which do not include the crediting of interest, was an even larger shrinkage in the industry's total assets. For August, the total fell by $13.4 billion, to $1.318 trillion, the thrift office said.
Most of that was accounted for by the sale of $8.3 billion in mortgage-backed securities and $3.5 billion in non-mortgage securities held by the industry, the Government said. These assets tend to be much easier to liquidate than individual home mortgages and other direct real estate holdings, which fell $3 billion.
Besides not offering competitive rates on deposits, which encourages customers to go elsewhere, the industry paid off large amounts of borrowings from the Federal Home Loan Banks, the agency said.

HEADLINE: Japan's Maneuvering For a Big Global Voice

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct 23

 BODY:
Japan, the world's biggest creditor and provider of financial assistance, is quietly building its influence in global finance institutions long dominated by the United States and Western Europe. Having gained the appointment of a Japanese official to the top ranks of the World Bank, Japan is moving to promote a candidate to run the International Monetary Fund when the term of its managing director expires in January 1992.
After the United States, Japan is now the second-largest stockholder in the World Bank, a Washington-based institution that provides more than $20 billion a year, mostly in long-term loans, to help third-world countries strengthen their economies.
The bank is headed by former Representative Barber B. Conable Jr. of upstate New York, who is a friend of President Bush. Newly appointed as one of two executive vice presidents is Yoshio Terazawa, former executive vice president of Nomura Securities in Tokyo, the world's biggest brokerage house. Sir William S. Ryrie of Britain is the other appointee. 
 
Behind-the-Scenes Maneuvers
Now Japan is seeking a larger voice in the International Monetary Fund, which oversees currency developments and offers conditional loans to help countries balance their international accounts.
American and foreign officials say that behind the scenes, Japan is positioning Toyoo Gyohten, a well-known official in international financial circles, as a candidate to succeed Michel Camdessus of France as managing director of the I.M.F.
Mr. Gyohten, Japan's former vice minister of finance, served for much of the 1980's as Japan's chief spokesman on international monetary matters. He was a Fulbright scholar at the Woodrow Wilson School of Princeton University during the 1950's and an I.M.F. economist in Washington in the 1960's. He is a graduate of Tokyo University.
Mr. Gyohten, an avid golfer, is now a finance ministry adviser. As such, he speaks for Japan in opinion-shaping international economic seminars, where he gives presentations and meets with academics and journalists.
Articulate in English, Mr. Gyohten, 58 years old, has a reputation for wit and grace.
 
Far-Reaching Changes Seen
He declines to comment on any ambitions he may have. But at one recent gathering he said, ''Changes that have taken place in Japan's role in the world have been so rapid and far-reaching that it requires a very substantial effort to be made for political leaders to catch up and understand what has happened.''
Most international officials are sympathetic to Japan's ambitions to increase the nation's voice in the I.M.F. and the World Bank.
Mr. Camdessus has said there are ''great talents'' in Japan, adding, ''I do not see any legal reasons not to have Japanese talents managing these institutions.''
But Tokyo still faces a tough fight, chiefly against Europeans, to place its man in Mr. Camdessus's chair.
The post has historically gone to a European, just as Americans have always held the presidency of the World Bank. The institutions were established in the wreckage of World War II as pillars of a postwar economic system.
 
Others Interested
Mr. Camdessus, who headed France's central bank before going to Washington to take over the I.M.F. post, has given no indication that he wants to return to Paris. And should he step down, there are several European hats in the ring, including that of the Dutch Finance Minister, H. Onno Ruding, and the president of West Germany's central bank, Karl Otto Pohl.
Japan is the fifth-largest stockholder in the fund, behind the United States, Britain, West Germany and France. It wants to become No. 2.
Although voting strength in the organization is linked to economic position, national prestige is at stake as well. Britain, whose Lord Keynes provided most of the intellectual stimulus for the fund's creation, is reluctant to cede to the Japanese.
Tokyo had hoped to sew up the No. 2 position at the I.M.F. at the annual meeting of the bank and fund last month in Washington, but Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer blocked the move.
 
U.S. Position Awaited
Washington's role is crucial, and American officials have yet to tip their hand. Should the United States tilt toward Japan, Europeans could be angered. If it appears to favor Europe, Japan could be hurt. Last year, American intervention secured the bank's executive vice presidency for Mr. Terazawa, who was competing with several Europeans.
Voting strength would be reconfigured as part of efforts to provide new capital to the I.M.F., which has $120 billion in resources.
Although the United States has yet to approve the capital increase, Treasury officials are sympathetic to Japan's desire to move to the No. 2 position, once new resources are agreed upon.
One possible compromise is to give Japan and West Germany the same number of shares, making them co-equals behind the United States, and to give France and Britain the same number of fewer shares, making them co-equals in a No. 3 position.
Of more than 6,340 employees at the bank, only 83 are Japanese, representing a little more than 1 percent. Along with Mr. Terazawa, Tokyo earlier this year obtained a bank vice presidential slot for a finance ministry official, Koji Kashiwaya, who is now the second-highest-ranking Japanese at the bank.
Of the I.M.F.'s 1,855 employees, only 26 are Japanese.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
The Turnaround Of the H.M.O.'s

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
MOST health maintenance organizations did well this year, recovering from two years of heavy losses. Industry experts said most of the prepaid health plans should remain profitable at least through 1990, when the cycle may turn down again.
The H.M.O. industry lost $900 million in 1987 and again in 1988, said Joel J. Menges, director of analytical services at American International Healthcare Inc., a unit of the American International Group, a multinational insurer. It has recouped its losses by aggressively raising the monthly premiums charged to employers and individuals. 
''Two-thirds of all H.M.O.'s in the country had losses last year,'' said Peter J. Grua, an analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. in Baltimore. Now most publicly owned H.M.O.'s are profitable, he said. ''Even some of the smaller companies are back on the track.'' Stock prices of many large H.M.O.'s have more than doubled this year, he said.
The turnaround came as insurers were forced to stanch losses they took while covering soaring medical costs. The insurers raised their rates as much as 50 percent for traditional fee-for-service health plans in 1989, while H.M.O.'s increased theirs by 12 percent to 20 percent.
For 1990, Mr. Grua said, insurers are seeking increases of 25 percent or more, which means H.M.O.'s can stay ahead of inflation, remain competitive and still show a profit if they raise rates by 12 percent to 15 percent. Kaiser Foundation Health Plans, an industry giant with 6.2 million members, has announced rate increases averaging 19.2 percent for 1990. Increases averaged 11.2 percent in 1989 and under 5 percent in the three preceding years. Kaiser did not report losses. H.M.O.'s charge a fixed monthly prepaid fee for each patient. Thus, hospitals and doctors have an incentive to keep costs down by offering checkups and other preventive measures to keep patients healthy and by minimizing expensive services.
''H.M.O.'s have truly been able to control their costs better than an insurance company,'' said Larry Greenberg, manager of the Fidelity Select Medical Delivery Fund in Boston. A few tightly managed H.M.O.'s like Pacificare Healthcare Systems Inc., based in Cypress, Calif., pass along only a set share of the per-patient premiums to hospitals and doctors, adding to the pressure to keep costs down. FHP International, based in Fountain Valley, Calif., owns a hospital and employs its own doctors. Humana Inc., the hospital chain based in Louisville, Ky., owns H.M.O.'s with more than one million members. Todd Richter, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds, said the H.M.O.'s were providing 17 percent of Humana's patients.
Analysts predict that insurers may start cutting prices again in 1991. ''When pricing turns negative, the H.M.O.'s will still be able to make profits in the downturn,'' Mr Greenberg said. But Seth H. Shaw, at Prudential-Bache Securities, is less sanguine. ''Next year political problems will emerge,'' he said. As pressure grows to hold the line on prices, he added, ''H.M.O.'s that raise rates by 20 percent will not be part of the solution.''
The prepaid health plans had 32.6 million members enrolled at the beginning of the year, up 3.3 million from Jan. 1, 1988, according to the Group Health Association of America, an H.M.O. trade group in Washington. James F. Doherty, the group's president, predicted an additional 3.3 million members will be added in 1989.
But some H.M.O.'s have lost members as companies required employees to help pay for rising premiums. ''We realized we couldn't hold the line on the premiums,'' said Alan Peres, benefit planning manager at American Information Technologies, the Chicago-based regional telephone company.
In the 1990 sign-up period now under way, employees at Ameritech's Illinois Bell unit are being asked to pay $42.83 to $62.23 a month for family coverage in Chicago and more in downstate Illinois, said Bill Watson, Illinois Bell's director of benefits. The company will pay the remaining portion of the premiums, which range as high as $320 a month in Chicago. Illinois Bell pays the full H.M.O. premium for single employees, who are less likely than family groups to use hospitals and doctors.
H.M.O. membership among Illinois Bell active employees fell from 7,418 in 1987 to 6,659 last year, when the payroll deductions for H.M.O.'s started, Mr. Watson said, and he expects a further decline at the company's five H.M.O.'s in 1990 because ''employees are voting with their pocketbooks.''
''The H.M.O's were caught up in the hysteria of trying to attract and retain members, but there has been a clear change in mentality,'' Mr. Menges said at American International Healthcare. ''Now they are willing to lose members to get on their feet financially.''

HEADLINE: Revamping Is Planned By Qintex

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 23

 BODY:
Qintex Australia Ltd., whose $1.5 billion agreement to buy the MGM/ UA Communications Company collapsed two weeks ago when it was unable to produce a $50 million letter of credit, announced a reorganization plan today and an accelerated program of asset sales.
The announcement came after the Australian Stock Exchange suspended trading in Qintex's shares because the company had not answered an exchange question about the extent of its loans, investments and deposits in relation to Qintex Entertainment Inc., an affiliate based in Beverly Hills, Calif., that filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code on Friday.
Qintex Australia, a Sydney-based operator of resorts and television stations, plans to sell its remaining 51 percent stake in Mirage resorts in Australia and Hawaii, Christopher Skase, its chairman, said. No buyer was identified but in March Qintex sold a combined 49 percent stake in the three Mirage resorts to the Nippon Shinpan Company and Mitsui & Company. 
 
Faster Sales Planned
Mr. Skase said in a news release that the company would also speed up plans to sell its Adelaide television station and two regional stations in Queensland. The sales are expected to generate a cash inflow, reduce interest costs and eliminate other financial liabilities, Mr. Skase said. Qintex intends to retain a long-term management contract on the resorts to generate fee income.
The planned restructuring involves the merger of Qintex Australia with Qintex Ltd., which owns 55 percent of Qintex Australia. Mr. Skase said this move would ''significantly reduce administrative costs.''
Before trading was suspended, Qintex Australia shares had plunged to 16 Australian cents (12 American cents), half their Friday value. The shares had traded at around $1.50 (Australian), or $1.15, in March, when Qintex announced the bid for MGM/ UA, which is 80 percent owned by Kirk Kekorian, the financier, through the Tracinda Corporation.
 
Four Problems Cited
Mr. Skase said in the news release today that ''group cash flow has been negatively impacted by an excess of $200 million (Australian)'' ($154 million) because of four recent problems - the termination by MGM/UA of the acquisition pact and the ''consequential impact on Qintex Entertainment,'' which was denied access to banking facilities after the deal dissolved; high Australian interest rates; a strike by domestic airline pilots that is affecting resort attendance, and the deferral of a settlement in a previously announced sale of two Queensland regional TV stations.
The announcement today came in response to the stock exchange's question about Qintex's exposure to Qintex Entertainment, which is 43 percent owned by the Australian company. The American affiliate owes Qintex Australia $38.1 million in loans that are not secured by specific assets. Qintex Australia said it had a further investment of $83.3 million in Qintex Entertainment shares.
''Qintex Australia will complete an evaluation of this investment and provide a follow-up report on completion,'' Mr. Skase said.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
$575 Million Refinancing By San Antonio Is Priced

 BODY:
San Antonio's $575 million tax-exempt bond issue to refinance debt previously sold when interest rates were higher was tentatively priced yesterday through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The maximum yield on the electric and gas system revenue refunding bonds is 7.30 percent for bonds due in 2009. 
For shorter maturities, serial bonds were offered, with yields of 6.15 percent in 1991, 6.45 percent in 1994, 7 percent in 1999, and 7.10 percent in 2000. Other longer-maturity bonds were priced to yield 7.25 percent in 2012, 7.20 percent in 2014 and 7.15 percent in 2016.
The debt financing also includes capital appreciation bonds. If held to maturity, bond yields will range from 7 percent in 2001 to 7.10 percent in 2003 through 2005. Underwriters tentatively priced these securities from $462.29 to $345.95 per $1,000 of bonds.
Underwriters said the issue was rated Aa by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Session Lower As Traders Await U.S. Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar drifted lower in lackluster trading yesterday as currency markets around the world awaited direction from United States economic reports scheduled for release this week.
Gold prices declined. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery settled at $367 an ounce, down 30 cents from Friday's settlement. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted a 4 P.M. gold bid of $366.25 an ounce, 25 cents lower than Friday's late bid.
Dealers at home and abroad reported that there had recently been reluctance to establish significant positions in dollars until a clearer economic picture emerged.
 
Trading in Narrow Range
The reluctance has kept the dollar trading in a narrow range against other major currencies.
A report on orders for durable goods is due today from the Commerce Department, followed Thursday by the department's first estimate of third-quarter growth in the gross national product, the Government's broadest measure of economic health.
The dollar has also been weighed down by speculation that United States interest rates might recede in the near future. Lower rates would reduce returns on dollar-denominated investments and tend to lessen demand for dollars.
In New York, the dollar was quoted at 141.90 yen, down from 142.43 yen on Friday. A pound cost $1.6030, compared with $1.5885 on Friday.
 
Late New York Rates
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, included: 1.8470 West German marks, down from 1.8578; 1.6190 Swiss francs, down from 1.6285; 6.2740 French francs, down from 6.3105; 1.1704 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1741, and 1,356.00 Italian lire, down from 1,367.00.
Silver barely budged in quiet dealings and closed unchanged. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.089 an ounce, the same as late Friday.

HEADLINE: Possibility of a Reunited Germany Is No Cause for Alarm, Bush Says

BYLINE: By R.W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he did not share the worries of some European leaders about the possibility of German reunification, and he predicted major changes in Germany's status in the next decade.
Speaking on the morning after at least 150,000 people marched through the streets of Leipzig pressing for political reform, Mr. Bush asserted that Egon Krenz, East Germany's new leader, ''can't turn the clock back,'' because ''the change is too inexorable.''
The President also expressed confidence after a telephone conversation with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany on Monday that Bonn would not develop neutralist tendencies.
''And yet I don't think we ought to be out pushing the concept of reunification, or setting timetables, or coming from across the Atlantic over here making a lot of new pronouncements on this subject,'' Mr. Bush said in an interview in the Oval Office. [Excerpts, page A12.] ''It takes time,'' he added. ''It takes a prudent evolution. It takes work between them. And understanding between the French and the Germans and the Brits and the Germans on all this. But the subject is so much more front and center because of the rapid changes that are taking place in East Germany.'' 
 
Europeans Voice Fears
Leaders of European countries that fought Germany in two world wars -Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and President Francois Mitterrand of France prominent among them - have privately expressed concern about German reunification, and commentators on both sides of the Atlantic have voiced their anxieties in public. The Soviet Union, which suffered the greatest losses in World War II and which is committed to maintaining two Germanys, has criticized those advocating reunification, something it views with great apprehension.
But Mr. Bush, who was in relaxed and spirited form throughout the 30-minute talk, said, ''There's a lot written on the fear of reunification that I personally don't share.''
At the end of the interview, after the White House stenographer and other aides had left, the President motioned to his interviewer and to his chief of staff, John H. Sununu, to stay behind, and he turned to the subject of his leadership on foreign policy.
''These changes we're seeing in Eastern Europe are absolutely extraordinary, but I'm not going to be stampeded into overreacting to any of this,'' Mr. Bush said. ''Democrats on Capitol Hill have been calling me 'timid.' I have other, better words, like 'cautious,' 'diplomatic,' 'prudent.' We have a good team, well seasoned. We're unified.''
Mr. Sununu interjected: ''It's like hooking a 20-pound fish on a two-pound-test line. React too precipitously, jerk the rod, and the fish will swim away. You have to play him carefully, keep a steady tension on the line.''
The President, apparently reacting to Democratic leaders who have accused him of offering only niggardly aid to Eastern Europe, commented bitterly that he was tired of ''taking hits'' from ''people who found Poland on the globe about three weeks ago.''
On Panama, where the United States declined to intervene militarily to aid an attempted coup this month against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, President Bush rejected suggestions that the failure of the coup would make it harder for General Noriega's opponents in the Panamanian Defense Forces to rise against him again in the near future.
''I think any time you have somebody that is as demonstrably evil as Noriega and who is frustrating the will of the people, as he continues to do, there's bound to be an upheaval,'' he said.
''His response post-coup, in my view, has just shaken to the core the professionals in the P.D.F. That does not enhance his standing there or guarantee that they'll put up with him forever.''
 
Lessons of the Coup Episode
While maintaining that nothing he has learned since would have changed his decision not to involve American forces, the President conceded that ''I've learned'' from the coup episode.
''I think maybe we can improve communications so that it's all across the bureaucracy,'' he explained, adding that there was ''a disconnect'' - a misunderstanding - over whether the rebels would or would not, should or should not, hand over General Noriega to the United States for prosecution.
Mr. Bush saved his sharpest partisan thrusts for the battle over the budget, which has led to automatic across-the-board spending cuts required by the Gramm-Rudman budget-balancing law. The principal culprits in all this, the President insisted, were the Congressional Democrats, and especially their leaders.
''The perception out there is that it's the fault of the Congress,'' he added. ''And you can look to the leadership and ask them why that is the perception of the American people.''
 
Economic Situation 'Not Urgent'
Although he conceded that some Americans felt frustration over ''this strange way of governing'' and blamed everyone in Washington, Mr. Bush said most were not alarmed, because the ''economy keeps moving reasonably well, the percentage of Gross National Product in terms of the deficit is moving generally in the right direction.''
''If you had a more difficult economic situation,'' the President said, ''then I think you'd have a more urgent feeling. Today it's not urgent.''
Recalling that he had campaigned for a capital gains tax cut in 1988, he accused the Democrats of resorting ''to this old gambit - this man's trying to help the rich and hurt the poor'' - to prevent approval of a measure that he said the American people had endorsed by electing him, the House of Representatives had passed despite its Democratic majority and the Senate would pass if allowed to by its Democratic leadership.
''The votes are there in the Senate for it,'' the President said. Missed Opportunities? Mr. Bush was asked later whether he felt that he was missing chances during the first two years of his Presidency, which historians consider the most propititious for new initiatives, because of financial strictures. He acknowledged that he felt somewhat ''boxed in'' in such areas as the war against drugs, aid to earthquake and hurricane victims and foreign economic aid, but he offered no suggestion that he would be willing at any point to raise taxes to get more money.
''I don't want to leave you the wrong impression - that if we just had tons more federal money, we could solve everything,'' the President said. ''I don't think that's the case.''
Asked to explain, once and for all, his choice last year of Dan Quayle as his running mate, Mr. Bush demurred. But he vehemently defended Mr. Quayle's performance as Vice President, said the former Senator had ''gone the extra mile to help me'' and disclosed that he still kept in a file some of the newspaper articles mocking his Vice Presidency under Ronald Reagan.
''You're talking to a guy that took it for eight years,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Urban Jobless Joined to Suburban Jobs

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Tenants of a Chicago public housing project last week joined the nation's growing ranks of low-income, long-distance commuters, riding a new bus service designed to connect inner city people unable to find jobs with suburban employers who cannot find enough workers.
Like similar projects in about 25 cities across the nation, the commuter van serving the LeClaire Court housing project here crosses city and cultural borders in an attempt to restore balance to an urban landscape where jobs and opportunity are badly out of sync.
While many suburbs have been overwhelmed by an explosion of growth, which compounded their congestion and fostered labor shortages, the poorest neighborhoods within the cities have been afflicted by rising unemployment and despair.
Ruth Banks, a mother of five who lives in LeClaire Court, now knows both of those worlds. The 40-minute trip from the low-income housing development on the city's Southwest Side to her new job as a maid at a hotel in suburban DuPage County means an opportunity to make $5.85 an hour, nearly $2 more than she was earning as a part-time worker in the city, plus full health coverage and other fringe benefits. 
 
Service Expects to Grow
''It's better all the way around,'' said Ms. Banks, as she boarded the maroon and gray van one day last week along with five other tenants of LeClaire Court.''It's a real job.''
Another eight tenants are scheduled to start their suburban jobs next week, and organizers of the van service expect to be carrying 90 commuters back and forth in two vans within a year, said Teresa Prim, the operations manager of the service.
Mark Alan Hughes, an assistant professor of geography, public affairs and urban planning at Princeton University, said that as urban areas become more decentralized it is becoming more important to provide mobility for inner city poor people. They are increasingly isolated from the new jobs in suburbs because suburbs are not well served by public transportation.
At issue is the larger question of black unemployment, which in many urban areas is about twice the rate of whites. In the draft of a report that Professor Hughes has written on behalf of the National League of Cities, he says transportation must be considered in framing antipoverty policy, along with job training, child care and crime prevention.
Such a strategy will be pay immediate benefits, he says, because it does not make the fortunes of inner city residents dependent on whether central cities and their blue-collar economies can be rebuilt, nor on creating affordable housing in suburbs, both of which are politically complex and expensive propositions.
 
Both Sides Benefit
Professor Hughes said at least 53 programs have been organized since 1985 in 25 metropolitan areas to transport city workers to suburban jobs.
More than 500 people are traveling in vans each day out from Milwaukee in an experiment for which the Wisconsin Department of Transportation set aside $200,000. In Washington and Philadelphia, nonprofit community groups have organized similar bus lines, and another Chicago group, Just Jobs, has been carrying 300 people since 1987 from four inner city neighborhoods to temporary jobs in the suburbs.
The Federal Urban Mass Transit Association, working with the National Center for Neighborhood Enterprise, has provided more than $1.8 million in planning grants in last three years for reverse-commuting projects in 18 cities, including St. Louis, Camden and Jersey City in New Jersey and Boston. The grants pay for job training, recruiting and transporation plans.
Scholars gathered at Northwestern University at a conference on urban poverty last week agreed that changes in the economy that have chased jobs from the city to the suburbs are an important factor in black unemployment.
But they also insisted it is not the sole cause. They cited other factors like racial and cultural stereotyping among employers, the low skills of many young minority applicants and the absence of effective networks of information about available jobs in poor neighborhoods.
 
Transportation Comes First
But at LeClaire Court, the other factors will come later. For now, the transportation problem is being confronted with the van service, which is financed by employer contributions and Government subsidies. The daily service is intended to operate at a profit eventually and to expand to connect other low-income neighborhoods in the city to suburban employers.
Although the jobs at the other end of the ride tend to be entry-level unskilled service positions in stores or hotels, the shortage of labor in these areas has driven up the wages that employers are willing to pay.
William Banks was making the minimum wage, $3.35 an hour, at a Chicago restaurant when he heard about the commuter program. Now the 19-year-old has been hired by Stouffer's Hotel in suburban Itasca, where he will be making $5.85 for work with the hotel's banquet staff.
''I heard there were good jobs in the suburbs, but until now, I didn't know how to get out there,'' Mr. Banks said.
According to statistics from the Illinois Department of Labor, unemployment among blacks in Chicago in 1988 was 12.7 percent. Among LeClaire Court's tenants the situation is worse; more than 60 percent are not working, and an even higher percentage receive some form of welfare.
 
Imbalance Is Seen As Continuing
In contrast, the unemployment rate in DuPage County is only 3.4 percent. One study projected the county would have 100,000 more jobs than it does residents in the next 20 years.
Using a $90,000 grant from the Urban Mass Transit Authority, LeClaire Court not only organized the van service, but also recruits prospective employers and helps provide job training for tenants. The training includes classroom instruction on the work ethic and job discipline, and includes subjects like dressing properly and getting to work on time.
''It's culture shock to take a bunch of minority people into a lily-white environment like DuPage County,'' said Stanley Horn, who is the executive director of the Clarence Darrow Community Center, which provides social services at LeClaire.
Another big obstacle is the reluctance of many public housing tenants to take jobs, because their rent is fixed at 30 percent of their income.
''We are talking with people about jobs, and they are calculating that it's sometimes best for them to stay on welfare rather than work, because their rent will go up with their income,'' Mr. Horn said. The rent figure is set by law, and Mr. Horn has joined other housing officials here in pressing Congress and the Department of Housing and Urban Development to establish some sort of flexible rent ceiling, so people with jobs will not be pushed out of public housing.
 
Pay From $5.50 to $9 an Hour
So far, about a dozen businesses in DuPage County have agreed to use workers from LeClaire. They include two large hotels, a nursing home chain and a cleaner. Hourly pay is $5.50 to $9.
Businesses are asked to share the cost of the bus service by paying $2 a day per employee. The workers pay an additional $2 a day for the door-to-door commuting service, which is less than it would cost them to travel the same distance on public transportation.
The bus service is operated by the LeClaire Service Corporation, which is the profit-making arm of the LeClaire Court Resident Management Corporation, the tenant group that has been managing day-to-day operations for the 3,500 residents of the housing project since May.
The residents also operate their own laundry and a catering business that supplies 1,000 meals daily to child care centers in the Chicago area.
Like some other residents of the housing project, Mildred Allen said she had been looking for a job when she saw the leaflets advertising the commuter service. ''This is a great opportunity,'' said Ms. Allen, who will work as a telephone operator at a suburban hotel for nearly $6 an hour. It is her first job since 1979.
Nearby, Mr. Horn watched nervously as the first group of LeClaire residents boarded the bus. ''This is kind of an emotional moment,'' he said, as the bus pulled away. ''Like watching your kids on their first day of school.''

HEADLINE: HOMOSEXUALS GAIN MORE ACCEPTANCE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. KAGAY

 BODY:
Public tolerance of homosexual relations between consenting adults has increased, returning to a level that existed in 1982 before public concern over the spread of AIDS caused a backlash against homosexuals, according to the latest Gallup Poll.
Forty-seven percent of the 1,227 people interviewed Oct. 12-15 said homosexual relations between consenting adults should be legal, while 36 percent said they should not be. The remainder had no opinion. 
In the most recent previous poll, in 1987, only 33 percent said homosexua relations should be legal, while 55 percent said they should not.
The new national telephone poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
While 45 percent of those polled in 1982 said homosexual relations between consenting adults should be legal, the public became more negative in polls in 1985, 1986 and 1987.
Larry Hugick, vice president of the Gallup Organization, offered this interpration: ''Tolerance of homosexuals fell when Americans first started worrying about getting AIDS. But as people's fear of getting AIDS themselves has diminished, tolerance of homosexuals has rebounded to previous levels.''
 
Equal Job Opportunities
Support has also grown for equal job opportunities for homosexuals, with 71 percent saying homosexuals should have ''equal rights in terms of job opportunities,'' up from 59 percent in 1982 and 56 percent in 1977, the only other years in which the question was asked.
But many people distinguish among occupations as appropriate for homosexuals. In the latest poll 79 percent said homosexuals would be appropriate in sales work, but only 60 percent expressed themselves that way regarding the military and 56 percent regarding doctors.
Only a minority said homosexuals were appropriate high school teachers (47 percent), members of the clergy (44 percent) and elementary school teachers (42 percent).
Such differences about employing homosexuals have persisted since Gallup began tracking the six occupations in 1977, but support for equal job opportunity for homosexuals has gradually increased since 1977 for all six.

HEADLINE: How C.I.A. Concocts Soviet Defense Numbers

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''The Russians Are Still Coming'' (Op-Ed, Oct. 9), Richard Pipes argues that the Soviet Union has not become a more peace-loving nation as many believe; rather, it is as aggressive as ever, but has learned to disguise its true intentions. Among other things, Professor Pipes asks:
''How genuine is the change in Soviet foreign policy? Take defense expenditures. Moscow has finally released what it claims to be its true military budget. The 77 billion ruble figure announced earlier this year is about half of what U.S. experts believe to be actual defense appropriations.'' 
Professor Pipes has too much faith in the United States experts. The Central Intelligence Agency, which puts out our official estimates of Soviet defense expenditures, is considered by national security specialists to be our most reliable estimator. Yet, over the last 15 years, the C.I.A.'s estimates have been riddled with errors and misrepresentations, all making Soviet defense expenditures appear larger than they actually are.
From 1975 through 1983, the C.I.A. said Soviet military spending was increasing 4 percent to 5 percent a year. In 1984, the agency acknowledged that it had been wrong - that the increase since 1975 had been only 2 percent a year. After conceding its error, however, the C.I.A. failed to make the appropriate adjustments in its Soviet military spending figures.
In 1982, the Soviets instituted a wide-ranging price reform, the first in 15 years. In 1986, the C.I.A. switched its estimates of Soviet defense spending, which had been in 1970 ruble prices, into the new 1982 ruble prices. Soviet defense spending took a large leap upward because, according to the C.I.A., prices of weapons had increased much faster than prices of civilian goods between 1970 and 1982. But this was all guesswork.
In November, 1987, the agency conceded that it had been unable to obtain 1982 weapons prices and, further, that there was reason to believe that weapons prices had risen more slowly than prices of civilian goods. Yet the new and much higher figures for Soviet defense expenditures were never rescinded.
In 1986, the C.I.A. made another change in established practice. Without explanation or warning, it began to include in its single estimate of Soviet military spending a number of civilian activities that are not included in estimates of United States military spending (such as civilian defense, internal security forces and civilian space activities). This made Soviet defense appear still larger relative to United States defense than it should have been.
When the C.I.A.'s estimate of Soviet military spending is corrected for these errors and misrepresentations, it turns out to be very close to the 77 billion ruble figure announced by Mikhail S. Gorbachev on May 30 -much lower than the C.I.A. estimate and also about one-third lower than United States defense expenditures. Since then, President Gorbachev has announced sharp cuts in Soviet defense spending for 1990 and 1991. Despite Mr. Pipes's fears, there are good reasons to believe President Gorbachev will reduce defense spending. It is to be hoped that President Bush will soon follow suit. (For documentation, see my article in the fall issue of International Security.)
 
FRANKLYN D. HOLZMAN
Professor of Economics, Tufts U.
Medford, Mass., Oct. 11, 1989

HEADLINE: How C.I.A. Concocts Soviet Defense Numbers;
Exchanges Work

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am sure many readers will applaud your editorial proposal of Oct. 18 (''Help Who?'') to expand academic exchanges with the Soviet Union as a way of helping the Soviet restructuring program of perestroika. They would be distressed to know, however, that 35 Soviet research scholars who are at American universities this year participating in the longstanding intergovernment exchange program administered by the International Research & Exchange Board will have to be sent home early because of insufficient Federal funds. Even the modest traditional quota of 50 participants - which was supposed to go up to more than 100 in 1989-90 - has not been met for many years because of fund shortfalls. 
Many of the leading reformers in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe are graduates of these exchanges, which we managed to sustain for more than 30 years, even during the worst East-West tensions. Our Soviet alumni include such key figures as Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, the Politburo member who oversees foreign policy; Yevgeny M. Primakov, chairman of the upper chamber of the Soviet parliament; Tatyana I. Zaslavskaya, the sociologist and public-opinion institute director, and the economist Nikolai P. Shmelev.
In Eastern Europe, to cite only Hungary, alumni include the minister of justice, the minister of culture, the president of the new Hungarian Socialist Party and the prime minister. Exchanges work: much of the conceptual framework for the new thinking in the region has come from scholars whose American experiences were pivotal.
So you are right to call for an expansion, not only for Soviet scholars but also for the growing number of American researchers who need access to the Soviet Union. But unfunded enthusiasm isn't enough. It would be better not to raise hopes unless the United States is prepared to deliver.
 
ALLEN H. KASSOF
Executive Director, International
Research & Exchange Board
Princeton, N.J., Oct. 18, 1989

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
After the Dawn, a New Day

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
In two recent speeches, Secretary of State James Baker showed that the Bush Administration had at last grasped some sense of the vast, historic changes taking place in the Communist East.
That is certainly an advance over earlier incredulity that Mikhail Gorbachev was serious about new policies, and then supposing his failure would restore the Moscow status quo.
Mr. Baker now says sensibly that ''any uncertainty about the fate of reform in the Soviet Union is all the more reason, not less, for us to seize the present opportunity'' for arms control agreements. ''For the works of our labor - a diminished Soviet threat and effectively verifiable agreements - can endure even if perestroika does not.'' And he pointed out that ''with agreements in place, any attempt to break out of treaties'' would alert the world. 
But this recognition that America's interests are indeed served by new Soviet policies, including the policy of allowing Eastern European reformers to break their Communist parties' monopoly of power, is still reactive. It doesn't represent thinking ahead in Washington, any effort to shape events rather than submit to them.
A check of major allied capitals indicates that no government, except perhaps Italy, is seriously looking beyond the immediate problems of the East's struggle to get out of the wreckage its Communist regimes have imposed. The West is acting as though the only choice were to revert to the structure of Europe between the two World Wars.
But if that were possible, and in many ways it is not, it would be disastrous. The task of leaders now is to foresee new forms of organizing relations so as not to let the vacuum be filled by incoherent pressures.
Some think tanks are starting to talk about the future ''European architecture,'' a broad notion seeking to outline various ways that new East-West relations could be framed. People involved stress that the effective tool of power is becoming economic might, no longer military force. New economic patterns must be devised.
Italy's Foreign Minister, Gianni De Michelis, is preparing to attend a ground-breaking meeting in Budapest later this month with the Foreign Ministers of Austria, Yugoslavia and Hungary to discuss what kind of regional cooperation might be developed in Central Europe.
These are urgent issues because as the Eastern countries break out of the rigid post-World War II mold, they need some chart of where to go so as not to risk floundering in the crises of the Stalinist legacy.
The West, both Western Europe and the U.S., has to accept intellectual responsibility for creating a new design, as it did for half of Europe in the wake of victory. The new leaders in the East are overwhelmed with the enormously difficult tasks of discarding their heritage. They cannot sit back and think longer-term.
Even the strictly military issues of arms control require more than conventional approaches focusing on parity, verification, minimum defense. It was pointed out at the conference of the Institute for East-West Security Studies in Frankfurt last weekend, for example, that European arms reductions can create serious new problems in the burgeoning third-world arms race.
As weapons procurement is cut back, military producers in East and West will be tempted to expand other markets. So this question should be included in talks to provide some kind of agreed restraint on increased sales outside Europe.
It is not enough to move toward demilitarizing East-West relations if the effect is to encourage militarization of other international relations. India has developed both long- and short-range missiles, apparently by diverting foreign help on space technology, and this will accelerate military rivalries in Asia.
Mr. Baker did say the Administration wished to broaden the arms control agenda with Moscow ''far wider than its traditional East-West nuclear focus.'' That is necessary, and it has begun in talks on banning chemical weapons and some show of concern for the spread of missilery. Attention should also start being paid to promoting third-world arms reductions.
The ''German question'' is coming to the fore in worried talk about reunification. It is time to start thinking about what conditions would finally make it acceptable to negotiate a German peace treaty. This has never been possible because the East insists that a treaty must validate partition, and the West refuses.
Saluting the dawn of a new era is only a beginning. Washington must do much more than watch if it wishes to influence the coming day.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 25, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 31, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 656 words

HEADLINE: Deficit Reduction: A Love Story;
We Made A Commitment

BYLINE: By Phil Gramm and Warren B. Rudman; Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, and Warren B. Rudman, Republican of New Hampshire, are members of the Senate budget committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Those who call the 1985 Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced budget law a bad law because deficit targets have been missed and accounting gimmicks have been used to avoid tough decisions would probably also suggest that religion is a failure because there are so few saints in the world.
Sure, the balanced budget law is not functioning perfectly from an accounting standpoint, but that misses the point. Critics fail to comprehend the purpose or effect of the law.
They focus on mechanism and minutiae when, in fact, the law represents a continuing commitment to deficit reduction. And the fact is that both the Federal budget deficit and Federal spending are lower than they would have been without Gramm-Rudman-Hollings. 
Before the balanced budget law, the budget deficit for fiscal year 1986 was projected to exceed $230 billion and Federal spending policies had the country on the way to $300 billion deficits by the end of the decade. The law, however, immediately cut nearly $11.7 billion from the 1986 deficit.
Currently, the ''great failure'' of Gramm-Rudman-Hollings is to reduce the deficit below $117 billion -half of what the deficit was when we began. Moreover, the deficit, when measured against gross national product - which many economists consider to be more important than the actual dollar number - will be 60 percent lower in 1990 than it was in 1986.
Average annual real growth in Federal spending has dropped from 4 percent in the years preceding Gramm-Rudman-Hollings to 1.6 percent since.
In late 1985, most economists and many businessmen believed that a recession within the next four years was unavoidable. That recession has yet to materialize; the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings inspired change in Federal fiscal policy is at least partially responsible.
Too, the balanced budget law has dramatically affected specific legislative proposals which would have raised the deficit. This fall the Senate passed an amendment increasing anti-drug funding by $3.2 billion over the amounts previously agreed. That additional funding was fully offset with spending cuts in other areas. Can anyone imagine that happening before Gramm-Rudman-Hollings?
In 1986, during an election year, the Senate killed a $1 billion farm credit bill on a point of order created by Gramm-Rudman-Hollings. That same year, Congress enacted a revenue neutral tax reform law - something most Washington pundits had thought was impossible.
Finally, the defense budget, when measured in real terms, has declined in each of the last four fiscal years. Incidentally, both of us would have preferred somewhat higher spending on defense.
All of these actions are direct results of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law.
It is certainly true, albeit regrettable, that Congress and the Administration have resorted to budget trickery in order to avoid some hard decisions. And, while gimmicks to hide the true cost of Federal programs have existed for many years, we concede that the willingness of the two branches to resort to such tricks has increased somewhat this year.
Yet, even with the gimmicks, the deficit is projected to continue on its downward path in 1990.
If the across-the-board spending cuts that went into effect last week stick, Congress and the President will have failed in their work on the budget, but the deficit will go down.
If the necessary deficit reduction steps are taken to void the cuts, both the budget process and Gramm-Rudman-Hollings will be working. And it is noteworthy that, for all the concern expressed about the across-the-board cuts, nobody is talking about waiving them.
The Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law is a statement about our will and determination to confrong the most serious economic problem facing our country - the Federal budget deficit.
Just as we don't judge the success of religion by the number of saints but by whether or not the world is better off, so should we judge Gramm-Rudman-Hollings.
