PUB-DATE: October 25, 1989

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1177 words

HEADLINE: In New Jersey, Silence on Fiscal Squeeze

SERIES: COURTER AND FLORIO ON THE ISSUES - LAST OF THREE ARTICLES

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 24

 BODY:
Unlike any other issue in New Jersey, the issue of raising taxes or cutting government programs brings out a certain reticence in the two candidates running for governor.
With the state facing a slack economy and growing budget troubles, many fiscal experts say the next governor will have to raise taxes or cut services. But both the Democrat, Representative James J. Florio, and the Republican, Representative Jim Courter, refuse to talk about doing either.
The candidates often speak about encouraging economic growth while protecting the environment. But they appear to prefer not to offer specific - and, most likely, unpopular - answers on how they would balance the state budget until after the election. 
In separate interviews last week, Mr. Florio and Mr. Courter presented their views on taxes and a wide range of other issues to reporters of The New York Times.
Mr. Florio, who proposes an array of initiatives and a vision of a more active state government, said he would pay for new programs by increasing efficiency. But before he can pinpoint the waste involved, Mr. Florio said, he has to conduct an audit. And, he said, he has to wait for its results before specifying where he will find most of the new revenue and where he will make cuts.
''I do not foresee any new taxes,'' Mr. Florio said. ''I think it's responsible, before anybody talks about any new resources, to find out where the resources went that have been coming in.''
Mr. Courter's stand on taxes is based on his belief that social good grows out of economic growth and that government can often do the most good by just getting out of the way. Accordingly, he has pledged not to raise taxes, and he will try to institute a cap on state spending and offer the elderly a freeze on their property taxes.
But Mr. Courter will not say what he would do if budget problems worsen or what programs or employees he would shed. ''I'm going to make tough decisions,'' Mr. Courter said.
Both candidates are aware that taxes, cutbacks and calls for tax changes are likely to be the main subjects of discussion next year for the new governor and Legislature.
After seven years of thundering economic growth and a doubling of the size of state government under Gov. Thomas H. Kean, New Jersey faces lackluster growth in at least the near future and a shortfall in revenues for next year's budget. Experts estimate the shortfall could grow to more than $500 million.
The State Constitution requires a balanced budget. This year Mr. Kean slashed programs and speeded the payments from some taxes to balance the $12 billion budget.
The Office of Legislative Services, the fiscal arm of the Legislature, and Laurence S. Weiss, Democratic of Perth Amboy and chairman of the State Senate Revenue, Finance and Appropriations Committee, have said revenues from the sales, business and income taxes will not be enough to support even modest growth in next year's budget.
In addition, suburban homeowners have grown furious in the last year, as their property taxes have jumped. Poor cities have complained that the system, which makes them reliant on their dwindling property-tax base, drives businesses and residents to the suburbs.
 
Under Eye of Court
The new governor is also expected to be confronted with a ruling by the State Supreme Court that could require a revision or overhaul of the tax system. The court is considering a suit that contends the system of paying for public education violates the State Constitution because it has not eliminated disparities in financing between affluent suburban districts and those in poor cities. School districts rely on property taxes for the major shares of their budgets.
The last time the court ruled on the issue, in 1973, it forced the Legislature to establish the first income tax for the state and to enact a law that increased state aid to local districts.
When questioned about the looming pressures, Mr. Florio repeatedly harkened back to what he described as the failure of the Kean administration to keep track of its spending.
''We have seen in the last eight years an increase that is beyond description,'' Mr. Florio said. ''There is nobody in the business community that I've talked to who said that you can go and pump as much money into this state government as we have pumped into it in this relatively short period of time and have any degree of confidence that it was spent correctly.''
 
Community Psychiatric Centers
As an example of mismanagement, Mr. Florio pointed to the Joint Underwriting Association, which was created to provide automobile insurance to motorists with bad driving records. The agency is more than $3 billion in debt. He also pointed to a scandal in the Human Services Department, in which a midlevel executive dispensed $32 million in unauthorized funds.
Using an audit by consultants, Mr. Florio said, he would search for duplicated services or ways services could be improved at less expense. He said if proper community treatment centers existed, he would release 610 people now in psychiatric hospitals to such centers, where their care would cost half the $70,000 a year a patient that the public pays today.
Mr. Florio said he hoped to provide added aid to municipalities to relieve the burden of property taxes. But, he said, he cannot be sure where that money would come from until his audit.
For Mr. Courter, a central theme of his campaign has been his promise not to raise taxes, which he dramatized this month by signing what he called a no-tax pledge. Mr. Courter has said on many occasions that in the long run taxes stifle economic growth, in turn limiting tax revenues.
 
Proposal for a Freeze
To relieve a burden on elderly people, who often live on fixed incomes, Mr. Courter proposed allowing people at the age of 65 to apply for a freeze on their property taxes. The state would receive a lien on the taxpayer's house and collect the unpaid taxes when the person died.
When asked about predictions of a shortage of revenues to balance the budget next year, Mr. Courter expressed optimism that revenues would increase and that cuts would not be necessary. He declined to say what programs he would be most likely to trim first.
On aid to education, Mr. Courter said he would like to help increase financing, but stressed that money alone would not solve the problems of public schools. The state has spent more than $8 billion on education in the last 10 years, Mr. Courter said, the most spending per student in the nation.
''Money is important, but it is certainly not the only thing,'' Mr. Courter said. ''If money made for perfect education, the children in the State of New Jersey would be the best in the United States of America.''
 
Comparing Their Answers
In separate interviews this month, The New York Times asked the two candidates for governor of New Jersey to discuss the problems facing the state and how to deal with them. This is the last of three articles comparing their responses. These are excerpts from the interviews.
